GAME: Arkham Horror
RANK: 235
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(bought)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fascinating theme played in cooperative style, with a ton of great bits that help in setting the game into the right mood. 
Trying to prevent the creatures of the Cthulhu Mythos from overwhelming Arkham, the players use their investigators to run across town, look for powerful objects, defeat hideous monsters and close dangerous portals on alien worlds. The idea is great, but the implementation seems to have its fair share of problems.
The rules are not as streamlined as I’d hoped: some mechanics are unnecessarily fiddly and the game just out of the box is partially "solvable" (some locations are much more worth securing than others, giving the players a consistent advantage against the game). The final, direct confrontation against the Ancient One is silly to begin with, but again it's the implementation that transforms an absurd idea into an even more unconvincing set of rules. Making the final showdown a set of brief narrative quests and encounters would have had much more sense. 
AH is also quite sensible to the number of players:  with more than 4 the game becomes easier, the time requirement bothersome and the downtime annoying. This might be the natural consequence of the fact that often an investigator doesn’t actually *do* much during a single turn, other than rolling for ability checks or combat. It can take two or three turns to get to a destination that you really need to reach and getting into something interesting in the meantime is basically a matter of luck. 
I love the idea behind AH, it's the execution that left me hoping for something more.  Still, if you use at least one expansion (so far Dunwich Horror, with its Injury and Madness cards, would be my first choice) and some house rules to make it run smoother and increase the difficulty, Arkham Horror can be a really good game, with a fascinating theme and a great, great atmosphere. 

FFG at the top of its form. The quality of the cards is still average, but other than that everything is really good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
A classic. Themey, gothic, impossible. One of the first games of this style I ever played and it took more than a decade to better it with Eldritch Horror. But being lost in time and space in the portal still can't be beat.

RATING: 7
Only skimmed the rules, which seem a little hard to digest.
Edit: Have now played once, with the Dunwich expansion.  The game seemed a little bewildering to begin with:  Doom, Terror, money, skills, weapons, spells, monsters, other worlds, gates, closing/sealing, lost in time & space, etc, etc.
My '7' rating is an initial rating and I hope to update it after another play. Maybe I will have a solo play with just the base game.
Oh, and we lost, which is how it should be!

Finally played again, 7 years on, much less bewildering, but playing without an expansion probably helped. My character achieved basically nothing all game, but then most of the others didn't either. We lost, which was deserved. It was an experience that I enjoyed, but there wasn't much game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really enjoy the system, the exploration, and building up of your character. The town works very well, though I wish I were compelled to have encounters more frequently, rather than simply going to the same places to take the same actions.

I also thought the Other Worlds are pretty boring. When you hop through a gate, you're stuck for about three turns or so. The fact that the main focus of the game involves going on hold really bugs me. Also, the fact that all the investigators immediately just start running around closing gates waters down their individual characters.

What I'd like to see from the game is the following

1) a GM style player who manages most of the encounters and information. She would have a mini-map of the town and would track monster movement behind a screen - that way, the players don't know what is where, only the initial location of where the monsters appeared. She would turn the card encounters into proper encounters with minor role-playing scenarios, and the GM would provide additional modifiers to skill checks based on the role-playing. Finally, she would manage the GOO, keeping their identity and the doom track secret, but would provide hints as to what the investigators ought to be doing.

2) To counteract the increased difficulty of the secret information, players would be allowed to have two encounters per turn, and their movement might be boosted a point or two. With the hidden monsters, it would still be dangerous to go too crazy moving around the streets. This would let players have encounters at locations they wouldn't normally go to.

3) Rather than all going after gates, each investigator would have a specific goal based on the story on their card back. The GM would create a short string of encounters specific to that character, which trigger when the characters move to certain location (with clues leading to the next location given at each point along the way). Once the goal is completed, the character becomes a "Hero." Heroes would be akin to a horror movie hero - bold and aggressive with little to lose. The exact specifics of this could be tailored to the hero. For example, you might set their Will and Fight to their max no matter where their slider is. 

Verdict: Long Island Iced Tea

Plays
3 - Vanilla

1 -  w/ DH & CotDP

RATING: 10

Have played several more times, with 2-3 players, and it is AWESOME!!!  The only downside is the length, which is closer to 5 or 6 hours than 3, but perhaps that will go down as well once we get better at it.  

 The downside to co-operative games is often that the theme drains out and you're left with making decisions about which cards to discard, which piece to move where, etc., like in LotR or Shadows Over Camelot.  I'm hoping that never happens with this game, but even if it does, I bought the two expansions to introduce when the main game loses its flavor. 

I've played with both expansions I have so far, and I've enjoyed them greatly as well--this game plays out so differently every time, it's amazing.  I'd still like to find a reliable way to cut down on some of the length, just so I can get this game played more often!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great genre! A blend of 'real world' and surreality set within H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu mythos.

The game requires a 'collaborative' play style to win. As human characters set within a [notionally 1920s/30s] [East coast] American city looking for clues and means to 'shore-up' the portals [to other worlds] through which monsters and demons pour; before physical deterioration and/or insanity take you out of play.

There are an enormous number of play-aids, cards, events, items, spells, character enhancements, monsters, overlords, locations etc, that ensure variety and a degree of 'freshness' each game.

The collaborative play style requires players to work together to beat the game, and as such everyone wins or everyone loses - there can be individual winners calculated if you are truly competitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of the best adventure games in existence. Can be quite long with many players, but it's highly scalable. If players are experienced they may play many phases simultaneously. Cooperation is a must most of the time. Very tense towards the end, and the end is usually highly climactic. A LOT of dice rolling which might be a problem for heavy eurogamers.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
(1, 8) #players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I truly love cooperative games. My regular gaming group (which is to say, my pen-and-paper RPG group) tries to get together every two months or so and have a board game party where other people (who don't play in our RPG) can game with us. And this game is played almost every time. We absolutely love it. It really does feel very desperate right up until the end when we can finally tell we are winning.

Admittedly, in the base game Sister Mary is kind of weak but our group got the expansions so she is now a stronger character. In one game, someone had Sister Mary with a shotgun, and she rocked (the nun with the gun, as we called her). 

The learning curve might seem steep - but with some help we have taught many non-gamers the joys of battling Lovecraftian horrors.

I hear that some people are bothered by the length of the game, particularly when you get to playing with 6 people.  As we rarely have played with less than 6 people, I have only found the length of the game bothersome ONCE where we had a terrible downward spiral for four hours... and we were able to bounce back from it, but it took five hours to reverse our fortune... after nine hours we were not too happy about how long the game was... but that was one play out of around 8.

Also, as most of us are RPG gamers, we aren't bothered by all the skills to keep track of, the order things happen in game, etc...

We do, however, find the rules tend to meander like a drunken yak, taking us hither and yon through the rules booklet until we finally stumble across what we are looking for.  So be prepared for some hunts to find certain rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Σαν να διαβάζεις ιστορία τρόμου του Steven King.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Very well accomplished GM-free RPG. Packed with details from the stories and RPG, and vast flexibility means you never have the same game twice.
Impressive number of characters and ancient ones in the box means there are already hundreds of possible start situations even before drawing random items. The ancient ones are different enough and their effects on the game change the flavour of the experience a lot.

I wouldn't play with 8 again, four or five is probably the advisable maximum given you will probably have new players. Two players with 2 characters each is fantastic.

You don't need any of the expansions to get started - the base game is crammed full of enough cards and monsters to keep you going for a long time.

This is not a euro game, theme is everything and fate is cruel. Definitely set aside an evening to play and don't bring it out during a regular games night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3

RATING: 4
This game had so much potential... 

There is simply too much here. Too many fiddly rules, too many components, etc, etc. On top of that, some unfortunate design decisions make gameplay a little frustrating (the monster chips have critical information on both sides, the mythos cards don't show the information in the order they are meant to be executed, etc). 

The worst part, however, is that it doesn't capture the theme very well for me. The overwhelming amount of game mechanics keep pulling me out of the moment. I don't understand why the game is so focussed on combat (particularly, the endgame combat with the Great Old One seems completely out of the spirit of the game... shouldn't the game just end in failure?)

It doesn't help that a number of the rules are very difficult to interpret (the monster overflow and the damage application against the Great Ol Ones are big offenders here).

Oh well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

There's just not enough actions to do anything except run around in a panic trying to close portals.  Maybe that's the point, but I'm not so sure.  It's much less hectic, and easier, with more people.  I'm not a huge fan of how long the game takes to play, but it -can- be done quickly if players are diligent.

RATING: 9
At three in the morning, you fly through the empty and dark streets on the old motorcycle that Phil bought for you yesterday at that weird shop on High Street. The motor sounds as if the old beast might not make it through the night, but it doesn't really matter. Nobody will, if you don't reach the Library tonight and close that bloody Gate. In fact, you are not sure if YOU will make it through the night in any case. Your stamina is running low, and your mind is ... so ... far .. beyond what ordinary people would call "madness". The things you've seen. The risks you've taken. Nobody should do that. And live.

Oh well, at least Joe can take the shotgun, he might put it to good use. Shoot himself, before The Servants arrive. Before everybody gets Lost In Time And Space.  

Oh, how I love Arkham horror! It is a game that is impressively true to its name. The rule book is insanely complicated. There are aspects of the game I still don't understand. I am truly afraid of risking a direct battle against one of the Old Ones. Full games take a ridiculous amount of time - using that motor cycle at three in the morning might actually be a realistic (i.e. real-time) option. Arkham takes you along a wild exciting journey of surprising madness, and is truly full of wonderful, mind-boggling, highly entertaining HORROR.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Maybe once or twice ever six months or so.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A cooperative and complex game. Objective of the game is to close all the gates and preventing monsters from swarming into the city. If too many gates open, then prepare for the final boss. Kill him, everyone wins. Killed by him, everyone officially wasted 2-3 hours of their life.

The game consists of many components, cards and tokens. Different characters and different final bosses. Fighting a battle require die roll. And throughout the game, there will be spells, weapons, allies, unique items, money and clue tokens to collect to help the player in his journey.

There's just too much of things to look out for and to keep in mind. And there's no sign of how long this game will last. So only play this game if there's a lot of time to spare, say minimum 2 hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really takes a long time to set up and it took even longer for me to wrap my head around the rules... but after putting in the time, I've been able to enjoy an incredibly immersive adventure horror game.  I'm not really an RPG fan but this takes all of the elements that I enjoy from that genre and utilizes a model that is at times deep and complex but manages to stay really quite lean.  I adore the theme and the illustrations are incredible.  Very well done.

Expansions owned: [thing=21059]Dunwich Horror[/thing], [thing=25945]The King in Yellow[/thing]

RATING: 10
Probably my only ever 10. Never made it to less than 4 hrs with 4 people. I always get tired after the 3rd hour or so to the point where I want it over with, but once it's packed I can't wait to put it on the table again. It's something magical I can't explain. It took a serious investment to figure out the rules details, as the game is super-fiddly (and I own a lot of expansions), but once there, it's very rewarding. The most thematic experience I ever had in a boardgame. 

But it's a game from the time where someone would get obsessed with a game for months. These days, every game gets a small window of attention and then collects dust since the next big thing comes in. It would be impossible for anyone to appreciate this game in this day and age....

RATING: 9
this game is chalk full of theme. extremely fun to play. does take a nice chunk of your day (2 1/2 hours is my shortest game and 5 hours was my longest, post first time through). can be played as a solo game or up to I think 8 people. everyone works together (u don't have to but if u want to win you sure as heck better) to fight back little monsters in hopes a earth destroying monster doesn't come forth. very fun game but expect it to drain you emotionally (in a good way) as you feel the darkness of evil coming forth to battle you and your compatriots. if you don't mind moderately difficult games that take multiple hours...then get this sucker!

RATING: 4
Pros:
- Lovely art
- Good setting
- Tells a story while you play
- Fairly easy to play and rhythmic once you get over the initial learning curve of all the exceptions and the procedures
- Surprises galore with the many locations and cards to play
- Good for solo play

Cons:
- Initial learning curve, different monster powers need different rules, exceptions to rules
- Once you learn the locations and cards it can sometimes lead to stagnant play; ex: you are always heading to one location to search and have an encounter
- The above can lead to relatively boring play for some characters so multi-player can be problematic
- Very fiddly in the sense of lots of tokens and cards and moving of same

RATING: 3
I played this game just twice, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

I was not impressed at all with Arkham Horror. The theme is very strong, I'll admit that, but I was shoked by how shallow the gameplay is. You don't feel like you have big choices to make... You just have to move in different locations trying to close portals, while random events happen all around. I didn't see a puzzle to solve and also the action in Arkham Horror doesn't excites me. There's WAY WAY WAY too much dice rolling... You roll for everything in this game! Everything! And it's not even about the randomness at this point, which is still huge although there're ways to help your luck. Even then you're just rolling cubes of plastic for the entire game! And, since that's not random enough, there's also random card drawing.

I understand why this game appeals thematic gamers so much, but as far as mechanics are concerned: Come on guys! It's a dice rolling game that lasts 4 hours... How can this be fun?

RATING: 10
Yes
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a great game to play with the lights dimmed, candles burning, with spooky music in the background, on a cold and blustery night.  The artwork is outstanding, components solid, and the theme is tremendous.  That said, why isn't the game a 10?

It is heavy, luck intensive game, that is not for everyone.  A game with 4 players will last 2+ hours and take up a ton of space.  There are hundreds and hundreds of cards, tokens, monster chits, etc., that can easily get mixed up.  And as I said, there is a lot of luck involved.  Sometimes the cards just beat you down, other times monster packs gather in the streets and block you from getting to where you need to go.  Sometimes the items you randomly draw to start the game are completely impotent, other times you have enough firepower and spells to take out a small country.  Some Great Old Ones are next to impossible to beat, others are easy.

All this said, I do recommend the game, just be prepared for it to be heavy at times, and difficult to beat at times.  If those factors will lessen your enjoyment of the game, steer clear ... otherwise, it is worth the investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
FAVOURITE GAME - It is cooperative game for connoisseurs. It has many rules, it takes a long time to play out, but it is an immersive game, where every minute is full of excitement, as it has a good share of randomness thanks to its many card decks. It is based on the universe by author H. P. Lovecraft, and the goal of the game is to prevent the Ancient One from awakening and devouring you. It is done by criscrossing a town and doing encounters at special locations or going to the so called outer worlds and exploring offworld universes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A co-op that wobbles in and out of feeling appropriately Lovecraftian, but does give you a nice sense of looming disaster. I have two mild concerns.  First, we've played this three times and won three times (against Nyarlathotep, Azathoth and Yog-Sothoth; two six player games and one seven player game).  While one was the result of a very lucky Mythos card at just the right time, there's a disturbingly easy ride in to victory from the middle game.  Second, as we become more familiar with the contents of the monster cup, and the encounter cards, the theming feels much thinner. Both concerns suggest replayability may be an issue here, which presumably explains why this is the Black Game of the Woods with a Thousand Expansions.

Update: A few expansion games later, against tougher antagonists, and our record crashes quite quickly, which is good.  I'm not sure all the extra chrome really does it for me, though.

Later update: we haven't played this one in years, because my friend who owns it doesn't care for it.  Entirely independently I've now got Eldritch Horror, which I've come to prefer as simply less ropey.

RATING: 3
I'll play this if people want to but I won't suggest it. A lot of what people call "strategy" in this game is just knowing the probability of stuff happening at certain locations and assigning (often tedious) roles to players with suitable characters. 

I don't like the dice rolling. It's lazily implemented. I do like the meters though.

I've heard the rules are a mess but I was taught the game and never cracked the rule book so I can't comment.

I fully admit that this game is providing an experience that I'm not really looking for but I don't think that it's particularly good at providing that experience even if I wanted it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Awesome game of fighting evil with your buddies. For ages the ONLY game that Mrs Algo would actively suggest playing (now, Shadows Over Camelot fits that bill too).

a cross between Board Game and RPG. It stands out in my collection as one of the only "cooperative" games in there. I mean that in contrast to "team" games since in Arkham Horror all players are on the same side against the viciously evil Cthulu and his horrible mates. you have to close gates to other dimensions and deal with the monsters coming out of them, and quickly, or the big evil demon that is running the show will make mincemeat of you in a final encounter. Lots of dice rolling is involved, but it remains great fun. Plus, we have a whale of a time creating our own characters and putting them up against the game.

Defeat the forces of darkness by closing all the gates, placing enough magical signs over the town or simply by waking the big demon up and kicking it out of this dimension.

That's all easier said than done, as the game is full of encounters, traps and monsters that keep your sanity and health on a knife edge.

The base game is excellent in its own right and is worth picking up even if you're not in the mood for the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love this game. I've always been a HP Lovecraft fan & the game gives me some of the feel of the genre. A good game to get non-gamers to play.

RATING: 7
Played through half a game with my sister. We played two characters each (one selected, one random), which turned out really well because one of my investigators "died" twice and I would have been really frustrated if he was my only character as the hospital trip and health recovery takes several turns. Very rules intensive the first read through and then had to check the rules for everything. I wish there was a storage tray a la Small World to hold all the bits in the "bank". Besides that, easy to see why this game takes so long to play through. And easy to see how cool the mechanics are with the different locations and location specific encounters (events). Definitely want to play this through again to the end.

RATING: 6
The game setup takes a lot of time and the table space required is too much. The rule book seems to miss on some parts of the game and the layout of the book requires some page flipping back and forth. There are a lot of things to keep track of and small parts of a turn can be easily missed. I would not recommend this for novice gamers or a group smaller than three. The theme is well-suited and the gameplay mechanics are interesting once you gain an understanding. There seems to be many similar games on the market that have been inspired by this original.

RATING: 9.5
Not a game for everyone:
1- You must like narrative/cooperative games.
2- You need imagination to fit into the story.
3- You must like Lovecraft (or terror, in general).
4- You must like chaos, event cards and tons of rules and exceptions.
5- You must like dice.

If you accept these conditions, then this is an incredible game!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Do you love feeling like a game is stealing your lunch money, kicking you in the teeth, running you over in its SUV, denying your college application, and spilling its drink down your shirt? You'll love Arkham Horror as this game does everything in its power to amp up the pressure on players every turn. While it has a lot of random elements, most of them tend to lend a feeling of horror rather than frustration. The base game has a lot of replayability until you start winning every game.

Update 2016: The community is great and has so much custom content just for the base game that even someone who is completely bored with it can find themselves being drawn back to it again and again for very little upfront effort. There are whole player-made expansions out there. This won't reflect on the score as it's unrelated to FFG's publishing of the game.

Update 2017: Game has definitely worn down with time and lack of substantial expansions make me aware of just how limited its potential is. It's still great to bring out when new people want to play.

RATING: 5
Given that it's trying to develop a narrative experience, I think that Arkham Horror does a fine job. But as a strategically engaging game, I think that it's pretty bloated and messy. It's okay, but since I've played Eldritch Horror I've already played a more streamlined, cleaned up version of the same basic game. 

Of course, both Eldritch and Arkham both boil down to little more than dice fests when it comes to strategy. But at that point the question is how interesting the few options the games do give you to affect your outcome are. I think Arkham is okay--best when played with people engaging with the experience. Eldritch is a bit better.

RATING: 6
Quality title. Probably the best pseudo-RPG in board game form I've played. Decent amount of depth, but could definitely be better.  

*eDit: Score lowered a half point due to the fiddly aspects of game play. The game is a touch more abstract than it should be, especially regarding monster / gate limits. Those kind of mechanics really kill it for me since they feel so contrived.  Still the best pseudo-RPG on the market in my experience thus far.  

*2012 update: Sold. The fiddliness really began to kill the game for me. The Other World cards were just too simple, and rarely painted a self consistent picture. Score lowered by another point (to six).

RATING: 6
This was the big game that got my existing game group (historically RPGs and occasionally Magic: The Gathering) into board gaming.  Super overwhelming at first, but thematically a load of fun.  Even my wife, who doesn't really have strong feelings for the Cthulu mythos or horror theme, really enjoys the game.  Plays great with 5-6 people.  And I'll occasionally break it out for a solo play (with 2-3 investigators).  We've picked up a few of the expansions within my group (I got Dunwich) and played it regularly every weekend for months.  

It hasn't seen the table for a while since I've been exposing my group to new things, but it'll see play again and will stay in my collection for keeps I think.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's beautiful for what it is--a monster coop against very tall odds. The serious fiddly-ness is kind of thematic, as it kind of puts you in the shoes of an investigator facing the ineffable. A lot of the atmosphere also comes from the fact that the game tends to run so long, most sessions I've played ended in the so-late-it's-becoming-early hours of the night.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As many have noted, the rules are fiddly and you are at times at the mercy of grim Lovecraftian forces–bad luck can overwhelm the investigators. Very fun and evocative though and can be tuned with house rules and supplemented with better rules summaries and wikis found online. Highly recommend if you have the patience and inclination to play enough to get comfortable with the rules. We've also found that a four-hour playing time is optimistic. With most Ancient Ones my experience is the games average around 6 hours but there are a lot of variables that can shorten or lengthen a game.

RATING: 8

This is one game that is made for house rules, so that it can be tailored to meet the wants, needs and desires of your particular group.

The written text on the cards is what makes the game shine, and with a little imagination, your group can envision itself as ordinary citizens trying to save the world from annihilation.

You find clues, you have encounters, you try to close gates, and you get hurt, you get driven insane and wounded by everything on the large board. 

Actually, i don't play this game anymore: Eldritch horror has captured all the good things of Arkham and add a lot to it. It really feels like an "enhanced Arkham".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Fantastic game
Lots of flavor and story potential

This is not a game to be taken out on a whim.  This is a title you want to center your game night around.  This title requires a significant time investment, even with veteran players.  

Having the host set up as much of the game as possible prior to game nights start is a good idea.  This is especially true if expansions are involved as the expansions make this already large game, much larger.

Warning: Play and become comfortable with the base game first before adding expansions to this game.

Tip: There is an app out there that will take the place of all of the decks of cards for this game.  This significantly reduces space needed.  Free on Android, unsure about other platforms.

RATING: 7.7
The Ancient One Stirs as One of his several eyes opens. 
Portals to other realms of Horror and Torment open randomly through-out Arkham City. More eyes open and monsters of the most nightmare-ish description spew through the open portals into the streets. 
Kill the creatures, close the portals, seal the portals all before the Ancient One Awakens from his millenia of sleep and reaks havoc and destruction while Arkham is over-run by TERROR in its most gruesome form: Lovecraftian based Horror. 
What a Great game. Four Player takes a long time to finish, but it is a theme that I realy like. I personally could play it all day and not get bored. Single Player is quite a nice challenge and is much faster by atleast a couple of hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Are you ready to pit your sharpest gaming wits to the ultimate test? Are you up for the challenge of playing a game where the win/loss chance is slicing its terrified feet on a knife edge so sharp that your insanity will be pushed to the final brink of destruction? If you answered yes to these questions....your messed up, go back to the mental asylum. lol. No, seriously though, this game will test you and your gaming skills to the absolute limits as you fight to close portals to other dimension and slay or run away from monsters so hideous and unpronounceable that even death may die. This Lovecraftian based game of horror and intrigue takes a bit to get your head around and may take a few games to get used to but once you have all of the phases and rules mastered, it becomes a game of epic proportions.
 P.S. do not play this game at midnight on the winter solstice or the unspeakable elder gods of the other-worlds might never let you live to tell the story. MUUHAHAHAHAHAHAHAA! Brilliant game, absolutely brilliant

P.S.S. When someone says "boardgame", if the games: Monopoly, scrabble and pictionary are the first or only games that enter your feeble little mind, then do not even bother opening the box on this one. Your mundane little brain will explode from the insanity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Gioco complesso, ma dopo la prima partita si è padroni delle meccaniche; purtroppo lo ritengo poco bilanciato, una partita può durare anche 10 minuti se gira male... o 4/5 ore.
Se un giocatore pesca male, è condannato a passare la partita marginalmente, purtroppo anche andare a comprare gli oggetti, per esempio negli oggetti comuni sono tantissime varietà, sopratutto quando si va ad aggiungere qualche espansione.
Difficile curarsi (bisogna andare in luogo apposito), ancor più difficile usare magie, perchè consumano sanità mentale (salvo recarsi al manicomio a curarsi). Tutto ciò non rende il gioco difficile, ma frustrante.
Ovviamente quando invece gira medio\bene, è entusiasmante vincere all'ultimo tiro, così come le meccaniche delle 100 cose che si innescano. 
Il tutto mischia un gioco da pensatori con il caso più che totale, ponendo il rischio di far diventare il gioco tedioso per l'intera partita (ore).
Consiglio sicuramente di provarlo, ma compratelo solo dopo averlo provato.

RATING: 9
Long, difficult, and incredibly tense, this game seems to perfectly capture the Lovecraftian feel of struggling against the unnamable horrors that could end our world!

I've had 2 hour games, I've had 6 hour games, all have been fun, but some have been pretty stressful. The rules are a little complex so it helps to have a lawyer/game master keeping an eye on things, but the options open to players and the feel of control you have over being prepared for the situations that pop up is very strong. Great, great cooperative game!

RATING: 10
Dedicated to H.P.L.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu Rl'yeh wgah'nagl fhtagn!

RPG-lite. Arkham Horror inspired me to devour a "best of" Lovecraft's literature, so it's neat to come back to the game knowing the story behind the characters and locations. I initially rated this game a 10; in short, it is amazing. However, as I'm learning strategies to "beat" it, I find myself less and less inclined to pull it out with people who've played it before.

House rules we use to toughen things up:

1) Take the Elder Signs out of the unique item deck.
2) Two monsters appear at each new gate.
3) Gates are placed face down.
4) Raise the terror level by 1 every time a monster takes to the skies.
5) If a gate appears on a sealed location, the seal is broken.
6) Investigators CAN NOT trade items and spells at the beginning of or during combat with the Great Old One.
7) Investigators make a Sanity Roll at the beginning of combat with the Great Old One using the GOO's combat modifier and the Sanity Roll modifier. Any investigator failing this check immediately discards half of their items, spells, and allies. 
8) During battle with the Great Old One, investigators' special non-combat abilities may be used only once and only if no attack is taken on that turn.

RATING: 8
I have this, and all the expansions.
The game has a demanding setup, and the play time can extend way beyond 4h (like in an 8-players game, where 6 are first time players).
Randomness fucks you up more often than not.
All of that limits my rating to 8/10, otherwise the game is great and very much enjoyable.
Add the expansions and everything goes up to eleven: the complexity increases; setup and playtime get longer; and the game gets even better.

RATING: N/A
Third attempt at engendering a theme of dread and suspense. I was underwhelmed by Eldritch Horror, as noted below—all the globetrotting seemed random pretty quickly and ended up as so much pushing cardboard. The Arkham Horror map is more focused and intimate, and I’m hoping it will do a better job of creating that sense of creeping dread I’m looking for.

With a little help from the BGG community to make Encounters and Monsters, etc. more thematic and less arbitrary, this seems to be closer to the mark in terms of what I’m hoping for. I like the potential for relationships between characters, trading of items, etc., as well. Here’s hoping...

Great game but fairly cumbersome rules. Supports up to 8 players and is a good social cooperative game.

Play time is LONG (maybe 6 hours, plus considerable setup and takedown time).  Components are very nice, well made.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is one of my best purchases because it fills a unique niche pretty well.  It's a complex cooperative game that supports a good range of players with lots of chrome -- items, abilities, spells, monsters, locations, events, etc.

There are a few small downsides from all that complexity and chrome.  The first is that one person needs to learn the rules very well to help run things.  The second is that it isn't a flawless engine -- sometimes you might have to tweak things to get them working right.

Overall, I haven't found either to be that big of a problem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After 800+ hours of playing Arkham Horror with all combinations of expansions I'll rate this at 9/10.

It's wonderfully random which makes no two games act out in the same way. It can actually be fun losing a game, which is a good thing since you'll be doing that a LOT.

+

Investigators and their background stories. 

Some of the investigator abilities are a great deal of fun. Rex, Wendy and Hank comes to mind.

Artwork and components are of excellent quality.

Reading encounters are tense and fun as they often result in unexpected and hilarious outcomes.

The atmosphere is dense and fits the setting perfectly. This is an evil game in so many ways!

Fiddly in a good way. I much prefer this over the more streamlined approach in Eldritch Horror. Arkham Horror has you running around town and other dimensions collecting monster- and gate trophies. After a few hours of play your investigator carries the rewards and scars of your accomplishments. You become attached to your character. 

After having played hundreds of scenarios the past four years we still play at least one scenario a week. 

Deputy Dingby as a comic relief. 

-

Sometimes it's a bit too random. You just won't know if you'll succeed at a check no matter how prepared you are. If you're really unlucky with the mythos cards the game will be over fairly quickly (or just keep going for 12 hours...) and there won't be anything you can do to stop it. We've lost at turn 2 against Cthulhu due to some bad gate spawns and monster movement in Innsmouth. We've also won against all odds by being extremely lucky in late game.

Some of the investigator are just bad due to a combination of bland abilities, low willpower and sanity and/or low movement. The personal quests (expansion) redeems some of the characters. 

So. Many. Cards. Me and my wife decided to just buy a huge table and leave Arkham there at all times. That way we can get a game up and running whenever we feel like it. We once tore the game down and it took us half a year before we actually bothered to set it up again. 

Deputy Dingby trying to do good but ending up ruining your game instead (please, just stop trying to clean that revolver...).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Just bought this game after playing Eldritch Horror (which is one of my favourite games) and I really like this game as well! It is different from Eldritch which I like and has a lot more to remember and keep up but this is personally something that appeals to me. It is definitely a game to bring out though when you have plenty of time to play! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.66
I love the Lovecraft theme. This game does well to capture a sort of pulp adventure trying to save the wold from the Great Old ones.  It annoys me that people say this game isn't dark enough. I personally wouldn't want a game that makes the winner "the guy that kills himself last."  The amount of bits are daunting, but they all work together rather well. Word to the wise though: Get the universal head cheat sheet. The instructions in the box, while being good at illustrating individual concepts, do very poorly to tie them together into something cohesive.   I love this game, but will only play it with my brother, who only visits one time a year.

RATING: 6.5
My problem is much more with the genre than this particular game. Great theme, great atmosphere, but turns always seem to devolve into a group discussion of what to do followed by a mechanical resolution of turns based on the discussion. That is to say, mechanically this game would play just as well with 1 player controlling everyone, which always bothers me.

That said, if you want to do something relatively light and just enjoy the company of some friends-- particularly if any of them are non-gamers-- you could do a whole lot worse.

RATING: 9.1
Played the original when I was young, but when I started collecting and playing designer board games seriously in 2013 I jumped straight into Eldritch Horror and Elder Sign. Well, would you know it, I quite like this too. The revised core game has a lot of content in it, and apart from the art being a little simpler it's all good quality. I'd also argue that while I like the gameplay more in EH, this one feels more thematic since you're not exactly globetrotting but focusing in more like an actual Lovecraft story. That said, there are enough subtle differences to enjoy both of them. EH will likely see more table time among my friends, but AH will also see some, and certainly solo play.

RATING: 10
One of my favorite games, Arkham provides an indepth adventure experience with spot on flavour and spooky atmospher for players to cooperatively struggle against unspeakable odds.
Pros: Theme/Art is fantastic, flavour text is rich and variable
Co-operative adventure with unique characters and abilities offering loads of replay-ability
Involved gaming experience with truly nail biting moments 
Fantasy Flight has brilliant art on each component 

Cons: Set up time & # of components can be intimidating to new players.
Time games are generally 60+ minutes
You lose a lot (which I like! but could be discouraging for some)
Horror theme maybe not for everyone?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Slowly moving up in my ratings.  I was disappointed in my initial experience -- The game seemed a little too easy and the ending was anti-climactic.  This isn't very "gamey" and generally misses the tense decision making from classic Euros.

It does have a great theme, and potential for highly dramatic situations.  Key die rolls can elicit cheers or groans from the whole group and after reading through the FAQ and playing with the appropriate rules it is much more difficult.

It's a long game with a "Role-playing feel" to it.  With the right attitude and an invested group of friends it makes for a good time.

[One smaller criticism:  The board (while very nice to look at) can get very busy, making it hard to get an accurate account of everything in play.]

Edit:  this game ended up falling pretty far in my ratings.  With the right (and smaller) group I expect this can be quite enjoyable, but for me there's not enough GAME in there to justify all the crazy rules and fiddly bits.  

I see why people who love it REALLY love it, but it's not really for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Long game though (3.5 hours +), and a lot to keep track of if you play with just a couple of expansions. Love some of the mechanics in Arkham better than Eldritch. Hard game (win/loss: 1/4)

RATING: 8
THEME THEME THEME !!  
Gotta love this game with all its fiddlyness it still rocks!!

Eldritch Horror is great also but aside from theme its a pretty different game thin Arkham Horror, contrary to what some people say.  Eldritch is much more of a quest oriented game (go here and do this go there and do that travel to this space and kill this)  where as Arkham is a much more combat oriented single focus game - close all gates before the great old one awakens 

Definitely space for both of these games on your shelf !!

4-19-2007
First few times I played this game I was very excited with it.  I enjoyed the sessions very much.  I figured I found a rich gaming experience that I can share with my wife as the game is a cooperative game.  However, tonight's session just fell flat.  Maybe I was tired and I was as patient when I was learning the game.  Maybe I was also annoyed that my wife wasn't paying attention because she was also tired.  Maybe this game is just one of those that I cannot play everytime I want to.  I have to be up for it and my ratings will reflect it.  My 10s are games that I can see myself play and enjoy even if I am tired.  I will keep trying the game and see if I have improved experiences.  For now, I can only see myself playing this in special occasions.
Rating: 7 -> 6.

RATING: 10

This game will never die! Every match is completely different! Love it!

EDIT 2015: This game is a classic. But you will have games where the game drags on forever. On the other side Arkham will create one of the best eperiences you can have in a roleplaying-esque board game in its best moments. Therefor I love Arkham. And will ever do...

EDIT 2017: This game never gets old. Eldritch Horror is a sicker-flop after more and more games but this game stays fresh. Interesting. And - even for newcomers this game is so much clearer (even with being fiddly) how to win or lose.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my all-time favorite games. Straight-up co-op, which is a win in my book. Excellent theme, excellent mechanics, though it does feel a bit dice-chucky sometimes, which is fine for me, but does aggravate folks from time to time. Tension is palpable pretty much every time we play this game--you are never sure who will win, and about 50-60% of the time the players end up losing it.

Three small downsides: 1) there are a massive number of components to this game. It covers the entirety of an 8-person dining table easily with an expansion or two. 2) It can suffer from "President Syndrome" where one person ends up making all the decisions for a group of players who each "control" different characters. The nerdier players need to guard against this, getting input and making sure to allow players to control their own characters. 3) This typically (not always) plays in 3+ hours, so for people that want a quick study, this is not it. The mechanics are simple, but there are still a lot of moving parts. 

I love this game, but I fully acknowledge that not everyone will. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
A beast of a game, extremely immersive.  An extraordinary story always unfolds when it hits the table.
Almost endless replayability based on the high numbers of characters, great old ones, equipment and encounters.
Difficulty level may be high for some players, but it's part of the game's appeal.
Lots of rules to remember, but the game flow becomes fine once you get a hang of it.
Great for solo play, but be warned : the game requires a few hours and a big table!

RATING: 9
Yeah ok I'm probably going to get hassled over giving AH a 9.. but well.. I love it.  It could be largely due to my obsession with anything Lovecraft-related.. you'll note a few Cthulhu-themed games as you go through!

A lot of people criticise this one for a lack of actual playability, and that the board dictates where to go/what to do.. I've got to admit, I've had some plays like that.. but there have been others where we have been free to roam, gear up and experience more of what the game has to offer without chasing the gate count (one game in particular where we sealed a gate early on, and then the next several gates spawned on the sealed spot.. Free Parking!!!)

RATING: 10
Wow what a fun game.  Probably my new #1.  We play for hours and hours and always lose in the end, but I don't care.  It's not about winning it's about the immersive experience.  Yes, it would be nice to win sometimes but I enjoy it immensely whatever the out come.  Just added Dunwich Horror expansion and have 2 others on order.  I love love love all the components.  Card, Card, Cards, piles of Cards!  Love it!  Setting it up, packing it up, just part of the fun of the game.  
Hubby and I were playing this at Game Summit with a couple other guys we met in the game library and we were doing extremely well and I felt that we were actually going to win for once.  Unfortunately it was getting clost to closing so we had to pack it up before we could finish.  The interesting thing was that we were sitting at a table near the entrance to the hall and everyone who passed by stopped to comment "Yer all gonna die!!"
Fun stuff here.

RATING: 5
I love the Cthulhu theme and pretty peices, but what this game really lacks is the 'game".  I find it more like watching a show or something: "Let's see what happens to the characters this game" with very little to do other than move around, draw cards and roll dice.  I don't think there can even be a "Bad" or "Good" Arkham Horror player.  The group aspect leads to mostly always knowing what the best move is (which usually means "go seal a gate" or "collect those clue tokens there" and nothing ever more complicated than that) and then I draw things and roll dice to see what happens.  Meh... I'll play again with the expansions and alternate rules... but I'll never be the one to suggest playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Right now Arkham Horror is driving me crazy.  It's a board game that is dripping with theme, there's a lot going on and difficult choices to make, and it's a cooperative---all of which are big wins to me.  Add on top of that the fact that the game is fiendishly difficult to win---kind of like LotR with Sauron on the 12---although I'm sure it gets easier with more than, say, three players (and definitely more than with two.  And one player is not going to win this game, period, unless they take on multiple characters, which is not a bad thing).  I'm a big fan of adventuring-style games, so I love Arkham Horror.

(Several months later, and the game still drives me crazy, in a good way.  And there are expansions coming.  Woohoo! and all that.)

--

Update 2015: 

Well, now there are a bunch of adventuring co-op style games, and Arkham Horror has fallen by the wayside for being incredibly long and convoluted. A shame.

RATING: 4
I dig the cthulhu mythos but hate the extremely long playing time (especially with many players) for such a light game. I wanted to chew my own foot off by the end just to get away. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Most obviously, this game has too many bits.  Cards and chits and markers and more cards. Setup is long and tedious.  Once the game gets started, though the pace slows down dramatically, and the hours begin to tick away.

Once you get into it, you'll realize that Arkham Horror has nothing clever about it.  The entire game is painfully straightforward, and there is no artistry to how it plays.  There is no real strategy to be had.

The rules are complex and poorly explained.  Spells and item cards are often not clear.  Monsters are crammed with too much information.  Fighting monsters is overly complex.  

Ultimately, there isn't much redeeming about Arkham Horror.  It is a VERY long game with too many rules and not enough strategy.  They could have made a much better game if they would have not tried to cram everything in the world into the box.  This game also betrays the Lovecraft mythos; turning it into "Let's hunt the Monsters", instead of a more "Oh, God, what is that thing?!?".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Theme is great, an involving and complex game. Takes a long time to set up, and even longer to play - The more of the crew that knows how to play will speed up gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With the right players, this is a ton of fun. With the wrong players, it's tedious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played this when I was first getting into the hobby. I still enjoy it to this day. However, I want to play eldritch horror because I have heard that it is a refined version of this game. Again, another game that I will not turn down if someone wants to play. I am always down for a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
rating after 0.75 plays. ...with 6 players.

Cons: 
Whoooooo....  3.5 hours, and the game wasn't complete?  BULLSH!T.  Not a fan of that, at all.  I blame it on the 6 players (and not 4), and it started to feed-back on itself pretty hard.  We would get lost and sidetracked on the story because we were all collectively getting bored of the game 2.5 hours in.

We almost need a DM for the game, because someone has to know the rules inside and out, backwards and forwards.

For as cooperative as it was in working towards a goal, there wasn't a lot you could do, team-style.  One guy would have to tank the monster explosions and fail eventually.  Then the next guy, then the next, then the next.  Likewise for closing gates.

With the particular game we played, towards what would have been the end, it was fairly clear that we needed to brace for arrival of whatever mythos beast was going to come and get us, about 4 turns (or a half an hour) before the end.  That's my only knock against the narrative.  

With 6 players, there's the added challenge against you, but there may not be the additional firepower against the added challenge.  That is, only 4 of you may be worthy adversaries against the monsters, but yet there are 6 of you raising the difficulty level.

Pros:
Everytime I play D&D from here forward, I'll be thinking of how much better Arkham Horror is.  A very excellent, excellent, excellent story narrative.  I found myself, for what little I was playing, getting into this game like it had a plot.  I mean, really getting into this, and feeling the ebb and flow of the game.  So, I really liked it, but I didn't like the 4-hour play time.  Much more, at the end of our time playing this, it felt like we were just about to lose.

The single player mechanic had no flaws that I could see.  It was like, a perfect D&D.

Sold:  Really liked it, but it just wasn't going to get to the table anytime in the next 6-8 years.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gloriously theme-heavy bit of Ameritrash where you and your fellow players try to save the world from a (literal!) Lovecraftian horror intent on devouring it.

The game can get a little grind-y, and the setup is infamous; this is as perfect an example of Fantasy Flight's "More tchotchkes means MOAR FUN!!!" design aesthetic as you're ever going to find.  Still, when it's going well, it's a tense, exciting game, and bringing down the Big Bad is a rush.

In theory, this game should have a major problem with The Colonel.  (See my comments for Pandemic.)  In practice, I've never actually seen one alpha-dweeb trying to boss the rest of the table around.  Perhaps the role-playing elements are enough of a psychological barrier to keep that at bay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Not as good as Eldritch Horror but still is a classic. The Arkham Horror shall never die. Once you master the game you can challenge yourself and make the game even harder by adding expansions.

RATING: 8
Suszone grzyby
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In 2005 I rated this game a 6 and wrote:
"What is wrong with this game?
1) It is hard to play the odds without studing the decks. So to be a smart player you have to do research outside the game.
2) It can feel repetitive, even like a chore at times.
3) The mechanic of skill adjustment is really strange. The speed/sneak combo makes some good sense, but fight/will and lore/luck do not make as much sense.
4) The Mythos cards are poorly laid out. They should progress top to bottom with what you need to do when you draw the card. Instead the information is spread all over the card, and after hours of play I still find myself referring to a cheat sheet to help me do things in the right order and not leave anything out. This may seem like a minor gripe, but I bump heads with it every turn, every game...
I wanted to love this game. On the positive side, the vanilla game feels like it already has tons of expansions straight out of the box."

In 2008 I stand by all the above criticisms, but my opinion of the game has changed radically, and it is fully due to how I have learned to approach the game. This is a game that I really wanted to love, but I ended up concluding that it is actually a pretty crummy game. In 2008 I found myself wondering why so many people love this game so much, so I did some BGG research that has change me as a game considerably.

While I've always known that theme, atmosphere, and story is very important to me, previously I've never thought to approach a board game with the primary goal of creating story. Rather, I've generally approached board games, and judged boardgames, with the idea that the primary goal of play is to make wise decisions within the mechanics of the game in an effort to achieve victory, and in doing so have fun. In other words, if a game didn't offer a player enough opportunities to make smart choices to achieve victory, I wouldn't consider it a good game. Luck and randomness were not shunned, but I felt as though too much luck and randomness would drown out the worthiness of even the most beatifully themed and bitted game.

Reading the Geek has expanded my concept of what can make a game worthwhile. Players who speak lovingly of Arkham Horror often speak of creating a story. Indeed, the Arkham Horror session reports are sometimes short stories unto themselves. 

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/304415

Exposure to this attitude inspired me to give Arkham Horror another try. I approached it as a game whose primary goal is to make a story, rather than make wise decisions.

I am not one to study the cards, so the encounters, and their outcomes, usually come as some surprise. Since the outcomes are usually a surprise (for example, a character may go to a location that exhibits a clue and a sanity icon and ends up gaining a dollar), I find it very hard to play an informed, tactically wise game, which makes it difficult to adhere to any conceived strategies. This is a huge negative if your intent is to make wise decisions that will lead to victory. But if you are playing to create story, you come to realize that playing Arkham Horror, with the ridiculously vast expanse of all its expansions, is like walking in an alternate reality.

As with life, you just don't know what is going to happen next. You can make reasonable decisions and assumptions, and sometimes they will work out just the way you might expect. But more frequently they won't. 

So you want to learn some spells? It is reasonable to think that the library may be a good place to research spells, and the board helps you out in that regard. But when you show up and the librarian offers you some fantastic reward for the tome that you just read and discarded on the way to the library, well, crap, that is life. How frustrating. And virtually impossible to plan for or anticipate. And wonderful.

And since Arkham is a such a wonderful and dangerous alternate reality, spending time there and having a hand in an unfolding adventure really is a lot of fun. Again, all my initial criticisms stand, but I'm changing my rating to an 8.

4/12: Changing my rating to 7.

12/12: Changing my rating to 6. I tried playing again with Oslo and Rio, as Oslo has been reading Lovecraft and was into giving it a try. It felt like a chore. The layout of the event cards is so horrible, just remembering what order you are supposed to resolve things is difficult. I think I should get rid of these games as they aren't worth the shelfspace. I think if you were playing with people very familiar with the game and really into it, it could be good fun, but as an occasional casual experience, it isn't a good choice for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pretty good game, dripping with theme, but it's just....
so....
slow....

I love heavy games and even I have to mentally steel myself for a marathon before agreeing to play this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A sprawling mess of a game that somehow manages to be pretty fun despite its many flaws.  The most egregious problems are that tension doesn't necessarily increase as the game progresses, and it's perfectly possible to be clearly winning with an hour and a half of play-time left to go, both of which lead to tedium.  Good for a snowed-in Saturday, but definitely one to break out every few months at the most.

Raised to a 6, as I keep coming back to this chaotic brew of ill-fitting mechanics and enjoying it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Thematically one of the best games around, Arkham Horror requires you to be a Cthulhu fan in order to enjoy it fully: yet, even if you’re not (I surely ain’t), you may have a very good time playing it, since it’s quite challenging and sets up a superb cooperative play, most likely thanks to it being developed around and with a solid theme such as the lovecraftian mythos is.

Even though Arkham Horror is a very enjoyable - however complex and long - game, my favourite in the horror genre is Mansions of Madness, followed by Betrayal at the House on the Hill, the best choice for a lighter, Goosebumps-like experience: as a heavy and thematic cooperative, go with the fantasy-set Defenders of the Realm instead, and even more so since it was designed by the same author of Arkham Horror. (January 2012)

[b]Update[/b] - Several games later, I noticed a severe issue with this game is the excessive length its turns may take, especially when new or competitive players are around: the former because of their obvious lack of experience with the rules, resulting in the experienced players explaining to them all the available options they have that turn; the latter because of their unceasing pursuit of the optimal action, which means they think endlessly about what to do next.
And in the meantime the other players simply wait and wait and wait...

Such issues aren’t negligible, as they turn Arkham Horror into a cooperative game of boredom, not horror: thus, yawn after yawn, in October 2013 I’ve reduced my rating from 8 to 6.

RATING: 6
The game is a mishmash of  multiple phases, obscure rules, lots of card flipping and reading of flavor text.  Then you roll dice and hope 5 & 6s show up. Wash, Rinse and repeat for 3-4 hours.  A long and engaging game that will give everyone an interesting story when it's all said and done.  You just have to be prepared for a dense game with lots of little rules.  In this day an age of streamlined mechanics and euro hyrbids, AH seems like a relic of a bygone era. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Arkham Horror is a game set in the Lovecraftian universe and does an excellent job of capturing the feel of those stories. The game can be challenging, especially for new players, but that makes victory even more enjoyable. The components all look very good and professional.

The game usually feels intense and desperate at times. The skill sliders allow for some customization of characters in a very simple manner that doesn't bog down the game. The combat system is handled very well. You can sneak past monsters or fight them. However, most monsters can inflict sanity loss so being good at combat isn't always good enough.

What don't I like? For one, some of the rules seem haphazardly scattered throughout the book. Some better editing could have cleaned this up and made it easier to read and reference. Two, the game doesn't scale very well with the number of players. It will pretty much always be easier to have a group of four players rather than two. Three, while the encounters that you have during the game are very entertaining and sometimes feel almost like a RPG, you have very few choices during these encounters and they do not adjust based on what actually makes sense for your character. Finally, between the large board and the dozen separate decks of cards, it takes up a good bit of space to play. I have no idea how some people play with multiple expansions.

None of those shortcomings are crippling. If you are a fan of Lovecraftian horror, you should own this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

I think this one really depends on your group and how invested they are going to get into a game like this. I think it has a lot of potential, but I feel myself wishing for something a bit shorter. Also the game takes up a crazy ammount of space.
I think this is a game I want to try and enjoy more, not sure if I have time to learn to do that though.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I can't believe I haven't made a comment here - AH has fast become THE staple game in our collection. it's easy to learn, has little downtime, and presents a significant but not insurmountable challenge to the group despite being a straight-laced co-op with no traitor.

This game is just FUN. Occasionally it just kills you and there's nothing you can do about it, and sure after you seal the fourth gate there's not much that can stop you just winning, but for those broad flaws you will enjoy the three hours of the game 90% of the time.

It's also the only game I've ever played where the fact that there are so many bits is part of the fun. Having loads of GOOs and loads of investigators should feel like a lame fix to a boring set of mechanics, but each investigator's power and each GOO's different effect on gameplay means it is almost endlessly replayable. 

This one deserves its reputation as well as its spot as our go-to game for games nights. I think it belongs in every gamer's collection.

Got rid of pre-Melbourne move

RATING: 7.5
The first cooperative I've owned, and one which I certainly enjoyed at first. That said, it is very complicated, somewhat random, and quite long. While I don't regret having played it, I think their are more streamlined options out there for people who don't want to burn three to four hours on a cooperative game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is not meant to be about tactics or strategy. It is random yet story-driven and atmospheric with a very nice feeling of impending doom. Players are free to go their own ways but cooperation and specialisation within the group makes it easier to win.

My biggest gripe is that the time constraint within the game is a disincentive to explore which is not balanced by anything else, thus half the players visit the same locations turn after turn while the other half try to tick off the biggest priorities of the moment.

It also takes a lot of space and a lot of time to play. Playing time is fine for my group but setting up and packing away probably takes yet another hour.

It should also be pointed out that the game is rather thin without any expansions. And that it is expensive.

RATING: 5
This is not so much a game as an unfolding story and you, the viewer/player, get to insert some decisions on which way to go and less often about what to do. Possibly the single most important thing you can do on each turn is to tweak your character abilities before moving to an encounter spot. At four hours per play, there is too much chrome and not enough game to be a genuine contest. However, the production is top-notch and just about everything Lovecraft ever mentioned is in the game. For fans of Lovecraft and Talisman, "C'thulisman" has arrived...

RATING: 8.5
Arkham Horror is a great game IMO.  The rules and mechanisms do seem complex at first but once you understand them they are actually pretty easy.  But the learning curve can be a little steep.  I highly recommend that you sit down and play a solo 4 investigator game to learn the rules.  Then once you feel comfortable, give the rules a read through again and print out the flowchart on this site and play a multiplayer game.  It will go a lot smoother rather than spending most of your time with your nose in the rules while the other players are waiting.

This game offers a great Lovecraftian mythos feel and the cooperative nature is great because you all either win or are devoured : ).  

Personally I think this game is worth the effort to learn it as it offers great value.

RATING: 5.5
Definitely enjoyable.  Dripping with theme.  I would agree that there are better co-operative games out there, but the atmosphere of this game just sucks you in.  With more than 4 players, there can be a lot of down-time... also there are lots of little rules so it's best played with someone familiar with the rules.  **UPDATE** There is a VERY skewed distribution of gate openings & clue token appearances.  This makes me feel that the base game is pretty scripted (i.e. seal the most active gates, then slowly win the game).  I'm anxious to try the Dunwich Horror expansion... which sounds like it will fix this super strategy.  If you want a tougher game with the basic set, i would suggest playing the Hastur scenario (which makes it harder to seal gates).  Perhaps random die rolls to determine gate & clue appearances would make the game feel less scripted.

RATING: 8
The first day I played this, we tried three times. Stopped Game 1 after an hour because we were learning the rules and had made crucial errors. Game 2 was unbelievably frustrating: an environment card that put virtual mummies in EVERY STREET, combined with Shub-Niggurath (all monsters 1 stronger), meant that we could barely move and couldn't get to any gates, let alone seal them. After a 6-7 agonizingly frustrating turns, this environment was STILL there. We threw up our hands, conceded to the game again and ordered pizza. Thus fortified, we tried a third time and finally played a full (3 hour) game, which ended with us sealing six gates and winning. While the third game was ultimately satisfying, my overall first-time experience was not. However, after a number more plays both in-person and PBEM, the game has really begun to grow on me, and my rating has gone up. The game rules are complex and detailed, but I didn't find it strategically taxing (only annoying), so I consider it a light-medium weight.

RATING: 8
I love this so much that I've run a stack of PBF versions of it. I love the theme, the mechanics, the group interaction... it can be a little clunky at times, and it needs the accident/injury cards to avoid becoming horrible at times, but I love being able to mix and match in things from the various expansions. I'd happily play this every week, if the opportunity arose.

It does have its flaws - it's easy in the base version to end up unable to move around the streets, because fighting the monsters is pretty much the hardest thing in the game, and if you end up getting knocked out or driven batty, you lose half your stuff... but the monsters are stopping you getting to the shop, so you can't buy more stuff, so you can't beat the monsters. It can also suffer from one particular player telling other people what they should do each turn.

But I love this, I really do. I just wish I got to play more.

RATING: 8
The game is legendary and you feel it when you play it; it feels as if the game has a consciousness of its own. Especially when using the Dunwich expansion, you are on the edge of a knife the whole game. Resources are scarce, you put together plans in collaboration with the other players, and dread the next card draw to see if the game crushes everything you've put together. It is fiddly and there is much to remember at a time, but all of it seems oddly appropriate, as if it were part of the ritual. If you refuse to relate to a Lovecraftian horror theme or despise fiddly, long games, then you will want to steer cleer. Otherwise, you owe it to yourself to give yourself over to Arkam Horror at least once.

Update: As much as it pains me, with so many games out there, I don't see myself reaching for Arkham as often as I'd like because it asks so much - and doesn't always deliver. It hasn't changed; I have. It goes from a 10 to a still classic 9.

Update: Further pained. Eldritch Horror has made such significant improvements that it knocks Arkham down to an 8 for me. EH delivers much (and in some cases more) of what Arkham does while asking so much less in terms of playtime and bookkeeping.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was one of my favorite games for a long time. I've played it a ton, but have not played it in several months. I actually had it on the table, took the top off (well of one of the boxes, it takes two stuffed boxes to contain my Arkham Horror collection), peered intently into the box, looked around the table, put the top back on and played something else. Here's what dropped its ranking:
* The game is largely the same. Yes, I play this more as an experience game than a mechanical game (many games allow both, but AH is not one of them IMO). We battle the Great Old One (GOO), and try and tell a story. Pity that the story is often the same. Here's the script: "GOO is waking up, courageous invesitgators risk all to force GOO back into slumber! Investigators break into skill-based roles (street sweeper, shopper, gate closer) seal the appropriate number of gates and win." Rinse, repeat. Unfortunately, even the interesting/funny jokes are starting to get old, as there is no new material. We had a running joke for ages about me. My character ALWAYS was reduced to one sanity early in the game, and no matter how I tried I was always reduced quickly back to one, perched precariously on the edge of insanity. Jokes ensued, laughs were had, but there was nothing new to drive an evolution in the experience.
* Adding expansions didn't really change the experience much. Sure, there's the odd new/different mechanic added, some were good, some were lousy, but the core way of playing the game was virtually untouched. Guardians and Heralds seemed fun at first, but didn't really change much. New critters? Sweet! Not so much, just a bit different and maybe taking some different equipment to deal with. Yeah, new cards and areas, but there's only so much you can add from three lines of text for a given event. Most of them boiled down to the same thing. "Win your die roll or lose 2 sanity". Same jokes, same story.
* The mechanics of the game are fiddly and not particularly interesting. Oddly enough, the game is quite easy to win despite all the dice rolling. The few times things went south and we fought the GOO in combat directly (which is not the desired way to win the game) the dice could grant or steal away a victory. It didn't make the game interesting, just random.
* LOTS of components. I like games with lots of components. I like games with few components. I dislike games with components that are not useful in the game. The spell deck for AH with the expansions is several inches thick. The number of spells you're HAPPY to get out the deck is pitifully small, and the number of spells that are almost unusable (except in some obscure situation that will likely not occur in that session) is quite high. Pull Shrivelling, Flesh Ward or Find Gate? Sa-weet! Pull many of the other spells? They're either useless or have such a high cost that you have to either have the Healing Stone, the tome that prevents 1 sanity loss from casting spells or be the psychologist to be able to use them. A good portion of the common and unique item decks are the same way. I'm not saying that everything in the decks needs to be super powerful, far from it. I'm saying that the percentage of even nominally useful vs. total crap is totally out of line.
* Since AH is a co-op, that can be both a positive and a negative. My current group is not big on co-op at the moment, and I'm likely a big part of that. By playing too many co-ops for too long, I think I'm burned out on them for the moment. I like smashing other players in the ground and trying to prevent them from doing the same to me. Having the game roll over with a whimper or just waste us all in moments due to total dumb, random chance is not particularly appealing to me.
* I guess it boils down to this: Once you solve the game, the story component will only last so long before you want something else. AH has been great for a while, but it's made the migration from the games cabinet to the storage closet. It's not a mainstay of boardgaming anymore and may never be again.

Don't get me wrong, I've loved many games of Arkham Horror. I think some of the weaknesses take time to notice, and your gaming group is a bigger factor in your enjoyment of this game than it is in many others. I still recommend it if I think the fit is right, but it's not the brilliant game I once thought it was, it's just a good, solid co-op for people that are willing to roleplay as part of the boardgaming experience.

I decided my time with Arkham Horror was at an end and solid this.  I do like the game but I didn't want to play it anymore. Space considerations sent it on it's way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I have the ultimate love/hate relationship with Arkham Horror, because it's a neat game with so much conceptual potential, but at least two hours out of the six and a half it takes to set up and play is spent on tedious "book keeping" tasks such as readjusting your character stats, and moving around/keeping track of all this other little pieces around the board. 

Tons of complexity does not always equal tons of fun, sometimes it just makes for a heavily padded play time, which I'm sure Fantasy Flights learned by the time they created Eldritch Horror, which takes everything I loved about Arkham and removed the tedious stuff.
The only thing in Arkham Horror that I kind've miss that isn't in Eldritch is monster movements. It was fun anticipating monster movements and planning your movements accordingly. But that it literally the only thing. Every other change is a vast improvement.

Almost anybody who has played both games will say what I'm about to say. You can skip this and go straight for Eldritch Horror. You'll be glad you did.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
