=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Phhhbbbbbttt!!!  Marbles...?  I've lost em.  

This is the quintessential "ameritrash" game that just oozes theme from every pore.  It is set in Lovecraft's world of nondescript terror and mayhem.  There is abundant phychosis dripping from this little gem which is a rich ecperience and a great game to bring out and adventure with.

It feels like roleplaying and yet it has the simplicity to draw in gamers that wouldn't glance twice at a DnD table or text.

Everyone selects characters which are trying to save Arkham against monsters porting in from other dimensions to wreck and ruin.  The flavor is of the 1930s and there is that heavy art neuveau feeling to it which is appropriate.  I think it is lovely as far as components. Another bonus is that there are tons of players  within the geek community and many other characters and variations which help to tweak it for difficulty,time and flavor.  There are all sorts of creative variants which can help you scale you game to intensity so beyond the printed rules there is just another whole world out there.  

I love to play this and once you get the dice rolls down and how things affect each character its just a great time to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great theme.  One of the best adventure type games out there.

RATING: 8

The amount of material available in the expansions makes this an awesome customizable game system that's pretty much infinitely replayable.  Replaced somewhat by Eldritch Horror.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
Pre-play impressions:  
Lovecraft - should be great
BGG rating - very high - should be great
Components look excellent - should be great

Gameplay :
1. Move from place to place on board
2. Wait
3. Read text on card
4. Wait
5. Roll Dice and check what happens
6. Wait

Repeat steps 1 thru 6 (*)
....Again
....& Again
....& Again
....& Again.........

(*) actually sometimes there are variations in the rounds that really spice up the gameplay such as:
1. Wait.
2. Wait
3. Wait
4. Wait
5. Roll dice and see what happens
6. Wait

Postplay impressions:

After 3 hours in our 8 player game we did win, but to be honest I really didn't care in the end one way or the other.  About half the group had played this one before and all spoke very highly of it.  Those of us new to AH (all seasoned serious gamers) all came away with the same impression....we had just saved ourselves $100. 



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's a monster of a game that takes up a lot of table space with all of its cards and chits and whatnot, but it's well worth the the time it takes to set up. It's even better with the expansions. UPDATE: I'm lowering my rating to 7 because the fiddlyness of it all is beginning to get to me. It's also the sort of game that will only work with some groups.

UPDATE (January, 2009): After a particularly grueling session of AH I've lowered AH to a 4 and put it on my trade block. YEs, it's LOvecraft, and yes, it's RPG-ish, both of which I'm a fan of, but the gameplay simply isn't engaging. Just about every sessions I've had with AH includes a lof of downtime and confusion as people forget what is going on and conversations drift. A good game keeps your attention...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favourite co-op titles, this game pits a group of adventurers against otherworldly forces inspired by the Cthulhu Mythos created by H. P. Lovecraft and his successors. The downside is that the Mythos information is drawn heavily from the interpretation used in all of the "Call of Cthulhu" games and products, meaning that their interpretation of the entire mythology is fundamentally flawed to the point that it's almost as if no one working on the product line has ever even read any of Lovecraft's work in any level of depth.
That said, the game itself is an incredible amount of fun. The rules are a bit complex, so I wouldn't recommend playing the game unless someone in the group has a high level of experience with the game, or if your group is fine with sorting through a large number of rules to figure out the way the game actually works.
Overall, the "events"/cards in the game are well-written, the box, board and pieces are all really well-made, and it's a really solid co-op game. A great way to spend an evening.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Arkham Horror just looked so COOL, I HAD to get it. I bought it, punched the pieces, set it up, looked through all the cards, picked my characters, played a solo game. We won with no casualties (I think against Yig or whoever the rulebook suggests for an easy game), and we were never in any real danger. I wanted to play another game, with other players, so I brought it to a couple of gatherings. The game length and complexity meant it never hit the table; and as time went on I wanted to play it less and less. I bought the Curse of the Dark Pharaoh Expansion, but it didn't increase my desire to play again. Now I have no interest.

RATING: 10
One of my first modern tabletop games and still a favorite. Arkham is a beautiful mess of a game with a glut of mechanisms and rules that somehow produce a brilliantly fun and thematic experience which simultaneously manages to feel both punishing and winnable, tactical and luck driven. The base game suffers from not enough encounters, but my personal copy is mutated with cherry-picked pieces from most of the expansions and it comes out routinely and is always a blast.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Game tries to be two things at once, which ends up
leaving me simply not enjoying it.

1) It's a co-op optimization puzzle. Too heavy 
in terms of the complexity (due to luck) to easily
solve as such for my tastes. Worse, the fact that
it's this completely gets in the way of the other
aspect of the game.

2) The folks who really love this game seem to not
be into the puzzle, but more into the experience.
I enjoy plenty of experience games (like Tales
of the Arabian Nights) but get hung up on trying 
to win this, because that actually appears to be
the goal. In a game like Tales, I gladly just play
to explore the space. Using prior knowledge of 
events seems like cheating - and the game loses 
much of its flavor once you 'know' most of them.
With this one, there's no where near that level of
story going on - so it's far easier to be driven by
the puzzle; and that puzzle is just not much fun.

Better game than Talisman, but more effort to play
(and about as much to set up). If given the choice
of which bad game to play, I'd probably pick Talisman -
if only for the fact that I have internalized the rules
more.

RATING: 8
Juego cooperativo para entre 1 y 8 personas (quizá con 7-8 demasiados tiempos de espera) y unas 3 horas de duración de media.Me ha encantado este juego. No conozco nada del universo Lovecraftiano. RATING: 9
One of the first hobby board games I was ever introduced to. Played with a great group of college friends. We got walloped by Shub-Niggurath and I demanded we immediately set up and play again. I've played this until 3 in the morning more times than I can count, and I will always cherish my warm memories of those college days. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played an 8 player game on Tabletop Day 2015

I honestly thought I was going to hate this game. I've played Betrayal at House on the Hill...and hated it! Arkham Horror in my mind was going to be an even more bloated version of that.

I was wrong. One of the things I liked was that I had purpose and could go around and do things (fight monsters, close gate, etc.). Yeah I still think encounter decks are kind of cheesy, but for some reason it didn't bother me as much as it usually does in games like this.

Granted, it had some of the things I don't like about Betrayal: lots of downtime while someone works out their encounter or fight, sometimes boring turns (I moved to the second half of the gate!), lots of pieces to keep track of, etc.

My biggest complaint about Arkham Horror though, was the narrative arc. I could tell at about hour 3 that we were going to win. There was no way we couldn't, and yet we still had to slog through 1.5 hours of jumping through hoops and going through the motions. By the time it ended I was just excited to be done with the hoop jumping, not excited that we had won!

I will not buy this game, but I would play it again. I think though I would want to institute something like a "Let's just say we won" vote if it looks like we'll just be hoop jumping for the next hour or two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There are few games I've fallen in love with as much as Arkham Horror.  The theme, the setting, the monsters, the psychological horror, the locations, the characters, the replayability.  Who isn't terrified of the Great Old Ones?  For games that play long 3-5 hours, this one is the top of the list.  I know this isn't for everyone, but for some good old storytelling and monster trashing, nothing beats this game. Ia! Ia! Ia!

RATING: 8
It's all about the theme - you have to see the story behind the mechanics to enjoy this game properly.

I experience a more consistent storyline when playing solo, although I guess that with the right people (my group isn't much into Lovecraft and the Mythos) it might get better.  

I'd rate it a bit higher but the set up time, the actual playing time and the space it needs won't allow me to take it out often. Also the rules are not very intuitive in some parts and you 'll need to have a few games under your belt to be comfortable with them.

It's a great game though!

tip: Download and use the Universal Head Game Aid!!!

Final edit: Traded it, moving on to new adventures!

RATING: 4
I played it two or three times with a big group and we didn't finish the game any time. It takes too long, and there's a lot of downtime with many players. I think it might be a good game with fewer players, but maybe not even then. You cannot really make a plan or work together. It's too fiddly with too much downtime. Best (worst) example: you have to skip turns doing nothing, whenever you try to close portals. That's just no fun.

This is exaggerated by the fact that it looks gorgeous, and gamers want to play and like it. UNO is an awful game (for adults) but who cares, nobody is going to suggest playing it. Arkham Horror, on the other hand, is pulling you in (and then spitting you out).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Can't wait to play a game!  Wow this is a heavy box!

Update:

Played with 2.  What a wonderfully thematic game.  Initially the various interactions can seem a little overwhelming and the rules book can be tough to find little rules in (would have benefited from an index), but the play aids here on BGG are very helpful.  Aside from these minor issues this is a wonderful and engaging game with layers of theme that seems to tell a breathing story as you play.  Very fun.  I really have enjoyed this and imagine it will see quite a lot of play with my wife and I.

A great aspect is that it is easy to set up, play a couple of turns and walk away to come back to at a later date.  This is how my wife and I play these longer games and Arkham Horror really suits this style of play.  Great fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[b]Arkham Horror[/b] is a cooperative game in which the players are trying to prevent the Ancient One from awakening, or failing that, battle with the Ancient One to return him to slumber.

AK plays like an RPG whereas you get a character and build him up according to his strengths and weaknesses, and then battle monsters.  It is well balanced, and easy victories are rare. You have to cooperate well and manage all the emerging difficulties.  Concentrating too much on any one problem will allow other problems to overwhelm the players.

I play with many of the expansions too. The expansions add more characters, monsters, rules, and areas to control. The expansions are rewarding, but they really increase the fidliness of the game.

And that's what I actually like least about the game. It is overcomplex.  There is a ton of rules to learn, and most of the rules are not intuitive. There are a lot of situational rules, and many of the rules are similar to each other  making it doublely difficult to remember how to apply them. I've played this game over two dozen times and I haven't yet played a game where we haven't mistakenly broken or forgotten a rule.  Just about every game we have to pause to look up a rule or ruling. And even though the rule book is indexed, it is time consuming to find that one rule that applies to that situation.

Normally I am the rule guy in our play group. I read the rules for any game we play, and then reread the rules after we played to make sure I got them right. And I try to find the latest FAQs and errata. And with AK, I have read all the rules, errata, FAQs, and errata to the FAQs, many times over, and I still have to search bulletin boards for clarifications.  And even still, I get rules mixed up all the time.

I liked the game, but I am starting to tire of the burdensome rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Just acquired 3/2009.  I am looking forward to this for a change of pace from my ususal wargaming plus I love the short stories of H.P. Lovecraft especailly The Rats in the Walls  :gulp:

With more than five players the game can take a very long time to play, approximately double the two to four hours listed on the box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
OK, at about game 8 or 9, reality sets in. The ambiance for Arkham Horror is fine. But the underlying game is garbage. You just spend way too much screwing around: lost turns, cursed, time-wasting encounters. If you get hit by an encounter and need to recover health and stamina, visiting the Asylum and Hospital (which are on totally opposite sides of the board) takes absolutely forever, assuming you aren't blocked by monsters and completely screwed. It's really a nightmare of downtime and mucking around, a game stuck in the distant gaming past. The trade-offs between being stealthy and being fast (for example) are nonsensical and serve only to make you feel hosed when you chose to focus on, say, Luck instead of Lore, because we all know that those two abilities are exclusive.

And there are way too many cards in the game. Apparently they had a 110 card deck but only 55-ish ideas, so we are treated to the spectacle of a "unique" item deck with duplicate items; it's insane that you can get so many dupes in the game simply because they bloated the card deck far beyond the number of ideas they actually had.

This is a silly, amateurish, hack of a game design that has barely moved out of the mediocre mainstream of the 70s, salvaged only by the good art and the players' affection for the theme. There is no worthwhile game here.

Thank goodness Z-Man recently game out with Tales of the Arabian Nights, which while it certainly has a few issues of its own, it throws the utter mediocrity of this game design into sharp relief.
---
Arkham Horror is frustrating because it really ought to be quite good, but there are a number of niggling finishing issues that give it a lot of problems. The expansions tend to have directly addressed the issues, but the base game is just not what it should be. The main problem is pacing and length. Games tend to run out of interest before they end, as players helplessly wait for the last doom token or two that will trigger the final battle for 20 minutes knowing they have no hope to win via gate closings. The final battle is then tedious and anti-climatic, as you roll tons and tons of dice, and the Ancient One usually bites it with more of a whimper than a bang. Also, Ancient Ones who require a lot of doom tokens can result in a long, long game as once a few particularly unstable locations are sealed, gates open rarely and the pace of the game slows to a crawl.

My advice to get the most out of Arkham Horror:
- Stick to 4 players or fewer. 5 maybe in a pinch. But 6 or more can create a somewhat tedious game, and one that is pretty easy on the players (and Arkham Horror is already a pretty easy game until you stack on expansions).
- Use an expansion. So far, I think the best one for my money is The King in Yellow, because it accelerates the game and adds more tough decisions. You can now use nastier Ancient Ones and not have things take forever. Dunwich Horror is probably the next best, just because the new gate locations postpone the tipping point where too many high-frequency gates have been sealed and the game stalls. The mini-expansions play a little better in their "touring" mode rather than "permanent" mode, I think.
- If you have Dunwich Horror, I recommend using the Injury/Madness cards even when not using the expansion itself. It's a pretty easy add, and it lessens the amount of time wasted in the hospital/sanitarium. But, many of these cards really are not that debilitating, so it does make things substantially easier for the investigators - a problem if you're using only the base game. Also, the Dunwich Horror investigator cards seem to me to be on average better than their Arkham Horror counterparts, so bear that in mind too when mixing and matching. Because of the range of strengths, getting a good mix of investigators makes the game significantly easier. For that reason alone, it can be worth playing with only the basic game investigators, since Arkham Horror in general does not suffer from excessive difficulty.
- The expansions seem to have diluted the item pools. Try not to just mix in all the items from all the expansions into one huge deck. I'm toying with the idea of always allowing investigators to draw one extra item when shopping if an expansion is in play, just because  of this dilution (but, this would not apply to the "touring" variations in the two small-box ones).
- Be wary of Stormknight's variant. I know a lot of people like it, but these tend to be more experienced players. For inexperienced players and newbies it can easily double the length of the game, which is madness (because you can tread water by closing gates but not sealing them, so players can run a holding pattern for hours - at least under the core rules, the game will *eventually* end).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Not a tremendous amount of strategy, but more of an RPG board game hybrid.  You pick a direction/action, an event randomly happens and your character abilities, items and stats adjust the outcome of the event or the dice rolls from the event. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
Enjoyable game that we grew tired of over time.  To keep it interesting we played with two house-rules: the first being that monster tokens stay art-side up and you are not allowed to look at the stats on the reverse side unless you choose to fight it.  Second, we would have another player read the encounter cards and not tell the current player the outcomes if the card presented a choice.  

I would never choose to play this game again without those house rules.  They made the game much more tense, interesting, and suspenseful.  We didn't play in a short enough time span to remember the monster stats so this always kept us guessing.  

At times fun, but ultimately grew a little bored and it wasn't seeing a whole lot of plays.  Sold it off.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

After getting Eldritch Horror, which plays tighter and scratches the same itch, Arkham's days were numbered and it was sold off.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is not really a BAD game, but the downtime (which makes the game impossible to play with more than four people), setup/teardown time, and game length are just impossible for me to bear. The 4 is sort of a mix between my willingness to play this (at this point, probably never again) and how good the game is (more like a 6.) The game starts out somewhat fun but I rapidly lose interest after the first half hour. 

One of the biggest problems for me is the game seems to be biting off a more than it can chew. There's so much stuff to do in Arkham that a lot of just gets lost in the shuffle because everyone is too busy trying to keep the monsters and gates to a manageable level. I really don't think the game gives you enough incentive (or time!) to explore a lot of the board so you just end up with some unnecessary edges that feel like they could be smoothed down. 

The only thing the game DOESN'T have enough of is location cards. After only a handful of plays you're going to start getting tired of seeing the same events pop up over and over again.

The theme, however, is excellent. The board is fairly ugly but the cards/monsters/investigators and all the flavor text is top notch.

Really what it comes down to is games like Pandemic and Ghost Stories have the same level of urgency, play in 1/4th the time, and - in the case of Pandemic - stronger mechanics, so I see no need to bother with this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Excellent condition, only played a few times.

RATING: 10
At my opinion it's an outstanding game. It's cooperative and you personally can't loose it. You'll never feel dumb or muddle-headed with the game. It encourages teamwork and brings a lot of positive emotions. 

Cards are closely connected to topic and seem meaningful. Sometimes game even questions your moral principles: "You see that well-dressed man tries to walk away with child. You feel something bad about the situation. If you mind your business later the child found dead. If you intercede the child you're banned from this district for insult to citizens".   

Cons are rules are rather complicated and game is long (4-5 hours).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Arkham Horror is a cooperatve board game with the odds stacked heavily against the players (or at least it feels that way!).  Players take on rolls of investigators in HP Lovecraft's town of Arkham, fighting off denizens of the Cthulhu Mythos.

The goal of the game is to close all of the portals leading to other worlds opening around the city before the Great Old One awakes.  If he should awake then players must fight it in a cataclysmic final battle.

In RPG-light fashion each character has their own pool of HP (and Sanity), skills, special abilities, and equipment.  Skill tests are based on a dice-pool mechanic, with the goal of rolling 1 or more dice with a value of 5+.  Equipment, ability scores, and special circumstances affect how many dice are in the pool.

The game is fairly easy to learn (the mechanics are not difficult), but gameplay can take a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I didn't get to play out my first game of this, but we all really enjoyed it.  If you were/are an RPGer you'll like it.  It has many RPG elements.  It's probably a better game than Shadows Over Camelot.

RATING: 9.5
This title has stood the test of time.  It's withstood competition.  It's always enjoyed when it hits the table, but one does have to be in the mood and has to have time, or the ability to leave it set up.

It's not as chaotic as the nay-sayers say.  Good players see the choices, see the strategy.

It's not perfect, but it's a nine if not a ten.

Discover all the fan generated content to really enjoy the game.

We have Dunwich, Innsmouth, and Curse of the Pharaoh (1st).  We find it best when playing with an expansion, to play with only that one, and to keep the cards from others out of the game (save the wealth of items/spells/ etc from Dunwich).

RATING: 8.5
BASE GAME
Players: 1 − 8 
CO-OP

Set aside a full Sunday afternoon for this one. Co-op game. Lots of rules. Odds are not in your favor. Just when you think you might be getting somewhere, you can get steamrolled.

But fun! Loads of theme and story telling. Fairly simple once you know all the options and rules (the instruction book is 20+ pages long). Might just be my favorite game. 

I really like the monster movement mechanic.

11th play introduced: Black Goat Exp.

13th play introduced: Dunwich Horror Exp.

20th play introduced: Dark Pharaoh Exp. 

28th play introduced: King in Yellow Exp. 

33rd play introduced: Kingsport Horror Exp.

RATING: 10
Aside from some issues with how the rules are laid out, this is a great game!  I've grown a little weary of the "clean" elegance of the euro-school lately.  Arkham Horror appeals directly to the role-player and fantasy lover in me.  Fiddly rules, exceptions, lots of cards and pieces, moving around, fighting monsters, going insane, great!  The other downside is length of time, but I'm willing to make the time for this one.  This also gets more playing time because it works fairly well with two - usually we play that each player just plays two characters.

RATING: 10
Arkham Horror got us back into the gaming world.  It holds a special place in our hearts.  Even if we put it aside for a few months, we'll always come back to it.   

The base game by itself has become routine for us.  We know where most of the activity happens and can usually clean it up before anything major goes off.  Adding some expansions really brings the life back into this game.

We just played the shortest, most anticlimatic games of Arkham EVER!  Cthulhu never woke up (wasn't even half way there).  There were no monsters by the end of the game (caused by an environmental mythos card none-the-less).  Five gates were sealed, we won be closing all the gates (only one of which was not sealed, the last one).  Oh, and it was two-player.  We're just that awesome!

And then today we played a 5 hour long version of Arkham with two expansions.  We won though because we're still that awesome.

RATING: 1
What a bad game. Unless you like taking brain dead turns where your highlight is rolling the dice and hoping that they roll your way. STAY AWAY from this game.

It is also unnecessarily long, 4+ hours. If you like cooperative games where the only real cooperation that you do with the other players is hoping for them to get good rolls on their turn and talking about how good or bad your rolls are while someone is taking their turn rolling the dice, then this is your game!

The expansions basically consist of making this game longer and adding more random game elements to make the game more random than it already was.

My favorite is the deck of cards from the Innsmouth expansion. Basically, every turn you draw a card from this deck and the deck consists of 20 cards that all say the same thing.

"You dont have the look of Innsmouth about you."

One card says something different, "You Die."

This is an expansion for this already horrible and totally random game. You get to pull cards from this deck. When "You Die." you die. You discard everything that you were working on for the past 2 hours and start all over. What an awesome game right?! Dont buy this game ever. If you already have it DONT trade it or sell it and inflict it upon someone else BURN IT before someone else gets hurt by it.

RATING: 7
What I like about Arkham Horror (the newer edition) is the quality of the components and the wonderful flavor text. It really creates an immersive and enjoyable atmosphere. What I dislike about it is mostly the game itself. Its not terrible. Its just very old-style American, but not in the good way. Its incredibly long for what it offers. The amount of decisions you get to make is a lot smaller than it ought to be. You can have luck which will make it impossible to do certain things, even without you making any real decisions to impact one way or the other. 

That said, I'd be willing to play this if other players were really up for it. I think every so often it would be the right set of circumstances that I would really dig it. But I am glad I traded my own copy away, yet am able to enjoy a buddy's copy.

RATING: 1
huge expectations for this game based on the IP, mythos, and major development of expansions... that falls flat on game play.

CONS

- large chunks of down time that is wasted time waiting for your turn because the actual "co-op" tactics of game play is, by and large, minimal... which leads to... fairly long game play for a not-so-epic experience (in an 8-player game we had one player wait 42 minutes between a turn.... the down time completely kills this game.

- monster movement based on card draw/symbols is kind of boring

- trading gate tokens for 5$/things... sounds realistic. "i just traveled into a nether-dimension and closed a weird-realism portal. i'd trade that life altering experience for 5 BUCKS." poor gate cost/benefit mechanic.

PROS

- Lovecraft made you a great mythos/IP

- decent challenge but laborious

possibly change score over time but after a handful of plays, score has dropped. more engaging co-op games out there.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
For such a fundamentally simple game, Arkham Horror is a rules nightmare the first time you take it out for a spin. For the one person who hasn't played this: Arkham is a co-op game where players attempt to evade or beat on Lovercraftian beasties, seal gates to otherworldly dimensions, and otherwise prevent the town from being destroyed by ancient demons from mysterious neighbouring dimensions.

The game mechanics in this are much simpler to explain than they are in practice: on a given turn each player can adjust their stats a bit, move around the town (possibly fighting or avoiding monsters in the process) and can collect various items, clues, status modifiers, allies, and so forth. At the end of each round, gates to other worlds attempt to open, unleashing monsters on the town and causing general consternation. If too many monsters show up, then bad things happen, and if too many gates open, the great old one shows up and all hell breaks loose. As I said, the game is fundamentally simple, but the original Chaosium engine is presumably in evidence here because the game is full of stat checks, niggly special circumstances, and ambiguities that have been dealt with in a mind-numbing 45 pages of rules questions here on the Geek.

All of this sounds quite dire, and I can see how this game could be a nightmare with the wrong group or pace. The game isn't fast, but it's not glacial, nor should it be. The game is playing you a lot, but that's the case with any co-op, from Lord of the Rings to Pandemic. The dice are evil and have stringent requirements that can screw you, but it tends to be standard fare for these types of games. I found myself enjoying the overall atmosphere and feel of the game even though I still don't know if I will ultimately feel like I'm actually playing the game more than having the game dictate logical paths where the dice will either be with me or against me. I would not want to play this with a big group, or probably even with more than 3, but at the smaller count it seems to work well, at least if the investigator number is adjusted to make the game manageable (i.e.: do not play with only 1 investigator if you're by yourself, I do not feel that 2 is insurmountable, or even problematic if the game goes your way, but with 1 it is nigh impossible). The atmosphere is good, and there are some interesting decisions about how to approach any given situation on the board. Again, success can often be dice or deck dependent, but this is more of an experience game than a serious game, so I consider that acceptable.

One major niggle I have is the battling the great old one to potentially win thing, which is not in flavour with the rest of the game. I prefer to play that the awakening of the GOO results in an auto-loss with no climatic combat, which is apparently the rule that was present in the original Chaosium version of the game. At small scales this seems to destroy the only advantage that the fewer number of players would otherwise have, but I would rather have the correct feel than a more balanced experience in this case.

If I have an actual gameplay complaint 6 games in it is that the game seems to be that the difficulty is largely based on familiarity. Several locations on the board have a much larger number of mythos cards opening gates at them, and once you start to become familiar with this, the game becomes easier as you can then wait for gates to open at such spots and seal them early, making the rest of the game much easier as monsters will stop spawning there. The game can still throw you curves along the way but it seems much more manageable with the aid of this familiarity, and I can see why people are interested in expansions that ramp up the difficulty as I have been consistently winning the game after a couple of troublesome early plays. (Yes, I have read the voluminous rules posts here, yes, I am playing the game correctly, trust me).

Ultimately, this game went down from a high of 7 to the 4 where it sits now. Mostly this comes down to 2 things: 

1) It has so many niggly rules that they will not all still be in your head if you're taking too many months off between games; we're talking reams of FAQs. This doesn't jive well with my general feeling that the game is too long for what it offers to play regularly.

2) In the decade+ since this game was released there are several better options available that scratch the same itch for me. Arkham Horror: The Card Game has very similar movement and theme, but much more interesting game mechanics and combat. Mansions of Madness 2nd Edition has all of the theme as well, but is much more accessible and easy to pick up after long breaks between plays. Both of the aforementioned also have a better, more cohesive narrative structure that immerses me more in the theme. With those 2 games in my collection there is really no way I could see ever dusting this one off again. Perhaps FFG will eventually app-ize this one ala Mansions of Madness to make it easier to approach, but I don't see myself playing this base game again unless someone needs an extra player and is ready to guide the game along (i.e.: knows all of the sub-rules so they can manage the game along).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Definitely my favourite board game.

RATING: 10
A really great, on the edge of your seat game!
Either you all win, or you all lose!

I love this game and it's expansions!

The only thing is, the expansions do add rules and can be a chore to remember.  So I usually assign people different tasks for the Mythos to make it go smoother. (the first player still being the first player for the Mythos, just everyone helps it move along by doing the same things each mythos)
it can also be a long game to play. 2-4 hours, normally.  Though I have had shorter on rare occations.

This is still a really fun, great game!

10 points

Update on 25 November, 2013.
Arham Horror is a milestone for me. It showed me the world of board games beyond Settlers of Catan or Carcassonne. I love the latter games, but I think Arkham Horror was my first ameritrash board game ever and still it's one of my favourites. It introduced me to this theme-heavy, and in this case complex genre.
We play the game with Dunwitch and Innsmouth expansions. 

10 points
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best game with HPP lovcraft thematic
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm eating crow on this one, I initially thought this was an good game buyoed primarily by the Lovecraft theme but after 10 plays I think this game is tremendous in terms of an old fashioned, 1980s style adventure game.  Arkham Horror is clearly the best of that field chiefly due to the ridiculous number of interactions, possibilities, and variety the game offers.  Unlike any other board game, Arkham Horror creates a real world for the players to move about in and some great opportunities for collusion and cooperation that aren't immediately evident, largely due to a somewhat protacted learning curve.  After a few plays a level of familiarity sets in and the game moves from "good" to "great".  Two things should be noted however, one is that games with more than 6 players can be a disaster of downtime and completely unchallenging, therefore uninteresting.  Also, the high degree of variability means that some games are inherently more thrilling than others, but when it all clicks (which is really about 80% of the time) it's magical.  Black magical.  I still think the "fight the monster" endgame is bizarre and not really very Lovecraftian, but at least the redesign team saw fit to include Azathoth, whose attack is "Destroys the world".  Great dark humour, hopelessness, and insanity round out another terrific FFG production that puts just about everyone else to shame in terms of graphic collateral and design.  Top tier, all the way- the best adventure board game ever published.

ROLL
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pozitívumok:
- gyönyörű
- szerepjátékos kivitelezés
- mindenki a "játék ellen", közösen harcol
- bármennyien játszhatjuk, mindig izgalmas marad!
- újrajátszhatósága a karakterek, főgonoszok, a helyszínlapok miatt magas (plusz a kiegésztők miatt is, de azok közül sajnos még egy sem jelent meg magyarul)

Negatívumok:
- még gyakorlott játékosoknak is bonyolult és nehezen megérthető (a szabályfüzet elég szerencsétlenül néz ki, ennél átláthatatlanabb játékszabályzattal még nem találkoztam), nemhogy ha olyanokkal játszunk akik nem annyira jártasak a játékok között (nekik nem is ajánlott)
- nagyon-nagyon hosszúra el tud nyúlni egy játék (ami egyébként nem feltétlen gond)
- a kockadobások, lapkafelhúzások miatt túl nagy a szerencsefaktor 
- eleinte nem így gondoltam de több játékkal a hátam mögött azt mondom: túlontúl sok a jelző.

Összegezve csak azoknak ajánlom akik ezt a Cthulhu világot nagyon szeretik, illetve akik nem fáradnak bele hogy az első pár menetet a szabályzatba bújva kell végigjátszani. Illetve csak összeszokott, gyakran összeülős társaságoknak ajánlom, akik bátran rá mernek szánni több órát.

Én sokkal többet vártam tőle - csalódtam benne. De még így is van olyan jó játék hogy örüljek hogy beszereztem és bármikor kapható vagyok egy játékra!! ;)

A hozzáállásom az utóbbi hetekben változott: egyre jobban élvezem a játékot, de érdekes módon még mindig van 1-2 szabályrészlet amiről megfeledkezünk és most három, de annál nagyobb hibát tudok mondani róla:
- túl sok mindenre kell figyelni
- kockadobálás dönt
- ha legalább 4-en játszunk túl simán győzünk

Játszási szám: kb. 20
Amióta megvan: kb. 2009

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A good theme is spoiled somewhat by a poorly-written and confusing rulebook, as well as a play time that's longer than it really should be. A few event cards bog the game down, making it even longer. While there are decisions to make each turn, the game would be improved if the decisions were more meaningful. I think a clearer rulebook and a few houserules to speed up play could make Arkham Horror a game I'd want to play on a regular basis.

RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game.  A sign of a good game is a game that you think should have lasted longer and you have been playing for several hours.  Some people have apparently come up with strategies to beat the game, but my goal is to have fun.  So I run around and buy things and try to fight things and then get devoured.  I need to find a similar game with a different theme to play with my family.  I guess Shadows Over Camelot is the closest you can come.  But I like all the random weapons and spells and things in this (Similar to Runebound I guess)

[c]
Production  -> :star::star::star::star:
Fun         -> :star::star::star::nostar:
Play Desire -> :star::star::star::nostar:
Theme       -> :star::star::star::star:
Down Time   -> :star::star::nostar::nostar:
[/c]

I routinely make decisions in this game based on whether or not I think they fit with the theme.  I also lose at this game most of the time.

Apparently down time is the big killer of this game for me.  I don't like sitting around for a really big game of this.  Fewer, faster gamers would make this nearly perfect for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A nice one every now and then, but probably not one that I need to own (although I've been tempted from time to time). Except for the flavor text and monsters, there is precious little Lovecraft feeling here. I'd even say that it's more of a David Eddings feeling (archetypal characters racing around, chasing one or more MacGuffins to defeat a big bad who is different every time, yet still surprisingly samey). OTOH, the only stuff which has given an HPL feeling has been De Profundis, Trail of Cthulhu and more or less freeform CoC. So as long as I keep my expectations to a fun romp, this is a pleasant diversion. Somewhat strange narrative arc from time to time, though, with much of the difficulty early on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I really don't understand everyone's obsession with the Cthulu mythos, and to play this game, given it's length, is much more of a chore if the theme doesn't interest you. It's a cooperative game where all players are attempting to prevent one of the Ancient Ones from breaking into this world, and you go around upgrading your characters and fighting smaller monsters while trying to close different portals around the board. The problem for me also would be that it's been so long since I've played that I would need some rules explanations at the start to even remember what we're doing. Overall, not really for me.

RATING: 3
There are things I just can't get behind in this game. The first is the length. It feels way too long for what it is, I have the same complaint with BSG and I feel that the complexity the game tries to make gets in between you and the win condition of the game. And the second which ties into the first is the fact that this breaks one of my rules in Co-op games. If you know you are going to lose make the loss quick! Ghost stories does this excellently...you feel that you can indeed win until that moment when you realize you can't and then the game very quickly ends. On the other hand AH can both create situations that are actually statistically highly improbable/impossible to win in and second then make you play the game for another hour before you actually lose. That's just not fun

RATING: 8
Want an easier game? Let everyone choose their characters? Want a risky more difficult version? Pure randomness! We've been playing the heck out of this game every weekend. It is long enough to warrent snacks and a comfy seat, but doesn't take you multiple evenings. It requires effective cooperation, encourages self-sacrifice (for the good of the group) and oozes Mythos from every orifice. The fact that is is gorgeous and a blast to play tends to make up for the elements of card design and turn order that seem a little counter-intuitive.

RATING: 8

Older thoughts: I love the components, the character cards, the weapons, the monsters. I just feel like its too punishing, especially when it comes to fighting monsters.  If there's not a tankish character on the table (the gangster with a flamethrower comes to mind) then its easy to get wiped out over and over again.

RATING: 9
Lots of fun to be had in this game - each turn players are faced with a variety of choices.  The different roles add some nice flavor and this game has a really strong theme.  I think the only negatives are that you get more downtime as the number of players increase, and keeping track of all your pluses and minuses gets confusing.  But on the whole this game is solid and if you have the time to play you'll be richly rewarded; it gets in your head and it's an experience you won't soon forget.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
SOLO PLAY:

1 Player Minimum
8 Player Maximum
Wow, where do I start? This game is epic! Dripping with theme and full of adventure. One of my all time favorite games.  I have all expansions and all the miniatures. I absolutely love this game

GAMEPLAY AND RULES NOTES:
-DEEP ONES RISING TRACK:  is on the Innsmouth Board. Add one Uprising Token each time a Gate is stopped from opening and when a Monster enters a Vortex Space on the Innsmouth Board. To remove Uprising Tokens investigators spend Clue Token in any location in Innsmouth. When the Clue track is full on the Deep Ones Rising Track both tracks are emptied.
-DELAYED INVESTIGATOR:  does not move, just stands up. Has Encounter still.
-ENVIRONMENT:  is a trait on some of the Mythos Cards. Environment Cards stay in play until it is replaced with a new Environment Card.
-EXHIBIT ENCOUNTERS:  Investigators in the same space as the Ancient Whispers Marker must have an Exhibit Encounter. Only one Exhibit Encounter is allowed per turn.
-PATROL MARKERS: Investigators make a Sneak +0 check or they are Arrested.
-RIFTS:   are on the Kingsport Board. Check movement symbols, if matches add a face up Rift Progress Token, if full Rift is spawned at the gate location of the active Mythos Card. If Rift moves spawn monster in new location. If move along arrow of same color. Add a Doom Token to Ancient One. To close Rift have an encounter at all 4 shown locations on the Rift Progress Markers.
-VORTEX SPACES (Dunwich):  are on the Dunwich Board. If a Monster moves into Vortex Space, it is returned to the cup. Terror Level is increased by one and add a Dunwich Horror Token to the Dunwich Horror Track.
-VORTEX SPACES (Innsmouth): are on the Innsmouth Board. If a monster moves into a Vortex Space, it is returned to the cup. Terror level is increased by one and add an Uprising Token to the Deep Ones Rising Track.

ANCIENT ONE NOTES:
-EIHORT: Use Brood Tokens stored with Mask Monsters.
-GHATANOTHOA:   Use the Ghatanothoa's Visage Tokens stored with Mask Monsters.
-QUANCHIL UTTAUS: The dust cards are stored with the Mask Monsters.
-SHUDDE M'ELL:   Rubble Markers are stored with the Mask Monsters.
-ZHAR:   Use the Zhar Token stored with Mask Monsters.

VARIANTS:
-Difficulty Cards:   Total, 2 Easier, 2 Harder, 1 Neutral
-Epic Battle Cards:   Shuffle 12 Green on top of 12 Red and locate 3 cards the correspond with current Ancient One. Draw ONE Epic Battle card every Upkeep Phase during final battle.
-Gaurdians:   Assist the Investigators. Easier
-Heralds:   Increase by preparing the way for the Ancient One. Harder
-Institutions:   Assist the Investigators. Easier
-Personal Story:   Each player gets 2 Personal Story cards that correspond with their Investigator. Could be good, could be bad.   Neutral 
-STARTING RUMOR:   Dance of the Damned, during set up start with this card in play. (Stored in the Heralds box.)  Harder 


MISSING FIGURES:
Barnabas Marsh
Deep One Hybrid
Priest of Dagon
Star Spawn



Ancient Ones left to defeat:
Yog-Sothoth
Bokrug
Eihort
Y'Golonac
Hastur (Promo Variant)
Yibb-Tstll
Atlach-Nacha
Cthulhu (Promo Variant)
Zhar
Rhan-Tegoth
Quachil Uttaus
Nyogtha
Ghatanothoa
Cthugha
Chaugner Faugri

RATING: 8
Like:

-The mood and theme.
-The components are wonderful, as would probably be expected.
-The personality behind the many investigators and GOOs which really make me want to try tons of combinations.
-The mechanics feel solid, and I particularly appreciate the combat.

Don't Like:

-How hard it is for me to teach this game (could totally be my problem).
-Sessions that end too easily are not satisfying.
-An investigator being controlled by a stubborn gamer can spell doom for the whole squad.
-The potential time investment really keeps this game from hitting the table more often.  What a shame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
I can’t express how much I enjoy this game.  It was one of the first boardgames I purchased when I just got into the game scene of the boards.  I’ve played with two and I’ve played with six people and every time I’ve had a complete blast playing it.  We go into it like a committee, so we never get the leader syndrome I see in other peoples plays; we also fall into the theme of the game.  We’re usually explaining what Dexter Ward is doing or how Amanda Sharpe found the King in Yellow once more.  Once you fall into the story you’re creating the game opens up and you enjoy it even if the worlds crumbling around you.   
  
The base game, after all the plays I’ve done, can seem tame.  It goes by at a good pace, and even without the extras I can still see myself enjoying the game. 
 
As long as you enjoy theme and really get into it, I don’t know how you wouldn’t like this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros:
-Cooperative game
-The theme is very immersive
-The Battles against Ancient ones are epic
-No 2 games are alike (great diversity of cards & events)
This is probably Arkham's greatest point: the potential is great and no 2 games are alike. The quantity of items, of Mythos cards and of expansions (and therefore more of every cards) is the biggest I've seen so far.

Cons:
-Takes a long time to set-up
-Fiddly.

Overall:
This is one of my top cooperative game out there. It is one notch above Pandemic in complexity, potential and depth, although it does lack the easy-and-quick-to-play aspect. A choice better suite to those who appreciate complexity and replay value in a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Complex, long, tough cooperative game but very thematic and enjoyable, even if you get devoured by the Ancient One!  

Made by Fantasy Flight Games so the artwork is awesome and the components are well made.  (The board is large though so you need a lot of room).  

It can take a while to set up (15-20 minutes for the base game) but that could probably be improved with some clever storage.

I love thematic games and Arkham Horror has this in spades.  This game sure does create a fantastic immersive narrative.

Arkham is great to play with some music by Nox Arcana playing in the background.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Components: Great artwork on durable components. There are a few things I would change here or there, but mostly the components are functional and make great strides to convey the game's theme.

Experience: Not terribly fun with just one player (my first game). Lots of referring back to the rules, and a little bit lonely wandering around the monster-infested streets all by myself. The variety of locations, monsters, and Mythos cards ensures a lot of variable choices per turn. I'd like to play again with more players.

Last Played: 2010-06-28
Eagerness to Play Again: Soon

RATING: 6.5
Fun game to play with 2 people. The large number of characters, spells, monsters, and so on to choose from, I can't see how you'd end up with the same game being played. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are those who wouldn't like AH, and there are valid reasons why.  However, for the type of player looking for the kind of thing AH sets out to provide, AH does a remarkably good job.  AH is an attempt at simulating the experience of playing a Call of Cthulhu Role-Playing Game session, and it does a spectacular job of this.  I'm sure RPG players have had many less satisfying RPG sessions than the average game of AH ( I know I have! ).  I found the theme incredibly consistent, and whereas I previously thought the game had TOO many cards and bits, etc. it turns out these are all really necessary to fully flesh out the theme and world that the game provides.  There are problems in the games design - it runs too long (but with repeat plays we might be able to get the games down to 2 - 3 hours - our first game took 5, including a long rules explanation from a vet) and perhaps it is too easy to win with the base rules (we won first try, but we may not have played all of the rules correctly, either).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
ARKHAM HORROR
This is one of the best games I have ever played!  The theme is FANTASTIC, and the entire production is just beautiful!  An adventure in a game box!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I do enjoy an evening of Arkham.  Sometimes the game just dumps on you from the first turn.  Sometimes you actually get somewhere - here and there you actually beat it.  But I've always enjoyed the insane little journey your investigator goes on before doom occurs.  Our group enjoy this coming out because we all get to laugh at each other being put through the mill before taking our own go at being subjected to all manner of lunacy.  If your requirements are "hey - let's all play a game that we are highly likely to lose through random events, but it will just be funny and cause laughter!" then this fits the bill.
I would never add more than one expansion at a time though.  Each expansion adds a particular theme and mixing them all up would be like trying to read all of the Lovecraft stories at the same time.  Or listening to all your favorite songs played at the same time.  Or having chicken and beef and pork and key lime pie all in the same sandwich. It's just going to get confusing and you'll wish you hadn't.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my personal #1 game. I own many games, and have played a full spectrum of Euros, thematic, dice fests, etc. I enjoy all types of games. Yet through many years of games, many different types of games, AH remains my top choice!!!

The first few playthroughs can be daunting, so I try to get the board setup before players outside my family show up. If you're considering this game, try to find a group that is experienced with it. The rules can be a bit fiddly, so having someone experienced to run the game is a MUST!!!

As an update from 2007, I've changed my rating from 8.5 to 10 based on dozens of plays. This is mainly due to the fact that my wife will now join my son, daughter and I in the game (a superb FAMILY co-op game). We really enjoy it, and I've since purchased all of the expansions (including revisions of expansions). 

My youngest son, now 7 joins us at trying to stop the evil that lurks in the darkness...For a family fun, co-op game, buy it NOW!!!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
"Accounting: The Boardgame". Fiddly, complex setup (a LOT of bits), and takes a ton of space. Once you get used to it, it becomes much easier. Each turn consists of a whole bunch of tiny details to take care of. On the upside: everyone's involved all of the time. Downside: they're involved in doing tiny, almost meaningless actions. This is especially true if you get sucked into a gate -- so much for your next 2 turns, but you'll still have to pay attention. There are still many decisions to make, and several paths to victory, but overall the game feels hollow to me. Takes forever when you're learning. You can play two or three shorter, more fun games in the same time as one big AH game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Heavily reworked edition of the Chaosium co-operative play classic. While there are enough elements of the original design to make it obvious what game it is a remake of, it is not a faithful copy. The game is much darker and just not as much fun. The game has beautiful artwork (much better than Chaosium's original - probably the only thing that is better in this game when compared to the original), wretched rules, and some serious gameplay issues. The game does not scale gracefully - do NOT try to play it with eight players (despite what the box says). The endgame just does not work - it is too long.

After having tinkered with the game rather extensively (including buying and trying one expansion), I have given up. This is certainly not the game I expected, and it is a crying shame. Of course, I know that others love this new edition, which is good for them. I recently played the original and that experience convinced that I needed to return to playing the original and, in trading this one off, I now have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Verdict: play someone else's copy, but don't bother to buy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I used to really like this game. After each later co-op and adventure games i tried, i find i liked those games much better than Arkham Horror.
As a consequence, i'd rather play Pandemic, Gears of War, Death Angel, Ghost Stories for co-ops and for adventures, give me Android or Middle Earth Quest over this anytime.

Just not my cup of tea anymore i guess. I would still play it (my wife still likes it), but i get less enjoyment than i used to.

EDIT: played it again. It strikes me that there's so many different aspects of the game that are never used. What's the point of having encounters at "Ma's boarding house" when the only reason to go there is to spend tokens to get an ally... which will result in you NOT getting an encounter. That's true for almost all green locations... which is half the board.
And the numerous cards such as the "silver twilight lodge membership" cards, that we see only once in a blue moon being used. There are tons of those cards and even whole decks of cards from some expansions that have NEVER, EVER been used.
Too many components, too many useless game elements.

I'd still play it, but secretly wish we were playing something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Arkham Horror is one of my favourite games and the most thematic game that I have played. There is so much replayability here that it is ridiculous. The base game alone might get boring after a while but an expansion or two . After almost thirty games I'm still seeing new things happen in this game that I have never seen before. I also have a deep affection for the Cthulhu mythos and that combined with the way the game creates stories makes this one a real winner for me. Don't go in waiting for a strategy game - play this one for the story and enjoy the fifth turn in row that you spend lost in time and space.

RATING: 5

I like a bit of a denouement but not over the entire game!

We became increasingly tired/disengaged but this may be because we weren't yet so familiar with the rules.

RATING: 9
Great game, best for 4 players. You'd better ein before the Ancient one awakes or you are toast. I love the cooperative nature of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like big games and this is, by sheer amount of bits, no doubt the biggest game I own. So why only a 7?
Well, one thing bothers me. Clues and exploration. I know, it's an integral part of the core game, but...
"I wonder what goes on down the docks..."
"Don't bother, go to the woods. There are two clues we need."
I like the stories, but exploration ends up being forced into a frantic run for clues. And since you end up hurting everyone's chance of winning if you go to the docks anyway just to see, there is not much incentive to explore freely.
In the end there are just so many cards you end up never getting to read.

*SOLD*
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played this solo a few times now and this game has kicked my a$$.  Can't wait to get a chance to play this with others.  Trade interest fairly low, but a game I can only get to the table maybe once a year is going to be one that is perpetually on the chopping block.

RATING: N/A
Edition: Fantasy Flight Second Revised Printing 2011 (2011)
Language: English
Condition: Very Good. Played several times but with great care.

Includes the following expansions, all collapsed into 2 of the boxes, with plano storage for tokens. 
- Dunwich Horror
- Innsmouth Horror
- Kingsport Horror
- The Black Goat of the Woods
- The King in Yellow
- The Lurker at the Threshold
- Curse of the Dark Pharaoh (1st edition)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cooperative game in which each player is a character with specific skills (speed, sneak, fight, will, lore, luck) which can be adapted (within limits) during upkeep. They start with a number of items and can collect more of them during the game. These items are used to fight against all the monsters which enter Arkham through gates to other dimensions. The objective of the players is to close and seal all gates that are opening during play, before the Ancient One awakens. If the latter happens, they have to fight against this "end-boss" in order to win the game. Players and monsters move in the streets and locations of Arkham, and through the gates to locations in other dimensions. In all these locations the players have encounters (can be good or bad). In a lot of the locations in Arkham players can choose to trade in monster or gate trophies to avoid an encounter and instead perform a specific action (recover stamina or sanity, obtain money...).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A bit too fiddly -- I'm sure I've not yet played this properly.  But it's still fun with a group that's into the theme and willing to work together.  It also scales extremely well, which means I carry it to more gaming days than most other games.  Still, it can bog down when you have to look up again some obscure rule in the opaque rulebook.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The learning curve is quite intense, and takes some time to teach.  Also, there were too many expansions which all add additional game rules which is all a little too much for this casual gamer.  Otherwise, this game is amazing.  And assuming I don't have to explain every nuance to a room full of new players I am always in the mood to play.  Eldritch Horror was recently released as a successor and has a lot of interesting global travel elements and a simplified mechanic, but the earth map board is super boring.  Even though it's nearly ten years older, I still find the city layout of Arkham offers increased realism over the globe trotting sequel.  A future release with the global focus and the simplified mechanic of eldritch, but adding playable city maps for each location in the game while maintaining complexity at a reasonable level - That would be perfection. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent dungeon crawl.  All the players against the game system, and it works.  Perhaps a bit tough for three people, perhaps a bit too easy for five.  Expansion cards for the various neighborhoods add more replayability to the game.

On the other hand, there don't seem to be that many interesting choices to make in the game, it takes too long to play, and there are too many rules to remember.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game didn't live up to the hype for me.  I don't relate to the theme, the combat system is overly complex, there are way too many bits and cards to sort, shuffle and keep track of, and the solo game is way too difficult.  That said, it does have a nice story feel to it, race against time, and replayability. Spellcasting is terrible and rarely worth using. Frustrating as it's difficult to plan for anything. Characters have six abilities they need to focus on, but because these abilities are all paired the increase of one will decrease another. The problem is each encounter will test one of these and you never know which one, so it's a crap shoot. One part of the game I enjoy the most is moving around the map to the different locations in Arkham to collect items, clues, receive healing, blessings, become deputy, etc. If I were at all interested in Cthulhu as a theme, I could overlook the mediocre gameplay, but as it stands I cannot. Traded for Die Macher, which is a much better fit for my gaming tastes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
Way, way, way too long and repetitive, repetitive, repetitive.

The first problem with the game is deciphering how to play, since the ruleset and rulebook are both a bit squirrelly. I could overlook that, however, as I have with some other games (Phoenicia and Bridge Troll, for example).

But the next problem is that, once you've got the rules down, you're really just moving from place to place over and over again and rolling dice over and over again. (For a loooooong time.)

Frankly, this game stands or falls on the narrative and the theme. As we played Arkham Horror, cards with story elements were drawn, but what little narrative they did provide was disjointed, sometimes contradictory, and toward the end of the game began to be repetitive. I cannot imagine playing this game repeatedly and getting anything whatsoever from the narrative.

I find that these sorts of boardgames generally fail to have any theme immersion or coherent narrative. I've got a huge past history of playing RPGs (D&D, certainly, but [family=276]Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay WFRP1 and WFRP2[/family] extensively)... and compared to those experiences, these games pale in comparison.

In short, Arkham Horror is "[family=814]Call of Cthulhu[/family], Jr."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What kills this game for most people is the play time.  An experienced crew can easily throw this down in under 2 hours, but there's a learning curve to get there.  The key to enjoying the game is to understand that each person essentially has a choice between 3 actions: beef up your character, kill monsters, and work on a gate.  It's not a hard decision, but new players get lost in the details.  The second thing that is required to speed up play is that each player needs to be assigned a bookkeeping role (move monsters, flip cards, etc.).

RATING: 4
Another game that I really wanted to like. Gorgeous components, and artwork. I'm a big Lovecraft fan, so the theme was exciting and fun.

The theme is completely lost to all the book keeping you need to do. "Ok, it's the X phase. Time to move this chit here, and roll this die."

RATING: 6
Hrrm.  I think I like this.  Actually kind of interesting.  Couple problems though.  Long as all hell.  After strange aeons and whatnot.  Also, as you might expect, the dice introduce a hyper-random, hyper-annoying element to the whole thing.  The cards and board are nice though and the gate/other world system is cool.  UPGRADE.  We finally finished a game!  You know, it was worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Absolutely one of the best cooperative board game, and one of the most engaging board gaming experiences ever.  The inverse pairs of adjustable stats is a stroke of genius.  My 4-year old loves playing this with me; obviously I read his cards for him and tell him what they do, and make various suggestions about too-subtle things for him, but he really gets into it, understands how the stat sliders work, knows the full 3-turn procedure for closing a gate, etc.  Plus if he gets too antsy, I can always finish the game myself.  :-)

Would be a 10 if it was a bit shorter.

Edited slightly in wake of BSG. :-)

And downgraded a bit in the wake of Eldritch Horror.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played this game almost 100 times.  One minute I have complete control of Arkham...4 gates sealed, all monsters defeated...for the moment.  Then a monster surge occurs, extra monsters join in from an arctic expedition, and wounded heroes are caught in the street by flying monstrosities.  The game turns to chaos...exactly as it should.  Can the heroes rebound and turn back the tide?  Any game that you can lose yourself in for 4 or 5 hours and not notice the time...is the definition of a good game.  I do not think the expansions are as good...but this original game is one of the best. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
OMG!, what have I gotten myself into?  This game is addictive, but it takes so darn long to play!  It's hard to learn, hard to teach, and very difficult to beat, but, I love it!  
Having tried it solo,  I find it to be much less satisfying than group play, but at least I did win.

Overall, a great game.  I just wish the rules were a bit clearer, as I'm pretty sure that, after 9 games played, we still haven't played it exactly correct yet.

Well, I usually game at my friend's house, and he owns a copy of this.  I've only tried it solo once, and I don't think I'm going to do it again. So there it sits collecting dust and taking up valuable space on my limited gaming shelf. A cost/benefit analysis clearly shows the need to trade this, so on the block it goes.

The only co-op game I truly enjoy, mostly because it doesn't feel like a co-op until the end.

RATING: 8
I am a big Lovecraft fan, used to play a lot of the Call of Cthulhu rpg, and this game really scratches my itch for that sort of experience.
The flavour text is nicely done, the mythos lore is pretty accurate and comprehensive, and if played with the right crowd, this game is really awesome. 
For me, personally, that means people that play it mostly for the experience and the narrative that the players and the game engine create, win or lose (of course we always try to win, but hey, those Old Ones are pretty darned gnarly).
Min-Max'ers that play the game mechanically, and don't even bother to read out the cards in an ominous way need not apply.

RATING: 8
Wonderful, top notch production values.  Don't go into this one looking for a german style game.  But if you are a cthulhu fan or are looking for a lighter weight adventure/exploration style game, this is a good choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
You need to get yourself into the mindset that you are actually playing an interactive story as opposed to a game. Possibly the absolute opposite of a euro - it's all mechanics, rules and theme. There is some strategy but it's almost not the point - the best approach is to role play the character within the mythos of the game.

Is still lots of fun especially if you like Lovecraft/Cthulhu. 

Update (17/06/09): I am tempted to udge this up a notch or two. Once you have the rules completely sussed the mechanical nature of the game dissappears and the game really starts to flow - same as any game I guess, but particularly important in an attempted atmosphere piece like AH is trying to be. We have settled on a way of playing now which also helps - 2 players with 2 investigators each. This gives you more to do than when playing with more players with only 1 investigator each. Also we now limit play to the base game and one expansion (major or minor). More than that just complicated things too much and therefore broke the flow of the game, as well as taking up too much space and requiring too much set-up and take-down time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

And yet……….it’s totally addictive and endlessly replayable and an enthralling immersive experience and perfect for solitaire play.

RATING: 8
Bought: April 2010
49 - 37, W2

My Review: [thread=659735]A Year With Arkham Horror[/thread]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First impression ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A large game with so many raw elements (tokens, characters, monsters, equipment, spells, encounters) makes it easy to find interactions that confuse your understanding of the rules.

Once you have played it a few times, you learn things are actually very simple and following the turn sequence will answer nearly any question.

Even still, there is no elegance to these mechanics.  One's enjoyment of the game will be based upon how much they get out of the story.  I happen to love this theme and the byzantine gameplay actually adds to the atmosphere for me.

I do not get to play it nearly enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great and challenging, we found 4-5 players is the best number for a good round. Also got Innsmouth Expansions which made it way more difficult.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun both solo and with others.  However, this is not a game that you break out of the box and are playing within minutes after buying it.  The rules are easy enough to grasp once you start playing, but a read through the rules prior to play is very beneficial.  It's a lot of fun to work as a team in this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Quite a lot of rules to remember in the beginning. After few games it is much easier to control everything. There is not too much time to loose as every single missed opportunity comes back twice as hard. Looked as simple, friendly adventure, horror game - but it requires bit of planning - not mentioning luck and friendly dice :) and you need to have lots of them (dice). Definitely has a potential. Looking forward to play more games and to put expansions on the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Just kind of tired of Arkham. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A game of epic proportions, with tons of flavour text and millions(only a slight exaggeration)of pieces, scenarios and a strong theme. I just can't get my group to play it due to the long game time and complex rules. I've played it a few times solo and with one other player but everything is in great condition. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Arkham Horror was one of my early favorites, and I played this quite a bit in my early days of the hobby. This was aided by the fact that my girlfriend liked it quite  a bit, and I still appreciate large parts of its design, but it has largely fallen by the wayside (and been traded) due to a cratering of my interest in cooperative games and the fact that my girlfriend does not want to really play board games anymore. I traded it away.

extremely beautiful and in depth game. Extremely long but satisfying.a great deal of group interaction. Massive imaginative world. One of the most interesting games ever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Players charge around the town of Arkham, slaying beasties and closing the gates they are entering through.  A large and very lavish boardgame, in the spirit of Talisman.  Buckle on a character, wander around town, and see where the game takes you.  All players are cooperating and trying to defeat the game by keeping evil under control.  Lots of bits, lots of rules (not well laid out, considering the amount of time we had to go searching for specific items), lots of time and lots of squinting at the board (black text on purple, black text on brown, ... not a great idea!  Update - seen the reprint with a sepia type background - vastly easier on the eyes).  Some are going to love it, some will think it's too long and random.  I'm on the fence.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Keeps everyone involved at all times, which is a big reason to like it. However, there are a LOT of rules to keep track of, and the game is VERY fidgety. This detracts from my enjoyment and is the reason I am not usually willing to play it. Also it can be VERY long (4+ hours).

Keeper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
A success in the tough RPG-style boardgames vein. A co-operative effort to defeat a fairly difficult automated game challenge. Features a host variables to keep the game fresh: a different Great Old One to defeat every game, a wide and unique selection of heroes, and a deeper pool of encounters at vaious locations. At heart it remains a "kill monsters and advance your guy" game, yet it is a evocative and well-polished one. The more recent Last Night on Earth is a quicker-and-dirtier version, btu this one is ggod for a more involved experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Had high hopes on it being a Lovecraft fan. Unfortunately, theme is all there is in it --and not much else.

The system pushes you under its wheels without allowing for any significant decisions to be made (unless drawing, reading and executing cards can be considered decisions). And 5 hours without any decision-making can be a very long time indeed...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love the theme! Bought it last Christmas as a present - for myself. Played it a lot during the holiday and it felt like back in the day when Talisman was still good. Got all the expansions and will blindfoldedly buy all that are to come. It is a storytelling game anyhow so if you don't like those, stay clear. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Very fiddly. Too much downtime in the game I played. Endgame was disappointing and time-consuming. I would consider it again with 3, maybe 4 players - but 6 was just too many. Great theme, but poor execution in design and function IMO.

RATING: 8

But that's a personal preference, the game is definitely not for everyone, especially not mechanically-orientated players or those who enjoy simple rules.

RATING: 7
Traded to [user=mpin][/user] for [thing=29368][/thing].

Horror themed games are near & dear.  Cthulu mytos are no exception.  I bought this game with solo ventures in mind, and it did not disappoint.  I find that you need a place to 'save' this game since duration can get long.  I've played it solo (2 hrs.), 2-player (2.5 hrs), 3-player (4 hrs.) & 6-player (8 hrs.).  Dripping with theme & beautiful production, this was one of my favourite co-ops.  Unfortunately, it sat for over a year unplayed.  Even though I  managed to get set-up time down to under 15 min., the duration turns a lot of people off.

RATING: 10
Aki szereti a hangulatos játékokat, kiváló választás. A szerencse szerepe jelentős a kockadobások miatt, a játék előkészítése és elpakolása is időt vesz igénybe, a játék nagy helyigényű, ez negatívum. Az első játék alkalmával a játékidő elnyúlhat 4-5 óra fölé is, játékosszámtól függően, a játékszabály állandó böngészése miatt. Aki viszont szereti a szerepjátékos érzést, beleélni magát a játék világába, a negatívumok ellenére, remek szórakozásra lel.

Kipróbáltuk a családdal, egy 4 fős parti, 2 kisebb szünettel 6 órán keresztül zajlott, de észre sem vettük az idő múlását. A kooperatív jelleg nagyon jól működött, mindenki egyformán kivette a részét a játékból és együtt izgultunk minden egyes próbadobásnál. A játék nagyon hangulatos és szórakoztató, "Lots of Fun" mondaná az angol. Nekünk megfelelő kihívást jelentett ez a játék. A kellő mértékű pakli keverés ellenére az első három mítosz kártyán ugyanoda nyílt a kapu, így hamar ott találtuk magunkat, hogy Arkham utcáin mindenfelé szörnyek kóricáltak. A szabálykönyvet még sűrűn kellett lapozgatni, így is sikerült egy-két dolgot elhibázni. Nem túl felhasználó barát a szabálykönyv. A játék megérte a befektetést. (2013.10.31.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.22
One of the best cooperative games with great theme and tempo, deep in the Lovecraftian world of Arkham Horror. Every player has a character with special attributes and skills, who portray investigators and fighters against mysterious forces of evil and chaos or even Chthulhu himself!!
Character development is great, but there is never enough time to build it to the full potential because of constant spamming of monsters and portals that must be closed and sealed.
The biggest disadvantage is high dependency on luck which sometimes can cause a great imbalance between reword and punishment and punishments can be severe, but teamwork and coordination help a lot in the end.

[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Acquiring skills which are further specializing your character and hers or his abilities.
