=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Yes, this is an exceptionally high rating for a game like Arkham Horror, but I am going to simply admit bias and have you move on if you disagree with it.

This is the game that got me into boardgames.  Not Catan, not Ticket to Ride, not Carcassonne, not Caylus, but this.  I played all of those before Arkham Horror, but was content not to start my own collection.  Why?  Narrative.

This is nowhere near to being the perfect game and it allows for an alpha gamer to completely dominate decisions - admittedly, it's a co-op game that requires either amazing co-ordination or a director to win, but when I play it, I don't tell anybody anything.  You are free to make your own choices because to me, what's really important about Arkham Horror and its many expansions are the stories it allows you to tell.  Even if you're not big on the Cthulhu Mythos (why the hell not?), the game provides a tremendous sense of adventure and thematic tension.

What AH did for me was show me that boardgames can actually provide cool experiences.  Euros are great and I like to play them, but in the end, most of them are all about optimization and points-gathering.  That's fine.  It's fun!  But what has always attracted me to games, especially video games, are the stories (though admittedly, you're not going to find any Oscar winners in video games).  Outside of that, if I was going to plunk myself down to play a game for hours, it was going to have strategy (Total War, for example).  

So here I was, minding my own business when a buddy busts out AH.  "You take a couple of dudes, I'll take a couple of dudes, and let's see if we can beat the boss. Here's some donuts to choose your stats."  Say what, now?  Boss?  A party system?  Stats?  Is this an RPG?  What happened after that blew my mind and I walked away with the thought, "Boardgames can do that???"

And here we are, some 200+ games later and $$$ poorer, but I tell you what - my life is hundreds of times richer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Arkham Horror is way too long a game for me. When we played, it seemed to have no ending in sight. It was  painful evening. Not at all the genre of game that I enjoy playing.

Arkham Horror is the same genre as in Betrayal at House on the Hill, but Arkham Horror is WAY longer. I prefer playing Betrayal at House on the Hill. House on the Hill plays rather fast.

Arkham Horror doesn't really hold my interest. There are too many better games out there that playing this game on a regular basis is a waste of time. Why would you spend time playing a bad game when you can play a game which is more worth your time and enjoyment?

I don't plan to play Arkham Horror any time soon. One painful experience was enough for me. Never again.




Update:



I did try Arkham Horror a second time. This time, with a different group of players. These players already knew the rules since they all played before. So, compared to the first time, rule wise it was a lot more smoother. I actually saw the end of the game too this time around. Although, we we no match for the creature at the end. So gaming experience overall was better than the first time. I'll have to think about the rating again. Not sure it's quite my type of game.

Rating goes from a 1 to a 4. Playing with the right players makes a difference. My first game ever was real torture.

The more I play this game, the more I enjoy playing it. Rating up from a 4 to a 7.

Rating went up again from a 7 to a 9.

Got all 6 expansions at the same time for a very good price. Now will get basic game.

Just got basic game.

RATING: 4
Good.  Probably best "RPG in boardgame form" there is -- the fact that it's based on [i]Call of Cthulhu[/i] instead of [i]Dungeons & Dragons[/i] is not really relevant.

However, compared to CoC, it's longer, fiddlier, less thematic, less immersive, and really just not as fun.  Due to the complexity, it's harder to stay sharp on the rules, so unless you get it to the table all the time, it'll be a bit of a slog as you relearn everything.  So, why not just go play CoC?

RATING: 2
If it wasn't for the uninspiring Cthulu theme, would people actually like this game? The bottom line here is this game is BORING, and not just boring for a little bit, but boring for several hours.  I mean, one way to win basically involves players doing nothing for three turns in a row, SEVERAL TIMES during the game.  The boring-ness of the game is reason enough to avoid it completely, and that's without mentioning the dull theme, the excessive dice rolling, the absence of tough choices, the hour long set up time, the repetitivenes, and the overly complicated and detailed rules. But still, this game seems to get an absurd amount of blind love from Cthulu fans who enjoy watching paint dry.

RATING: 8
UPDATE: Knocking this down to an 8. Still love it, but I feel that succeeding games (Eldritch Horror, AH: TCG, Mansions of Madness 2nd Ed) have shown themselves to be great alternatives.

UPDATE: AH is still one of our favorite "event games" as well as our favorite FFG franchise. We have all the expansions and enjoy the variety. I seem to be alone in our group because I think the endgame versus the Ancient One is kind of anticlimactic and boring but I still love to play this game.

Rapidly becoming one of our favorite games. Yes, there are a lot of rules but there are some EXCELLENT game aids here on BGG and they make everything easier to handle. I like that there's always something to so (fight monsters, look for stuff, close gates) and it always feels tense. Role-playing fun in a boardgame package. HIGHLY recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's cooperative and for me and filled the niche that used to be occupied by playing Pen&Paper RPG's.  There's no role playing, but there's numerous characters to use which you can customize stats, equipment and go around town whacking monsters.  What bothers me is the excessive space it takes up, 2 - 5 hours game time plus the setup/packing up time involved with playing the game.  I like it, but can only play sporadically.  

Be sure to play this like Tales of the Arabian Nights: Have the player to your left read out your encounter card.  If there is a choice, only read out that choice and not the results of the choice until after they choose.  If they don't choose to do a skill check, don't tell them what would have happened.  If a person fails a beneficial skill check (ie nothing happens), don't tell them what would have happened if they had passed.  If a person passes a negative skill check (ie nothing happens), don't tell them what would have happened if they failed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I didn't care much about the old "Arkham Horror", even though I own it and it is super rare. The new version does everything right - more choices for the investigators and less randomness, but keeping the constant level of threat. The amount of cards and variety in this game is nearly staggering, and it was a good idea to tone down the more humorous approach of the first game. One thing that could be improved though is the dark board that makes it very difficult to see where monsters are - moving monsters in the Mythos phase is a drag, especially if Arkham is overrun. But all in all an excellent new effort by the ever improving Fantasy Flight.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great Lovecraft universe game that is a bit heavy and overwhelming at times especially when you are playing with less than 3-4 players.  You can solo, but it is EXTREMELY difficult to win in my opinion.  If you have a few hours open and a group of friends who enjoy the universe or horror games in general, this is definitely one to play.

RATING: 7
I played Arkham and loved it. A big 6 player game where we just won. 

So the second game, with my partner, was to see if she liked it and whether I should buy it. It was okay, but it seemed to lack repeatability. Going through gates takes ages and you want Elder signs, how the gates and monsters pan out meaning you can't always do what you want, but sometimes you're screwed and can do nothing but wait for something to happen. 

Good to play, but I don't need a copy myself. I'm told each game/expansion is good for about 10 plays.

Edit: Played a lot more, seems a game where it plays you as much as you play it, but fun to bring out every so often.

RATING: 9
I enjoy the artwork and theme. The combo of RPG elements in a board game. It takes quite a bit of time to setup and the rules are complicated (very RPG like with Horror Check rolls and Sneak rolls). Also - the game is very hard to beat - especially if you wake the Great Old One. I also played solitare and found 3 characters too unwieldy. Best to stick with 2 characters if you play solo. Also - expect to lose 9 out of 10 times. 
If you like this theme - the same characters and artwork can be found in the much lighter Elder Sign by the same company. Elder Sign was ported to iOS and Android -  give it a spin and then get that board game too.

RATING: 10
This game surprised me. It grabbed me and pulled me in...

An odd game category, but one that fills a nice spot for me. This is basically an RPG with no game master. The game is the GM.
No real strategy, just going around modifying stats, getting stuff, and stopping the bad guys. If you play the same scenarios all the time, it will get old, but that's what the expansions are for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.6
Rating 6,2:
Purchased exactly for solo 1 player/investigator. 
Good game and atmosphere but some rules are flawed: 3/8 Ancient Ones are too easy and can be gamed; you have penalizing terror checks for spawn but not for the big Ones; rumors and other events are not scalable; one investigator, Mandy, can win the game by herself; quite a few poorly explained procedures, particularly in cards' text. Wholly strange for a mature game with a huge follow up and one major reprint.
It is not clear wether the game is really supported for 1 investigator.
I use D&D pre-paints for extra fun and because that helps me keep track of monster numbers in Arkham.

Rating 7,8: Great replayability; after all you can win with a single investigator, but not with every one.
Rumors can kill the game.
Discarding flawed Ancient Ones; enjoy the challenge of an hard game, not one I can predictably win.

Rating 6,9: can consistently be played under 1h with a single investigator, yet satisfactory play would require house rules.
Far too easy with 2 investigators or more.
When the rules are mastered the basic game feels just like a stub, heavily dependent on expansions.
This would indeed be an 8-9 game with proper fixes. 
AH is a stub that requires expansion components to become a complete game.

Rating based on about 100 games w/ 1 investigator and 8 w/ 2 investigators: 6.6. Sold game and all plastic minis.

RATING: 10
I love everything about this game.
The game is hard to understand if you play it for the first time. But don't let that scare you away. Once you are familiar with the rules it is a great game. 
The game is hard enough without expansions, specially the ones where they add an extra board. If yu have played the game multiple times and know the cards it is fun to buy an expansion with new cards. 
If you are looking for an evening filling game with horror and coop, Arkham horror is highly recomended.

RATING: 6
I really like the Cthulhu theme, but for most of the game there really wasn't any tension.  We handled 90% of the game without any real threat of losing, until we failed to realize the importance of one particular card and didn't fulfill the actions required to eliminate it.  If we'd been more experienced we would have sailed through the game.  I also think this is a game that needs some player elimination, as I don't think a little time in a hospital or sanitarium would 'fix you up right' in Lovecraft's world.  However, we played it with a large group.  I'd love to try it again with the BGG recommended group size.

RATING: 7
Está bien pero a mi parecer le falla una cosa: la mayoría de las veces ganan los malos.
Es un juego cooperativo donde siempre (o casi) nos gana el tablero.
Colabora con tus compañeros, procura estar bendecido y tener muchas pistas. Si tienes pocas pistas y estás "maldito" no podrás ayudar nada para la lucha final.
Es un juego complicado, donde además debes saber algo de inglés, es original y además puedes jugar tú solo contra el tablero.
PARTIDAS
13/04/2008 4 jugadores (Tyrion, Juas, Pi y Gato)Nos toca contra Yog-Sugot (o algo así, que es un bicho de cuidado, creo que el segundo más chungo después de "Tulú"), cogemos los personajes al azar; estuvimos con el tablero casi todo el tiempo controlado, pocos mostruos y pocas puertas abiertas y cerramos las 2 primeras con "Elder Sign"; al cerrar rápidamente las primeras puertas no salieron muchas más y cada monstruo que salía temblaba imaginándose lo que le iba a venir. Aunque todo iba bastante bien los 4 fuimos devorados y cogimos nuevos personajes; al final no terminamos la partida porque se nos hizo muy tarde, pero ya teníamos 5 ó 6 puertas cerradas y los más probable es que ni siquiera llegara a despertarse el "Bicharraco".
20-04-2008 4 jugadores(Pi, Tyrion, Juas y Gato): nos toca contra Husler y nosotros vamos con el Mago, el de la Guitarra, la Científica y la Monja. Durante la partida los monstruos están muy controlados y las puertas tambien pero en 2 fases de Mythos nos meten 2 contadores extras del Monstruo Final. con lo cual acaba por despertarse el Monstruo y a pesar de que es facil atacarlo a falta de 2 Token nos devora a todos a pesar de que yo había sacrificado 2 aliados para ir ganando tiempo. Una pena!!! El próximo día lo ganamos fijo.

RATING: 6
[b][thread=479050]The PLAYMOBIL® Legion reviews "Arkham Horror"[/thread][/b]

(As of [b]1+[/b] plays) A highly-thematic co-op. Great components and evocative event cards help immerse players in H.P. Lovecraft's universe, but unnecessarily complex rules and a monumental playing time make it forbiddingly unwieldy. Not being a Lovecraft fan, I would prefer to play other co-ops, as this one  invariably feels like its takes more time than its worth.

[b]2 year verdict:[/b] I'm not a fan of the theme or the gameplay, and I would never suggest it, but neither would I turn down a game, as long as it is with people I like.

RATING: 9
Looks like a reputable cooperative game, love to try it some time.  Unfortunate title, really gives it the wrong connotations IMHO.  Played it twice, the first time from 10pm-3:30am, and it was one of the most epic and fun game sessions ever!  Second game was four player and also fun.  Somewhat like Pandemic on steroids, and tougher too!  Great components, very well themed, works very well as a cooperative game, and very very fun!  Perfect for burning the midnight oil on a guys nite out!  Some of the thematic aspects may make it unsuitable for a family context, which is the only reason I (and my wife) would be hesitant about buying it, and the fact that there's a lot of details in the rules.
A friend recommends A Touch of Evil as a simpler and better game to get, similar feel but less complexity.

Status: Owned for about 5 minutes, J&I got it at J&J for C&L for his B&C.

RATING: 5

RATING: 3
dice dice dice.  Also, the rulebook is such a kludge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It’s impossible to comment on this game now without comparing it to Eldritch Horror. My original comment for this game called it "a long drive for such a short journey."  That is, the overhead of rules and component set up outweighed the fun delivered. I found it too long and too complex for such a light gaming experience. It was more tedium than terror.

Then EH comes along and hits the note just right for me. It pulls off the thematic, Ameritrashy, lots-of-dice-rolling game in [blogpost=27416]a genre that’s a favorite of mine [/blogpost] in a way that feels commensurate to the experience. They streamlined the overhead but left the experience. 

From what I see, some people prefer the added rules chrome of AH, and some of us prefer the streamlining of EH. Rather than argue over which is best, fans of Lovecraft should marvel that we have these choices. Fans of other genres envy how many Cthulhu games there are. Their genres live in shacks while we have mansions (of madness!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game I would very much like to play more often, not least because of an interest in Lovecraft and a long dalliance with Call of Cthulhu.

Update: We've prioritised Arkham Horror for 2 player play in 2015, hoping to work through all of the Elder Gods. Three games thus far.

RATING: 6
I've only played this solo ... twice. After extremely long sessions (8+ hours each) I abandoned both. I really, really, really, really wanted to like this game as I love the theme ... but its so fiddly. The footprint is huge, the number of things to keep track of (environment effects, elder god effects, rumor effects, etc, etc) is soul crushing (hey, that's probably part of the theme), and the difficulty can be pretty brutal. I'll keep it and trot it out every 8-12 months and try it again, maybe the moons will align and provide me the experience that the real fans have managed to find. Until then, I'll just play Elder Sign.

RATING: 7
I've played this a few times now and have mixed but positive feelings about the game.  Arkham Horror has a lot of mechanic, some of which is pretty clunky.  You have to grok skill adjustment, monster density, and a lot of odds and ends to fully appreciate the game.  It's not for casual gamers and will turn off even semi-serious boardgamers, but it has appeal for pen-and-paper RPG players who are jonesing for good horror content. 

But against the harder Great Old Ones with three players, it can be a nailbiter once you've got it down.  I'm looking forward to some serious games of Arkham Horror over the next few years.

RATING: 8
After a lousy first play (my cousin and I didn't have all the rules straight and if you don't remember the whole town monster limit/outskirts rule things get out of hand fast), I let this game sit on my shelf for a couple years. Recently, my girlfriend suggested I re-read the rules and we've since played two highly enjoyable sessions. Thank Heavens for girlfriends who want to try games that have been sitting dormant on the shelf forever.

Because of this, I have upgraded my rating from a 7 to an 8. I'd go higher if play time wasn't 15 hours (that includes set up, play, tear down, going insane.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I find this a very enjoyable cooperative game.  After a few plays, you can get a feel for the way the base game plays and (at least in my experience) that gives you an advantage to win more often than not.  This is especially true when all the players are highly cooperative and plan/strategize each other's options.

Bad luck can always make the game harder, even if you have some of the better investigators in the game.

If you keep play moving, especially during the upkeep phase when players tend to try to plan out their turn's activities so as to adjust their skills optimally, it can be a 2-1/2 hour game (and a victory).  With snack breaks, explaining rules to new players, or over-analytical players, a 3-1/2 or longer session should be expected.

The dice rolling mechanics allow for luck to help you in a fight you should really lose, or force you to spend valuable clue tokens for rerolls on fights you should win.  The right combinations of items can nearly seal a victory, though it's always a gamble to go hunting for them with gates opening up and monsters terrorizing the town.

The game ambience is fantastic.  I find that I really enjoy imagining I'm my investigator experiencing these events in the 1920's.  This is definately my current 'favorite game'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Based on 25 plays:
+ The components are gorgeous (superb illustrations).
+ For almost any number of players.
+ Optimal package size for the base game.
+ Good gameplay, if a bit clunky.
+ Tension at its best. "Now that I have the money to buy items, I don't have the time."
- The rulebook is a bit messy.
- The board is overly large.
- Many components get lost to the graphic mess.
- The beginning of the game dictates the tension of the endgame. If investigators do well in the beginning, there will be little tension.
- After 25 plays I don't quite feel the tension like I did before. Need to find out why.

Since 2008, updated Dec 2011.

RATING: 10

I have an entire room dedicated only to Arkham Horror & will undoubtedly play this game the rest of my life. I keep stats on each Investigator & Ancient One & roll randomly each game. I don't believe this game will ever get stale because of the rich Universe that has been created for this innovative boardgame.

However, for some reason, I still like this game.  Could be my bias towards Lovecraftian stuff, though.

Can be pretty long though; I don't feel like playing this often because I usually don't want to block off a whole afternoon (and possibly evening) to play it.  Still, it makes it to the table occasionally.

RATING: 4
It's really long, it feels a little bit like math class, and it starts out slow, but the tension starts to build in those last few turns while everything goes to shit and all of a sudden, you're like, "Oh my god I was just devoured by Yog-Sothoth," and you realize that the last five hours were completely awesome.

Edit: With the proliferation of awesome coop games, I can't really justify getting this played.  It's simply too long, and too uneven, for what you get. It's not a bad game by any means, just one that I won't often choose to play.

RATING: 10
  I personaly really love this game, but I wish it was more of a hit in my circle of friend.

  I played several time alone, once or twice with 2 player and once with my group of friend. 

  We played with 6 people, which I do not recommend unless it is with experienced gamer that do not take too much time doing their turn. (about 2 person in the group planned their turn ahead, the rest took an eternity to choose what they should do.)

  Where I find this game challenging and love the mechnanics, they find it very long and 'spent a lot of time doing nothing'. We spent over 6 hour on the game, furtunally it resulted in a win. 

  On the positive side 
    -The art work is beatifull specially if you are into horror/lovecraft. 
    -There are a lot of components and they are well made.   
    -The theme is awesome and very present thru the whole game. 
    -The mechanic is interesting and challenging. 
    -There is a tons of replayability, and a tons of expension. 
    -You can play alone and still make it fun.  

  On the negative side 
    -There is a lots of component and cards, Which can get very annoying when playing with a 5+ people. 
    - It needs a big suface to play on.
    -The sliders keep moving which may cause you to cheat even though you do not mean to. 
    -It is not a 'ungamer friendly' game
    -Hard to predict how much time it will take to play, it may take 20 min or 6 hours... 

I give the game a 9
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Best if you are already steeped in the Lovecraft ambience of dread and despair.  During my last session we kept saying "I can't believe we've survived this long."  Our bodies were slumped in our chairs, our voices were a dull monotone, our eyes were glazed and our minds were numb.  It was a great experience.  --Oh, and of course we lost.  Which means we all were driven insane and then devoured by the Great Old One who had stepped through an interdimensional portal onto the streets of Arkham.  Wanna play?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[u]The Good[/u]: 1) Lets you be part of a story where 1920's earth is on the brink of utter Lovecraftian annihilation. 2) Has a ton of quality expansions, and further fan-made stuffs, that give it serious replayability. The bloat is real, but can be mitigated with smart use of the cards, and lend to giving each play its own unique feel. 3) One game of this can fill an entire day -- and still be entertaining going into the final stretch.

[u]The Bad[/u]: 1) Rules are layered and messy. The UniversalHead player aid is essential. 2) Footprint of this game is staggering. Forget a table, it will take over your entire [i]room[/i]. 3) Decision-making takes a back seat to the narrative.

[u]The Bottomline[/u]: An enormous, sprawling, story-telling Ameritrash. Awkward in places, but quite fun if you enjoy the narrative of a game as much as its mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game was my first taste of Lovecraftian mythos and I loved it.

Unfortunately the game itself does tend to lend itself to a few experienced players telling newer players "go here", "do this" etc. etc.

I like not knowing what a monster is until I go to try and hit/sneak past it. I like being afraid of everything and so I should be. Lovecraft's 'monsters' were written to be scary and dangerous. I think it really adds a level to the game that can be lost on experienced players.

Sold with several of the expansions in 2016.

RATING: N/A
After 3 attempts to play it and only one completed; I try to only play it only with my hardcore board game buddies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game can be a major time (and sanity) commitment, especially with larger crowds, but the amount of things that can happen, and that players can do, is pretty astonishing.  Even without the plethora of expansions, the ways each game plays out will be incredibly diverse, given the amount of characters, monsters, Ancient Ones, locations to visit, various items to collects, and events to survive.  While it often comes down more luck of the dice rolls and card draws, than to successful team or individual planning, when you do pull something off, it feels really good, and is the sort of game where there is a real sense of teamwork and camaraderie involved, even if all participants know it will probably be for naught.

While the theme is fantastic, it certainly is more based on a simplified take on the Cthulhu Mythos, than the actual writings of Lovecraft.  That aside, the game does have the ability to make it seem like some unspeakable evil is actively thwarting your efforts, and the text for the events is fantastic, though only seven event cards for each location seems a bit low for the base set.  Cannot wait to get some more games in and inevitably expand it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dripping in theme. You cannot play this with people who take cards and just read the required actions, you have to read the flavour text. Have not played enough to comment on fully, but really want to get this one out more. And it plays solo, so why don't I?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played 1 time with 5 players. This was one of the wierdest gaming experiences I have ever had. It started out with great anticipation, having read so many good reviews. Then as I learned the game, I was blown away by the cool mechanics. Then I started to realize how cool this game must be if you know the Lovecraft mythos. Then I realized there were a couple mechanics I hated in this game like characters with equipment cards and hit points etc. And then the moer the other guys raved about the theme and made story references, the more annoying I found it to not understand anything about the stories which made me feel like I was missing out on an important poart of the game. Then I started to get a headache and realized I had a lot of reading to do for this week, so I left my character convalescing in the hospital and went home. Weird game experience. I rate it a 9 AND a 4, so we'll give it a 5 because it ended at 4.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Love it.  Heavy theme. Played with the right people, this game can have some great tabletop memories
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
AH is my first foray into this style of game.  It's a bit daunting and there is a lot of dice rolling, but the thoroughly executed theme and variety of elements make me want to play it pretty much all the time.  What can I say?  Playing solo is a bit tiring and lonely, but it works quite well, which says a lot for the design.  The art and bit quality are both excellent.  It does have a pretty big board with a ton of decks to lay out around it.  I could do without shuffling so many tiny cards, but that's a problem with a lot of games.  Anyway, it's a very good game with a great theme and high production values.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I am really glad I got to play this classic, but I doubt I'll ever play it again.  So much time reading.  I know a lot of this text (& text in other games) is supposed to be humorous and add to the fun of the game.  While others are laughing I'm thinking, "Let's get on with it. I want to play."

The game is very fine quality, and I was especially impressed with the heavy cards.  If I liked the game at all, I would buy it because FF makes such quality games.

RATING: 7
It's fidgetty, a lot of time is spent in tedious shuffling, it is long.  Yes but I enjoy playing this game regardless.  It has wonderful atmosphere, the bits are beautiful and the slow progress makes the story unfold much like Lovecraft's books, lots of words and uselessly long sentences but dark and intriguing.  I like the fact I can play solitaire and that it is a challenge.  I'm anxious to try it with more players but I can understand that the charm may not work equally well on everyone.

RATING: 8
I've been playing this game for years. Even if you don't like horror movies or books, this is still a fun game. It does have a pretty high learning curve and many tiny rules to pay attention to. Eventually we got to where we decided to ignore some of the really tricky monster rules that weren't adding anything to the game, as a house rule. This game often works best if you have at least 1 player who really knows the game well to sort of act as a game master as they play the game, to keep things on track.

RATING: 9
When I'm in the mood for Arkham Horror, absolutely nothing else will scratch the itch.  Whether the game ends in victory or spectacular failure, this is always a great time. 

Typically, we play with one big box expansion and one small box expansion at a time. We're kind of in the process of finding what we like and what we don't, on the way to building our own Arkham Horror "kit". As such, plays are usually recorded under whichever big box expansion we play with. For those occasions where we do play "kitchen sink" style (multiple expansion boards, etc.), those plays are recorded under the base game. My "10" rating is for the Arkham Horror system as a whole, and not necessarily for the base game on its own.

My regular Battlestar Galactica play-by-forum group took a crack at playing AH PBF for a little while. Here are links to the games we played:

[thread=549275]A Piece of the Action[/thread]
[thread=558279]The Big Goodbye[/thread]
[thread=569303]Manhunt[/thread]
[thread=586195]Clues[/thread]

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&gameid=15987&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze]Ratings[/url]

RATING: 9
Excellent game! Played this countless times. The setup can be a drag and the game is long, but when we have the time, I love to pull this out
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Pros
-Lots of variety out of the box
-Collecting items is fun
-Large game board and decent amount of components
-Well supported, lots of expansions (may slow down with Eldritch Horror now out)

Cons
-Game plays you - you basically go to places with a 50/50 chance that something good or bad will happen to you
-Lots of miss your turn (e.g. while trying to close gates, you basically miss two turns and just resolve random card effects, no decision making)
-Reverse tension game. Game starts off intense with lots of things happening. As you progress, the game gets easier and easier
-Having the Great Old One awaken often did not feel like a big deal as killing them didn't seem difficult (even when you weren't preparing for it). This was fixed in the expansion however as they made the fight more interesting and difficult
-Sealing gates (the primary game objective) can be made completely pointless if you don't finish it in time as you are not rewarded for almost succeeding, the boss will be the same difficulty regardless of how many gates you seal (with some exceptions)
-Depending on boss you choose, can have very long play time (4+ hours)
-LOTS of book keeping between turns, often with no player aid on the game board itself - e.g. what is the limit of monsters in the city (depends on the # of players), limit of monsters in outskirts (depends on # of players differently than prev.), how many gates are there (depends on # of players again differently), which monsters move and in which direction, what gate opens, where does a clue spawn, what prior environment or rumour effects are there, what great old one effect is there?
-Game is not well balanced (some locations have more gates than other for no reason; some specific locations counter intuitively have events with more good than bad outcomes or vice versa)
-Game breaks theme (you can have a nun with two guns riding on a motor cycle shooting at monsters)
-Need large table for game board
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love Lovecraft, and this is the great granddaddy of monster-smashing co-ops. I've played A Touch of Evil and Middle-Earth Quest, both heavily influenced by this game.

However, I'm still on the fence. The game wasn't as fiddly as I feared, but did require several rules lookups for stuff that wasn't really important.

I like:
* choices on the encounter cards (MEQ and ATOE don't have them)
* Sanity (thematic)
* slider-bars (they add some choice)
* variety of Great Old Ones and characters

I dislike:
* very powerful and arbitrary effects
* prevalence of combat (unthematic)

RATING: 3

Arkham is too long, too big, and is too much about a hive-mind (more often than not controlled by one person who has slightly more experience) going through the motions. If all the stars align it turns into a pretty amusing role playing game, but that doesn't have anything to do with the actual game.

RATING: 6.8

I believe a BM is needed to raise other players' interests for the first time, especially when others are not used to play RPGs and have no idea about Lovecraft).

RATING: 9

I get attached to my investigators as we try to battle on with dwindling sanity and stamina. The only thing I don't really like in this game compared to Eldritch is combat, which I feel is more elegant in Eldritch.

I have all the expansions for this game. I has great variability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Arkham Horror is specially indicated for those who enjoy the adventure more than the mechanic aspects of a game (in fact, this one is decided by luck much more than for other aspects).
In my opinion, an appropiated atmosphere may be created in order to enjoy this kind of game (to play with the indicated gamers and in the precise moment are essential aspects, for example). AH could be especially boring if you aren’t the kind of person that would enjoy time imaging a story full of supernatural situations.
I love Lovecraft’s works, so this game is good for me, but not as good as the geek rating says. 
One last commentary: components are very good designed and have a pretty appearance!

RATING: 10
Great game, loads of re-playability and whilst I understand folks saying it can be too complex to be easily accessible I've found one person "knowing" it around the table can happily lead the others through a session.
The stories that unravel are a joy to behold, dark and gritty and the game always makes it feel that odds are against you and disaster is imminent.  Which is exactly what I want from a game.  Victory feels earned and every success is a result of strategy and skill.  In a co-operative game like this it draws the players together into a tight unit. 
Admittedly I am biased and have all the expansions, but with time to plan out and working with my friends to set a game that everyone will get something out off (assigned investigators that appeal to them, a particular boss and/or herald etc).

RATING: 9
Great game - all the different gameplay strands work perfectly and none feel superfluous. I love the challenge of the high difficulty level and the good level of balance in the game which means it is very rare to feel certain you are going to win. The atmosphere in the game in fantastic and the game has this weird ability to really creep you out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Just not quite ready to rate a 9 because the game is sooooo long.
I predict that Arkham Horror will be considered a true boardgame classic in the years ahead.  Not so much for it's theme but for the way it combines the feel of a role playing game onto a boardgame format.  Every boardgamer fan should have the experience playing this beauty at least once.

RATING: 9
Its great very rarely do games hit all the nails on the head like this one. the theme and atmosphere is perfect, the replayablity is massive. the components are like wise great the only real fault i fin dwith it is that unless you have a group of people that already know how to play the game then your goign to have to spend an hour explainin gthe pieces and whats going on the pace of the game is such that you really cant jsut let someone play till they get it. even if youve got expierenced players its still a 2 hour game (though onc eyou get the flow it hardly seems like it, never a dull moment) still one of the best games ive played for a while and i cant wait to get them expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My one-time favorite cooperative game! I love: the number of playable characters, the number of actions available to them at any time, and the fact that this complex game leaves you room to do anything you want at the beginning. You can hang out at Hibb's Roadhouse and try to get that ally card if you want, or you can go to the administration building and get another skill. You aren't immediately forced into a hyper-competitive state where a single misstep could spell doom for your team. Rampaging through the streets to slay monsters is very fun too.

The rulebook is terrible. It takes several plays to fully understand the rules given the rulebook. Read the FAQS well. 

I bought this game within a year or two of when it was first released. In 2015 I think I'm ready to sell it now. It's very complex to teach, and compared to a lot of other really complicated games the payoff isn't that great. It's pretty engaging, but very procedural, so playing with a group can feel like very halting as you repeat the cycle of a player turn over and over. Combat is pretty dice heavy and fair for a Lovecraftian universe too. All the things I said I really like about the game above aren't really true anymore compared to other games I've played. 

In terms of story, I've read that this game is outdone in the Lovecraft universe by Elder Sign. In terms of payoff for teaching and complexity, considering it takes a game or two to get used to it, it's totally outdone by more recent games like Archipelago, Nations, and Chaos in the Old World. For a cooperative game, Sentinels of the Multiverse is better because of how the mechanics integrate into the theme (and it's also easier to teach). 

Sold in 2016. It's fine to play if you have someone to DM it, but it's outclassed by other games nowadays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 8

The mechanics are so integral to the story and it immerses you in this horror world.  Plays great solitaire which is a big plus.  Lots of rules to remember but the flowchart aids here on BGG help immensely for that.  I wish it was about something else (it probably would get played more if it was), but I can see why people love this game.  It is all about story and narrative and the game itself sort melts into the background while you are playing.

RATING: 8.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love the Lovecraftian theme and artwork.  It plays a bit like a non-competitive version of Runebound and even shares some of the game mechanics of that game, with appropriate modifications for the Lovecraftian theme.  The health/sanity system is more intuitive in Arkham Horror than Runebound, as you lose hearts instead of gaining them when you are injured.  The game can take a long time to play and can get rather repetitive, but there is some potential for variety with the different gods that you can face and the different conditions they impose on the game.  The expansions also add variety.  I enjoy this game more the more I play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 6
If asked to rate this upon my initial honeymoon period with this game I most likely would have given it a strong eight.  However, after a while the elements that compelled me initially began to reveal themselves as too fiddly.  This is an interesting title in the cooperative game genre, but it's length and fiddliness  is unbalanced in regard to the fun it offers.  I would play this title if suggested, and probably have a good time with it, but for cooperative play I will take lord of the rings, and for a longer game give me something with more depth most nights of the week.

UPDATE:  We tore through a couple games of this with the Dunwich expansion, and I have to say that with some time between playing my opinion is more aligned to my original interpretation.  I still feel A touch of Evil might win out over this, but the flavor is strong, and it isn't quite as fiddly as I once thought.  back up to an 8.

RATING: 9
Even after EH has been out, I still really enjoy this game. Between the two with a lot of expansions, I like the feel of Arkham Horror more because I enjoy the more build up more in Arkhamn Horror, I just feel more powerful and I have more control of certain things. Also you will encounter a lot more monsters in this game than EH. It's really a battle against monsters/ancient one

EH feels more of an action effective/puzzle since your goal is to rush to completing the mysteries.

Both are excellent but I like the RPG feel more. However AH is a lot more fiddy with the focus counters, rules and especially the monster movement/tracking.

RATING: 9.5
Great game! The theme is dear to my heart so added points for that. Also co-op without a dm gets more bonus from us. It doesn't really stay true to the mythos but just the names, places, items, etc pull me right in. Beautiful artwork and components. first time learning is a bit of a task but with aids here on BGG can be done reasonably. A billion pieces! I greatly recommend a pile of little "snack cups" for all the tokens, as well as the set of card boxes that can be "print and taped" here. Game needs a lot of room and quite a bit of time. We spread it over several evenings and all is well. Looking forward to the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It is a fun cooperative game. The main issue is the length combined with the complexity. There are a lot of rules and components, which means it takes several plays to get proficient enough to focus on strategy and gameplay rather than just getting the rules right. However, it is long enough that getting multiple plays in takes a very, very long time. And you better not get any new players in your third of fourth play! If you look at the runtime, assume that for your first two games, you will be at the upper end of that range. 

This could easily jump by a few stars if it had a Vlaada Chvatil-like sequence of tutorial games to introduce players to everything. But it doesn't.

Update:  dropped my rating a couple of point on this because it's no longer a game I'm likely to suggest playing, mainly due to game length and downtime issues, but I still enjoy playing it when someone else brings it up.

Update: dropped another point as the length makes it a game that is one I'm unlikely to play even if someone else suggests it unless I'm in the mood for a longer game.

RATING: 8.65
For the first play I made sure to bone up on the rules (did a few rounds solo), separated the pieces into a plano box, and used some good advice from BGG to streamline the learning experience.

We had 4 investigators total, and apart from a few isolated confusing situations, we had a total blast.  The skill sliders are a smart mechanic, as is the monster movement, and the flavor and sense of adventure are all palpable.  The monsters are quite varied, in both challenge and function, and support the mythos well.

The game fell apart at the end when some distractions were introduced, but we all look forward to playing it again now that we are familiar with the rules, and we know how much impact distractions have on the experience.
+++8.5

Update: Played a full game late last night with no distractions, 3 investigators, and one angry Cthulhu!  In just a few turns we were on the ropes, but we stuck with it and won by sealing 6 gates (after extensive psychiatric counseling).  I think we only forgot one rule, the destroying of monsters when a gate is closed, which actually made the game harder for us.  Look forward to playing next time.
++++8.8
Update: We're 3 for 5 and the last game was so easy it only took us 2 hours (set-up + play). I think we've seen the best of Arkham, so it will likely stay on the shelf until I get an expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
A very chrome-y adventure game with cartoony Lovecraft elements. I like the fact that it's cooperative, but there are problems- it takes too long, and the tension dissipates rather than mounts. Also, there are so many bits and little maintenance issues that it can feel very fiddly, a problem made worse by a poorly-written rule book. That said, it's good 'Ameritrash', like a very light RPG if you're in the mood.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
They got H.P. Lovecraft right on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Arkham Horror is a game dripping in theme. From the character backgrounds to the nifty encounter cards all the way to the uniqueness of each of the big baddies, theme oozes from this game at every corner. This is both a great thing and a bad one. It's wonderful because there is no way not to get drawn into the dark story as it unfolds. 

However, I think it's bad for a couple of reasons. One, the game focuses so much on telling it's story that sometimes I think it forgets it's actually suppose to be more than just a narrative; it's supposed to be a game! A game with difficult choices, carefully laid plans and above all an under current of tension. Am I making the right move? Will I save Arkham or am I leading us to our deaths? At the end of the day this is an adventure game. For any adventure game to work I have to feel my choices are more than just a painfully obvious reaction to a randomly drawn event. No matter how strong and beautifully crafted the narrative, I have to care about the character and the adventure they're in. At the end of the day, as sorry as I am to say it, I simply do not find the Arkham Horror experience captivating. There is no [i]tension[/i]. If we lose I'm usually annoyed that we wasted a few hours and when we win I usually saw the win coming a mile away and am just happy to have it official.

I feel Arkham Horror has great components and an enthralling creepiness that can get into your bones but the mechanics make me feel like I'm just going through the motions. It doesn't help that, with the base game, my group very, very rarely loses. It's like going through a four hour long obstacle course when you know the finish was never and will never be in doubt.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARRRRRRRRRGGGGGGGGGGGGGGHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH

AAAAAAAAAAAARRRRRRRRRRRRGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Huge fan of this game, if I was better at tracking my plays my number would be much higher. I love the horror theme and Arkham Horror does and excellent job sucking you into the theme with a sense of dread and hopelessness. It is one of the greatest moments to feel like your losing the game only to win out in the end. That being said if you don't plan as a team 8/10 times this game will beat you into the dirt and then cast your soul into the endless nether. 

You do not have to be a Lovecraft fan to appreciate the horror, but understanding Lovecraft's style will help you sink further into the story and appreciate the justice this game does for the genre. 

The one mechanic I do not like is the all or nothing dice rolls. You tally the number of dice for an event and get one roll at it, in other games like Fortune and Glory as long as you get 1 success you can keep rolling. In Arkham Horror you get one chance to get all your success. While this helps play to the feel of the game its very frustrating to envy Fortune and Glory when you roll 10 dice and get zero success. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Even after reading the extensive FAQ and clarifications on the publisher's site, specific event rules are extremely unclear, to the point of game being unplayable...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Too fiddly. Love the thematic cards; hate a lot of stuff (money, always working similarly etc).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow!  This is an interesting game (I'm not going to say good). There is so many possibilities and so many options.  Sometimes it doesn't seem like it though, due to all the terrible things that need to be managed.  When the pressure is high, there are turns you don't really get any choice in your actions.  That's alright though because this is not really a game where your plans matter. This is a game that takes over and shows you an adventure, one that you usually don't think you'll survive.  It's true, with good planning you can put off the trouble for a long time, but the chaos always seem to catch up to you.  This game is at its best when you let go and try to ride the wave of the chaos.  Surf it, and you may survive.  Fight it, and you will definitely lose.  
  Now for the bad parts. This game has terrible setup and tons of fiddlyness.  Most of all, this game is not for everybody.  This is not a game for someone who likes perfectly laid plans.  This is not the game for someone who has places to go. It takes time to build the story, and the worst thing you can do is rush it. 
  In order for this to be the game that people rave about, the group must accept its fate, and play the game the board wants.  It must be allowed to grow, and the players must be allowed some freedom while teamwork is mandatory.   Practice doesn't hurt much either.  This makes the game great for the single player who wants to experience a story.  It is really good for a group that wants to experience a story, though the smaller the better (Do Not play with six or more players).

RATING: 10
An excellent fully cooperative story-telling game dripping with H.P. Lovecraft's 1920's horror theme.  I love the flavor text and the character enhancements are a lot of fun.  One of the few moderately complicated board games that my wife is willing to play (and ultimately why I rate this a 10).  We can't get enough of this game in our house!  I highly recommend "play as you go" style learning so new players don't get too overwhelmed from the beginning.  Recommend all the official expansions, and lots of great unofficial expansions here too: https://neilscuriosityshop.wordpress.com/board-games/arkham-horror/

RATING: 8

Drawbacks include too many components (making gameplay clumsy at times), Steep learning curve and A LOT of rules to remember. To this day I'm not certain if I've ever played a game correctly as the designer(s) had intended. I think Arkham Horror is a great, innovative game that I don't get to play as often as I'd like. Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite solitaire games, I usually play with 3 characters at the same time, less and you have fewer options and more just becomes a little unwieldy.  What makes this game a great game is the theme, great atmosphere and can get pretty damn tense even when playing alone.  Even though there are lots of cards, I think setup is easy and streamline.  On top of it all, I think the mechanics of victory, closing and sealing gates or confront the ancient one really works and remains very thematic.  I can recommend this to anyone that likes a little fantasy.  The expansions are not really necessary, even though I own most of them.  But they do add a little variety in play.  Like most I don't mix more than 1 large and 1 small expansion in any one play, or you'll dilute the cards and hence the theme somewhat.  

Can't wait for an expansion-expansion to bring all the expansions gameplay and story altogether.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
If you have the time, and at least one person at the table knows the phases well, this is a great co-op.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quite simply the best co-op game I've played.  It has wonderful variety, tons of great art and bits and it plays well.  Some games are closer than others but when you get a good game, man, is the game tense.  Overall, it overcomes the cooperative puzzle sense that most games of this type naturally have by giving you tons to do, many options, and lots of wrenches in the works of your best laid plans.  Creates a great narrative, second only to the best narrative games, Fields of Fire or maybe Magic Realm.  

I'm not sure I'd want to play this with more than 4 players.  I am quite happy with it as a 2 player game with 4 investigators.

Plays fast and isn't very fiddly once you get up to speed with the rules as well.  Main problem is that once you are pretty experienced, at least w/4 investigators, the base game is rather easy.  That is changed by the expansions which bring it to its full potential.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Arkham Horror plays best without the additional boards from the expansions, they add too many spaces and detract from the central goal of the game, saving Arkham form the clutches of a Great Old One. The smaller, card only, expansions are fantastic though, and add a great deal of flavor and variety to the game. Don't play Arkham with 8 people, that's just stupid. You CAN do it, but it will really, really negatively impact your experience as it will take forever for your turn to come around. To speed things along I very much recommend one person (the one most familiar with the rules) act as sort of a referee and draw the encounter cards and read them aloud so everyone can feel involved at the plight of the active investigator. 

The components of the game are of very high quality and the artwork is both thematic and visually appealing. The wide variety of monsters, characters, items, spells, and Great Old Ones ensures that no two games are ever the same. The rulebook could be better organized but after a couple of plays the games flowed smoothly and were a blast, even when we failed miserably and were eaten by the monsters or the Great Old One.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great fun with 5 people.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Being a fan of the original version of this game, I had high hopes for this game.  The art is beautiful although the art work is so dark, it is actually tough to see it, especially the board itself.  I do think it is nice and moody, so I may lean towards the darkness rather than the reprint.  The game is rich in theme, but can drag a bit.  Some of the personality is lost from this game in comparison to the original.

Finding anything you are looking for in the rulebook may cost you sanity, even if you have played the game a few times.  If you are a fan of Lovecraft, you will enjoy the game I think.

The original was more streamlined but had poor production quality.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The most rich, beautiful and engaging game of all.  A monstrosity of detail and moving parts (which may be house-ruled fairly - I routinely do this with the monster limit/outskirts/terror track mechanism in a way that slightly enhances difficulty but reduced fiddliness and constant handling of monster tokens)), but incredibly varied with all of its expansion materials in place.  What it lacks in variations of theme by AO (AOs provide background conditions but generally not specific encounters in a game session), it makes up for in replayability - an endless diversity of location and other world encounters and mythos combinations, and the array of investigator characteristics and starting possessions (in direct comparison to Eldritch Horror).

RATING: 6
This is a game that used to rank higher for me: I still love the theme and the things the game is trying to do. However, it's one that no longer makes it to the table often. I attribute this to a few things. First, the game is intimidating: there are a lot of parts and cards and places to go. The rules are not streamlined, and between set up and explaining it to new players, we've already eaten up a large chunk of time. It also doesn't scale particularly well to low or high player counts. It is still fun, at the sweet spot of around 4 or 5 players, but there are other, newer games with the theme or the co-operative style that are more streamlined and fun to play.

RATING: 7

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A cooperative game set in Lovecraft's universe. It has quite a lot of expansions as well so if you like it there are lots of things you can add to the original game.

The Game:
As I have already said it's a cooperative one. Setting up the game isn't difficult, there are just lots of things that must be placed conveniently around the board. The purpose of the players is to prevent the selected Ancient One to enter our dimension by sealing the open gates or to defeat it in combat if they don't manage to prevent its entrance. For the fight there are lots of mundane and magical weapons and artefacts.
If they want to stand a chance against the powerful Ancient One and its minions  players should make a common plan, share items and generally help each other and that's why I like the game so much: you must talk with your fellow investigators, come up with a plan and then adjust it along the way.
Even with a low number of players it can take a lot of time if you are unlucky with dice and events.

The Box:
Very well organized and with a bit of care there is place for everything. Using small plastic bags to keep tokens separated helps with the setup of future games. One thing that should be improvised is an "urn" from which you'll extract monsters. Another good this is you have either on the back of the box or inside the manual an example on how to set up the game on the table.

All in all a nice game which I'm willing to play again and can't wait to introduce the expansion/s as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Long and quite a lot of rules, but really rewarding and fun at the same time. A real adventure, where you have to establish a connection with your character and fully cooperate with others if you want to succeed. You need to develop your character (no levelling here, but you gain items and skills), but also be ready to go out of your way to save your team and the world at the same time. The thick, dark atmosphere makes the experience even better. If you like Cthulhu themed works, it's a must have.

Reason for selling: Either this or Eldritch Horror. The latter won.

RATING: 7
Arkham Horror is a 1 to 8 player game in which the players play the roles of Investigators of the supernatural trying to avoid doom brought forth by an Ancient One (something like an evil god). It has been said that this is a game for Lovecraft fans, but it is also a game for horror fans in general and for people who appreciate difficult games.

From 1 to 8 players.
Ages 12 and up.
Playing time: 120 to 180 minutes

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
House rules I play with all extensions in (most not from my creation):

* When you draw a task or mission (from Dunwich Horror), you can immediately discard it and draw another card. Rationale: these cards are mostly useless, and the decks are diluted enough already, but still someone might want once in a while to try one.

* When you make an Other World encounter, roll a die. On a failure, draw cards until you find a card matching your color and exact location, on a success, draw until you find a card matching your color but not your location. Rationale: this avoids the dilution of the deck and having too many “Other” encounters.

* The Ally Deck is generated in the normal manner: draw 11 from all those included in the setup. The remaining Allies form the Ally Reserves. When you draw a random Ally, use the Ally Deck. If a specific Ally is required (for instance during an Encounter) then the player searches both the Ally Deck and the Ally Reserves. If the Ally needed is found in the Ally Deck then no extra action is needed. If it's found in the Ally Reserves the Ally is taken then one random Ally is transferred from the Ally Deck to the Ally Reserves. If you are instructed to return a random Ally to the box, (for instance when Terror Level increases), return the top Ally from the Ally Deck, along with two from the Ally Reserves. Rationale: it is annoying to be instructed to look for a specific Ally and realize it's not available (which happens most of the time when playing with standard rules and all expansions).

* When using the Bast guardian (from Kingsport Horror), Bast's Favor is triggered when an elder sign is removed by a gate burst, and any player having a Bast token takes the Bast cards (the first one in turn order if more than one player has a token). Rationale: This powers up the Guardian which is pretty useless otherwise, and actually allows the event to happen (drawing The Stars are Right in the all-in deck does not happen that often). It also gives a small help when a quite bad event just happened.

* Characters, Great Old One, Herald, Guardian, Institution are chosen by the players. Rationale: this is to avoid way too easy or way too difficult games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Difficult game to pick do to all the rules needed to know the game. This is a game that doesn't see play time anymore because most people in my gaming group adult its just to random and feels unfulfilled more often than not.

RATING: 4.5
I really wanted to like this game, but the poorly written rulebook and convulted or vague game rules really put me off. This is a game that sounds intriguing but just doesn't play out very well. I will look for alternate rules and check out rule changes and errata online, but I doubt we'll ever play this again.

RATING: 7
Decent cooperation game, but certainly VERY luck dependent.  There's also a TON of stuff to keep track of, which makes it easy to miss something on a card or tile.  Reminder cards for turns would be handy.  Overall, a fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A lot of randomness, but that keeps it from being as much of a set-piece game as some other cooperative games. The game also tends to work with any level of commitment from players, from "how do I shoot this guy?" to "the optimal sequence for those tasks is..." -- as long as at least one player is committed enough to be able to answer the question "how do I shoot this guy?" when other players ask it. This makes it a better gateway game than its complexity would lead one to believe. 

Theme is a very important part of this game, and one of the big oversights there is the lack of tension, and the ability to plan for a particular old-one's weaknesses from turn one. To address this, I use a variant that slowly reveals clues to the old one's identity instead of flipping him at the beginning of the game -- usually this one: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/299333 or something similar.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An enjoyable cooperative game.  It is solvable without variant and house rules so replayability is somewhat limited.  The biggest drawback is the game's excessive length.  If it was half as long to play it would be twice as much fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the best game ever. All my family loves it. We had an 8 player game: 2 (grand)parents, 5 brothers and sisters, 3 wives/husbands, grandkids sitting on laps. We just beat Cthulhu. First play of the game for everyone except my wife and I (I am one of the brothers and sisters). We all loved it.
Its the deep, deep, theme. Based in 1920's gumshoe/detective/Marlowe stories with a creepy twist. Everybody gets it. It doesn't matter if you've never read every single Lovecraft story ten times over like I have. My wife has no idea about any of the Mythos, but loves this game. Made me buy every expansion.
I ran the game (like a GM), smoothing over the rules, presenting each newbie player with a simple set of choices which everyone could follow from what our current 'missions' were. The rich flavour brought each player into the game and they all felt part of the team. One player is trying to close a gate while another is gathering clues, someone else is killing monsters to clear the streets, etc, etc, etc.
You do have to pick and choose from which elements you use from the expansions, but they are great for introducing a bit more challenge after you get the hang of the strategies.  
Its a great game, and you will find you keep forgetting some rules (like monsters in the sky, or fiddling with focus) but none of that matters. 
Its normal people against the cosmic horror. Everything is against you. Everything. 
And yet (after a few failures) you do prevail. What a feeling.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game has a strange attraction for me. The mechanics of the game feels a little too old school for my taste, but there is generally nothing wrong with it. The rule book has room for improvements as there are many rules and it is hard to find what you want to find in it. Especially annoying is the other rules section which could have been incorporated with some other rules. I don't think it is generally a rule writing flaw, but more of a design flaw where the game is so free form that you have stipulate rules so that it is controlled instead of having it cleared up in phases. The sheer amount of rules doesn't help.

That said, I like the game, because otherwise I wouldn't rate it as highly as I do. I like the dual nature of the game where you have to think about either closing gates or prepare for the GOO to arrive. I think it makes a better game to really close the gates even if it isn't always beneficial. But what's best with the game is the theme as it is wonderfully incorporated in the game. The experience of the game is wonderful and is like playing in another world. The many different investigators and GOOs make this game feel different every time. I also really like the narrative of the game, but there is something that keeps me from wanting to play it more than I do. The game takes ages to finish and even though I don’t mind long games, this is more an experience game than strategic game to me. Strangely, it’s so simplistic, but convoluted at the same time.

There are many expansions to add to this game. Sometimes you want an epic experience and add all things together, but generally I prefer to just add one big expansion to the game and maybe several small expansions. Otherwise it gets bogged down with all the rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game. Wish I could play this more often with more Lovecraft fans. Very difficult to win, but the very fun and rewarding to succeed. 

Great condition, all bits stored in a single tackle box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Awesome game for the Lovecraft aficinado in all of us; it has high quality cardboard stock game pieces and jaw-droppingly beautiful (and beautifully horrific) artwork. I enjoyed seeing references to some of my favorite Lovecraft stories and characters peppered throughout the game.

All the praise aside, this game has a rather lousy rulebook. I have read it three times, played once (last night), and only NOW begin to understand how it functions. The index in the rulebook is anything but helpful at times and the layout of the sections pertaining to gameplay seems to have been cobbled together in some cyclopean, indescrible, foetid manner (as I type this I wonder if it was done this way on purpose).

Aside from that complaint, we had a very good time playing with 7 investigators and I do hope that our group can play this game again (perhaps in the way that the rules actually intend this time?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of those "experience games" that I don't mind playing once a year or so. There are a lot of moving parts on this design (particularly when compared to other cooperative games like Shadows Over Camelot or Lord of the Rings), which means either additional detail, or additional clutter, depending on how you look at things. Plays well enough when an experienced player "gamemasters" the thing. Generates a narrative, a fun bit of mutual solitaire ... but I can't see every playing it again, now that the in all ways superior Eldritch Horror is available.

Mint szerepjáték pótlék sokáig megállta a helyét, de szép lassan rutinná vált a játék, nem hozott újat, ezért inkább fárasztó lett a több órás társasmaraton. Jó emlékeim vannak róla, de nem sikerült túl gyakran olyan játékot összehozni amit mindenki és végig élvezett.
Ezért nem is gondolkodom abban, hogy kiegészítőkkel dobjam fel.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Arkhamm horror is a fantastic abstraction of a classic RPG.  Cooperative play is necessary in order to beat the game, and offers every player an opportunity to contribute.  It's all about the story-telling, and if the players choose then the game isn't about "read a card, something happens, roll a die, advance the turn marker" - it's actually about visiting the Silver Twilight Lodge, poking around in back, finding a mysterious book that reveals the nature of your very soul (by transporting you to Another Dimension where you need to escape something so horrible that the designers didn't put a picture of it on the card!)!!!
It's easy to mistake the game, I think, for a "turtle resources, wait for the perfect opportunity" game, given the size of the board, the height of the objects decks, the obvious options, etc. However, the rough-and-tumble, "get out there and mix it up strategy" is a lot more fun, and in my opinion, effective.  Team work is essential, and a great part of the game's charm.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Great theme integration and some very interesting mechanics (especially monster movement). A bit too many dice rolls, though. Enjoyment of the game rises exponentially the more you're familiar with Lovecraft's work. 

Bumped down recently - after a considerable amount of plays, the unmodified game turns out to be rather easy with any number of players, making variants a must. The mechanical aspect of turn resolution gets a bit boring and also killing off most monsters is easier than it should have been - I feel this goes against the spirit of Lovecraft's work. However, this is a game after all. 

Also, the game becomes rather anticlimatic with an experienced group of players - instead of an increase of tension, there´s a comfortable plateau of bookkeeping. This is unfortunate.

RATING: 8
The 2005 version keeps that same basic theme, but game mechanics are greatly altered. Players assume the roles of characters who travel the town of Arkham and other worlds in order to close gates and kill Cthulhu monsters.  In the 2005 edition, all the little rules tend to slow play.  ie - "Wait, how many monster is the max for 4 players.  What does a green border on a monster mean?  Do monsters move before or after the Headline takes effect?"  After some time learning the subtle rules, however, game flow increases and is worth the effort.

RATING: 8
Mark's
---
Very thematic and fun game, but oh so long.  There's a definite sense of urgency and terror, though the game seems to balance itself out quite nicely.  There are quite a few fiddly bits to this game and a lot of stats to keep track of with variables, so inevitably things are overlooked, but it doesn't bog the game down.  Looking forward to another session and actually finishing the game.  We were a couple turns away from defeat, with only the faintest glimmer of hope to win.  Wish we could have seen it through, but five hours later we had to call it a day.
---
Okay, this one is growing on me.  Despite the long play time, it's a great game for its purpose.  Thematic and chaotic, but with enough strategy to keep all players interested, this is one that should be in my collection for those Sundays when you just want a light, fun, co-op to kill a few hours. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I want to love every co-op game, but Arkham Horror is very hit-or-miss.  About a third of your games will be exciting and/or close, but most of the time you either blow the Ancient One away or get totally owned.  A game with this level of time commitment should deliver every time.

Even when you do have a good time, some player usually falls behind through bad luck and doesn't have fun.  That's a dealbreaker in my book.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Too many small rules... BUT, so darn good! The game is based on storytelling more than any other games except maybe Tales of Arabian Nights which is about storytelling in the end. Eldritch horror is a bit more than Arkham Horror, but it is a lighter version of AH but is brand new, and is only inspired by AH.

Buy at least the base game and Innsmouth horror or Dunwich Horror expansion. You need one (or both) of these to make your gaming experience reach another level.

Arkham Horror is good on its own, but those two expansions brings it to an excellent game.

If you are not afraid of small rules and love thematic and games that tells you a story as you play, buy this one. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A cooperative, card driven story based game in a Lovecraftian setting. Accidental heroes move around a city's many locations in order to hinder the advancing nameless doom that is realised just fine by several interdependent game mechanisms. It seems that this premise is near impossible to mess up. 

I had enjoyed the '87 Chaosium edition for many, many years. The new edition is - quite simply - an improvement in almost every regard: atmospheric art, suspenseful descripitions, myriad of items and small details, perfectly produced without changing the essence of the original. To me, it was an instant classic the first time around, but the new edition rounds wraps it all up in an amazingly thematic package and makes it accessible for everyone. 

A big plus in my books is the fact that this game works perfectly as a two player game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

sold

RATING: 8

Once you have become familiar with the rules and mechanics, the game will flow and you can really immerse yourself in the flavour. Love this game, probably my all-time favorite and will jump at any chance to play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm a little ambivalent about this title.

From an artistic and thematic point of view, this is an excellent game.  The art is fantastic, the world is immersive, and the mechanics create a very pronounced feeling of overcoming overwhelming odds.

On the other hand, game play is often not that satisfying.  The game tends to drag after a few hours, and it often does not feel like there is much player choice.

I still enjoy this game, but between the length of play and the passive game play, I don't see this hitting the table more than a few times a year.

I recommend Elder Sign, a game with a very similar theme, but the gameplay is much shorter and much more satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Dani
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Lovecraft világával kapcsolatos társasjátékok megismerését az Elder Sign-al kezdtem, majd az egész világra őrületet szabadító Eldritch Horror is nagy kedvenccé vált. Volt alkalmam kipróbálni a híres elődöt is, majd sikerült nagyon baráti áron magyar nyelven is beszereznem. Rengeteg hozzászólás, vélemény került megfogalmazásra, amely a két nagydobozos játékot hasonlítja össze ezzel együtt viták sorát generálva, hogy melyik játék a jobb és miért?
Általános véleményem az, hogy a két játék nagyon jól elfér egymás mellett. A játékmechanizmusok egy része az Arkham, a másik része az Eldritch Horror társasban került jobban kialakításra.
A játék egyik nagy előnye vitathatatlanul, hogy maga a kezdődoboz is teljes játékélményt garantál többszöri újrajátszásra is, valamint, hogy elérhető magyar nyelven.
Választott nyomozóink keresik, kutatják a rejtélyes történések okait Arkham utcáin át-átkeveredve más dimenziókba, elkerülve vagy legyőzve a megjelenő szörnyeket akár az épelméjük feláldozása árán is. Közben folyamatosan újabb kihívások nehezítik karaktereink dolgát, azonban a kezdeti kilátástalanság akár reménnyé is változhat, ha a csapat összedolgozik (mert itt csapatjátékról van szó, néha be kell vállalni az áldozatot egy nagyobb jóért).
A szabálykönyv nehéz falat, nem tudok elképzelni egy első játékot hibák nélkül. Szívesen ajánlom, hogy a szabálykönyv lapozgatása helyett döntsön a csapat és majd a játék végén keressék meg a helyes értelmezést. Az egész hangulat rombolója a játék közbeni túlzott szabálymagyarázat keresés, esetleges vitatkozás az előtalált értelmezésen.
Nagy erénye a játéknak, hogy jó csapattal különleges hangulatú játékban lehet részed, ahol kicsit is beleélve magad a nyomozó háttértörténetébe többet ad, mint egy munkáselhelyezős, lépésoptimalizációs, euro típusú játék (szerintem).
Viszont, aki nem szereti a kockadobásokon múló sikereket és a szerencse nagyobb szerepét, messzire kerülje (talál más alternatívát, ha játszani szeretne).
Nekem egyik kedvenc!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Just my favorite Co-op game. If you have not played this game then I highly suggest that you do. Best with 5 people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
