=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game, betwen RPG and a classic boardgame. There is many way to reach victory...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
If I had to say about the only thing this game has going for it is that it is thematic. Here are the problems that keep me from enjoying it:

1. The manual doesn't list a way to scale difficulty, which is a huge problem. The game is way too easy with 4, in fact we are 6-1 with 4 having only lost our very first game. It is fairly hard with 2. We have about a 50/50 win percentage with 2, but generally it seems to come down to things that are out of our control. For example, we drew a wicked Mythos card with a continuing environmental effect that was spawning 2 monsters each time. With 4 players something like this would be ok, but with 2 it makes things unmanageable. I don't want to have to rely on half baked and untested ways to adjust the difficulty. I have read many posts and people have ideas, but I don't want to play a variant that has not been tested especially considering what a time commitment this game is. 

2. The best part of the game is usually the middle. Generally speaking I like a game that builds up to a grand ending. This game is fairly procedural for the first few rounds as you try to get good items, Elder Signs, and clue tokens. It gets interesting in the middle as the board starts to fill with gates and monsters. Then there is a point where you have sealed off several locations and you know you are likely to win, but it still takes another hour of play to do so. It is very anti-climactic and often the game ends with a thud. I have only ever had the ancient one awaken in 1 of 11 games, it was a 2 player game and I still won. The rest of the time it was trotting around sealing up a diminishing number of gates with the board completely under control. 

Generally speaking I can't recommend this game. People say you can add expansions to make it more difficult, but the game is already a chore. I shouldn't have to add another board and a bunch more bits and pieces to make the game work. The game should be scale able in difficulty regardless of players, and likewise the difficulty shouldn't vary much at a certain level regardless of player count. Pandemic, for example, does this very well.

I'm sure it can be fun with the right people and in the right circumstances, but it's not for me.

RATING: 9
Why not 10. Although base game is great by itself I found much more fun to play in Campaign mode and that mode is not supported by the game unless you download extras from internet. (Some of them Official extras).
The game is long, yes, but it is said as such in the box. You can't rate this 1 because it is long, you were warned.
The game has lot of randomness, same as an RPG, but is randomness you can control in a way, or alter, or manage. You won't just lose just because...
Every match, either win or lose, feels great. If you win you celebrate as a group, we sometimes even hug and cheer during very difficult matches. When you lose you get stuck thinking how to win next time, and feel thrilled to play it again.

RATING: 8
Mine

El Clasico juego de investigación y aventura Lovecraftiana (ojo, no lo digo yo, lo dice la caja xD). 

Padre de El Simbolo Arcano y de Las Mansiones de la Locura, Abuelo de Eldritch Horror, Guia de la docena larga de juegos existentes hoy dia basados en los mitos de Cthulhu, y uno de los juegos cooperativos por excelencia del mundillo. 

Bueno. Ahora no es como cuando me pilló a trasmano hace 4 años que no habiamos jugado ni media docena de juegos y  nos asustamos con solo mirar el manual. :D

El juego es duro... duro de pelotas. se nota que algunas cosas las suavizaron en el posterior Eldritch Horror. 

edit. despues de 3 partidas, mi valoracion de la jugabilidad y del juego en conjunto es muy buena pero con algunos altibajos. algunas mecanicas demasiado repetitivas le bajan nota, y no es tan inmersivo como su sucesor Eldritch Horror. Asi todo es una experiencia de juego, parada obligada para todo lovecrafter que se precie, y sigue siendo un excelente juego. 

pd. No se si calificarlas de "muy buenas", pero las cartas de este juego llaman la atencion, son casi losetas, de lo recias que son. la leche.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A very nice collaborative game. Takes a few hours, but is interesting most of the time.

When playing with expansion boards, it is usually more fun to play with a single expansion board than with multiple boards.

This game is a typical 4 player game. With three players you cannot close gates fast enough. With 5 players it already takes a bit too long. Should only be played by 5 players, if everyone is experienced enough in the game to play a bit faster.

A few pointers to the expansions:

The Dunwich expansion is kind of a must have. The Dunwich board makes the game more balanced.

We usually play the Kingsport expansion kind of reversed, i.e. if a Mythos card places a clue in Kingsport, we spawn a gate there, and place the clue where originally the gate would have spawned. Otherwise, you can usually ignore Kingsport completely.

Innsmouth expansion is also fun, but Dunwich is better.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Great Game.  I've played several solo games and a few 2 and 4 player games.  Now I have played with the 7 and it still works!  (Update: well over 50 plays, still awesome)

I think the skill distribution choices and the resource management is the meat of the game, at least in my experience.  Aside from those two things its a game of reacting to what happens to you.  The broader strategic choices usually aren't that difficult, though in a close game they become very important.  I do not like AH as well as War of the Ring, which is what I traded to get Arkham.  However, I can see that AH might well have more replayability and a greater appeal for non-gamers.  This is a great game.  Arkham played very smooth and was not very clunky for something with so many different decks of cards and piles of chits.  I am going to give it a preliminary rating for now, but the rating will probably go up with more plays.  I do not regret trading WotR for it with the WotR deluxe on its way.

Update: the game grows on you the more you play it, and you realize just how deep and interesting the gameplay is.  Probably the biggest "every game is different" factor of any game I've ever seen without a modular board.  I've played it with 7 players, and it mostly worked, especially if you keep people moving to decrease downtime.  Some weird balance issues and I think we would have creamed the GOO if we had our shit together from the beginning.  We had one guy that horked all the clue tokens then didn't seal a gate, but we still won.  Pretty damn funny.

The flowchart player aid on BGG really clarifies things.  My biggest gripe is that your turn to turn decisions are not very interesting and a lot of games it makes sense just to load up with guns and wait for the great old one, which is totally anti-thematic.

2011 update:  Just upped the rating on this, because Arkham stands the test of time like few other games.  Years later we still play this on a regular basis when most games of Arkham's vintage are reduced to a once or twice a year playing.  Every game has a great story to it, and there is always unpredictable stuff going on.  The group planning element is fantastic and the game mechanics create a very real sense of dread and foreboding.  One of my all time favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Just bought it for my husband's birthday and tried it out. We loved it, and can hardly wait for the next play, but we left out some rules at first. The rule book seems a bit  complicated first (none of us has ever played the game), guess it will get better.

Update: the second play went much better and we really enjoyed it (time flies by,really). This is a preliminary rating though, it may drop with time when we see how big the replayability is.

RATING: 7
A cooperative game. The thing with coop games is they end up being a session where one experienced player basically says "Here's what we should do" and everyone does it. It's fun, but there is an air of constant hopeless struggle. When the win is in sight, there is relief, and rarely are you derailed at that point, but it happens. The base game is good, but can be quite long. The perfect number of player, imo, is 4 for both timing and mechanic-balance.

I don't like the randomness of some events or the amount of cards that make you lose turns; that makes it slower, not harder. Loved the components and theme though. The slider system of stats was very cool as well. For a co-op (which I tend not to like) it was pretty good, and it didn't feel as long as it actually was.

RATING: 7
I go back and forth.  I want to like this game a lot more: I'm a huge Lovecraft fan for one thing; and I do appreciate the game in a lot ways-- beautiful components, a lot of activity to track, a lot of options, great story-line element, etc.-- but somehow I've just been bored during some of the gameplay.  There's a lack of any real tension because actions can play-out in a fairly auto-pilot type of way. Solo is definitely not good.

But I've also had some great games.  Enough so that this is high on my list.  It's a very rich, story-driven experience and plays out with RPG-type of overtones.  Still, I'm always dubious about which game experience I'll get when I crack open the box-- tense and fun or automatic and dull.

Maybe expansions are important here?

RATING: 9
There's not much I can say that hasn't already been said, but I really enjoy this game. 

I love the theme of the game: Investigators rally together to stop an Ancient One from waking up and destroying the entire world. 

With all the expansions the cards and pieces easily number in the thousands, so if you don't like that kind of game, don't even go near it. But if you do, the gameplay is fun and addictive. 

If it didn't take about 2-3 hours per session, I'd play it a lot more often, but it is still a favorite of mine.

RATING: 9
One of the only three good horror games in my opinion. The theme is great and there is a lot of it. There is an air of tension that rises quickly through the game and each Great Old One changes the game enough so it's a different experience but not so much that you need to memorize another few pages of rules.

Plays best with 4 people and under and plays best when players really take their time and get involved instead of speeding through their turns. Also great for solitaire play.

I rate this a ten because this was my first real boardgame and this is what sucked me into the hobby. This game can do no wrong in my eyes.

RATING: 9
Once you get the mechanics down, and that will take some time, you may start to enjoy this game. I really recommend to play solo games to get the rules and concepts down, unless you are in the lucky position of having someone to teach you the game. There are a lot of rules, a lot of concepts you just have to wrap your head around, and it will take some time and effort. Also, you will find that there are a lot of rules that are easy to forget during the first gameplays.

Dunwich Horror expansion is strongly recommended. Game plays perfectly a as a solo game (play with 3-4 investigators), although this is a cooperative game that is more enjoyable with 3-5 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Tough to get into, and to keep momentum going the first few plays. It's not an elegant game, your motivation in what to do is not clear until you've played a few games, or if you're playing with an expansion that'll force your hand.

But, as some other web author put it: "The game knows". Through the chance of a card draw, or the predefined movement of an enemy, or a failed dice roll, the game will put you in a world of hurt. The game just "knows" what you are doing, and where you were going.

It was a great reward to finally defeat an old one (it took us many a game).

Setup time gets quicker with practice, and you'll need a large table to host anything more than a 2 player game (God help you if you have any of the expansions Edit: which I now do, and purchased an adjoining picnic table!).

Strap yourself in for a beer or a glass of wine - you'll be playing it for over 2 hours a game.

Edit: After many plays, I'll give it a 10/10. It's not perfect, but it's one of the few games I enjoy even when I lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update: I caved in a big way.

RATING: 7
1 - 8 players

The classic Lovecraft adventure game where you play a member of a team trying to prevent an old one from awakening and save the world.  This game has grown on me over time though it can be fiddly at times.  Game length can vary wildly based on how many players there are and how the game unfolds.  Somewhere between 2 and 5 hours is common.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great Co-Op game. I can see where it starts to get old, but there's plenty of expansions to keep it fresh. It's expensive to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
11-10-09
Downgraded my rating from a 9 to a 7.  We don't really play this game anymore for a number of reasons.  It takes far too long to setup - lots of fiddly chits, too many decks of cards, etc.  It takes a long time for a new player to learn, so getting new people to try it isn't easy.  It also takes a long time to play.  It's abnormal if the game itself lasts less than 2 hours.  More often, it's 4-5 hours.

That and the gameplay just isn't that much fun.  There's a fair amount of thinking, cooperation, and strategy, but not much action or fun.  The combat feels very weak and unless you're decked out with weapons, your characters never feel very powerful.  I suppose they're investigators, not warriors, but when tough enemies come out and you have to constantly avoid or run away from them, it makes you feel weak - how could you possibly beat a GOO if you can't kill a simple monster?

However, the randomness of investigators, enemies, and cards does have a benefit.  Each game can feel very different, depending on what's going on the board and who is able to do what.  There is a strong sense of cooperation and once you get into the game a bit with the right group of people, it still is a very fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Played 3 times solo, and twice with a full table. The game has its merits, with the feel that the team is cooperating towards a goal, but it's rather hard to get there if you don't get everyone to agree soon on a strategy. I'd rate the game very alpha-prone. At least for me.

The randomness of much-everything doesn't suit me that much.
The theme isn't my prefered either - I bought the game at the time because it was highly rated on TricTrac (the site that used to be good), full-coop and solo-capable.
It hasn't aged all that well in my view, just because it's a fairly long game to play. If I liked the theme, I'd probably call this a keepers, still.

I don't, so this game is on its way out. ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great board game for roleplayers, especially those interested in the works of H. P. Lovecraft. I've used this game as the template for an RPG session. My only gripe is the endgame which resembles Runebound too much (or less charitably resembles Monsters Ravage America). When Great Cthulhu shows up, everybody should die -- that's how we play. The idea that characters can use their Tommyguns to waste Cthulhu is simply not keeping in the spirit of Lovecraft's genre of cosmic horror. It's like ants being able to kill the exterminator sent to wipe them out -- it's ludicrous.

I would give this a "10" were it not for it's very long playing time.

Too much downtime between turns. I was knocked down last turn. Then, when it's my turn, I stand up. Next. Just shoot me.

Update (1/26/11): Let's be honest... I'm never going to play this game again. It may be a rich gaming experience, but the gameplay sucks. It's a '2'.

Update (10/31/12): Someone recently commented that this was more complex than TI3, so I had to reexamine my thoughts about this game. In terms of game mechanics, it is aggravatingly trivial, with few meaningful choices. BGG user Daveboy's [thread=661908]review[/thread] has very specific points that I could not articulate back then (emphasis mine):

[i]...you spend too much time in a [b]mechanically uninteresting[/b] area, which is traveling through other dimensions to close gates. This is basically an automated move-and-draw-cards step for your character. It's totally random, and [b]you don't make any interesting decisions[/b] while this is happening other than the decision to adjust your character's statistics.... 

Arkham Horror just leaves too much to chance and, too often, [b]does not have interesting stakes[/b] on the gambles. There's a point where a game crosses the line into being a "dicefest" and Arkham Horror is purely in this territory. There are just too many times where your turn ends up being, "which of these random events should I subject myself to?" with [b]no clear idea of what the outcome will be[/b] if you win or lose....

It just feels capricious and slapdash all the time, where you can't really plan anything or make a long term strategy. [b]You're constantly reacting to the variance[/b] and while this can be fine... when your choice is to roll the dice one way or roll the dice another way or roll the dice a third way for slightly different losses or gains it starts to blur together. [/i]

The only difference is that it took me only one play to come to a similar, emotionally-based conclusion--Daveboy played AH for two years before coming to his own conclusions. There is something about this game that pissed me off, right from the get-go, and the above stated points are exactly what triggered my response. While I can appreciate why people like this game or this kind of design, it is these kinds of game mechanics and design philosophy that I will be wary of in the future.

Update (04/16/2014): A [b][i]far superior[/i][/b] implementation of the Cthulu mythos can be found in [b][thing=141517][/thing][/b], which is actually a Lovecraft/Cthulhu/Sherlock Holmes/vampires/zombies mish-mash. In terms of game mechanics complexity that actually [i]convey[/i] a sense of theme, Arkaham Horror feels more like [thing=5048][/thing] by comparison.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
It's fun to play with people that are into role playing and know all the fiddly rules but I would not want to own this one
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still a fun game though.

With only the base game it can be too easy so I recommend to play this with at least one expansion.

The quantity of material for this game and the sheer number of permutations allowed by mixing and matching elements is maddening.  In a (mostly) good way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]

An RPG in a box, playable in a single evening.  It's a lot of "pull a card and read the encounter" followed by lots of dice rolling.  If either of those mechanics bother you, stay away.  If you don't mind (and I certainly don't) then this is the best of the genre.

[b]PROS[/b]

- A rich and detailed experience.

- High replay value. 

- Cooperative play.

- Solo play!

- Art and production values to die for.

[b]CONS[/b]

- A sprawling rulebook with almost no summary.

- Little rules that are easy to miss, and change the game when you get them wrong.  (For example, we overlooked the fact that closing a gate banishes all monsters with like symbols.  This made a lot of really awful monsters hang around much longer than they would have otherwise.)  Expect to play the game incorrectly several times.

- The final battle is nothing but dice.  (Who knew Nyarlathotep could be defeated by nothing more than the world's longest [i]Yahtzee[/i] game?)

- It's long.  Really, really long.

[b]BOTTOM LINE[/b]

[i]Arkham Horror[/i] is thick, meaty and completely immersive.  This also means it takes a while, but that's not always a bad thing.  It fills an evening to brimming with blood, terror and good clean fun.  Recommended for players who enjoy the [i]Call of Cthulhu[/i] RPG.

UPDATE:  After several plays, the game is becoming easy—almost too easy.  With a crack team of selfless, team-playing RPGers it's a pretty simple thing to win by sealing six gates or closing all gates while having the requisite gate trophies for victory.  This drops the game to a 7, but it still gets the extra point for the whole Mythos thing (and the fact that it's easily handicapped).

UP-UPDATE:  I have realized, with much dismay, that there really is no "horror" in [i]Arkham Horror[/i].  It is extremely rare for anyone to get devoured, so much so that no one really ever worries about it at all.  Also, the characters don't "wear out" like they do in the RPG—they are not eroded by repeated contact with the mentally-corrosive Mythos.  Again, house rules will fix this (by having max sanity reduced by 1 every time you fail a Will check), but still, I shouldn't have to put the horror in Arkham...  It shoulda been there in the first place.

My rating holds at an 8 for all the kicks in the knickers we get out of the experience, but just barely.

UP-UP-UPDATE:  Forget all the whining.  The expansions fix everything and take the experience to a well-deserved 10.  So, an 8 for the base game, a 10 with any expansion (especially Dunwich—goddamn Dunwich).

ALSO:  Have the First Player act as the "Interim Keeper" by drawing and reading encounter cards for all players.  Makes it way more fun when you don't know what your choice (or failure) will bring when you have to make a decision.  Allows for more storytelling, too.

FINALLY:  I will always use the Injury & Madness cards from Dunwich and the Final Battle cards from Kingsport in every play.

PS.  Played once with 8p—NEVER AGAIN.  The sweet spot is most definitely 4p.

(Includes one each of the [thing=155643]Blessed[/thing] & [thing=155645]Cursed[/thing] dice sets.)

[microbadge=3412]

[b][thread=151027][/thread][/b]

[b][thread=202663][/thread][/b]

[b][blogpost=31865][/blogpost][/b]

RATING: 4
I really wanted to like this. I love the Call of Cthulhu RPG and I was delighted when the old, and very hard to get, board game was re-published (re-imagined may be a better term).

Unfortunately after four plays I still hated it. It seems like a cross between a shopping simulator and a management game.  It takes too long to set up and too long to put away. It takes too long to play, which considering how much I disliked playing it, could be any amount of time really. 

I think it appeals to people who like the Rube Goldbergesque intricacies and watching all the moving parts and they update various tracks and add tokens, obviously taking account of the tons of rules associated with everything that happens.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Inspired by my Secret Santa I want to explain my rating of 1.  The game takes too long.  When it is not your turn you don't have to strategize for your next turn.  You simply have to wait until it is your turn.  There is a lot of board maintenance (moving NPC monsters, advancing counters etc.) and if you are a quick player in a 6 player or more game you will spend very little of your time playing Arkham Horror actually playing Arkham Horror.  I strongly recommend instead playing Elder Sign.  There is not very much board maintenance so in a 4 player game you should actively be doing something between 20% and 25% of the time.

I have played Arkham Horror multiple times and I never understood why I needed to make any decisions.  I didn't feel as if I had any agency (agency: my decisions matter and can meaningfully alter the outcome).

If you don't love the theme of Lovecraft I would recommend you stay away from this game forever.  If you prefer tic-tac-toe over chess then this may be the game for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I have to agree with SDaSU review after playing a 4 player game.  Its long, its thematic, its random.  As they stated, 'The game plays you'.  I can certainly see the enjoyment of the storytelling and as one reviewer stated, you kind of have to treat it like a light RPG where the board is the gamemaster.  The bits are very nice and the game board is nice to look at if not a bit complicated till you sit and play.  The biggest bummer is the lack of cooperative play.  Sure, there is a little bit of interaction and sometimes skills of other characters can help you, but not often.  You are pretty much on your own for any task.  It's very difficult to find enough movement points to join a friend for coffee and trade an item or get a boost from their skill when interdimensional gates are opening across the street.   Pro: Very thematic and sets a great mood.  Con:  Clunky combat, frustratingly random, and not enough real co-op in my opinion.

RATING: 4
Cons:
-Poorly written rules can make the game confusing at the beginning while its actually a rather simple game.
-The story in the game is badly implemented. Events on the cards are extremely lame and spoils your mood for the whole thing. I expected something rather interesting event at the Witch House f.e.
 -Decision making is close to zero, its always too obvious what one should do, (at least at a solo or 2 players game) just go for the gates asap while try not to die. Seriously, you could write a script and just watch the game play itself.
The most fun game I had was probably the one where I didnt go for the gates but used my time to prepare for the end fight. And probably the only one I won. 
-Some of the creature cards look bad. 
-Rolling insane amount of dices. 

Pros:
-The combat system while isn't complicated, you can put some tactic in it and it feels somewhat interesting. 
-Item cards are very well made.

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In Arkham, games play you. 

2 of 3 times you are just making optimal moves. 1 of 3 times you make some sort of decision, but as everything is so random, no matter what you choose, your success or failure will be determined by luck.

This game looks complex without being deep. Your brain is busy following the game's algorithm, but there is little strategic thinking here. 

Thematically, however, it has a point. The "fighting against the odds", the fluff text of the cards, the lovecraftian artwork, the cooperational aspect... all this creates an atmosphere of play that can be rewarding. In this sense, this game is closer to Talisman than to Pandemic (or any other cooperative games), and maybe that's why it's the only coop I can stand. You have to play ocassionally and with the right group.

EDIT: I have eventually sold it. I would still play if asked, but it was so heavy and complex that it rarely hit the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I know i'll get heat for this but, after setting up the game and reading the rules for a solitaire game, I packed it up and posted it for sale. Ugh is there such a thing as having too much theme? Yes I love thematic games, but I like it within mechanisms that make thematic sense, not novels of flavor text, dice rolling, and burdens. It feels like anyone who enjoys this is a masochist. The "theme" people rave over this game is all in the flavor text. "A Man sitting in the back, stares at you as you walk into the bar. His eyes burning through your soul it feels, you lose control of perception and reality...roll a die and see what happens!" 

Wait, what?!? Yeah, it's stupid. This is my problem with pure Ameritrash games, theme is great, but it all comes down to dice rolling and more dice rolling and reading gobs of text and luck, and you have a 4 hour long game that should've been over in 60 minutes.

Setup alone takes 20-30 minutes. I couldn't even imagine trying to explain this monster(no pun intended) to people. Let alone the fact it can take upwards of 4 hours or more. I'm not opposed to playing long games, I would still love to try TI3, but that game has a ton of variety from what I've seen. This game is just brutal, brutal brutal with more dice rolling than a game of Craps. 4 hours just to almost always lose?...I'll pass

I still would like to give Eldritch Horror a try since it's been called a more streamlined Arkham, making for a quicker game. But does it fall into Arkham's same tripes, just in a shorter play length? I will more than likely not, since it's getting just as many expansions and as bloated as Arkham.Also, Seeing as how I dislike both Arkham Horror and Elder Sign, I guess the whole Cthulhu and H.P. Lovecraft themes are dead to me. It doesn't help that Cthulhu is being thrown at us ad nauseam, seriously a Cthulhu themed Pandemic! Tides of time!....and a damned racing game as well! I thought I would never say this but bring us more zombies and dungeon crawlers please. Cthulhu is a scrub and over-rated at this point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I played 2 turns of a game, and it took 2 hours.  We gave up then.  I'd like to try it again, but I don't know what kind of time investment I'm really looking at.

RATING: 10
I moved this one up to a 10.  It oozes with theme, and games are always very different.  Sometimes you win and sometimes you lose.  I've played quite a few times and never felt like it plays out the same or that it's too easy or too hard.  Plus, with all the expansions, you've got so many different items, encounters, monsters and characters that nothing ever seems recycled.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
UPDATE (February 19, 2017): After giving Arkham Horror more chances at changing my initial reaction, it has failed to do so. The game is just too cluttered and burdened with a swarm of rules that makes playing the game practically impossible. I just can't keep up with this nonsense. This is really depressing.

UPDATE (July 8, 2016): Second attempt at Arkham Horror is pending. Going to give it another go and see if I can improve my experience and give the game a better rating. Stay tuned...

Arkham Horror was a big disappointment for me. I had looked forward to owning/playing it for years, only to discover that this game is overly complex. Let me reiterate... not JUST overly complex, but complex to the point of mindless, confusing busy work that I simply couldn't keep up with. Ironically, this goes perfectly with the Cthulhu Mythos theme. Why? Because trying to understand the instructions and play the game will drive you insane! I couldn't even complete six turns (which took a whopping 3.5 hours) before I gave up and put it back in the box. What a massive letdown.

RATING: 9
This game is great and very suspenseful.    I've never felt the need to expand it in my five years of owning it, because I felt there is a lot of replayabilty right out of the box.

I usually play it once or twice a year.  The reason it doesn't hit the table more (and the reason why I did not rate it a 10) is the time it takes to set up, play and put away the game, from my experience is somewhere in the realm of 6-8 hours!

Still, even with that.  This game is worth every penny, has tons of replayability right out of the box, and provides the players with a very challenging and engaging experience where literally anything can happen!

Me and my partners in crime also found it incredibly easy to role play the part of our investigators, providing some really memorable experiences that I will never forget!

Easily one of my very favorites!

I think with a faster ending mechanic my rating would jump a couple notches as everything else was nailed in respect to mechanics and atmosphere.  The luck was a bit chaotic on card draws and constant die chunking but I wouldn't expect anything else from the nether creatures of Cthulhu, servants of discord!  Erm...Ah-hem.  The game has definite potential.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Quintessential Ameri-trash. Dripping with theme, hundreds of cards, bits, character sheets and tokens, a huge game board, a 30+ page rule book, 1+ hour to set-up, average about 4 hours to play; so many rules and situations to keep track of, half of the game is remembering what rules are currently in effect and keeping track of the ever-growing collection of monsters, gates and other evil popping up in Arkham, only the hardcore need apply.  That said, there is a lot of fun to be had here.  As a cooperative board game, all players are playing against the game system rather than each other.  As the spiritual big brother to 'A Touch of Evil' by Flying Frog Games, there is much to love in it's core experience, but thanks to a seemingly endless supply of big-box and little-box expansions, the game is constantly evolving and changing.  Just make sure you have a lot of room on your game shelf!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

RATING: 7.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Jun08: Well, it delivers exactly what it promises.  3 hours of horrific, dice chucking adventure.  You get out what you put it.  I played it in a jovial family environment and had a pretty good time weathering the storm.

It is a coop, and can suffer from the "you do this" if you let it.  There also aren't a lot of really deep decisions.  You can however tailor how you want to play the game by somewhat controlling how your player develops.

If you want a coop adventure game with tons of replayability and great thematic trappings, Arkham is all for you.

Just don't come here looking for a cube pushing Euro.  This is about theme and dice rolling.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the first board game that I thought was "fiddly" with all of the card movement/shuffling, chit (monster, gate, clue) placing, counter (terror, doom) counting going on every turn.

But, I consider it to be a very fun cooperative-adventure game. Once I've play it 10-20 times I'm sure I won't feel that it is too fiddly anymore.

I'll let you know.

** UPDATE ** - Well, I've played it, along with expansions, over 50 times and what I still find fiddly about it is trying to keep track of your limits (open gate limit, monster limit Arkham vs. Dunwich, outskirts limit, also monster surge size, and how monster surges work with Dunwich...whew) which are defined by the # of players. I find it challenging to keep aware of those limits since they are not tracked visually anywhere on the board. It might have been good to include a way to visually display those things somehow on the board.

RATING: 9
My actual play count is closer to 300. This was the only solo game I owned when i was sick for a year. It has a special place in my heart. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Played it 10 times now.

Most games are not nail bitters (when compared to another co-op like pandemic), they are too easy or impossibly hard. This can be frustrating.

The luck component is huge, meaning many plans can fizzle before they can even be started. More monsters arrive and disappear due to the steady stream of mythos cards than our staggered actions.

I don't think I get much enjoyment from the theme, so that part is wasted on me. Perhaps Robinson Crusoe will work?

We tried to make house rules for 2 player (skip every 3rd mythos) so we can attempt to close gates instead of purely shooting the elder God each time. But I'm not really interested in designing and tweaking a game: developers should do that.

Also there are simply too many things to remember, even after becoming quite fluent with the game I would still forget to roll for blessings occasionally.

Some stable locations simply never get visited since players will mostly be in the street for a monster fight, at an unstable location for a clue/gate or at a stable location for a heal/purchase.
Further most spells and tomes are horribly underpowered, yet again more content which will never be explored.

Printing the unofficial flow-chart player-aid was needed during the early days.

It just feels like a badly designed game.

But I can't deny that I have had a lot of fun playing the few nail biting games and a lot of enjoyment from immersing myself in the oversized scale of (mostly unbalanced) content.

To those that enjoy this game, I envy you, since I really did try to make it work and had a lot a patience waiting for it to bloom. To the others which hate it, I understand you now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ideal Players: 3-8

Description: Explore Arkham while fighting monsters and closing portals. Cooperate and work quickly, or the world may end!

Pro: Great cooperative gameplay. Tells a thrilling story of horror and adventure. Fun random mechanic of drawing monster tiles from a bag. Each character has a special ability.

Con: Things can get very hard, very quickly. There are lots of fiddly bits to keep track of. You need someone who knows the rules forwards and backwards, or the game quickly bogs down.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Dreadful. If playing board games is about making interesting decisions, this is one of the most boring ones I've played. Sure, you do get some sense of what you need to do (gather clue tokens! close the portals!), but as soon as you start actually working on the problem, random bullshit starts happening. 

On one of my first turns, I went to the Black Cave for some clue tokens and got sucked into the Other World and got delayed. This meant that I could spend entire 3 rounds basically doing nothing of use. So much "fun". And yeah, next time I'd know about it, but I do not play board games to memorize what event is on each of the 20 locations or so. Especially when those are drawn from a deck so there's more than a few possible outcomes.

Thinking of it now, this reminds of "Monopoly". Sure, you have the freedom to choose where to go, but you still just go places and throw dice to see how you respond to things that happen to you. The culmination of that was the end of the game when we fought the Might One. It had 44 hit points and we could throw just 2-4 dice each most of the time. Because of that, we spent the last 20 minutes of the game trying to beat that thing, knowing that we'd lose almost certainly.

Finally, I've heard this argument that the randomness with a focus on negativity is supposed to convey the dread of lovecraftian horror. Well, maybe. But to me, frustration does not equal the fear of the unknown and the unseen. Neither does blasting off a monster's tentacles with a shotgun. Some might say that it's awful, because it needs to be. Fortunately that doesn't mean I have to like it. Or even play it...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
initial rating

HOLY CHITS Batman! Here we have AT pretty much at its best, TONS of very cool theme, lots of great detail, unique characters, tons of bits, tons of variety, lots of flavoured text and FUN!

Probably the best co-op boardgame game I have played albeit I'm not really a fan of the genre which is strange as I love D & D. Here acting together can be quite important to beating the system as you need to act efficiently together to try and keep things in check or the game could 'get away' on you. Very neat system overall but definitely long and somewhat fiddly, almost too detailed but I usually love that. 

For a game with so much going for it still something was missing for me in the game and I haven't placed it yet, maybe strategy or lack of as you really just explore until things happen and then act on them, also upgradable characters would have been nice as well.

RATING: 7.3
A better co-op game than Lord of the Rings, Shadows over Camelot, or Vanished Planet. That's because you don't feel as if you're playing co-op, you're doing your own thing by doing your part to slow down the coming onslaught and bulk up before fighting the Ancient one. Very entertaining. There is a lot of dice rolling and a good deal of luck is involved, nor is there any great strategizing going on. But it's a fun game and that's the whole point. The major downside of the game is the length, I got my group to play this once but they were very turned off by the amount of time it took to understand the rules and to finish the game. 

**UPDATE** It's been a full year since we first/last played this game but no one in the core group is willing to try this game again so I'm trading it away. (07-2007)

**UPDATE** Ok, I couldn't live without the game, I really wanted it back and I traded for it. Now if I can only get the guys to play it again. (12-2007)

**UPDATE** I can't get anyone to play this game, even I haven't been very enthusiastic to play it again, soooooo....I sold it. (06-2008)

**UPDATE** This game is driving me to madness!!!  I got this again in a trade at Origins.  I'll play it solo if I have to but it will be played!!  (08-2011)

**UPDATE** Nope, it still hasn't happened, neither with gamers or solo.  I'm losing heart. (06-2014)

RATING: 7
Scratches the cooperative problem-solving itch usually filled by pen-and-paper RPGs, and does it without the grueling planning, writing, graphing and thinking. I'm not a fan of the complexity-to-fun ratio; there are so many corner-case rules situations and parts to keep track of, yet the actual mechanical complexity of the game is slight. All the same, it's one of my preferred ways to spend an afternoon (often into the evening and night).

RATING: 10
First Citizen of Arkham! Actually, I played my first full game by myself, but using 3 characters: Bob Jenkin the Salesman, Vincent Lee the Doctor, and Mandy Thompson the Researcher. Nyarlathotep was the Ancient One, but we put him to bed without a fight, sealing 6 gates with only 5 tokens on the Doom Track. Bob Jenkins was the tank, sealing 4 gates, becoming Deputy of Arkham, and First Citizen! Mandy's ability to re-roll on failed skill checks once per turn was invaluable. Doc Lee was nonexistent for me, despite his ability to restore 1 stamina once per turn. He never pulled good cards and almost always failed crucial skill checks. I'll give him another chance later. Overall it was a great first run with the game, and I can't wait to play again!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my absolutely favorite games!  Dripping with a horror theme combined with fun cooperative play.  I schedule a game at my house every other month and it always fills up immediately.  We play with eight players and all the expansions for maximum insanity.  Leaves a certain amount of downtime but everyone is helping everyone and also just chatting and socializing.  Games tend to go down to the wire, one way or the other, so riveting.  I suspect that with experience we'll need to start upping the difficulty level a bit but for now basic level is plenty tough.  Always want another shot at it.  Lots of variety in the cards and events, exploration, building up your character, racing doom, randomness to keep things interesting and varied but enough strategy to keep it mentally engaging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic production value.  I've never read Lovecraft, but was still completely engrossed by the theme.

Great for solo play.  I love the dynamic where the players chip away at the bad guy, make steady progress during their turn, then get torched at the end of the turn by the Mythos draw.  It just feels right - the small victories are all meaningful, and the kidney shots really hurt . . .

Rules are a little fiddly on the first reading, but once you get the system down, it's easy as pie.  Now I only make occasional trips to the rulebook/FAQ for weird questions (like "can I get arrested while in an Other World?").  If you're not put off by the rules in Power Grid (or Silent War for you wargamers), get your hands on a copy of this gem.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Almost a requirement to own for any board game enthusiast.  Arkham Horror is a fantastic introduction into the deep end of the hobby.  Fully cooperative, lots of random elements for high replay value, and a huge number of expansions to choose from if you want to add even more variety to the experience.

The downside: It can take a very long time to set up (45-60 minutes), it has a lot of rules that aren't easy to remember off the top of your head unless you have played the game several times (and probably read the whopping 30 page rule book at least twice).

Lastly, playing the game with too many expansions causes the overall experience to suffer.  The games own mechanics end up fighting with each other for relevance due to significant deck dilution.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Drips with theme and atmosphere, though can become a slog with a lot of people. Still, a really fun thematic co-op to play, especially for Lovecraft fans.

RATING: 10

The rules are a bit OPAQUE. Please avail yourself of Mr. Skeletor's awesome flowchart to avoid going berserk. Of the expansions, the most important is Dunwich Horror--the Injury and Madness cards add a lot of value and decision-making. Just typing this up makes me want to play. Sigh.

RATING: 9.5
This is an "experience" game.  If you start with that mindset, and play with others who enjoy a good experience game, it's a lot of fun.  Bumped my rating from 7 to 8 after numerous plays.  I find that I'm almost always up for a game when someone suggests it.  If I have one complaint, it's that I don't enjoy the endgame dicefest of fighting the GOOs.  It seems like a letdown after all the atmosphere of the main game.

Update:  Bumped to a 9.  I love the story this game tells.  I really enjoy these kinds of "experience" games.

Update (Winter 2013):  Love, love, love this game.  It's fantastic solitaire, which is how I play it mostly now.  It's awesome, flaws and all.

RATING: 9
This game is not for everyone. It's long, complex, and sometimes hard to keep track of everything that is going on. That said, I love this game! I like the co-operative style of play as opposed to pitting the players against each other. It makes for a good game night game, as long as that night is really long. It did take a few dry runs through to get the rules down and even then I still have trouble with a few of them. My only complaint with the game is the rule book. It can be a little hard to find a specific rule you are looking for.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite games of all time. (Later edit: This is changed. I still love Arkham, but would no longer call it one of my favorites of all time.) The time element, as well as the intimidation for new players keeps it from a ten. I often play solo over the course of a few days (set it up on the table and just do 1 turn when I have time each day). For a hardcore gamer, I find this game a must. 

I should note that new players need to be introduced with ONLY the base game. None of this "all expansions for new players" bullcrap.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I liked this game, but I have to dock it at least one point for the following flaws: 
1) Random lose a turn mechanism, in a game with 20-30 minute turns this sucks 
2) A separate move and then later encounter mechanism, which adds substantially to the length of the game.
3) A separate Arkham/Other world move/encoutner. These 4 phases could have been combined into 1 phase without substantially altering the game and made the game much shorter.

However, the theme/flavor of the game is top notch.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
If you're new to the game, don't play with fewer than 4 investigators. Even if you have 2 players, play 2 investigators each. With only 2 investigators you're going to get demolished.

This game is not fundamentally difficult to learn or play, but it is extremely complex and intricate, and the rule book is a terrible reference (decent tutorial, though), which unfortunately you'll need to refer to during the game. If you're unsure if you'll like this kind of game, start with Pandemic for a much simpler game with a very similar mechanism (but with a much different theme).

By complex I mean that there is a lot going on and there is a lot you must remember during each turn: Does your investigator have a skill for that? How about a spell? Is there an environment in play that affects spell casting? Do you have a blessing or a curse? Because that affects your roll. Don't forget to add a doom token when a gate opens. Or remove monsters in play when a gate closes. And you have to move the monsters. And at the end of the round don't forget to take money for your retainer, but then roll a die to see if you get to keep the retainer. And the blessing.

Cripe.

Totally worth it, though.

Oh, and dice. Lots of dice. The more powerful your character becomes, the more dice you roll.

This game goes on about 1 or 2 hours longer than it should. There are many decisions to make, but few that affect your long-term strategy.

Needs a big table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
Plays well with smaller numbers but when it gets up towards 8 the downtime just makes it drag. You would almost need another person to take on the role of keeping the game rolling.

It was still too long, but the time didn't really drag as it did the first two times (despite two newbies).  I would still like to play it with a table full of experienced players to see how it would go.  Based on my third play, I've upgraded it from a 4 to a 5.  Update: The current fad at CABS (amongst Arkham Horror players) seems to be playing with *all* the expansions in games that last an insane length of time.  They have fun, but I don't think I generally would.

RATING: 7
Incredible visuals and theme. Fun cooperative gameplay but too long and unbalanced. I like it overall. I'll try to play faster.

***UPDATE***
Wow, this game is easy. I have played at least 15 games, and lost only one. Against Yog-Sothoth, the only slighly dangerous baddie.

***UPDATE***
I find this game boring now, but see my comments on Dunwich Horror.

***UPDATE***
This is the game (I still play) with the single most house rules I use. Some of them minor, some of them change the game drastically. What I love about this game is how much of a "toolbox" it is, and since it's so random and unbalanced anyway, it's borderline impossible to "break" the game in the usual sense, so all aspects of the game are open season for me. Still, you can't avoid that this is a heavy game, with lots of fiddly bits, and that the Mythos phase will never be fun.

[b]House rules level: 5/5[/b] (Tons of new content and huge rules changes and rebalancing)

RATING: 8.5
2010-06-21

Initial Rating 5.0 (May 2010)

The first time I played Arkham Horror was awful, we were 7 players and no one really understood the rules so my game group was very disappointed in the game. The theme is very important to me in a game and I LOVE the Cthulhu mythos so I gave it another chance and now the game is growing on me. I see it has a lot of potential. When I play the game I feel the tension of trying to stop the ancient one and that’s a lot of fun for me, also the game has a high replay value. On the bad side the game can take a long time to finish (although I enjoy lengthy games if the game delivers and this one does), it demands a lot of attention from the gamers because it has so many conditions that modify the game and the rules could be a lot clearer. I know this game is not for everybody, if you played RPGs in your life I think you would enjoy the game but I definitely recommend that you play it before you buy it.

Current Rating: 8.0
[hr]
2012-01-13

Arkham Horror is now (and has been for a while) in my top ten list of favorite games. I love it, it has so many cards that every experience is radically different than the previous ones. My main complaint with the base game is that I feel (and I know plenty of people disagree with me) the difficulty of the game is too easy. I fixed it by adding expansions. 

Another issue that can be bothersome is the downtime when you are delayed, other than that the game is pure gold for me.

Current Rating: 9.5

2016-10-09

I continue to love Arkham Horror. I still haven’t played with all the expansions, but I bought them all a long time ago :D. My desire to play it remains very high and I consider it a better game than Eldritch Horror.

As I own everything for the game, I decided to always play with all monster tokens (separate them after each play was a hassle), with the injuries from Dunwich Horror, with the personal stories from Innsmouth Horror, all investigators, all ancient ones and with a big and a small expansion (using the visiting variant). I don’t wish to mix all the expansions together because it would dilute them and it would be hell to setup and keep up with fulfil all the rules. Also, I will always play with the content from Miskatonic Horror that is relevant for the current game.

Current Rating: 8.5

RATING: 8
Not really a boardgame.  Not really a RPG.  But somewhere in the middle, there is a very fun game.  Its a game that rewards strategy but ultimately, its a luckfest... and thats okay.  Its an experience game that creates an interesting story if played in the right spirit.  Keep the number of players down or it drags too much to be worth it.

RATING: 8
It's all fun and games until everyone gets eaten.

One of the better coops, very thematic and immersive.  Slight drawbacks:  can seem a little too formulaic if everyone knows too well what they're doing.  As has been mentioned elsewhere, Elder Signs are too powerful for experienced players as is.  Our standard is now to play with two in the deck, and even that seems unbalanced toward the investigators.

The game does tend to drag on a little and with more than 4 the downtime is just unacceptable.  2 players, 2 heroes each is a lot of fun though.  It's standing up to repeated plays more than I thought possible, though after 10 plays I'm getting bored with base Arkham.  Still, that's about 30 hours of gameplay, and there are expansions to be experienced too.

RATING: 8
**Not sure I'd play with 8, but for 4-5, it's fun**

Damn cool. :)

I'm a fairly big Lovecraft Mythos fan. Lovecraft, Robert W. Chandler's "the King in Yellow" Mythos which helped in building a path/crossover audience for Lovecraft (heck, the king in yellow is in the game!), and Tolkien...anyone who creates such a felt world is fun to me. 

Is the game be any good? I think it is. 

It is much more involved if you're not used to these larger 'American' styled games, but you can handle it once you get it going and if you learn it from people who play it, it's a snap to pick up. 

It's a good co-op game, has good art, it's playable, I have fun with it, and it has a great theme for me. It can also be played solo which is a huge plus for sick days.

The production and the bits are great, but a bit dark to view across the table (note: this is NOT true with the second edition as the board art has been modified). Overall though, the look is outstanding and the range of characters is wonderful and well varied in abilities.

After many plays, I personally find the events at locations become repetative, so I'm really looking forward to the new event cards and expansions to give the game more legs than it already has. 

This is not a beast for everyone, but it's a fine RPGish game that you play together and work together in beating. 

It feels Lovecraftian to me (in so much as a boardgame can evoke such feel).

I'd also say, don't play with 8 as the game ground down (we were all good players with it) and we spent a lot of time just waiting for the last 2 gates needed to open in the few spots it could. While it was slow at the end, I still had a very good time. 

It seems to work best with 1-5 players in my mind, but it was nice to have 8 able to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've enjoyed this, but the sheer length of time it takes to play means I probably won't play often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Arkham Horror is a fun game that can take too long to complete (or die). In the game, you play investigators who go about town trying to end the rise of the Great Old One (i.e. Cthulhu, Yig, Azathoth, etc.). The game is played using a rather simple move-action-die-horribly-oh-no-why-not-again-please-cthulhu-spare-me-mercy-help system that uses a bunch of dice as its resolution mechanic. Fighting a wight? Roll dice equal to your fight skill+weapon+spell(if any)+other bonuses. 5 & 6 are successes, unless you are blessed (4,5 & 6) or cursed (6 only). Meet the required number of successes, and you succeed. Repeat until GOO is repealed, or you die.

My opinion on Arkham Horror leans toward the positive. One thing that I like is that the game provides the opportunity for narrative (albeit random narrative), i.e. The Professor was kicked out of the library for simply being there, then taken to a nearby mental institution, who found him to be completely sane and instead sent him to the hospital where a doctor hit him on the head, resulting in him being sent to another dimension and eaten by a ghoul.

The game is random, but in a fun way. 

However, Eldritch Horror may be better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game is fun when the group remains concentrated on the game and the theme but if they side track it kind looses its charm. I have played arkham about 5 times alone and i gotta admit it was fun now i wouldnt play it alone often it is still an option for some and very doable.
That being said find the right group and your set for a great time. Have a group that doesnt mind to sit for 4hours and wont complain (god people that complain ruin the game for everyone) Now the difficulty of finding this group is where this game looses its marks. I will probably play it during the holidays and may up the score a bit its been a while since ive played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love cooperative RPG-like games, and this is one of the best.  You actually feel like you are doing something on your turn and that you are contributing to the overall victory.  Great theme, lots of cool items, spells, creatures, etc.  It is a little long at first, but it plays faster once everyone is real comfortable with the rules.  Don't play it without a firm grasp of the rules first.  Make sure you look over the board and the various locations before playing also - it helps to know where to go to get blessed, allies, healing, spells, etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game oozes of theme and is visually amazing.  That said this is a game that I would like to see hit a couple of times a year.  Maybe break it out for halloween...setup takes awhile and actual game length is not for the faint of heart.  A few folks in my group own this one so I don't have a strong urge to own it myself.  

For those looking for a heavy themed co-op I strongly recommend this game...for the Euro enthusiats and ultra competitive types I'd look else where.

RATING: 7
After a few plays, I find this an enjoyable game, at least with the right people. The need to min-max the characters' actions are often in stark contradiction to any role-playing elements some people may wish to incorporate; in this way, I find House on the Hill more enjoyable. Maybe the biggest letdown of this game (for me) was that the characters cannot really cooperate in beating monsters or closing gates, but need to resolve these actions all by their lonesome. For the enjoyability, variability and production quality, I find this a stable '7'.

RATING: 7
So, so very fiddly, strongly dependent on luck of card/chit draw with excessive tabletop and playtime needs.  Doesn't matter - co-op theme is off the charts strong (predisposed as I am to Lovecraft shenannigans), and most successful RPG-grafted-to-board-game in my collection.  Emergent story-telling translates to peerless player engagement.  By wisely decoupling math from the die roll (math tells you # of die, not pip-math), the mechanics distill combat rolls, spell casting and saves to tight, tense dice fests.  Somehow even losing is fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Eager to try Eldritch Horror. But till I do: More parts than a space shuttle, half atmosphere and fluff, not really much underneath--and a great game! The psychology of cooperation and the wonderful texture and replayability make this game better than it has a right to be.  Yes, it's fiddly and takes awhile to set up, and you have pile after pile of different cards for seven types of items and various encounters, and endless "dice checks" for fear, fight, evade, luck, spells, luck (everything but taking a crap). But--and this is what critics forget--those are the very things that give the game so much atmosphere.  I love how there are so many layers of overlaying variation (investigators, encounters, GOOs, weather, headlines, rumors) that make each game unique. Stripped down games like Ghost Stories (which reminds me of AH) or Pandemic are perhaps better designs, but don't generate a narrative like this.  (Given its three or four hour play-time, it better!)  While GS or P are closer to the "puzzle" end of the cooperative spectrum, AH sits a bit more to "story telling" side. On first glance AH fools you into thinking it's just a "pick up items to put out fires" game; but while it does involve efficiency puzzles, it only succeeds if you're willing to go into the drama.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love Call of Cthulhu, so I couldn't help but like this game.  It is very "fiddley" though.. with so many things to keep track of that it detracts from the fun.  I will be buying the Innsmouth Expansion, though... Father Dagon tells me that it must be so.

RATING: 7
Mildly enjoyed my first play. It was an 8P game, so pretty long and chaotic. The Dunwich Horror, Kingsport Horror, and King in Yellow expansions were all in play. 

I didn't bother reading the rules beforehand, I just dove right in and took pointers as I went from the experienced players there. The cooperative nature of the game makes this an easy (and recommended) way of getting the hang of it all. 

The theme is obviously linked inextricably to the play, and the production value is very, very good--to be expected from FFG. The sheer volume of cards and components is overwhelming. I enjoyed the suspense of all the card and monster drawing, but was a little underwhelmed by the combat. Maybe it was the items I had, but beating the monsters seemed too easy, and the effects of running out of sanity too mild. In the end, we destroyed the Great Old One without a single person ever getting very close to dying. 

I'd play again, probably with fewer players next time to speed things up. A good game overall--not one I would buy, and there's no chance of it becoming my favorite, but fine as an occasional group game. I had no prior knowledge of Lovecraft's work, and I take it that being familiar with the mythos helps to enjoy the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Fantastic game idea with a wonderful theme.  The game is a little unbalanced (OK, maybe more than a little!), but the core of the game is so cool, that fans of the game have devised all sorts of variants to make things more interesting.  The game takes way too long to play, but it is still amazing.  I would give it a perfect 10 if someone could devise a balanced variant that could be played in less than 2 hours!  Warning - this is NOT a Euro-style Game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The best known and most popular co-op game. I'm not a big fan of horror in general but I do like H P Lovecraft. The guy was clearly completely crazy, but he created an incredible world, which this game allows you to experience in a very unique way. 

To get the most out of this game you really need to play it a bit like a RPG and craft a story as you play. I think it's quite a good game in it's own right, but if you can really imerse yourself in it, it becomes something very special. 

The only frustrating thing is that it does show me what a great game Tales of the Arabian Nights would be if only it was more of a game.

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Hmmm.  Arkham Horror represents the worst of Fantasy Flight Games.  Too long, too many bits, chits, cards, rules etc etc.  This is going to sound strange, but I actually think that the theme is pasted on here.  The *mechanics* of the game are not consistent with the theme.  Yes, there are a whole bunch of cards and bits with writing on them which fall within a theme but the theme is not inherent in the game.  As a counter-example, consider Incan Gold.  This is a push-your-luck game set in the theme of a treasure hunt - the game mechanics work with the graphics to create the thematic experience.  I just don't get that feeling playing Arkham Horror:  I feel like I am pushing a piece around aboard doing stuff which, oh yeah, apparently relates to some story.  Put it another way - playing the game did not make me care one bit about the story.  Saying that the theme should come out of the imagination of the players is just an excuse for lazy game design.  I think that this is why I dislike role playing board games in general.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the first co-op games I played. Love the theme and the pace of the game. Definitely a game I want to play with a good group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Long and elaborate cooperative game. Immersive atmosphere undercut by mechanics. [b][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/171469]See my review[/url][/b]

I gave AH another try 2 years after my review. It's a fragile game. You'll have the easiest time getting it to work as a 2-player experience, with each player taking charge of two characters. Other than soloing the game (not really my thing), that's the only viable path to experienced play. Trying to become familiar with the game in a multiplayer environment is a nightmare of tedium. Once you [b]are[/b] an experienced player, I think this could work quite well with three. I question whether or not it could work with more than that. Too much downtime and too little participation. 

My biggest criticism of Arkham Horror is that it is essentially a simple resource management game. You need clues and money. Lots of amusing events crop up in pursuit of clues and money, but as far as tough decisions go, simple risk management constitutes 90% of your choices. Once an encounter begins, there is virtually no room for strategy and response. Once you know that, it can still be an entertaining game. You make your choices about clues and money and then watch the AH Sci-fi sitcom. 

There's not much out there to compete with AH. Tales of the Arabian Nights is certainly a better game, but Tales does away with resource management entirely in favor or pure narrative generation. I want a game that generates narrative and allows me to make meaningful decisions [b]during[/b] the events of that narrative. I don't think that game exists, outside of RPGs, and my limited experience suggests those don't do it that well either.  

As a two-player game, I rate Arkham Horror an 7, but it bothers me that the rating seems so contingent on a lack of alternatives. As a 4+ player game I rate it a 4 or 5. I just tried it again with three and four, and there just isn't enough for me to do. With four players you inevitably start taking your turns simultaneously and screwing up the sequence. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An allright game but in dire need of streamlining. Too much bits, too little immersion.

RATING: N/A
Inventoried: 2014-09-21:EP, 2014-12-30:EP-Note, 2015-07-27:EP-Note

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Skip this and just go straight to Eldritch Horror, which is obviously the better-designed, more enjoyably, more thematic, and more stream-lined Lovecraft game. If you play Eldritch Horror, you will never want to go back to Arkham Horror.

I never really liked Arkham but tried to get into it because I enjoy the Lovecraft universe. It is only after 10 games or so when I realized that it is really not a well-designed game. The game is nearly pure randomness, there's no safe way to improve your chances in the random encounters, everything takes way too long to do with little real enjoyability, and the game can drag on for hours after it is clear your team has lost.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
There is an easy game underneath a whole bunch of rules.  I like the co-op nature but there are games that are easier to parse through the text and get to the core gameplay.  The only real way to learn this is to have someone else explain it to you or get ready for a lot of time fighting to understand what to do.  That being said, it's a decent co-op game that really captures its theme well if you have someone who knows the rules (otherwise you keep getting yanked out of the game in order to look up information).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Polish ver.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the few games that my wife will play so it gets loads of points for that. But actually a very good game indeed. It's really good to be able to strive for something and know that nobody is going to stab you in the back or is waiting to put you down a peg or two on your first mistake. But this game doesn't need any such behaviour from the players, the game mechanics do it quite well enough. To be honest, as a family, we are not used to winning this game. I am pretty sure we have lost every game so far. But at least we can all commiserate with each other.

I have played a couple of games on my own as well and have won - but only when there were four characters in play. Four seems the perfect number. With three there are not enough of you to mop up all the monsters and with 5 or 6, there are just too many monsters popping out of those portals. Also, with too many characters, there aren't enough easily available clues to go around making it hard to get the requisite 5 clues to seal the portals.

That said, an excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Arkham Horror is a game that I have known for a long time, and it always intrigued me, but also seemed a bit intimidating because of its long playing-time and huge amount of bits. Fortunately I bought and tried it, and I think it's very cool. It might be my favorite cooperative game that doesn't include a traitor. The adventurous experience and fantastic theme make this game for me. The game's mechanics are chuncky and need some getting used to; also, there's a lot of bookkeeping to be done. The quality of the experience is almost fully dependent on the people you play with, especially since this is a horror-themed adventure game, so you have to get into the 'zone' (read this review to know what I mean: http://bit.ly/b3uHSJ). I've had a couple of disappointing plays, because of players that lost interest while playing. This game plays extremely well in solo mode. The biggest flaw in the game is the highly variable playtime. I think 2 hours would be fine for this game, but sometimes it can drag on for 4+ hours, way too long for this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Drips with atmosphere. I really wasn't sure my wife would enjoy it (long play time, lots of bits usually don't sit well with her), but she seemed to enjoy it... to a point. A nice way to spend an afternoon with friends. Unfortunately, playing sometimes feels too predictable. As though the end of the game is a foregone conclusion that you're just grinding your way towards. From what I hear, some of the expansions go some way to correct this, making gates re-open, etc.; but we have yet to play with any of them.

RATING: 4
THE game that got me into the board gaming hobby, for few months, my group and I had dedicated our whole Saturday playing this game.

To conclude, Arkham horror is way too clunky for the game it offer. Especially for us (The first modern board game we got into). To list a few of the problems, the amount of rules, different phrases, moving component, different tracks to keep track of, is just way too overwhelming and energy draining.

Another major complain will be the unbalance between risk and reward for encounters, the more you play, the more you will limit yourself, as you WILL eventually find out that a lot of the potential contents in the game is just not worth doing at all (providing that you're actually trying to WIN the game, not EXPEREINCING the journey). 

In short, great experience, bad "game".

RATING: 3
[b]Quick Review:[/b] The game plays you. No real strategy or tactics, you just sort of do things, and things happen to you. It has a very large random factor. For a game that can last hours, the luck element gets to be frustrating to me. 

However, if you let the game act as a sort of Game Master, and you treat the game as an RPG-lite storytelling game, you'll have more fun. 

Turn off the lights, and set ambient music as you investigate the strangeness happening to the city of Arkham.

RATING: 5
This is difficult for me to rate properly - hopefully I will have the chance to try it again before I completely forget the rules.  I sense that we might have not played all the rules right, but not having any experienced AH players in the group, the rules are a definite challenge to master. 

I can see why many would enjoy this game.  The theme is evocative, and the artwork is not too bad as far as this mystic/fantasy stuff goes.  I've never really understood or appreciated the whole Cthulu mythos, but I would guess that that would really help one's ability to become immersed in the game.

Even though I'm not the biggest fan of cooperative games, this still felt engaging, and moderately fun, but it is just too long, too rules-heavy and too random.  If every player was familiar with the rules I think the experience would be vastly improved.

RATING: 1

Strategic Balance: 1/10

Player Interaction: 1/10

Thematic Direction: 4/10

Replay Addiction: 1/10

Additional Information
Cool characters, cool pieces, and then starting the game turned into a [b]enormous snore-fest[/b]. What clues aren't clues? Reroll? What did I accomplish by killing that zombie? Nothing? 

Advertises as a co-operative game, but it's nothing more than [b]multi-solitare game[/b]. Once one person gets ahead, the others have little use to exist.

The game should really be called: Arkham Horrible.

RATING: 8
A surprisingly strong horror coop offering that makes the most of its cool theme. I had been both doubtful and willing to try this for a long time. It wasn't anywhere as long as I had been expecting and it was fun. Rules editing has been done in a very bad way. The order of things in rules often doesn't make sense and there are gaping holes and basically missing information especially regards to monsters and combat. But going through the rules and starting to play helps make it quite fluid relatively quickly. Color scheme is also very bad, but suits the game and theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Only one play at Gamestorm 2012.  I enjoy the theme and especially enjoy the mechanic of having a very diverse set of locations with very diverse actions to take/cards to draw at each.  This would actually be my favorite cooperative game if it weren't for the shear difficulty in beating the ancient one.  It's hard enough to fight off the minions that are constantly showing up but then also to prepare for a huge end monster can seem overwhelming to the point it detracts from the enjoyment.  I still appreciate and enjoy the game despite this but would have liked it a little better if it wasn't that crushing.  The theme appeals to me but doesn't fit with my gaming group and certainly wouldn't play well with newbies/family.

RATING: 9

I love that there are support characters, although they may not be the most fun to play.  I try and play most games with either a solo variant, or playing as two people and I found it pretty difficult with this one.

RATING: 7.5
Rating is probably going to fluctuate, depending on my current "need" to play., somewhere between 7.5-9.

Time will tell if the looong playtime needed is acceptable.  It also helps that my wife actually likes it!
I own all the expansions, and I am sure those will enhance the replayability...especially Dunwich, which seems to have some fantastic additions...injury cards, tasks...

Update 7/7/08 :  I still love this one.  The vast amount of options make it an absolute blast.  The upgrade in difficulty has made it even more interesting (and deadly) and i think this one will last the test of all time...It may even crack top 5 one day...
It just simply eats too much of a game night's time that it's hard to justify playing often.
It's the only reason, really, that it loses points from me.

As compared to A Touch of Evil, which many do, I think it's different overall due to:

1) MUCH higher degree of difficulty
2) MUCH longer playing time
3) Many more options/variations
4) No competitive mode (outside of odd events here & there)

RATING: 7

Thanks to my friend... Seems that the "Black Goat" expansion brought some more difficulty to the table, and made the game more appealing to me. Now it isn't such of a "walk-in-the-park" anymore, and that's a good thing. Thumbs up.
