=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Carte imbustate, materiale controllato, diviso in contenitori.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I still haven't finished a game of this, but I like what I've seen. The art is genuinely creepy, the rules are simple but innovative, and the roles are surprisingly distinct and their special powers really have an impact on what you can do. It's an atmospheric but social game that works well with a big group, as long as everyone can manage to just be resolute. The danger here, like other multiplayer cooperative games, is that everyone ends up playing every character by committee.

[Update: After three more plays, I really like this, and had to move it up to an 8. The expansions aren't all necessary - I'm particularly unfond of The King In Yellow. The game itself is infinitely replayable, and has a robust enough AI that playing against the system can be genuinely creepy. I still wish the game had enough naked self-interest in it to prevent other players from dictating what I do, but it's a genuine co-op with no traitors, so groupthink is bound to crop up. 

I feel strongly also that players should not have to choose their characters at random - there are some real stinkers in there, and there are enough characters that everyone should be able to find someone they don't mind playing for a few hours. I find the photographer satisfying, the gangster less so. There appears to be a consensus that the researcher's clues give her a commanding advantage, but I don't enjoy tinkering with spells as much since the skill check margins tend to be tighter, and besides, you don't have to spend anything besides time to fire a gun in this game. Don't get me wrong, you need a spellcaster in your group. I'd just prefer it'd be anyone but me.

Some wise friends have ruled that people be prohibited from digging through entire decks as this can take forever, especially when you're playing with three or four expansions. Instead, take the top ten cards and pick one. A not unreasonable fix that should probably be in the rules.]

[Another update: OK, I love this game. While some of the Ancient Ones are WAAAY too difficult (paging Yigg-Tstll...) and there are times when flubbing a die roll or two can lose you the game, I love how much thought has been put into the expansions. 

Which leads to another question: a lot of people seem to think AH would benefit from a "meta-expansion" that would stitch together all the fairly disparate ones published so far, and make them work together. (a) I'm not sure anything could do this, though an errata FAQ would probably come closest and (b) what would they do if they wanted to add ANOTHER expansion afterwards? The flexibility of the Arkham Horror system is one of its great strengths. There are 5!=120 combinations of expansions you can play with so far, and if you can't find a combination that hits your own personal sweet spot as far as theme dilution, etc., you're just not trying very hard.

Arkham Horror reminds me a little bit of that Borges story where the guy makes a map of the world so exact that it ends up matching the world point-for-point, and taking up exactly as much space as the world itself. Except this world has foul squid gods.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Some people whine about this being a long game, but those people need to get a grip.  This game's dripping with theme and I'm always down with a game that actually has people working together.  Solid game that I wish I could play more often.

RATING: 4
Based on 1 play.  Another addition to the line of Fantasy Flight Games that I want to like but just don't have the patience for.   The first few turns of AH were enjoyable, but the remainder were repetetive and dull.  Towards the end I wanted so badly to close the final gates, not to win but so the experience would be over.  And this was with veteran players who had a strong grasp of the rules.  We ended up calling it quits at the 4.5 hour mark.  The content and strategy of the game can't justify that kind of time-frame.

RATING: 8
Very fun and thematic game play, though I've never played an RPG I think this board game is about as close to one as you can come.  You really do "feel" like you are your character and you are personally struggling against the Mythos.  The game also plays very well solo, but I haven't ever played with more than 3 players.

The mechanics of the game aren't really that fantastic though, and it gets a little too easy once you figure out the "strategy" to it.  I've heard the expansions can help ratchet up the difficulty a lot though.  Fun game for solo play and in the right crowd.

RATING: 8
This is an awesome game that is all about theme.  It does a superb job of filling you with a sense of impending doom.  It's very clear from the start that you have little hope of accomplishing all that you would want and so decisions become critical, in some cases razors-edge important.  That dark cloud looming over you coupled with one of the best themes in any game creates a cooperative gaming experience like no other.  Being an FFG game it also means that the components are chrome-tastic.  If you like lots of bits in your games (I sure do) then this game will be one more great box to add to your collection.

RATING: 9.8
This is one beefy, complex game.  I've played Die Macher, but Arkham just feels much more complex because of the massive amount of specific circumstance rules.

I also really love it, partially because I enjoy Lovecraft and partially because it's vast and challenging.

2017 update: Replayed recently, and I still enjoy it. I doubt I'll ever shake the nostalgic ties I have to this game. I think there are many objectively better games, but something about the theme, the rules density, and the fun of the dice will always keep Arkham Horror close to my heart.

Also, hi to anyone reading my bgg comments and laughing at how incongruous this game probably looks among my other top-rated games.

RATING: 9
Terrific fun, really exciting, even solo.  The theme is very immersive.  Rules take a while, but eventually it all flows.  As usual, Universal Head's reference sheets are invaluable.

Score increased to 9 after various improvements:
 - game blinged out with minis (investigators & monsters);
 - game blinged out with litko gate holders & elder signs;
 - I use cardholders so that half the table isn't occupied by 20 decks of cards;
 - added lots of cards added from various expansions;
 - I now use the 2-investigators-act-as-4 variant for solo play (1 upkeep & mythos phase for each 2 movement & encounter phases).
Together, these have substanitally increased my enjoyment.

RATING: 10
I love Arkham Horror. I love the theme. I love the cooperation. I love losing in grisly fashion when everything seemed to be going so well. 

We play this game in our group when we have the time, and though we win often, it's the horrible losses, when things just really spiral out of control, that are so fun. We prefer 4-6 players for our games.

The expansions can really change the game strategy and difficulty, as well as making it more thematically focused - using all of the King in Yellow mythos cards on top of the mythos deck, for example.

RATING: 7
Initial thoughts: Wow, this really captures some of the atmosphere of the Call of Cthulhu RPG. Has got great production value -- tons of counters, and nice illustrations too (you'll have to squint to make the most of them, though). 

Reassesment after second play: Suffers somewhat from its eighties american game ancestry -- mainly the long playing time, and this time also from a lack of endgame tension. (It was clear that we couldn't lose the game, but also that it would be a long, somewhat mechanical process to close the last gates, mainly due to prominent gate surges at terror level 10. This could be scenario-dependant, though -- we played vs. Hastur.) 

I'm still expecting to enjoy this, perhaps not all too frequently, and in the right company (some roleplaying/mythos knowledge goes a long way here).

RATING: 5
(FFG Edition) A long time in coming this is a revised, revamped and expanded version of the classic Arkham Horror game by Chaosium. At its heart a dungeon crawl, but what a great crawl it is.  As with all things Cthulhu the game is stacked against the players, but that's all part of the attraction, isn't it?    A cooperative game that scales well for 1 - 8 players.
(June 2005) First Printing.   
(November 2006) Revised Printing.

[b]UPDATE:[/b] So why such a low rating? Because despite the great theme I find the game boring. Downtime is a problem in games with more than three or four players. Game is way to "fiddly" with all of the card decks, etc, especially as expansions are added into the mix. Finally the game suffers from the "one player telling everyone else how to play" syndrome that is common to cooperative games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Arkham Horror is a cooperative adventure game set in 1920's Massachusetts in which a group of investigators are tasked with defeating a Lovecraftian elder god. Investigators make discoveries via encounters (in this world and others), gain equipment, fight monsters, etc. over the course of the game.

Arkham Horror is, by design, unbalanced. If the players choose their investigators and the Ancient One (the elder god you are tasked with fighting) randomly, and if they draw exceptionally powerful monsters into the game, then it can become nearly impossible to win if there isn't a clear path forward. However, this plays into the atmosphere of Lovecraftian Horror exceptionally well; helplessness and feeling overwhelmed are part and parcel with Lovecraft's work. Due to the length of the game, this can be discouraging for players. However, it makes the times when the investigators do manage to overcome the odds all the sweeter, creating a sense of comraderie that I've not seen from any other game I've played. Combined with the Roaring-Twenties-Meets-Science-Fiction aesthetic and this one's a big winner.

This game should be played by anyone who enjoys cooperative gaming experiences, and enjoys a good story; stories often evolve organically, which can be both compelling and oftentimes quite hilarious. If you've got 3 to 4 hours to play, and you stay invested, it's incredibly rewarding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
this one is a hard one for me to rate in some regards.  It is a heavy weight game to me in the sense that there is a large amount of nuances that happen every turn, a decent amount of setup, and a decent number of look ups in the rule book through-out play unless I happen to be playing with people that are experienced to share some of the mental load of rules

The theme is great, it does feel like you are trying to prevent Arkham, and the world, from being overrun by an elder one, but it is rules heavy and at this point, unless i'm playing with a group of experienced people at it, I don't really bring it out on the table anymore. 

depending on the group and how much meta gaming you want to do, it is not unreasonable to expect a 90-150 minute game out of this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Arkham Horror is, basically, like playing a tabletop RPG without requiring someone to act as game master or narrator. A hack & slash role playing session. The game has tons of chrome which, while they do add to the theme, also increase downtime tremendously.

The most important quality of this one is, obviously, the theme: it reigns supreme over all other aspects. Given it is a cooperative game, interaction in between players is high, as you will keep discussing the best moves and so on. The massive amount of cards along, with all the dice you will need to roll, shoots the luck factor quite a bit but, thankfully, the possibility of "customizing" your investigator each turn not only helps dealing with this, but also creates a mechanism which allows you to constantly take interesting tactical decisions.

So what is Arkham Horror about? The town of Arkham is going to be attacked by a godlike creature who wants to destroy the world, and you have to stop that from happening. 

Players will be exploring the town, battling monsters, trying to close the portals they emerge from, all while facing the uncertain (a.k.a.: randomly drawn event cards). If you fail to close all the portals, then the big guy will attack, and a last stance battle will commence.

The of lavish theme, high interaction and luck screams "AMERITRASH!" all the way, and that's what this game is. Though not only it has the best aspects of this genre, also sports its worst qualities: it's as fiddly as it gets. Even though the mechanisms succeed at giving it the RPG vibe, there are an absurdly high number of them, and a decent bunch of them are convoluted and unintuitive.

Its biggest issue, and the primary reason my rating tanks, is downtime: it's a chore to set up, and there's a lot of maintenance to be done in between turns. On an average Arkham Horror session half of the time, if not more, will be spent doing busywork. That's a huge deal-breaker for me.

All in all, if you are looking for something more than narrative when playing a game, skip this one and go for something else. Arkham offers a boardgamey RPG session set in Lovecraftian myths, nothing more, nothing less.

Rating: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:3~4
:thumbsdown:7~8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Much is said about this game. So here's my opinion:
One mighty big boardgame I (nearly) always love to play. There are some issues with rules (complexity, you kind of forget some of the "small" details very easily) and their presentation. Some of the expansions should be bought for maximum fun. I think they add quite a bit to the promising gameplay in the core box. 
It isn't overflowing with theme but the theme is there, especially if you read some or most of H.P. Lovecraft's stories (on which this game is loosely based). It's quite nerd-orientated and time-consuming, so probably not a game for a nice, little family evening. I have played sessions with around 4 players familiar with the game that had not ended after around 4-5 hours (with expansions)!
Bought it somewhen in 2009 and have played it with a bunch of friends nearly every other week for around one year (adding the expansions one at a time over the year). Then I was a bit fed up with the game. But I got it out for a gaming day the other day (2011) and had great fun (although we lost to Nyarlathotep) with a group of 6 other gamers who never played the game before.

Taken everything together I would say it is my favourite game of the ones I own. I think everyone interested in boardgaming as a hobby should have played at least a session or two in his gaming life and then can make up his mind if they love, hate or meh it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Only problem: The endgame is much to easy for the players (when you simply go for it rather than close the gates). But this changes a lot with the expansions - then Arkham Horror is a real blast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A nearly perfect adventure game that may very well become a 10 in time. Diverse characters, a loving use of the source material, a massive amount of non-dragging flavor text... everything to look for in adventure games. What's amazing to me is that this is partially cooperative but yet it doesn't feel that way to me (hence my use of the word 'partially'). There is still a huge amount of player interaction and everyone either wins or loses but at the same time I didn't feel like I HAD to work with my opponent/fellow-player in order to succeed. It would be stupid not to, but unlike Shadows Over Camelot or Lord Of The Rings, the game doesn't DEPEND on the cooperative to work and yet it is still fun and full of story. Amazing. The art work is the same used in the latest CCG and there is also plenty of elements that had been used in the original Mythos CCG that all Lovecraft fans should be very satisfied. And there are a lot of Lovecraftian elements not used that I could see fan expansions if not official booster possibilities galore (How about an international trip to London and Egypt with Harry Houdini? Or a trip to Innsmouth?). If the game continues to hold its excitement level for me, it could easily take its place on my 10 list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love the world created by H.P. Lovecraft. If you do too, you will also like this game!

I have to issue a warning though. It is a game with messy game mechanics that is quite complex to play even when you have mastered the rules.

RATING: 4
Rating assumes you're my brothers, who already know how to play; otherwise, it's a 4.

I'm not normally a fan of cooperative games, and probably won't play this with my normal group, but my brothers like this pretty well, and I'll happily play it with them.

The theme does bug me: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/107083
And some of the graphic design--the Mythos cards are the dumbest design ever!  But the gameplay has been just fine, delivering hard-fought victories every time we've played (always 2-3 players, 1 investigator each, using the base rules).

Update: it doesn't [i]always[/i] play that well; in one 2p game vs. Shub-Niggurath (tougher monsters), we got a rumor card which caused the terror level to go to 10 and the town to be overrun.  After [i]hours[/i] of waiting for enough gates to open for the GOO to awaken so that we could kick its ass, we finally just skipped ahead to that part.  That game was just tedious.

Update: the last two games (3P and 4P with Dark Pharaoh expansion) have kind of stalled out after the first hour or two.  We quickly get to four gates sealed, and then the game drags on for another two hours while we seal the last two gates.

Update: dropping this to a 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
AH has amazing production values.  There has never been a horror or Cthulhu game that looked this good or had such high quality components.  A lot of inelegant and unnecessarily fiddly rules do a fair job of simulating the Call of Cthulhu RPG and the game can be fun in balance.  But AH doesn't feel horrifying to me and is only tense in the early game.  The FAQ patches incorporated into the Dunwich Horror rules only slightly alleviate this, by ratcheting up the difficulty.  This FAQ's contents also demonstrate that AH was inadequately playtested before release.  The ratcheting up of difficulty with each successive expansion constitutes FFG acknowledging that the AH base game is imbalanced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
[2008.May.01] This weighty game--can you say high bit count?--nicely encapsulates the growing horror that H.P. Lovecraft gave us with his Cthulhu Mythos. A cooperative game where the Investigators [players] work (hopefully) together to prevent/defeat the horrors that appear in the fictional town of Arkham, Massachusetts (USA). Unfortunately, a number of issues mar this wonderfully rendered FFG edition, including: (a) excessive randomness introduced via both dice rolling and card drawing, and (b) game mechanics that seem to prevent the game ending conditions from being met, thereby increasing the length of play. Unless your gaming group is a well-oiled machine, this one may take quite a few hours to finish and put back into the box.

:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 5

Even so, the game will probably still be too easy.

[update] Traded away once I realized game was entirely luck-based and trivially easy to beat once you know how.

RATING: 6.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Yes the game is heavy, it has a lot of components, rules and takes a lot of time to play. But the game is open anough to make various alterations and play modes with the same game (ex: Playing Mages or cultist). The only thing I found anoying is that it is hard to determine yourself objectives at the beginning of the game. The fact that you can play in coperative and even alone is interesting. I like the fact that it is some sort of game where you determine your own objectives toward a common goal which seems to fit for "Wanderer" types of players.

For the theme, I find it better than the call of cuthuluh RPG. In the RPG, it feels more pessimistic: "You are going to die, just try to survive long enough". In arkham horror, you can alway get back from death by health or sanity and you feel less powerless.

Update: Many years later, after playing again, I feel the game to be more work than fun. There is a lot of hidden rules easily forgotten, it seems you spend a lot of time updating the game, like moving monsters and other stuff. Finally, the object of the game is not that fun. You just move through gates, get back, seal the gate. Repeat the process until victory.

Now that Eldritch Horror is out, I don't think there is any reason to play this game anymore. Some people say AH is good if you have many expansions, but I don't because I do not have the space for it. I rather have a game that runs smoother and ends up faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

When played with experienced or decisive players, this really works well, and if you've read the books, it is really rich in theme.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Interested to know why this game becomes so popular...sorry, but I was not impressed after one play.  It is more for the children, who is curious about exploration with an investigator in another world, full of Lovercraftian monsters, mido, vampires or dohls (yep, a lot of the names you won’t recognise).  The game takes the roleplaying model, where each investigator has different abilities in terms of 6 basic attributes Fight and Will, Speed and Sneak, Lore and Luck.  An investigator can use his or her Focus value to change the paired attributes each turn by the same number of move along a slide track.  I don't have a clue as to how the pairs are selected that way and why they must be so.  It looks too arbitrary as I don't believe the paired attributes are necessarily having an inverse relationship along the track.      

The combat system is a 5 or 6 to "succeed" with the no. of dices according to the investigator's attributes. The combat checks require "Fight" for physical monster and the horror checks require "Will" to stand up against monster.  An investigator is devoured when his Stamina and Sanity are both reduced to zero.  Fortunately you are never out of the game simply because of this.  You simply pick up another investigator to continue the story.  This may already suggests that it is a design solution when the investigators keep “devoured” by the game system when there are too many monsters to fight and havoc the streets of Arkham.  Before the investigators could have a chance to equip themselves adequate enough (they do have some possessions to begin with but…..), there are already a lot of the monsters on the streets, and some are quite powerful, guarding the way to the shop or other places where you can find or buy something additional to improve your attributes. 

If you don’t fight the monsters, they prevent the investigators to go to the gate and close or seal it in order to prevent the rise of the ultimate the Ancient One, the real one that you can’t defeat it easily.  If the investigator’s stamina is knocked down to zero, he or she goes to St. Mary’s hospital and discard of the items and clue tokens.  If the investigator’s Sanity is knocked down to zero, he or she goes to Arkham Asylum and lose the same half.  If they are knocked down when they are in the other world, they are lost in time and space and are delayed: they can’t move for the next turn. 

Monsters are spawned randomly anywhere in the city of Arkham by the drawing of the “Encounter” card, “Gate” card or “Mythos” card.  After they are spawned, the monsters walk randomly in the streets and locations according to the colors of their dimensional symbol (circle, diamond square etc.) along the black and white arrows.  Fast monster can move 2 spaces.  Flying monster can attack any investigators (the nearest or the lowest sneak value) on the street and attack them.  

There are random clues for the investigators to pick up when they stop after movement.  Random unique equipment but hack, the weapons are mostly physical and thus are useless while the mythos monsters are mostly physical resistant.  random clue tokens. Random gate open.

You use Elder signs to seal the gate.  An investigator can only seal the gate only after he or she return from the other world locations.  Of course, it means that you have to survive from the travel because monsters are encountered on the way.  The location of the gate and the types of monster encounters are randomly determined.  (Yes, random again.)  When you seal a gate successfully, the doom token would reduce by one on the doom track, delaying the Ancient One arrival.    

The game is trying to depict a sort of atmosphere backing up the story environment.  Some of these are trivial e.g. the environmental conditions while some are too random coming with the cards picked up during encounter.  There are book texts on the cards to create and describe the atmosphere but in the end, it is all about changing the numbers and values. You might gain skill card, magical card or ally card in the process.  Yes, someone might come up in a location and accompany you through exploration.  For those not familiar with the original stories, however, there is simply no difference to go directly to the changes and the reading of the text out loud for other investigators’ attention.  The other investigators would not be affected in any way what happens to one investigator.  

Arkham Horror...arghem...it really is a horrible game as its name suggests. Not my cup of tea, it is boring, truly random story development, search and destroy things with investigator wandering around on the board.  Yes, even how the Ancient One attacks is randomly determined in the beginning from one of the eight cards.  While the system is trying to build up the adventure, the pace and ratio of reward/ penalty just doesn’t match.  So you would find your investigators keep going to St. Mary’s Hospital or Arkham Asylum while they are half way on the road to their objectives.  It is very hard for them to restore their sanity or stamina to the full before they are asked to out in the field and explore again.  When they spend the money, money also hard to come by in the city of Arkham where everybody is trying to protect themselves and close the shops as the horror level goes up.  The time is short and the pressure is on too much.  This one is a pass on my book.  Other who have read the stories extensively, however, might find this game revives some of the most vivid but faded past memories in the 60’s.

RATING: 8
Yes, I'd never played Arkham Horror before 2013. I don't know how it happened, it just happened. That's now been rectified and I really enjoyed it. It's a whack-a-mole coop, in that the players mostly run around trying to put out fires as they pop up and building themselves up to take on the tougher baddies. There was real tension as it looked early on like we were doomed (and there was one exceedingly poorly timed environment draw that we thought wrapped everything up right then and there.) However, we overcame the odds and managed to pull out a win -- and a fairly sizable one, I think -- against Yog-Sothoth. It was a good time, and I'm glad to have finally experienced this classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Played this with 5 friends, then a 6th jumped in (seven players total). Could've spend 4½ hours (270 minutes!!!) of my life doing pretty much anything else.  

The game box really should limit the number of players to 3-5 (or at least state that as being optimal) instead of allowing for 8 players.  Needs some sort of "quick rules" like being able to move all at once or take encounters all at once and just passing the dice around.  Game needs more dice.  

Pretty sad day all around and only enjoyed by the one hard-core Arkham lover in the group.  At least 4, probably 5 of the players were absolutely miserable trying to play this, but in classic  Could've played 3-5 much better games instead in the time it took to slog through this (which didn't even finish).

The problem, as another rater suggested is that this game gives players no "Agency".  Decisions are meaningless.  Just prance around and hope that the cards don't royally fork you over.  When rewards do come around they are underwhelming and you feel as if you've worked for nothing and they can be lost easily anyway.

There are also TOO MANY mechanics. For example: why have cash?  How many players used it?  No one pursued getting it because it had essentially zero influence on the outcome of the game.  Why have 11 (or whatever it was) different decks of item cards?  Why not just have 1 deck for player cards?  Magic use always seemed like an awful choice and always came with severe penalties for not much benefit.

The narratives are nice but....maybe a little too much.  One rater on BGG who gave this game 10 stars (WHY?!!) said "Victory feels earned and every success is a result of strategy and skill."  Really, because I felt like there was 35 minutes of waiting around for my turn to even get to me and that there was absolutely zero strategy.  Skill?  Skill only matters when players have control over how their decisions affect outcomes.  I understand games need a chance mechanic (which I love) and need some form of risk an cost-benefit decision making, but Arkham Horror has none of that.  You essentially get what you draw and.....good forking luck.

Can I go ahead and give this game 0.5 stars?  It's terrible.  The artwork is beautiful though and I do enjoy the "universe" that it's set in.  So, there's that, at least.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
First play with 6 people went 4 hours and we were not even close to being done. Looking for a quicker end, we decided to take on the ancient one, Yog-Something-Or-Other. Reading what it takes to kill it (and noticing some more rules we missed) we decided to call it by stating we were devoured and move on to shorter fair.

Arkham Horror tries very hard to create a narrative and to be as realistic as possible. Unfortunately both of these aspects failed for me on some level. First, narrative was slow to develop as the rules were always a problem. A green monster moves what? A spell check is what (why they just don't call is a Lore check I will never know)? A nightmarish monster does what (why these abilities are not printed on the monsters also baffles me)? Etc. Second, the realism is conveyed in the following ways: by having many possible items that a player can collect, by having a variety of encounters, and by having cards/tokens each do many things. This variety creates heavy cognitive load for a game that is already rules heavy.

After one play, I think Arkham Horror could work well as a solo computer game (to handle the cognitive load and to have the ability to save then resume) or as a game with a maximum of 3 players because downtime was a problem.

[u]Result[/u]: Traded. Fun game and ideas, but too many rules and long play time meant it never got to the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Formerly my favorite game, now my second favorite through absolutely no fault of its own. It's system-heavy, its events are as random as a card deck gets, and the systems only relate because the game says they do, but the whole thing is redolent with its theme. It's not 100% faithful to the material (very few investigators deal with *that* many monsters in the Mythos stories), but it is a fun, pulp approach to the material, and it never shies from the theme for a second. I have never had a dull moment playing Arkham Horror, whether we're triumphing, being sucked into portals endlessly, or swinging from one to the other. I love collecting Clue tokens, fighting monsters, and getting pinballed around by the depravity that is the encounter deck. It's a long-runner, and the learning curve can be steep at first, but I can't recommend it enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of the best cooperative games I've played so far. I'm a fan of the mythos and I love to watch my characters struggle through. Sometime they are heroic (the dual sword welding psychiatrist who can barely keep herself sane) or inept (The magician who had the best kit and spells, went through his first gate and had is brain turned into jelly by a ancient one).I love losing as much as winning.

[update] I never play it anymore, just feels random. I'd rather play Mage Knight.

RATING: 7
I love this game. I love the writing and the artwork, and I love the dice mechanic which is a success on a five or six where you need to get (x) successes. I also really like Lovecraft, so that's a plus.

However, it does take a while to set up, and it's somewhat complicated to teach, so I don't get to bring it out often. Moreso since most of the people I play with are casual gamers. 

Additionally, the newer Eldritch Horror has a more streamlined feel while adding a few new mechanics that make it more interesting (like spells you flip over to see its effects). Much of the reason why I even keep this one is because I like the idea of travelling around Arkham more than travelling around the world (I'm a Lovecraftian fangirl like that). So, I would recommend Arkham Horror with a grain of salt.

RATING: 8
this is a 6 for the base game.

8 with dunwich

The base game suffers from a period of boredom in the middle to late game.   enough gates are either sealed or opened that few new ones open up, making the doom track go slow, and clue tokens become rarities.   if enough gates (and the right gates) are sealed then the last hour of the game is boring...the heroes are going to win and know it...its just a matter of gathering the correct # of clues.   

StormKnight Variant helps with this, but the best solution is to get Dunwich.

RATING: 6

The game being explained to me went something  like this: "If situation a happens you die. If situation b happens you die.  If situation c happens you when but only if situation d is not true.  If time expires, then your pretty much screwed, because you have to fight the old great one, and they are just super powerful."

After stating this, the person explaining the game to me must of seen the horrific look in my face stating, "How the hell does anyone win this game."  He said, "Don't worry, your supposed to feel helpless."

On a side note:  My team (6 of us were playing) did win the first time we played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can see how people could rate it low -- it's kind of boring, in a way; there's not a whole lot of strategy; the ending battles are total dicefests; there's a million rules, a thousand of which you're likely to forget; it's fiddly; a nightmare to set up; takes a long time.

None of it matters.  For an RPG experience distilled into a boardgame, it doesn't get better than this, at least for me.  The writing and artwork are superlative.  The materials are high-quality.  It's fanciful, over-the-top and somehow classy, all at once.  At the end of a game, I'm exhausted; I feel like I've been somewhere and back.  And exhausted as I am, part of me is just one impulse away from setting it up and going on the ride again.

RATING: 6
An enjoyable game with great theme and atmosphere, although a bit too luck dependent for my taste - some playthroughs are great, some are frustrating, some are boring, some are too long, and some end too fast. There's also a little bit too much pressure from the opening Gates - you never seem to have enough time to do some shopping or collect some clue tokens and I would like to delve deeper into the theme and exploration, not just race from Gate to Gate. I seem to have luck considering Elder Signs, without them I think it may get too frustrating and there isn't that many of them. Nevertheless, the game has great, dark atmosphere and enjoyable gameplay, not to mention beautiful artwork and component quality.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If, after playing my first couple games of [b][thing=15987][/thing][/b], had I been asked what I thought the replay value of this game was, I would have said, low. What a stupid, random, luckfest of a game...that just keeps getting more and more interesting. Once I got over the lack of Lovecraftian horror in the game and got to know it a bit better, I began to understand that [b][thing=15987][/thing][/b] is really not so chaotic and random; there are a finite number of cards and if you have some idea as to what's on them, then you can start to play the probabilities; what are the chances a gate in Independence Square will open as compared to Hibb's Roadhouse? What's the probability that you can sneak past that Dark Young one to enter the gate? How can I improve my chances and ultimately mitigate the risks?  I still don't consider [b][thing=15987][/thing][/b] one of my favorite games. There are plenty of games I would rather play, but for a cooperative, it's worth dragging out every so often. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

EDIT: It definitely went up after 2nd play, but not much. It seems there's just too much components and special rules, and a lot of them with no apparent use except in very specific situations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Solid theme, but smooth gameplay is hindered by the incomplete rulebook. In the two times I've played, I had to resort to BGG or the FAQ to find the solution to some rules-issue or contradiction. 

Furthermore, the game feels like there is very little actual strategy involved. Some people call this more of an experience than a game, and I believe they are right in saying so. You can sort of plan ahead as to what your strategy for the next few turns will be, but one bad die-roll or an unlucky card and your efforts have been without effect. That does fit the Lovecraft-theme, but perhaps works better in a book than in a game.

The story the game tells is not very coherent, there is not much of a link between the events that happen and the ancient one you try to keep asleep (besides the small number of special rules per ancient one).

The game takes very long for what it is, and I think there are most definitely better games out there that manage to tell a good story in half the time and with half the rules.


Update: I somehow still sometimes think back of this fondly. I miss a 'relaxed' gaming experience like this, where you can just watch a grand story unfold (even though the story is not always very good). I might check out Eldrich Horror, or the new Arkham card game sometime in the future..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Very fiddy. Lots of counters and rolls, egad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Picked up June 2006 - traded away
Picked up in trade Aug 2007

Cooperative as well as solitaire play.

Played my first solo game Aug 1, 2006
2 characters - The Gangster and the Researcher vs Yig
It was a short game as they managed to close 3 gates. The Gangster started with one Elder Sign and  he managed to be near the first opened gate. It didn't take him long to close it. During several Mythos rounds new gates were unable to appear. The Researcher had very high Evasion ability so was easily able to circumvent the monsters in her way to close her gate. There was a quick dash to the third and final gate and although the Gangster ended up lost in time and space, the Researcher got lucky and was able to pull herself back into Arkham via a mysterious rope immediately. A new gate was unable to open up so a monster appeared, which the Researcher was able to defeat. As soon as she did, she successfully closed the gate, sacrificing the Gangster for the good of all Arkham. All in all rather fiddly, but the turns did flow better than I was expecting. My initial rating is a 6 for now, but I will play it again because I think there is something here I have yet to discover. I think some organizational aids will be pretty helpful too.

RATING: 2
Great theme, which the cards really use, but the basic mechanism doesn't really work, nor do mechanics match the theme. Play is wandering round just picking up clues and closing gates. Feels more like tidying up than fighting evil.  

Lacks the "Will we make it?" tension of other co-ops. Many turns lack decisions and anything usefull to do.

Usually win and usually know whether you've won by half way through.  Last hour or so (at least) is a drag.

Several other complaints with it that I can't be bothered to go into.

LOTR does a better job of it by matching the actual game system to the theme;  AH has the right chrome, but the nuts and bolts aren't there.

If someone designed a good game with this theme, AH would never have seen the light of day.  It sells only because no other boardgame covers the subject matter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Arkham Horror is a very complex game, and for me (particularly while learning the game), that complexity often distracts from the rich theme of the game - it's a shame. I sometimes feel this game might have worked if rather than being purely cooperative, one of the players was instead made to a play an overlord (or GOO) - giving one player the responsibility of managing all the monsters' affairs would have left the rest of the gameplay more streamlined.

There are some tricks that make managing some of the details a little easier, such as using plastic stands to hold monsters as an effective way of counting how many monsters are allowed out at once. Once the game processes are down pat, focussing on the story becomes a little easier, and the game becomes a richer experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Played more than 100 times]
Sort of multiplayer gamebook (or simple RPG with an automated Master).
Theme is nicely implemented. Some efforts to "roleplay" (when possible) improve the experience.
A bit of strategy and tactic is possible, but luck has a decisive role (cards and dice rolls).
Cards and characters aren't too well balanced.
Rules have some ambiguities and missing points; you'll have to fill the gaps and add some house rules to make the game playable (download the latest FAQs as well, since they're finally available).
It doesn't scale very well: too easy with more than 4 characters (and a lot of downtime) and too difficult with only one or two (we suggest: when playing solo, use 3 or 4 characters; with two players, use 2 characters each). I won't play it again with more than 4 players.
Game lenght was significant, but is reduced to about 2 hours (with up to 4 players) after some games. 
It becomes repetitive (similar gameplay and too few cards). Expansions alleviate this problem.
Fine components.

Overall, it is an EXPERIENCE the first time(s) and you MUST modify it to make it a decent GAME (my rating regards the game after you find a suitable set of global rules; it'd get only a "4" considering the game "as it is out of the box").
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Arkham Horror served as my gateway to tabletop gaming many years ago. I was drawn to its deep Lovecraftian roots, but didn't expect much, as previous experiences with Lovecraftian video games and movies were usually disappointing. Thankfully, Arkham Horror delivered! It's a fantastic game filled with familiar horrors brought to life by well written flavor text and challenging gameplay. I will say, it's not for everyone. It's the kind of game I usually have to dedicate a whole day to. I'd say about half of the time my group ends up losing to the ancient ones. Granted, this is a game I can enjoy losing, but not everyone agrees with me on this one. The solitare play is still really fun though, so I can enjoy losing all by myself :P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
I really disliked this game at first, then became ambivalent, and finally okay with it.  After more and more plays I got a better glimpse of the beauty in the flow of the game.  Once you have the rules down tight, the game moves very quick and I can usually finish a game in less than an hour solo, or a couple hours with more players.

The entire thing feels very satisfying no matter how it all ends.  I feel like a story has played out each time and it always amazes me how each game feels so vastly different from the last.  I never leave a game feeling like it played out just like before.  Even more, patterns start to form in the random chaos to make you believe that the game "knows" or has a will of its own.  

In my last game I had a Warlock and a Cultist spawn right across the street from each other.  Then I immediately drew "The Great Ritual" card for Warlocks and Cultists in the street between them.  I failed to find enough tokens to stop the ritual, and a turn later, almost in response to my failure, the God of the Bloody Tongue emerged from the Warlock's Gate.  Yikes!

The game constantly throws stories out like this that seem to make logical sense.  Is it just coincidence, or does it really have a mind of its own?!  I don't know, it's kind of spooky, but I really like this aspect of the game.

I love the amount of choices each game that I have and how our players only get to participate in certain aspects of the world each time.  There are not many other games that provide for so much re-playability without relying on more content to deliver it.

The Lovecraft theme really helps this game as well, and the more stories I read and re-read from Lovecraft, the more I appreciate the game that builds on it.  This game really is like a fine wine that gets better the more you understand the Lovecraft universe.

Finally, I feel like the game really benefits from the number of expansions and fan content that has been released over the years.  I highly recommend the smaller board variant, it instantly makes the game far more playable.  Some say that Eldritch Horror surpasses Arkham because of its streamlining, and while I haven't played it yet, I don't think I would agree.  I like the heavier rules and choices, and I like the more "role-play" feel this game provides that many say has been lost in EH.

I also own the Dunwich Horror Expansion.

Not likely to repeat again unless asked.

RATING: 7
A horror-Cthulhu-theme dice-fest set in a classic Lovecraftian world. Player co-operate in saving the world from the imminent destruction caused by strange tentacly horrors coming through dimension gates. The game has its moments, but basically it's pure luck-of-the dice, and the odds are ALWAYS against you - most often so strongly that you just want to give up, leave the dice on the board and curl up in the corner of the toilet to wait for the end. And the expansions only add to the difficulty, making it basically unbeatable unless the players co-ordinate with military precision AND have magical luck with the die rolls.

RATING: 10

There are so many variables that you will never have 2 games the same.  I swear the thing is sentient, but then the system was created by a man with a degree in AI.

RATING: 3
This was a perfect example of how wrong it is to listen to the reviews, in stead of going with the brain/gut/heat.

This should play well with 2 people - even as solitaire.

It's co-op.

It's heavily themed.

It's being praised in the reviews.

So I thought it would be a good game for the girlfriend and me. Boy was I wrong. First of all, we are not used to games that plays in more than 2 hours. 5 hours into our first game, and we were still unsure about the rules of the game. It didn't run smooth. 

We gave it 6 or 7 tries besides that, but every time we played, we got tired before the end of the game. And I mean tired like you have been writing an exam for the past 5 hours. It was not fun. The use of dice made the game like a giant version of ludo, but with characters and special abilities - that will last for 5 hours.. 

-- no thanks!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Arkham Horror is a cooperative adventure game themed around H.P Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos. Players choose from 16 Investigators and take to the streets of Arkham. Before the game, one of the eight Ancient Ones is chosen and it's up to the Investigators to prevent it from breaking into our world. During the course of the game, players will upgrade their characters by acquiring skills, allies, items, weapons, and spells. It's up to the players to clean out the streets of Arkham by fighting many different types of monsters, but their main goal is to close portals to other dimensions that are opening up around town. With too many portals open the Ancient One awakens and the players only have one last chance to save the world. Defeat the Ancient One in combat!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Playing a session is a little like taking a lottery ticket.
Sometimes its great fun, sometimes its just frustrating.

RATING: 7.8
The game has some faults, some strengths, too much to describe in a short text. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wonderful theme makes up for slightly awkward mechanics. Has an epic feel and comes reasonably close to an RPG-experience. Comes with a million cards, which I love. 

It really helps to get into the theme/storytelling aspect of the game. 

Downside: it's very long! This, of course, contributes to the "epic feel", but the game requires stamina. Playing with larger groups is not the best idea, because it's guaranteed that someone will be zoning out somewhere around the end of the third hour. 

Plays well with two through four, though. With two, we like to use either three or four investigators.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very fun.  I love the co-op aspect, and it's got excellent replay value with all of the characters and possible Dark Ones.

Board Game
THEMATIC Cthulhu Mythos, Horror, Co-op, Dice rolling, Role playing, Fighting, Exploring, Adventure

1-8
180-240'

Complexity: M/H 3,53

Excellent cooperative board game with the perfect dose of Lovecraftian Mythos. Investigate, search, fight monsters, try to stay sane and survive... before the Great Old One awakens... Amazing artwork and components, excellent atmosphere! My absolute favorite and N°1 'Cthulhu' game.

RATING: 7.5
The game requires cooperative play, which is emphacised enough in the rule book. The forces of *EVIL* will win every time if the players don't pull it together. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
I know a lot of people love this game.  It just REALLY isn't my thing.  PERHAPS if I played with someone that knew all the rules, but I've put hours into it and MAYBE 10 percent of that time was actually spent PLAYING.  The rest of the time we're looking up fiddly little rules and clarifications, finding out we're playing wrong, etc..  Besides that it's just too long for my taste and I don't particularly like taking turns reading several sentences of scenarios, abilities, special powers, encounters, etc. etc..... and then reading the rules some more to make sure we're doing everything right.

No thanks.  I'd rather have simpler rules, shorter play time, and actually be "playing" for most of that time.

Having said all that, it appears that the game has a lot of thought and production value put into it.  I can appreciate that, but it just isn't my cup of tea.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is more of an experience than a game.  Lots of randomness, not enough variety in the encounters, and lack of clarity in the rules drags down an otherwise very strong theme.  More of a choose your own adventure co-op game than a normal boardgame.  

This is the kind of game that I might play once a year, with the right group, but no more than that.  

This game needs some serious streamlining to be enjoyable.  Downgrading to a 4 after a 4.5 hours (victorious) game.

1 (4.5 hour) play, 5 players
1 (incomplete) play, 6 players
1 play, 7 players

RATING: 8.5
This game gets too much of a bad rap.  It's totally cooperative, but unlike Pandemic, it doesn't lend itself to someone quarterbacking the experience.  There are lots of things to do, and the game is different each time, since besides the different character powers and weapons/items in play, there can be a different Big Bad to defeat!

Not a short game, and there are a zillion pieces and cards around to increase setup time, but I think it's worth it.  Also, it's good to have a slightly heavier game that can incorporate so many players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Average rulebook, game is a bit too much on the heavy side compared to the original game, but otherwise, the ultimate Lovecraft themed boardgame, action, horror and fantasy all the way. The fact that it has been expanded so much by FFG is great.

I found that the first edition "dark" board was better than the "corrected" one...

I must add that I don't understand why I read so many comments these days about how "heavy" it is (i'm talking the game alone, without the expansions). This is really the same weight and length for me as many so called "heavy" boardgames, like "Merchants and Marauders", "Dune", "Fury of Dracula", "Twilight Struggle", "Age of Conan", "Labyrinth"... 

But it sure is not heavier than them and does not at all deserve to be called "dauntingly heavy" or so. This is game that can be played in one evening, two games can be played in an afternoon...  Certainly not the monster game that it sometimes is called these days...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A 10 because it is in Spanish too!!!! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Looooooooooong. Played with 7 players... lots of down time and got mind-numbingly dull. However, I will play again - with a smaller group and see if this one cant get redeemed. Can so many BGG'ers be wrong??

UPDATE: 04-25-09

Played it with the CVW again last night after a long hiatus. I was pretty solid on the rules, but there is still a lot going on here and the initial explanation of everything takes a bit of time. Like before, I could tell that people were anxious to play, so I kept the explanations as short as possible and taught the game as we played out the first turn.

It took a few turns to get the flow going right, but once we did, everyone enjoyed the game. I think the sweet spot is 4-5 players as more tends to bog the game down - unless EVERYONE is comfortable with how to play.

We still made mistakes in some rules - but we corrected as we played and pushed on. We lost the game to the GOO that ends the game immediately if it ever awakens - we weren't paying attention and sealing enough gates - otherwise we might have had a chance.

Upgraded to a solid 8.5 and with plenty of interest to play again in the group.

UPDATE: 30-OCT-2010

Upgraded to a solid 9. We are now able to sit-down and PLAY the game without constant rule look-ups which increases the fun and decreases the playing time. The mechanics are now 2nd nature and we can focus on the strategy and game play instead of "what happens next?".

UPDATE: 12-10-2013

We got to play this two weekends in a row a few weeks ago (lost both games!) and it was a complete hoot! Arkham Horror has only steadily climbed up my ratings chart. It's tremendously fiddly with all kinds of exceptions and things that you have to try and remember, but once you have the basic flow down this all becomes much easier and you can simply focus on what needs to be done. Add in an expansion and watch the game take on a whole new feeling - Innsmouth is probably my favorite for this effect.

...[b] Abstract [/b]...__________[]...[b]Themed [/b].....
.........[b] Luck [/b]...______[]____...[b] Skill [/b]...........
......[b] Simple [/b]...________[]__...[b] Complex [/b]...
..[b] Strategic [/b]..._______[]___...[b] Tactical [/b]....
....[b] Friendly [/b]...__[]________...[b] Cutthroat [/b]..

I think this game is very tiring. It´s a lot of rules, a lot of details, a lot of dice, a lot of paperwork, for so little decision making. And the playing time does not help at all.

The problem is: my wife just loves it! But I convinced her to play Zombicide instead of AH. It´s not so immersive but it takes considerably less time.

RATING: 9
What a pleasure! Is it a game? Yes, but it's also a good story telling tool! Of course, avoid to play it under the bright sunshine of a beautifull summer day, and without the italic fun text! Choose your music, your room, your friends, your evening,... and enter the world of HPL. Replace the "token" with the depicted monter in your mind, read and figure out the scene in your mind... play this game as you read a book or as you see a movie! This is more an "adventure" game than a "strategy" game.

RATING: 9
Well it's a classic, I always want to play it, and never cease to amaze me. Yes it have a lot of fault: a play can last for hours and hours, it is impossible to play (to win) if you have 3 or less players.. you have some chance starting to 4 or more players.. and it's really really luck based. But I totally like the atmosfere, the story event are intriguing, the fight with monster difficoult in line with the story, you can play it 10 times, and it will be 10 times different. If you apply the expansion well it will never became boring. Yes to me is the game that resemble more the original story background of H.P. lovercraft.
And lastly it's a cooperative game, that's the point. When it appeared on the market it was one of the few coopeerative games, so I really love it for that reason.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A perennial favorite, and one that I credit with getting my group into modern-day board games. Love the co-op, love the, erm, Lovecraft, love the production values, love the encounters and story text and narrative opportunities.

You haven't lived until you've played a drifter forced to sacrifice his dog to a hideously betentacled beast in the streets just so the nun can charge in on a motorcycle wielding a flamethrower and wipe out the beasties. Yeah. It's that kind of game.

Playing time can be long (although nobody ever mentions the fact that it can also be quite short depending on how the game goes) and the original rulebook isn't terribly well written, but get an expansion or two and you've got an evergreen game for your collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Still my favorite co-op game.  Sure, it's got dice and theme and tons and tons of cards.  I've come to terms with it.

RATING: 8
Theme! The feeling of overwhelming odds only getting worse is bang-on for Lovecraft country; yes, it is totally random, but the atmosphere is excellent. My only gripe is just how random and characterless the otherworld encounters are, but I never did enjoy Lovecraft's Dreamlands much. The components are lovely, it's easy to see what is going on at any time (maybe the gates could have higher contrast to the board, but they're not hard to find. The art on the box makes me laugh: nobody seems too worried by the tentacles - business as usually in Arkham!

RATING: 8.75
This is one of those games that you have to be in the mood for.  It has a huge learning curve...our first game took about 4 hours, and we were constantly referring to the rule-book!  Once you get the gist of the game mechanics, it is one of the most immersive gaming experiences around.  Truthfully, this game is a punishing, non-stop pain in the butt...but when you want a challenging co-op, this is the one you go for!  The expansions are good for adding variety to the "encounters" phase, but can make the gameplay ridiculously overwhelming and unwieldy.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Solo: My first play of AH was also my first-ever solo game apart from Solitaire, purchased primarily for that purpose. It rocked. (Initial rating: 8.)

There's a ton of luck, which I don't usually like, but it's more than mitigated by the story that emerges over the course of the game, the mood, the Lovecraftian feel, and the fun factor. As a huge fan of both HPL and Call of Cthulhu, I expected to like all that stuff but was concerned the luck factor would still be too high; it wasn't.

I played (and won, which means I probably did something wrong) a two-investigator game over the course of a couple of days, leaving it set up on my desk -- where it barely fits. Loads of fun solo.

---

Months later, my first solo play remains my only play. Compared to the many other solo options that are now in my collection, notably Eldritch Horror, the fiddliness factor and length of Arkham have prevented me from wanting to play it. I re-rated it a 6 (down from an 8), sat on it for a couple months, and then sold it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Ok, I know that this game is not perfect. It can be long, have too many rules, is not so much cooperative as it promote itself, need lot of space, sometimes it maybe loosing atmosphere. All of it are good points, however for me this is still great game and I don't even have all expansions yet. First of all I need to say, that for me this is more survival, then cooperative game, but the coop still works for me good enough, when all the players will realize, that not all of them, will make it to the end and put the goal to win in front of they own survival. Also this game is not for players who are in rush to end it, this game is about enjoying the atmosphere and its really important how the people will approach this game. Role playing makes it more fun. And the best part is that each game is different.

RATING: 7
Fun game for sure. I can't say if it fully lives up to the hype as I've only played a few games. I wasn't bothered by the playtime or luck elements. It's an app that deals with all the location card drawing and shuffling. Since you don't even need to take the location cards out of the box, this saves a ton of time.

RATING: 10
5 / 5 - Great

Hokey horror fun for everyone! Clever design which limits (but doesn't eliminate) the impact of the co-op baggage (playing by rote, dictatorial players etc) at the cost of considerable complexity and administration overheads. Also has a big dose of game-plays-you rather than you-play-game but there's plenty of interesting risk management decisions to be made nevertheless. Generates fantastic tension and narrative but the theme feels more Buffy than Lovecraft with monsters swarming everywhere for our intrepid heroes to gun down. Challenging and fun played solo. Read my review here: http://fortressat.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1203&Itemid=551
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A creaking, groaning monster of theme, text, mechanics and tokens. A simple game disguised as a complex one, and mechanically full of crap things like 'miss a turn'. Despite all that it is excessive and glorious in its ability to crank out those moments in gaming which you'll talk about for years to come.

Never play with more than 5 people unless you like downtime big enough to play a separate filler game between your turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fails by taking far too long time to implement systems that aren't that interesting. Setup time is also a downer.

Being fair, the people that brought the game over didn't really know the rules (even though they had played more than a handful of times), so there were some capital mistakes that made the game boring.

Anyway, after having said that and reading the rules, I cannot see this game having far too much value for it's mechanics, it's all in the visual and text, it's all about the theme, and still, it takes far too long for a game that has theme, possibly as it's only strength.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Went into this game with high enthusiasm. By two hours, I was yawning non-stop and hoping it'd end. Game ended early in the forth hour in a lost. I'm not saying its a bad game. Three of the six players expressed that they had an enjoyable time. Not me.

1. Down time.
2. Ridiculous bad-luck. I tried to strategise, plan, but unable to roll a "5" or "6" for the longest time. Imagine three hours of sitting there helpless. Even the most "walk-over" combat where I get to roll seven (7!) dice, I couldn't get a single "5" or "6". Tell me, how can anyone enjoy this game (session)?
3. Game mechanics make it take long time to accomplish anything meaningful. Close gate? 1 walk there, 2 go other world, 3 still in other world, 4 attempt to seal. Seal gate? 4   X to collect 5 clues. Collect clues? Wait for each mythos or kill monster (1 walk there) to collect 5 monster toughness (x5) to exchange (1 walk there; total = 6 turns). However, you're likely to need to heal your stamina or especially sanity as many monsters are physical resistant. So add about 3 turns for total 9.

"Likely won't play this again although could be convinced. Bad."

Update: 3 » 2. Managed to be convinced into another game. Tried to be positive to the game and tried to enjoy it. Rolled much better this time round. However, the game is still overwhelmingly unengaging. The decision making time vs time required for execution is mind-numbingly long. I find myself having a much better time role-playing the time-travelling of Khronos than monster-fighting in Arkham Horror (Is that bad?). Someone has to give me a really good reason to play this game ever again. The time required for this psychological and mental torture, I'd rather sleep, or really, anything else.

One bad session of Arkham Horror could have been three awesome sessions of BattleLore (substitute with your favourite one hour game).

"Extremely annoying game, won't play this ever again."

RATING: 8.5
What can I say about Arkham Horror? How about: It's the most fun you can have getting your ass kicked by a diabolical board game. Arkham Horror is a lovely jaunt in to the world of H.P. Lovecraft and his successors. Featuring great artwork and excellent representations of the Cthulhu Mythos, Arkham Horror rates as one of the best atmospheric board games on the market.

It is, however, among the most dizzyingly complex board games ever made with more cards, tokens, and counters than you can shake a stick at.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(+ de parties non référencées)
noté en prenant les extensions en compte

Le plus gros défaut pour moi est la difficulté mal réglée du jeu : plus la partie avance, plus elle est simple à cause des portails scellés bloquant les invasions.
De plus la répartition très inégale des lieux d'ouverture de portail tend à augmenter les vagues de monstre et les blocages par scellé, donc ralentit l'avancée de l'échelle du GA.

Gros problème sur l'apparition du GA, seulement 11 lieux instables dont certains très rares, si par exemple 5 scellés + 3 portails ouverts et échelle GA à 7 ou 8, il ne reste que 3 lieux possibles, donc si l'échelle du GA est à 12 ou 13 par exemple, il n'y a presque aucune chance qu'il apparaisse de cette manière. L'échelle de terreur devrait compenser ce problème, hors elle augmente trop peu (à peu de joueurs surtout, et sans rumeur particulière ou autre mécanisme optionnel).
=> l'irruption de portail des extensions est une fausse correction, car (officiellement) l'échelle du GA n'avance pas, donc ça rallonge seulement la partie.
=> au contraire les cartes mythe avec double avancée de l'échelle de GA (à la place d'une ouverture de portail) est une meilleure idée. mais ça réduit les vagues de monstres donc ralentit l'avancée de la terreur.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a game I've played on my own several times, and with small groups of friends. It can be played with 8 players but it makes it into a very long game. Personally i find around 3 with 2 characters each is a good spot. hard to win but satisfying to play. Love the theme and i believe the game represents it well. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game. It is very RPG-like. Complicated, and very dark.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is beautifully atmospheric and drips with Cthulu theme as the investigators cooperate to try to close and seal gates and slay (and avoid) monsters.  Meaty, like a good hearty stew  - if only the game didn't take so long (budget on 4 hours + per game).

If playing solo, I'd rather use the Vassal boardgaming module then bother unloading all the pieces.  In fact, I highly recommend that anyone considering this game first either play in person, or test it via the Vassal app (both PC and Mac compatible)

As with most games with a reasonable level of complexity, plays better with more experienced players – who can help share the rules load.

While Cthulu is a great thematic universe,  here the implementation it isn't tied well enough to the mechanics for my liking.  There seems to be a lot of errand running.   And honestly, I doubt that a bunch of investigators could serious take on an old one.  

I get that this is an adventure game of story telling, but I'd much rather have a more open ended story arrangement such as Tales of the Arabian Nights, or something more focused like the Relic implementation of Talisman.  Or a Cthulu game with a much more personal encounter with terror (as the Cthulu books I've read have conveyed).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Have only played this solitaire (solo) and still love it.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Good theme; can be interesting in a large group if the personalities are right (but that has little to do with the game, really); usual Fantasy Flight goofy rulebook (though far from the worst); long, really quite long; it can be quite abstract.

It's not clear where the game is here: your turn might last 30 seconds, after which you'll endure a 20 minute wait for more action (in, for example, a 5 player game). Decision points are arbitrary or obvious: the game often seems to happen to you. Often, you'll spend several turns making no decisions whatsoever (e.g. once you've gone through a gate or end up in the asylum).

It's an awful lot of effort to enact a pretty static "story."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good: 
Great components. 

The theme is conveyed while exploring the city by encounters, locations, and monsters. It feels like the characters are in a Cthulhu world trying to uncover an ancient evil.

The game is pretty well balanced. We win some we lose some but we always had fun.

Bad: 
Games have improved in mechanics and pacing since this was released. It is just a little bit too slow and too long to be something that will ever end up hitting the table anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Summary of negative points I’ve seen in other poster’s comments:

Takes too long.
No seriously, too long. 
Lots and lots and lot and lots of rules.
Not many real choices. 
Lots of luck (though here I’m not sure how much I agree when you can plan for dice roll odds). 

Summary of the positive points I’ve seen in other poster’s comments:
Co-op game
Fun theme
Role playing aspect

My conclusions
What theme, what roleplaying? I must have missed something entirely. You move around, you do what the card says, you roll some dice. Next. 

I don’t mean to belittle it because I’m fine with dice fest stuff, but I find you really get 2 plays: either you win very quickly by closing all gates, or you take forever and have the showdown with the monster. There might be some tension there, but it’s just not enough. 

And goodness you need a large area to play the thing in the first place. I like the idea, but I think I might need to see some of the expansions as well, but I don’t think I ever will because I have so many other games that play faster, easier to learn (and teach) and with as much fun factor (or more). 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I play this once a year or so because it takes 3 hours to play and requires a weekend game workshop to review the rules and and teach other players. Still, playing this game can be an extremely immersive thematic experience. To recap: Awesome game. LONG and high-maintenance, but awesome.

RATING: 9

I find it more enjoyable than "Tales of Arabian Nights" because it feels like there is a known purpose, rather than the random wandering of TAN.  I would suggest this game for 1~4 players to keep it manageable.  The short encounters have some good flavor for stories and the artwork for the bits and pieces is great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Arkham Horror is the poster boy for the sentiment "a great theme doesn't make a great game."

The theme is terrific.  The game is practically nonexistent--your choices boil down to "do I want to go to Area A and have something random happen, or do I want to go to Area B and have something random happen?"  Add a soul-crushing amount of bookkeeping to make things even less fun.

You want theme?  In the time it takes to play a short game of Arkham Horror, you can read three or four of Lovecraft's stories.  In the time it takes you to play a long game, you can read all of "The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath."  It'll be way more fun, trust me.

I gave this game away to a buddy on two conditions: one, he never ask me to play it.  Two, no backs.

Rules: Arcane
Setup time: Monstrous
Play time: Aeons
Fun: Endless void
Strategy level: Chaotic
Condition of player after a game: Gibbering and insane

Lovecraft would be proud.

Rating falls from a 3 to a 2 because I realized that the only reason I would ever play this again is if everybody else wanted to and they needed me to make up a minimum number of players.  Then I remembered that this can be played solitaire...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A lot of fun, but mostly it's a wild pile of components. Amazing numbers of cards, tokens, bits and pieces, so it takes a while to set up especially with the expansions. Can get quite tense, though, and end in misery (for the investigators).

RATING: 7
I like the idea of the cooperation game versus the system.  Downtime for each player is not long at all - which is important in a long game like this.

want to play again now that I have some idea of what is going on.

1/09 - going to revise this down.  Becomes a bit repetitive for my tastes.  Cooperation can make things easy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
I think I've rated this game fairly. I like Arkham Horror but it's not one to just pick up and play. You need to be in the right mood, with the right people and be prepared for a long game with a number of components and variables to keep track of. Saying that, when all elements click, this game is an unforgettable experience with all players running around trying to deal with monsters and gates that seem to pop up with no end; while at the same time trying not to 'die' and also improve your character to deal with situations more effectively as they come up. Don't play this game if you're looking for strategy, impeccably balanced mechanics, calculating moves, cost-benefit analysis, bluffs etc. You play this game because it brilliantly creates a tense sense of drama and looming doom - and no matter if in the end you win or loose, you'll all be left with a satisfying feeling of having encountered something truly other-worldly and lived to tell the tale. Beats watching a movie!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my greatest surprises in 2005 was how well Arkham Horror was redone.  The new game is splendid and reaffirms the heavy theme of the original, but with vastly superior rules and components.  It is a cooperative game that forces players to work together very well and the board can light up and with concerted effort be brought under control just to flare again.  Madness is everywhere...  Play it.

RATING: 6
Okay - let me explain.  I am not a Cthulhu fanatic.  I recently tried the RPG and I must say it was an absolute blast.  The gradual depletion of sanity is hilarious.  Therefore, I am glad I tried this board game version and I could see how people very interested in the mythos/world would love it.

There would have been a time this game would have been adored by my group. But that time was approx 20 years ago.  As such Talisman still remains my pick for all things nostalgia.

The game is quite long and there is quite a bit of downtown esp in a 5  player game.  

In the game I played the Big Horror made his way to Arkham and in turn the final 1/2 hr boiled down to pure dice rolling.  This left me quite dissatisfied and I certainly don't mind a long game!

Fun for an occasional play but I doubt I will be adding this to my collection.

RATING: 6

I wasn't previously a fan of HPL or the whle Cthulu thing, but the theme/art/design/production value in AH are excellent and really get you into the game. Again I'm docking points for what probably isn't the game's fault: It's hard to  get people to play this a second time.

Edit 11/20/09: I'm dropping this because although I like it well enough, I really do need to be in the right mood to play this type of game.

RATING: 6.5
After one solo and and one 3-player game there's still too much too learn about this game to give it a definitive rating.

+ The atmospheric factor.

RATING: 5
Just received, but no play yet. The components overall are stunning, both in appearance and physical quality. Anyway, for less than $35 from Boulder Games, I don't see how you can go wrong.

Edit: I've played numerous times now. It's fun for people who like the topic, and don't mind the fiddly play. It's pretty process heavy for a lighter game. It's not something I'd like to play all the time, but I can be talked into it. RATING: 9.9
Pros: Loads of fun, thematic, dramatic, satisfying to win but still fun to lose, good variety for lots of replayability
Cons: Overly complex rules, too long, mythos cards can be swingy and make game much easier or harder
Conclusion: I have played this game a lot and have probably had more fun in total than any other board game. Once you get used to the rules and setup, it's tons of fun and a lot more strategic than people give it credit for. Plays best with 3 investigators. Starts to slow down with more.

RATING: 7
I picked this up for myself after playing it back when it came out. I hated it then, but the request of my group pushed me into making a swap for it here on BGG. Contrary to popular belief, setup is a lot easier than I remember (thanks 2008 Revision) and the game played a lot smoother than I remembered. I would say that this is a game you have to study before playing. We actually keep the Wiki up on my laptop as we play just in case something weird comes up.  You will do a lot of legwork in this game--setup included--to lose 90% of the time.  But when you do win, how sweet it is.
