RATING: 9
A very good coop game that does a wonderful job with the subject matter.  You'll have to power through the rulebook a bit, but download the excellent flow chart, and it will all fall into place.  It looks a lot more daunting than it really is.

Components are great, (Make a bunch of those paperclip stand-up holders so you can see the gates and monsters better.)  Tons of items and options.  This is one of the few games that I left out on the table after playing the first time, since I wanted to play it again as soon as I could.

The time to play is a little long, but you will be so immersed in the story that the time will fly by.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Game in a Nutshell: Cooperative game of running around Arkham City, and into other dimensions, to live out events as read off cards, build up character stats, and fight evil monsters by way of dice.

Played as: Solo, 2 player

Pros: Creative text, excellent artwork, and the best integration of theme of any game I've played makes this feel like you're living out a story rather then playing through a game. Cooperating, instead of competing, is a good change of pace because when you're down on your luck, you can still find ways to help out 'the team' (that's a big plus in a game that can last as long as this). And finally, if you can't find someone to play with, you can play by yourself.

Cons: Hands down the hardest game I've ever tried to learn how to play. You have my pity if you're learning this game on your own like I did. The game can be fiddly with so much stuff to remember at any given point it's easy to let it all overshadow one's ability to focus on the story (This wains with experience, but may come back if played infrequently). The biggest downfall is the game-length can take even experienced players as many as four hours (more if you're learning). Because of that, I've rated it where I have since it's a hard game to suggest.

Other: It took me three games before I could get it played under 4 hours (the first was over 7). The difference was how much I had to wade through the rules. Because of all that I think I've learned it's best just to play, make your best guess about the rules, write down questions, and keep playing. Save the rules deciphering for post game, because chances are the game can be enjoyable even when not played entirely correct, but can be a drag with excessive rule-searching down-time.

More Other: My feelings for this game took a big hit as soon as I played Tales of the Arabian Nights. I does everything AH did best (theme, creative text, storytelling) and does it so much better. All that without the excessive game length, nit-picky rules, or relative inaccessibility. I've traded the game away with the only fear of missing it as a solo experience.

Best Use: Played as an planned event or solo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Game has had a few plays. Cards and components are in excellent shape.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Arkham Horror es un juego de tablero colaborativo ambientado en las novelas y relatos cortos de H.P. Lovecraft. Los jugadores deberán de ponerse deacuerdo y trabajar duro para evitar que un endiablado ser primigenio se materialice en Arkham y con ello acabe con la raza humana. Los monstruos representan las criaturas y seres de otros mundos que aparecen en los relatos de Lovecraft. Te recomendaría leerte el relato "La noche de los tiempos", donde aparecen los pólipos volantes y la Gran Raza y te sorprenderías de la cantidad de cosas que el juego representa con completa fidelidad. Estamos acostumbrados por culpa de muchas peliculas de terror adolescente a que los monstruos son con cuatro extremidades, o en su defecto, sueltan babas y tienen ojos de gato o reptil... por poner un ejemplo. El terror que empleaba Lovecraft y en lo que fue, sencillamente, un auténtico genio, fue en darle a las criaturas de sus relatos un aspecto totalmente desconocido, e incluso primitivo. Incluso más desconocido y extraño para la razón humana. Ellos fueron los Primigenios, ellos son los auténticos supervivientes de este y otros mundos. Ellos están aquí desde los tiempos. Y quizá su aspecto no ha evolucionado como la raza humana debería esperar. Recuerda el nombre: pólipo. Su aspecto es el de un gran tonel esponjoso, totalmente primitivo, sin evolucionar... el terror está en que ellos si han evolucionado, pero en otro aspectos... e incluso experimentaron con los seres unicelulares y crearon al hombre por error... ¿porqué vamos a esperar que tengan ojos (es decir, que tengan más "descubrir" que un ghul) si ellos no se dedican a ir cazando a diestro y siniestro? Eso sí, que no te enganche ninguno, porque te cruje. Vamos, resumiendo, es pura recreación del mundo de los Mitos. Y el juego es bastante fien es ese sentido.
Al igual que pasa con el juego de rol, aquí no se incentiva los combates, sino cómo derrotar los monstruos sin que salgas muy mal parado. El combate es sencillo: le plantas cara al monstruo. Si no te da un ataque de locura, intentas darle la ostia. Pero si fallas, no te vas de rositas.
Arkham es un juego totalmente configurable. Es más, el autor original del juego recomienda que cada grupo adapte reglas del manual o incluso añada nuevas según sus necesidades. Hay reglas para hacer a los monstruos letales, reiniciando el juego con nuevos personajes. Incluso hay un programa con el que te puedes crear tu propio personaje e imprimirlo tal y como las fichas de los jugadores. Es decir, hay todo un abanico de posibilidades para adaptar el juego a los gustos y necesidades del grupo.
Considero que si no te llama nada la temática lovecraftiana este juego te pasará totalmente desapercibido. En cambio, a la gente que nos encanta los relatos del escritor de Providence, nos parece una auténtica pasada. Han conseguido hacer un juego de tablero lo suficientemente profundo como para representar el ambiente de terror de las novelas de Lovecraft. Y encima, funciona por sí solo. Los monstruos se mueven solos, los sucesos van hilando una historia...
Mi opinión personal es que Arkham es un juego que requiere 2 o 3 partidas para acabar de integrar todas sus reglas, pero una vez hecho, gana mucho. Está claro que ni de lejos va a reemplazar una partida de rol, pero no creo que ese fuera el caso de los creadores de juego. La idea, básicamente, es que los jugadores colaboren entre sí para solucionar los problemas que se le plantean. En mi opinión, como amante de juegos de mesa, le daría un merecido 8 porque se le nota que es un juego muy trabajado en cuanto a la mecánica. Además visualmente es acojonante y permite una rejugabilidad muy sorprendente (nunca jugarás 2 partidas iguales). El trasfondo ambiental está muy logrado. Y la novedad de que los jugadores no compiten entre sí, sino contra el tablero, para mí fue nuevo.
Puntos negativos:
No es un juego para jugar pensando en la hora en la que tienes que acabar, porque te puede llevar de 2 a 3 horas acabar una partida.
El trasfondo es un aliciente pero también una losa para aquellos jugadores que no les mola las novelas de lovecraft o simplemente, prefieren matar bichos.
Tantos componentes en la mesa acaban mareando a los jugadores.
Requiere un estudio concienzudo de las reglas y el tablero. No es un juego para jugar deprisa y corriendo.
Lecturas recomendadas de relatos muy cortos por órden de preferencia (muchos está en la red):
"La declaración de Randolph Carter" <- terror en estado puro.
"En la noche de los tiempos"
"La sombra sobre Innsmouth"
"La llamada de Cthulhu"
"El ceremonial"
"El horror de Dunwich" <- Muchas localizaciones del tablero parten de este relato, así como algunos aliados como el Dr. Henry Armitage
"Los que vigilan desde el tiempo"

RATING: 5
I think my rating for this will go up when the game finally beats us.

And I tried to like this game.

RATING: 10
I have revised my rating of all things Arkham Horror to a 10. That's right. I did it. The madness overtook me, and I like it. I could entertain the argument that, purely on mechanics, this is not a 10. But this is an experience game for me, one that generates great narratives and leaves me spent and exhilarated and eager to play again.

My only complaint--and I mean only--is that the end game seems anticlimactic when the enemy awakens and you fight it. I'd actually prefer to win or lose based on whether the Old One awakens, but of course that would require some tweaking. I know, I know, you smartass, there's an Old One who wins automatically if he/she/it wakes up.

The buildup is great. Lots of table talk, lots of cool cards, lots of cool events, lots of equipment, lots of choices, the time really flies by and a good group makes this game lots of fun. If you really get into the theme and have fun with your character, you will have fun playing this game and watching a very tense narrative unfold. If you are that kind of player, you must play this game. If it didn't take so much time and table space to set up, mega Arkham with all the expansions would likely be my favorite gaming experience.

I can't believe how much table space this requires, especially with the expansions. Yikes!

The rules do seem fiddly when you read them. But the game is actually fairly easy to pick up once you get going. Don't delay--play it!

I have played this thrice now with all the expansions, and it is truly a mind-altering experience. Utter madness. Sheer, howling death on a velvet platter crafted in Hell and hand-delivered by a murderous, nymphomaniac lovebot more or less shaped like Jessica Alba. Yes, it is that good. You should crawl into its embrace, sniff its bloodied glove and beg it to devour you. Go now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The fellows at "Shut Up, Sit Down" described it as "an H.P. Lovecraft story-telling engine," which is rather a brilliant summation. This is almost a roller-coaster in terms of player agency, but it almost condenses a lengthy CoC role-playing experience into only 4 hours. A demented masterpiece.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I love it.  A game that forces you to press your luck and adapt to difficult situations the entire way through.  Not only do different character/skill pairings create specialized roles, but each character's role will change drastically throughout the game as their resources and health grow and diminish.

That said, it is so devastating to risk everything and wrestle through this game for 3 hours to reach a moment where something catastrophic occurs and all our progress is undone.  More often than not, we disregard the rules in such cases and throw out nasty mythos cards in order to persevere and reach the ending that we've "earned."  The game requires too much investment to let bad luck ruin it in the end.  I don't like playing a game that makes me want to cheat rather than take the loss like a man.

But it's a cooperative game, so as long as we all agree that our cheating is justified, a good time is had by all.  Isn't that what matters?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ate a pickled egg, then died, would do again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a game that I love deeply for the theme and general gameplay premise of investigators adventuring for clues. Each element is well-matched to the theme, and I love FFG's slightly cartoon-ized version of Lovecraft's worlds. Each expansion adds, sometimes quite literally, a new dimension to the game. The way you can adopt pieces of each expansion for your game, mixing and matching to find the right balance for your group from the vast library of expansions both large and small, brings this game to an excellent rating of 9.

What drops it a full point from 10 is the tedium. While the game at times feels like a big, cog-ridden grandfather clock that you gleefully watch tick away while you try to save Arkham, it also sometimes feels like you get into a rhythm, with your teammates, effectively controlling the board, and still have to play for hours to complete it. In this way it has a slight fatigue element, and it seems the only way to fix it is to house-rule it so as to remove elements and obstacles, thus reducing difficulty. It is a tough balance, but this is what keeps Arkham from being perfect, and stops my group from playing it, and sends us to other boardgames, or Call of Cthulhu RPG.

Only have played a few solo games.

RATING: 5

People often consider this game to be one of the end-all-be-all of board gaming. I can't say I agree. If I had my choice of games that took as long as this one does, Through the Ages is the game of choice. 

I feel its length and non-evolving game play keep it from penetrating a greater audience. It's a shame due to it's rich fantasy. This is the main reason why it receives the score I've given it. 

If only this game was shorter and had the ability to allow newcomers into its rich lore... Oh wait -- Elder Sign is now available :p

RATING: 7
First, it screams the theme. The text in the cards is great, the art on the board and on the cards are beautiful. The problem is there is not much interaction/cooperation, everyone is desperate trying to seal some gates (which is maybe the intention of the game designer) or kill monster by themselves. Still, the game is complete randomness. Is good because everytime you play a completely different game, but luck plays a way too strong role in such a complex game. And you have only a limited number of real choices to interfere in the game (walk / adjust the stats / spend a clue to re-roll). Still, the game is really FUN to play. Recommended.

RATING: 8.5
If you like the atmosphere of H.P.Lovecraft's stories, you will like the atmosphere of this game - it picks it up perfectly! The mechanics is not too complex, yet offers very rich playing experience with medium strategic choices. The artwork is truly stunning! Due to inherent randomness, some 30% of games tend to be a complete miss - it could be a too easy win, too brutal a defeat, or a game could drag for 10 moves, never really getting anywhere. The replay value is immense - we've probably had like a hundred games so far (with the expansions). All in all, one of the best games in my collection.

RATING: 8
(020914) Arkham Horror is an odd bird in my collection. I rarely play it, since it takes a very long time. The game feels good (and having all your chits and bits in compartments helps with the setup), conveys an excellent HPL-feel and even though the rules are rather opaque, they are functional. Perhaps the reason I feel so strongly for this game is because I've done a lot of roleplaying in my past?

(311014) I've been on a real Arkham kick lately, playing up to two games a day and taking it on another spin today (of course with Innsmouth). I feel that the BGG additives really help with the rules - especially the wonderful flowchart. The game, at its best is really thematic, wonderfully engaging and really feels like an adventure in the town of Arkham. At it's worst it's nothing but a punishing chit-fest that forces you to redraw an investigator every two turns because you only seem to draw Mythos cards that spawn monsters and encounters that kill off investigators with no chance of averting them. The score of 8 still holds - it's a blast when it works, it's spiteful when it doesn't.

RATING: 9
Just the base game can keep you occupied a while.  If you can learn to cope with the tornado of fiddliness that this game evokes there is a real jewel of insanity underneath.  A winner for adventure games fans or Lovecraftians.  The player aids/flowcharts in the file section are a must!  This game is especially fun if you play with someone who has the rules internalized and can "run" the game while everyone else enjoys the ride.  Rating assumes you're toughening it up a little with the official RL variants or an expansion.

Beware the flood of expansions. . .until the base game becomes too easy for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Improve your investigator, pass skill checks and combat monsters to prevent the Great Old One from rising.

Plays: A couple.
Type: Thematic cooperative game – a theme-driven game where you play together against the game.
Complexity: Heavy cooperative game.
# of players: 1.
Playing time: Several hours.
Player interaction: Best played solo. Otherwise cooperation. 
Randomness: High – dice and card and tile draw with high impact and little control.

Replayability: Decent for solitaire. It’s a long and very random game. You play it to enjoy the ride. Those that enjoy the ride will probably want to play again. There are many different investigators and Great Old Ones, so each game will be a little bit different from the beginning.
Fun: Sure. The bastardized Lovecraft world is a fun place. Combating ancient evil is fun. Drawing cards is exciting, they are often high impact and you draw lots of them. Going insane from mythos exposure is fun and thematic. 
Memorability: Decent. All the random stuff happening comes together to tell a story. You're not just managing resources, you're desperately trying to save the world!

Thematic integration: Very good. This is designed theme first.  It's a bastardized Lovecraft theme, as in most games. The Lovecraft stories are more often about things not seen, while the game has you combat monsters directly.
Components: Decent. I would have liked plastic monster figures, but there are lots of cards and chits and producing the game with minis would probably have made it prohibitively expensive. The art is standard horror stuff. The box is heavy, you feel you get your money's worth.
Expansions: Definitely get Dunwich Horror for improved variety and the madness and injury cards (lasting effects of insanity and unconsciousness). It bugged me that the base game lets investigators shrug off temporary insanity.

Who will like this: Gamers that have plenty of time, like the theme and play for the experience more than for the outcome. Probably best solitaire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There was a time when my friends and I would finish a game of Arkham Horror and start another one right up, we loved it so much. Different time, 2005. There's still stuff here worth seeing, but it's so much work to see it and a lot of other games scratch similar itches without needing 3 hours and 2 tables.

RATING: 8
Fun game.

Only problem with this is that the rules were written by Fantasy Flight.

Fantasy Flight rules:  Explain one concept in contradictory ways among several non-consecutive pages, and among these pages leave out necessary instructions on how the rule operates correctly...put that part of the rule in with the pictured example example, but leave it out of the rule explanation completely.

Fantasy Flight does this ALL the time in every game they produce.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
This game is deliciously complicated, in an eldritch way.  The fact is, this game requires a LOT of time set aside; a series of gamers who thrive on complexity; and people willing to very probably lose to the game's intense enemies. I read all of Lovecraft's content and enjoyed the general presentation and ideas... and while the game does a good job of capturing many aspects of the set-dressing I enjoyed so much, the playability issues (requiring at least 2 different "quick" reference sheets) means it sat for a very long time without being played.  Sold, it was.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good purely cooperative board game which can be played solo.  Extremely thematic, visually pleasing, and quite variable with different roles to play and baddies to fight.

The rules are a bit steep to learn -- mostly just the book-keeping though (when to move chit A or number X on chit B  plus number Y on sheet C means to roll Z dice). The game play itself is quite straight forward.  Having one person in charge of knowing these things and asking as a 'keeper' of sorts helps smooth things out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It isn't a game, it's a work of art. I'm still looking on it and I'm whispering: "my preciousss..." ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Deeply thematic game, complex rules, lots of playing bits, and many options for strategizing and gameplay. This game runs very long (3-4 hrs), and may not lead to successes often. I downloaded FAQs gamer guides for guidance and clarification on rules. Love this game for the richness of rules, variation of characters/monsters, strategies, and difficulty. Tough like Ghost Stories, but with much more depth and options.

RATING: 6
Amellett, hogy baromi hangulatos, meg egész jól kitalált maga a játék, ugyanaz a bajom vele, mint úgy általában a többi ameris játékkal: 1-2 órán belül elérkezik az a pont, amikor a folyamatos kockadobálgatások és az 5-6-ra (sikeres dobásra) várás már agyoncsapja az egészet és onnantól számomra majdhogynem élvezhetetlen. Ezen a ponton túl már a történet is kezd hidegen hagyni, csak szörnyek és kockák és kapuk és az a rohadt sok kártya, amit már rég elfelejtettem, mi van nálam, mert már három órája ülök és csak dobálok.

A hangulata tök rendben van, meg az egész körítés. De tényleg. Csak az az istenverte, nyomorult kocka miatt az egész olyan, mint egy kaland-játék-kockázat könyv, amikor dobsz egy kockával, majd az alapján sérülsz, mész tovább, találsz valamit a helyszínen, támad meg szörny, stb, hogy mit dobtál.

Valakinek ez biztos marha izgalmas, én inkább euróznék helyette.

Inzertet kivettem, gyalázat.

Más most meg nem jut eszembe már, mert baromi késő van és úgy négy órát görnyedtem a táblája fölött kockavetős mantrákat morogva. Kérem, kapcsolja ki.

Update (2018.02.12.): Nem nagyon került, így inkább eladtam.

RATING: 3
I love this game, I really do, but it just takes so damn long...the setup and tear down time is a killer too.

I think our group tends to futz around too much before closing gates. The sense of urgency that comes later in the game needs to be there from the beginning. I'll play this more if we learn how to keep the games under 3 hours.

My wife fashioned a very ghetto, very functional, very awesome little cardboard caddy to hold all the cards. This will greatly reduce setup time, teardown time and reduce the amount of space it takes up.

I sold this. It had a high failure rate. For every good play of it, there were 2 long and frustrating plays where the game ran for 5 hours and everyone just wanted to be done with it.

RATING: 8
This game works only if you focus on the theme - read the flavor text on the cards, help construct a narrative as game events unfold, else it bogs down into three hours of seemingly meaningless token shuffling and dice rolling.

Recently picked up my own copy and have been playing it a lot with my son. Because it allows me to spend more time with him, and because we play it in the way noted above, we have a great time, and are even at a point where we can win it.
---------------------
Now playing this some with the kids in the gaming club. They seem to be just the right set of gamers to play this with - they have the right attitude, they have the right level of skill, and they are willing to treat this game in the way it deserves - as two or three hours of storytelling fun that climaxes in either triumph or insanity. The other day saw us fighting to the last man against Shub Nig, and as each of us fell beneath the black hooves of darkness and were consumed, we were cheering aloud, shouting and screaming, chanting "six-six-six-six" as dice were cast, and when we won, we were standing from our chairs, yelling and cheering, and giving each other hugs and high-fives. That's how good this game can be.

RATING: 3
There are two big problems with this game:
1) It has about the same complexity as Pandemic
2) The game can often feel like it plays you, similar to Pandemic.  You might initially seem like you have a lot of choices, but there is really only 1-2 choices that you really should do.

This second thing is okay with Pandemic because the game lasts less than an hour, but Arkham Horror can take about 3-4.  If I am going to play a 3-4 hour game, I want to play a game where I actually make meaningful decisions.  I know a lot of people said that the theme is great, but the theme of a game carries little wait with me, so it did not help the situation.  I do want to play it again now that I actually know what I am doing, but I have a feeling it will produce the same results.

RATING: 10
Don't let the rule book scare you. It did take a long time to complete our 1st game (referring to the rule book constantly which I now see as a mistake), but after that it was easy. Just under 2 hours for our second game and each subsequent game has been 2 hrs or less.  

A suggestion to help speed things up in your few first games is to DISCARD AND REDRAW if you are confused by a card or monster and NEW PLAYERS DO NOT USE SPELLS. Also, understand and be OK with the fact that you will not get everything correct your first few plays....You will get it all correct in time 
 
If you do decide to invest your time in learning, then Arkham Horror will reward you with tons of fun. My wife had not ever heard of Cthulhu and is one of her favorite games now(she actually asks me to play). We love the atmosphere, creepy flavor text, the feel of moving through Arkham (like a book or movie).

RATING: 5
[INLINEIMG]http://images.boardgamegeek.com/images/pic230790.jpg[/INLINEIMG]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
There was a time I would have rated Arkham Horror a 9 or 10. It was love at first sight for me, and I rushed out and bought my own copy after my first play. Since then, my opinion of Arkham Horror, and of co-op games in general, has taken a nose dive. 

I feel it's unfair to give AH a low rating just because I no longer enjoy co-op games, but at the same time, even for people who still enjoy co-op games, I think there are plenty of good reasons to prefer other co-op games over this one. Namely, this game is way too long, extremely fiddly, and the game gets to be really predictable and repetitive after a few plays. 

There's very little room for varying strategies. It's just a simple logistics problem. Who needs to be where, and do what, at what time, in order for us to get X number of gates closed/sealed before turn Y? Rinse and repeat. 

Initially, this logistics problem seems like a tough nut to crack, and the group struggles to get it done, but after a few plays, the decisions become fairly obvious, and the only differences between plays come from the dice rolls. At that point, it's just a very long story-telling game, telling nearly the same story every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's been a long and eventful 9 years since I bought this game, but it has been with me every step of the way.

It's been played with old friends that have long since parted company, it's been played on holidays away from home and has constantly been a talking point and reason to get together and have a good time. It's had times of little play but still keeps in the minds of me and my friends as we recount desperate battles won and lost against the Mythos over the years.

I expect it will receive many more plays to come (testament to AH's design and production quality) and to me at least it is one of the main reasons I still game today! It has made me a fan of all things Lovecraftian and I'm proud of it.

No other board game has effected me so profoundly.

Recently I've become conflicted with which is better- Arkham or Eldritch Horror? At first I thought Eldritch but as I play it more I find its just not as deep, satisfying or interesting as Arkham. It also has less control and effective decision making then Arkham, and that's saying something!

Biggest wins to date: 28 victory points against Hastur and against Ithequa in 4 player games!

A guide to playing a GOOD game of Arkham Horror (take it from me, I know what I'm talking about):

1/ Only play when there's 3-5 players.
Two players is not enough, and if more then 4 ALL players must be AH veterans. Otherwise AP and downtime will spiral out of control.

2/ NO non-gamers. Who is this idiot drinking, giggling, sending text messages and then looking stupefied when their turn comes around? I don't care if it's your girlfriend! Get them out of the gaming room! Arkham  requires concentration and people all interested in playing. Let these onto the table and you might as well be playing Monopoly.

3/ Don't start a game after 9pm unless you are all Arkham veterans. Arkham requires concentration and energy- nobody wants to still be playing at 2am in the morning because everyone's exhausted and slowed down their game.

4/ Check peoples moods. Arkham requires will power and positivity- don't play if someone has had a bad day. It may only make things worse. If people are looking like the Mythos is taking its toll stop for a break. Get a drink, go to the loo, have a cig, chill for 5-10 minutes and regroup!

5/ Have the two most experienced players handling all the book keeping, adding tokens, dealing cards, etc. to keep the game flowing quickly.

These steps alone will improve play- if you have only played Arkham once and hated it, chances are one of the above conditions was not checked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2013 - top 10
2014 - top 10

RATING: 8
8/17/2012
Daunting.  This purchase was made primarily for solo play, but I need to make the commitment to learn it (and to that end, it's been an epic fail to-date).  I'm fairly comfortable that I'll be taking a real swing at this game as the weather turns sour here as Summer winds down.  I've read through the manual a few times and while there are a lot of bits, the overall complexity doesn't seem as horrific as the game theme.

2/3/2016
3 1/2 years later and have yet to play.  However, after experience with games reflecting far greater complexity such as Mage Knight, the game no longer seems too big or complex.  However, is it worth it for me to pull out and play?  Still up for trade, but I could decide to pull it out and 
Play it at some point.

11/8/2016
OK... Now have played this plus expansions solo several times.  Very fun game and definitely a keeper.  Generally best for me during the winter when the Minnesota weather turns sour.  So, just about Arkham season again!

4/13/2017
I used to be on the side of playing "Epic Arkham" with everything mixed in, but in my recent plays have come to appreciate the niceties of limiting the expansions with each play.  This presented a whole new set of storage requirements which I have now completed with the help of foam core, hobby lobby and the broken a token.  I really do enjoy this game solo.

8/15/2017
Summer's here.  Gloomhaven has been sitting on my solo gaming space for 3 months with no plays yet since it is "outside" season here in Minnesota.  By the time the weather turns, I'll probably have to scratch my Arkham itch before working through Gloomhaven.  Still one of my enjoyable games to play (and even think about playing).

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
UPDATE:  Moved it up a bit after a very good 6-player experience.  I still think this design is based less on decision making than die rolling, but with the right group it can be quite fun.

I think this game would shine in certain situations, but in general all the constant rolling gets in the way of the mood.  And that's if you know what you're doing during the game, and don't need to check this card against that token with the other rule.  How can you get immersed into Lovecraft's world if you are constantly being jerked out of it to roll?  Roll for Sanity check, roll for being Cursed, roll to go to the bathroom.  That's  like the stage manager of a show coming onstage every five minutes to make sure the show is going well.  Get out of the way and let us enjoy it, please, for the love of...well, you know.

The production values are nothing short of amazing, but in typical FFG fashion, it seems as if the designers spent time finding new ways to include more bits.  Oh, for Martin Wallace to bring just a bit of his legendary elegance here!  Or even Knizia...he's right there after all!  

That all said, I would definitely play this again now that I know the rules.  Maybe in my next play I won't feel the machinery moving quite so much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Brilliant, brilliant game. So much replayability and variety it's ridiculous. The only downside is, like many FFG games, it's a pain in the ass to set up and tear down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A tough learning curve in the sense that so much of the game is spent in the rulebook. There is something about the flow of the turns and phases that just fails to be intuitive for me. Should I persevere?...

edit - I persevered! and upped it's score to an eight. A fantastic adventure/exploration game.

2nd edit - more play and more expansions... This game is huge. I can't think of a bigger adventure/exploration game in this style. Fantastic stuff and I'm upping it to a rare 9.

RATING: 5
As of this writing I only have one play under my belt and boy, all I can say is that I am underwhelmed by this game. This is so much rampant luck going on I might as well play a roll and move game. Also I didn't see any challenge; never at any point during our play did I feel as though we were going to lose. In fact at the end we just flipped over cards quickly to see if we could seal the last gate just to wrap it up. Now, this was with 7 players. Maybe if we played with the recomended 3 or 4 player I might have another opinion, but for now there are way too many other games I would rather play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have to be honest. I got into this game solely because it is a Lovecraftian horror and I had been playing the Call of Cthulhu RPG for a few years.  I wanted to recapture some of the cooperative gameplay and randomness without having our 8-person gaming group all present.  As we get a little older, we got busier as well.

This game is a great with 3-4 players but it gets to be a little long with more than 5 people.  You can even play solo!

You will lose some of the impromptu storytelling from the RPG because the boardgame will lay it out for you, but overall gameplay is a lot quicker.

This fun, polished game that does not disappoint!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Rating based on first 2-player game with Dunwich expansion. This is great if you like games that crossover between RPGs and boardgames. Lots of chrome and dripping with theme and beautiful artwork. I wouldn't play with the Dunwich expansion again unless there were 3-4 players. The 2-player version of the DH expansions seems to require more time spent on administration and less on players having any effect on the game environment to be worth the 3 hours play time. AH is definitely not for Eurosnoots, but those who are prepared to enjoy a pseudo-role playing experience should have a lot of fun. Looking forward to playing it again with more players, preferably 3-4. I think 5 or more players might have too much downtime. 
Updated to an 8.5 This game is fun if all the players are prepared to treat it as pseudo-roleplaying experience. Bringing alcohol to a gaming session will help (but keep it away from the board!). This game is NOT a mathematical puzzle to be solved, but an interactive story.
Updated to a 9. I think AH is really good to have in the game library for 3-5 players, to be played every 4-6 weeks as an excellent change in pace and tone from eurogames. It won't appeal to hardcore eurogamers, and players prone to analysis paralysis would detract from its pace and levity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RECOMMENDED.

Morgan's Copy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I took my former rating of 6 up to a 7, just because it keeps hitting the table. Replay isn't too bad, each game tends to spin off in a wildly different direction. All the card action makes for a lot of random elements, but in a way much of the fun is in adapting to the situation as it changes.

Edit- Up from 7 to 8. Still a favorite, and the expansions add a crapload of good times. Having introduced a lot of new people to this game, only a very few didn't find it interesting, and I think they were determined not to enjoy it regardless. "Cooperative" and "Cthulhu" are four letter words to some gamers, apparently.

Months later... still going up in rating as everyone always wants to play it, this time from 8 to 9. It's gone from being a decent game with nice components and theme to being "the" game we play with 5-8 people. Only two of us are interested in Lovecraft, CoC or the mythos. What this game offers is a new experience every time, lots of laughs, and tons of player interaction. We play with a few house rules to spice it up: the GOO and investigators are drawn at random, gates are played face down until entry, and someone else always reads your encounter card text, always stopping at the IF statement... you can't know the consequences of your decision before making it.

It's here that I have to stop and ponder the fact that I just rated Arkham Horror a 9. It isn't elegant, competitive or eurosnooty. It's grade A Ameritrash, and it's one of my favorites. I'm coming out of the closet.

It's worth mentioning that the few people who weren't interested in playing are now doing so regularly and loving it.

The main drawback of this game is the end battle. It's basically a dice-fest royale, and can seem anticlimactic. I would like to see an expansion that had some kind of end fight variants.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you enjoy the Cthulhu Mythos then this game will be even better for you. Sort of a stand in to RPG's, you get some of the mystery of Cthulhu without really getting into the RP side.

The game is great because it is a co-op game and can be played with one person. The rules are a little heavy and unless you play frequently (which I don't) they can really bog down the beginning of a game. The bad side of the game is that it takes up a lot of room, especially if you add the expansions, and takes a while to play. Most of the people I normally play with don't have the patience for the long time this game takes and you can be put out of commmission for a while during the game which can cause even more waiting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There isn't a better game in terms of the experience, the fun, and the atmosphere. This is a special game for me also, as it's the one I credit for getting me into the hobby, and I have yet to play something better than it. Being that I have a background in video games, Arkham Horror showed me what board games are capable of. Yes, it's fiddly. Yes, it takes awhile to set up. But when a game offers such an immersive and engaging RPG-like experience, I think those are easy facets to become accustomed to.

UPDATE: Age is finally creeping up on this one. Plus the fact that so many other spin-offs exist means that this one doesn't stand out from the crowd as much anymore. As long as the app exists, Mansions of Madness is my go-to Lovecraftian game. If, for some reason, they stopped supporting that, I'd come back to AH, as it does Lovecraftian adventure the best otherwise, by far.

RATING: N/A
Much like its brother "Fury of Dracula," it is a game which takes some patience to fully comprehend.  Once understood, however, this game is quite exciting, with multiple outcomes each and every time you play due to multiple playable characters, tons of monsters, and a mass of ancient ones who can change the course of the game by their mere presence near the board!  A must buy for any strategy lover looking to bridge horror with thought and bring their friends along for the adventure!!

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like AH a lot.  Downsides are longish play time and setup (gotta dig out all those cards and fiddle with tokens...), and not a lot of strategic decisions.  Sure, you have to make decisions, and there is strategy, but I think you're largely at the mercy of fate.  This ties into the thematic elements, which is what makes the game work.  I don't like the reverse momentum of the base rules- the game slows down at the end, instead of building up tension and speed.  But the Stormknight variant and a couple of house rules do a good job of patching that.  Once the momentum is fixed, there is storytelling goodness.  It's a good social game.  I feel like a couple of locations are broken in the base game (train station, Silver Twilight Lodge Inner Sanctum) in that I try to never go there due to unfavorable encounters.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The epitome of ameritrash. Too much setup time, too long, too many chits, too many rules, too many randomisers, too many exceptions, too many symbols, too much stuff everywhere. Wiser men than me once said: "If Arkham Horror was a competitive game, it would be considered unplayable." and "In Arkham, all the different Great Old Ones do is changing the rules we keep forgetting."

Even if you don't acknowledge that the real horror is the gameplay, on the story side location cards (telling random stuff your character does neither under your consent nor under madness) disconnect you from both the overall plot and your sense of incarnation. Also I'd really like to know how taking down an awakened Cthulhu with a church-blessed (!) shotgun doesn't obliterate any Mythos-related suspension of disbelief.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absulute good fun and great theme! Looking forward to the expansions!

RATING: 6
This is a very thematic game with lots of flavor and atmosphere, which is also one of its weaknesses since it's not for everyone or for every occasion. It does have a very Lovecraftian feel though, so on that alone I would have to give it some points. But the real issue with Arkham Horror is that it is so long and complicated that it's not easy to pick up. So, while it's very thematic, much more so than say Elder Sign with which it shares many commonalities, it's just not a game that I would every play very much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I really like cooperative games, so this was a must have for me.  You have lots of options as to what to do which makes re-playability a little higher than other cooperative games like Shadows over Camelot or Lord of the Rings.  However, there is huge setup and teardown time associated with this game and it can be very slow to play.  I am unlikely to ever play this other than with one other person, playing two characters each.

RATING: 8
I spent a long time waiting for this little blasphemous beastie, and I'm glad I did. Tickles the hard-core Lovecraft nerves that never seem to get scabbed over. It's no Eurogame, that's for sure. Highly random, wildly stacked against the players, and sometimes frustrating, it's a perfect simulation of what life might be like when finally the stars are right. Lovecraft would approve, if he hadn't detested games. That's the way the Star-Spawn swim, I guess. I loved it, and so did the two buddies I played it with (neither of which is a Lovecraft fan). Ia! Ia!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Excellent. Now I'm sure about it. Every time you open a FantasyFlightGames box, and see a lot of bits, cards and so... and finally you discover an encyclopedia instead of a rulebook, YOU SHOULD NOT BE AFRAID. FantasyFlightGames are easier to play than they seem.

Arkham Horror is a great game. Full of tension, VERY hard to defeat and in the end, even if you fail your task to stop the ancient one, it's one of the most satisfying games I've ever played.  If you have played Call of Cthulhu, the atmosphere is just like that (this game is for Call of Cthulhu, what Runebound is for Dungeons and Dragons... but multiplied by 10!!!).

My first session was Two Players. Took about 3 and a half hours and we didn't notice the clock ticking. This game just drags you into it just like Cthulhu would drag you to his mouth with one of his tentacles!

I still need to play it with more than 4 players to have another view of the game, but with 2 players this game is a blast!

2007-03-15: Another AH session. This time we were three players. Nah! It's nearly impossible to beat that game. our Ancient One was played by..... CTHULHU himself! We just died surrounded by a painful agony, corpses all over Arkham... and some Zombies chewing our brains. This game is really a blast. No game I have played before brings that frustration feeling so painfully than this one. I'm really impressed. It's just like playing Call of Cthulhu RPG.

2007-03-18: At last... an Ancient One was defeated. Yog-Sothoth fought hard to get our of his slumber, made our live almost impossible, but in the end, the gates were closed just in time. I think we were pretty lucky in this game, starting for the fact that we drew two elder signs from the Unique item deck. Will this game become a 10 for me? I don't know... but every time I play it, my game experience just gets better and better.

2007-03-21: Addiction. There's no other way for me to name how I feel about this game. The 4 playing hours are no issue for me. Today, we faced Ithaqua. Again, we were overrun by a swarm of monsters crawling down the streets of Arkham. This was a 5 player session. I really think 5 is too much for this game to be played with. Now, downtime starts to delay players, even if everyone has played the game before. I need to give this game a try with 4 players to see what happens. This game is awesome... probably, going right to a 10 rating for me.

2007-03-24. Shub-Niggurath killed us all. This time IT woke up right under our feet. We managed to hurt IT badly, but it was not enough.

2007-03-30: Azathoth is so dumb, slow and even if he is allmighty, we managed to stop him. Six Elder Signs sealed ITS way down to Arkham. 

2007-04-27: Nyarlathotep is not as deadly as his masks. He woke up from his slumber and fought against some sort of magician and a nun... to find his death against the angry nun.

2007-06-30: 5 player game against Hastur. He was defeated on the very last minute! Pretty hard to manage the extra Clue Token cost to seal gates.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
From a game design standpoint: singularly awful. 

Tedious bookkeeping to track the number of monsters that easily blend into the busy artwork, so that you can...what? Determine when shops close? Who cares? Yet if you remove that element, you can oftentimes break the game because so much should ride on the players eliminating the monsters. This is especially true with certain Great Old Ones that rely on the fear track. 

The narrative is force-fed to the players, who apparently cannot be trusted to determine for themselves what is occurring on the board. Instead, we need to be handed expository event cards that present a shallow causal relationship ("You go into a house and hear a low wind. Lose 2 Sanity.") which is divorced from the events on the board and are neither determined by player decision nor decided by them. Since nearly everything in the game is decided by dice or card, there is almost no meaningful player decision. 

Worse, players may (and usually will) find that their character is not very adept at handling what the game is throwing at them, and in groups of 4, usually at least 1 of them is left to meander around the board doing next to nothing. 

This game slows to a crawl when you are doing well; close the gates and fewer things happen. It is most interesting when you are doing poorly. 

In terms of theme: awful. Lovecraft's monsters were the culmination and evidence of an awful truth. Arkham Horror's monsters are fodder. This is especially evident when you play only to defeat the Elder Gods in combat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This has gotten a bit stale for me, and mixing in too many expansions just seems to dilute the game, plus I'd rather spend money on new games than on expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Must have the right crowd for this one. But my brother and I truly enjoy being devoured by Nyarlothep
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oh boy, what a great game this is!! I absolutely love it... The year is 1926. An ancient evil force is trying to get hold of Arkham, a fictional town in Massachussetts, opening dimensional gates and sending his monster servants through the streets. The feeling you get by playing this one is more than just a unique one. There are so many options, so many decisions have to be made and there is an abundance of thematic flavor that it really feels like you are one of the main characters in a (Lovecraft) book. I guess this must be one of the best titles I ever played. One of the longest ones too, so if you don't like games which can last longer than 2 hours, Arkham is definitely no place for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I guess this is an epitome of "Ameritrash." My first adventure game. Not terribly impressed, in no hurry to play again. Complicated but not deep, a lack of long term strategic thought.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like it a lot. Very deep system which provides excellent cooperative experience. Also i like art and what atmosphere it provides for games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I admit that the thematic feel of this game is off the charts.  It is also a great co-op game for you and your friends to try and beat collectively.  The quality is typical FFG and is excellent.  However, I feel that the rules are way too difficult to give the players much of a chance at winning.  Events are just too frequent and punishing to players if they make the slightest mistake.  One random card can ruin a couple of hours worth of strategy the team has put together trying to give themselves a chance to win.  I think house rules are in order for this one to make it a little more enjoyable.  As it is now, my playgroup looks at it on the shelf and skips it because of that dreaded feeling of "why play when you don't have much of a chance of winning?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love playing this game. I don't think I have ever had a bad time playing it, even when we've lost. Even when we've lost horribly! Even the times when I was frustrated because I couldn't use my character's abilities to their best advantage, I've had a good time playing. I like the theme, and I like that it's cooperative, and I like that it is so hard that you go into it with a devil-may-care doomed feeling...the euphoria that accompanies a win is glorious. Anytime Arkham Horror is suggested and we have enough time to play, I will say yes to this game. Anytime that I think we DON'T have enough time to play, I will groan like my heart is being ripped in half.

After we got comfortable with the base game, we worked into a habit of playing this with one big box expansion and one little box expansion (or two or three little boxes if we really wanted to depress, er, I mean, challenge ourselves).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've only played this game at Gencons, and although I enjoyed each experience (4 so far) the game just didn't engage me.  V. high production values, but fiddly, ie., lots of bits.  Just seems like another go around and collect stuff and then kill something game.

Update: O.k., I've been to a couple more Gencons, and that means I've played AH a couple more times.  Seems to play much, much better without players who've memorized some sort of mechanical strategy.  Played for atmosphere it can produce a tense, down to the wire game.  The expansions seem to crank up both the challenge and the atmosphere.  So, I've bumped my rating up by 1.

Update 2: After the annual Gencon plays (with someone else teaching the rules), I got this as a solo game.  IF you already know the rules it makes for a good solo experience.  Bumped up the rating another point.

It's a great game to play over vacations and decent periods of downtime over the holidays.  Set it up, play a few turns, go do something else for the rest of the day, come back to it and enjoy.

RATING: 7
Lovecraftian mythos in a game that just oozes theme. Great co-op play and for the most part avoids the "busdriver effect" (where one person more or less directs everyone's moves); there's rarely an obviously best option on a given turn, but rather two or three choices that all tend to equally push towards the goal.

RATING: 9
An intriguingly designed co-op/solitaire game which oozes atmosphere, tension and humour. Excellent production values and easily worth both the money and the effort of lugging it around! 

It only loses the last point because, if both the players and the 'game' have simultaneous runs of bad luck near the end, it can end up frustratingly drawn out. However, that is rare in my experience, and this is a firm and justified favorite.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wonderful co-op with a Lovecraftian theme! Surprisingly often, the cards manages to tell a story that you are glad to be a part of. Oh yeah, the game hates you :P
Lots of characters, equipment, spells, and... lots of everything really. High replay value even without expansions.
Extremly random. Sometimes you lose within 30 minutes, sometimes it's a 5 hour affair, but you always come back for more! (It's usualy closer to 5 hours though...)
Horrible rule book, even for FFG standards. Expect 5-10 games to get things right. I know of people who own the game, but haven't played it, because they can't understand the rules...
Hits the table rather often, but would have been more often if it didn't take 30 minutes to set up and then another 30 minutes to clear away...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I guess I'm going to have to buy Dark Pharaohs and then Dunwich Horror. I am some kind of a sucker...damnn

RATING: 7.42
I've only begun to play this one so I haven't formed strong opinions yet, but my first impression is positive.The strong theme makes the game easy to immerse one's self in. Although there are tons of bits and circumstances to deal with, gameplay is surprisingly smooth. The long set-up time and play time will prevent this from hitting the table too often, but the cooperative nature of the game makes it so that solo play isn't all that much different than multi-player, so it won't be as limited as it otherwise might be. By the end of my first games the repetetive nature of the game was getting to me a little bit. I was becoming impatient with the same-old-routine. We'll see if this trend continues.
***
Updated 01-20-09: I had given up on this one after my son (with whom I mainly play it) lost interest due to the tediously repetetive nature of the game, but I played it again yesterday with an adult gaming buddy and I had a good time. Now I have renewed hope.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A group of us finally got together and played a game of Arkham Horror and we had fun working together to keep the Ancient One from awakening by shutting down the portals that show up all throughout Arkham City.  While playing, it is very easy for players to immerse themselves in the theme of this game by reading all the text on the cards, the backgrounds to the characters, and the general story told by the game.

Because of the overly complicated rules we missed one or two monster surges and we felt like the anxiety was getting ramped up at the end, to just see us win quite easily.  Kind of a let-down for all the investment we had already put in.

This game oozes theme.  I would love to play again with a willing group, candles, scary music, and lots of spare time, although the time investment and the overly complicated rules makes this a game that might not be in my collection forever.

RATING: 5

RATING: 6.5
A very fun game that would rank much higher if the endgame was any good.  By the time it appears, you're pretty much aware if you're going to win or lose -- but it takes an hour-plus to get there, and one bad roll could reset that clock.

Before the 3rd Act, it's an 8.5.

Like many games from Fantasy Flight, I wonder if this would make a better XBLA game.  So much of the busywork of this game could be automated, and gametime would be down to an hour.  Six years later, in the thick of the game-app partnership, I'm amazed they haven't done something.  Get on that, ANA.

RATING: 5
Too long, too hard, too random. You can get screwed from the start with a bad rumor. By the end, you don't even care if you win or lose, you just want the game to be over. If you're fast and you don't really read the cards you can get the game length to around 5 hours. Just play pandemic. Or Elder Sign if you like the theme. It's way too easy to have one investigator just end up useless with each turn you just gain 1 stamina or 1 sanity. Also, the rules are a complete mess. There are so many exceptions and contradictions. For example, what happens when you die but are already lost in time and space? Who knows? Who cares? Played the game maybe a dozen times, and I spent just as much time online reading rules on the twelfth time as I did the first time (Although, the first six games I played so incorrectly that it didn't count).

Bumping from a 4 to a 5 cause I'm a sucker for these sorts of games, and I'm itching to try it again. I hate it, but I can't help myself.

RATING: 6
This game feels a bit long for what it is. The large amount of random stuff happening (items, gates, monsters, events, fighting) kind of overshadows the few choices you make in the game (where ot move/attack). Besides, your movement is fairly scripted since there will likely be an obvious strategy to follow. The theme is cool, but at 4 hours, this game is too much.

New thoughts. This game is mostly about getting into the theme. Since what you have to do is mostly scripted, it's mainly about just enjoying the game and getting into the mood of it. With the right people it's a fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The theme impregnates all the game. The characters really feel different, and the action mirrors the Lovecraft stories and the RPG games. The Ancient Ones are quite generic though, and they doesn't have that ambientation richness to them.

The most interesting feature of the game is the possibility of changing the skill levels, increasing ones at the cost of others.

Even if it features the "leader" issue that plagues most cooperative games, the joint planification and and coordination is paramount in order to obtain success. Even if it is ultimately possible, it is difficult for one player to think and manage every aspect of the game, there's always room for individual contributions, especially bewteen players with similar levels of experience.

Now, the issues:
-> Winning strategy: 
[o][SPOILER ALERT]
The game is quite easy as long as you focus your resources (especially the clues) in achieving the final objective, closing the portals. But the game becomes a walk in the park when you follow some easy tips: keep searching for unique items until you can buy 2-3 Elder Signs (or King in Yellow tomes), never close portals without sealing them, etc.
[/SPOILER ALERT][/o]
-> Very poor scaling (in fact, scaling is almost non-existant); the more players are, the easier the game is.
-> It's a bit long.

Even with these issues, and even knowing that Eldritch Horror provides a similar experience and adresses sucessfully all these issues, a game of Arkham Horror is still a good experience.

I have no idea how much the many expansions can solve this. I don't know if I will sell my base game and focus on Eldritch Horror or I will try my chances with some expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An cooperation game with a Cthulhu-theme. Game is probably the best cooperation game I have played. Theme is a great for an cooperation game. There are quite a bit of rules but it is enough that one player knows all the details, others don't need to know all of them. Game thematic and fun to play. There is a bit of downtime with 5 players but it isn't too bad.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With a half-ton of pieces, several different scenarios (Old Ones), and a dozen different characters, you certainly get a lot for your money. The event cards (Mythos) insure that no two games are likely to be the same. There are lots of toys to find and bad guys to try and stop, only adding to the fun chaotic play.

NOTE: get one of the play summaries/help sheets above before playing the game; it will speed the play up tremendously, and not make 25-50% of session be spent on looking $h!t up.

Arkham plays out like an HPL story. The locations are abstracted, but the theme sucks you in. Lovecrafts 1920s come alive, as flapper heiresses and dashing archeologists fight it out with cultists and mostrous things that should not be. A nameless horror is awakening and only you can stop it before it slaughters everything. Are you up defeating the Old Ones, or will you wind up a gibbering lunatic wandering the streets as the giant foot of Evil stomps down upon the world.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I never thought I could play a four hour game without getting at least a little bored occasionally. This is frighteningly good entertainment, and there is very little downtime except on those rare occasions when fighting several monsters at the same time.

Definitely needs a tackle box to keep all those components organized.

There isn't much incentive to visit some of the locations. Hopefully the expansions will tackle this issue.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game has a thrilling theme and nice components, I give it that. The game system, however, does not excite. This is actually a real stinker. First of all this game is very repetive. Choices you make are either obvious or trivial. Most of the time there is not much you can do except throw dice and hope for the best. Arkham Horror takes much too long for its own good: it can take over five hours. Did I mention there is a lot of downtime in this game? Most of the time you are just waiting for your turn without much need to follow random encounters taking place on the board. When your turn comes you throw dice. If you are lucky nothing happens and then you wait some more. Arkham Horror, it seems to me, is a board game for people who enjoy role playing games. I am not one of them.

RATING: 7
6 -> 7.5 -> 7 -> 6.5

This game is ONLY for Lovecraft's fans. 
Good that I'm one of them :)
(Rating should be 2.5 or 3 for "normal" players)

Edit: (comment only for a base game)

- Fiddly
- Long (ca. 150-210 min. for two players; ca. 180-270 for three)
- It's very easy to kill Ancient One (even for two players)
- E-X-T-R-E-M-A-L-L-Y random

+ Beautiful components
+ Full of theme (...but I have to warn you: you can easily kill Ancient One with your Tommy Gun)

I don't know why but I like this game :)

Edit2: Quite repetive after some plays. This game really needs expansions to be more fun. Rating down to 6.

Last played: April 2009

RATING: 4

Update 2/11/15
Meh. Got repetitive, and it's way too long.

Expansions:
Dunwich Horror

Verdict:

What I Like: The theme. I adore the Lovecraftian mythos. The teamwork can hum along nicely too sometimes. 

What I Don't Like: Endlessly fiddly gameplay. Random dice rolls and card draws determine everything. EVERYTHING. It's long (2-4 hrs unless death comes early), with not much variety to be had unless I drop money on another expansion. Sometimes you just die or go insane, which is thematic I guess, but frustrating.

Another great thing about the game is the fact that you can play it solo.

RATING: 9
I play this with my best friend Alex and we each control 2 characters. It is certainly a long and fiddly game, but I am a Lovecraft fan and I enjoy the story unfolding + we like the mechanics. A very satisfying experience and none of our games felt the same. Having said that, it takes time to set up + a lot of time to play + a lot of time to return it to the box, time that, most of the time, we lack.

RATING: 8
The game is fun when you understand the rules. My group had been trying to fall in love with it by force for about 4 years with about 1-2 games per year, with little success. Seriously: One players has to know the rules by heart, or the game will fail.
- On the good side: It's a talkative thematic game with many elements I like, and it's long enough for a full evening of play.
- On the bad side: expectations are not fulfilled. You may think there is a kind of role playing element - nope. You think the game creates an eerie atmosphere - nope. The rule book is one of the worst I know with no index and a forrible structure.
- Tactics: Your character needs money. Other things are far less important
- Best with 4 or 5 players.

RATING: 9.5
This is my wife's favorite game yet! The cooperative game play is incredible! No game is ever the same as any previous game! You must beat the game! She always requests to play it, but time is hardly ever permitting. She has now taken to playing it by herself. Yes, it is a long game, but who cares...it's a blast! What a game to thrust you into a world on the brink of evil devastation and you must prevent it from happening. Huge task to complete! 

Every time I think about AH I get excited. This game is more than a game it is an experience. Every game is unique and memorable! Your investigator is in for one heck of a night. The game unfolds like a surreal movie, the story is subtle and random...but yet...in every game...there are these moments of...Wow...that was meant to be! The events are always exciting and when this one comes off the shelf for play it stays on the table a week or more; it stays out for at least 5 or more plays before it is even considered to be put away again. My wife says it's pure perfection itself!

RATING: 5
Sooo many decks of cards in this game... close to 20 I think??  Some other things should have been cut before production (I'm looking at you Bank Loan).  On one hand you have an excess of cards and unnecessary features; but on the other hand, too much is over-simplified by coming down to a d6 roll.  Are you about to die after 3 hours of play?  Roll a d6 and hope you get higher than a 4.  The theme is cool but the game is too long when everything comes down to random cards and d6 rolls.  I think it would be a lot more enjoyable if it were 1-2 hours long instead of 3-4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
"An older pure co-op that is overly complex, and which overstays its welcome. It would be good at 60 minutes, but is a bit painful at 180+. Several rules are pointless and/or counter-intuitive. Requires houserules to play with just 2 investigators."

What I like:
- Flavor text, in fonts that are less illegible than Elder Sign
- Moving around the map is more fun than Elder Sign

What I don't like:
- Requires houserules with just 1 or 2 investigators (I don't like playing multiple pawns)
- It would be far better as a 90 minute game (not 180+)
- It can feel like a treadmill (for hours)
- It can feel very punishing, and the dice can be cruel
- It would be far better with about half the rules
- The board could be smaller and not lose anything

After a solo (1-investigator) loss, I gave it a tentative rating of 4. After a 2-player 2-investigator win (but with misplayed rules), I rate it a 6. After a 2-player, 2-investigator game that we quit after 3 hours, It's a 5. A 5-player game months later didn't change my mind. 

I agree with the BGG-voted weight of 3.5, due to complexity (I would give the depth a 2.2).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Excellent game with good solitaire possibilities.  Very "expansion friendly" which makes me think this will ultimately lead to new content.

Lots of bits means that set up time can be substantial. Gameplay changes a bit as the number of players increases.

I wouldn't say this is aging well. Find myself wanting to play it less and less, and when I do, wanting to play a streamlined version without so many expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Looks amazing when you first open it and dig into the rules and bits, but the gameplay itself can't live up to the bits. Too much errata/rules to get sorted out. Wife getting impatient with the constant back and forth from playing to reading the rules/flow charts. She expected more tension in the game, considering it is a horror game, but I have to say 'Pandemic' offers far more tension. They use similar mechanisms such as 'doom/terror track' and 'outbreak track' to move the game along, but in AH, there is rarely a time when the game feels 'tense' or that we are running out of time. The terror track never moves, and even the AO track never gets very high. A 3,4 hour game without tension is not a good thing. In 'pandemic' the tension is palpable almost from the start. Full points to AH for theme, though. Hopefully, some variants will increase the tensions factor, otherwise, the wife will be hesitant to play this again. I think her response was, 'Okay, there's a monster. I fight it, I almost always win. I don't win, I just get knocked out. Big deal. Where's the horror?" I cannot understand the rabid fandom that this game attracts. I love horror, but the only horror here is the ridiculous play time, the luck, the boredom, the lack of tension, and the endless setup. 

Since my wife doesn't like it, and I'm not too enthusiastic myself to try to get it back on the table, it's going to be placed on the 'trading' gate to get sucked into another dimension.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The base game has issues when played by itself.  Once the players have worked out a strategy it becomes pretty hard to lose and endings can really draw themselves out.

RATING: 7.5
Like evil beings out to destroy the world?  Like creepy towns?  Like a university where you'd prefer to be expelled than stick around?  Like going slowly insane as you learn about the horrible things that are out there?  Well, then this is the game for you.

A dark game where you're playing the investigators looking to keep one of the Ancient Ones from waking and doing something nasty to the world around you.  It's a cooperative game, so if you're looking for competition, go elsewhere.  Quite fun, but there's a fair amount of down time between players acting, particularly as the number of players grows.

A fun time that usually ends up telling a good story.

RATING: 7
I like the feel of this game, and of course I love the Cthulhu Mythos, so yes, I do actually like this. But there are a few problems. Firstly, there are too many fiddly rules that interrupt gameplay and stop you getting into a nice rhythm. Too many parts where you have to go back to the rulebook looking for an answer. And unless you are Blessed and have half a dozen clues, you might not even find the answer. Ultimately, this game suffers from something I've seen in a few FF Games -unnecessary exceptions to the rules that only serve to make things messy and give you a headache, rather than improving the experience. Also, the game is too long. After 3 hours I am ready to finish, but I still have about 8 rounds waiting for clues to show up... Elder Sign and Eldritch Horror are much better options.

RATING: 7
This is a great game for fans of complicated, multi-faceted games with a horror/fantasy twist, and is a fun game for the geek in all of us. Expect a moderately long setup time, and with all of the randomness in the game you will sometimes have games end up very exciting, and other times have games end up kind of boring and uninteresting. I found that playing with a large number of players was not generally a good idea both because of the time it takes and because having too many players rendered the game a little too easy. Small numbers of player (3-4) worked best and ended up with the most exciting games in my experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I picked this up when I first got into boardgaming heavily and really enjoyed it for a while. Now that I've played a lot more games I'm not so enamoured. My main issue is the sheer length of the game, it would easily be a 9 if I could get a game completed in around 2 hours. Unfortunately most of my games run at least three, if not 4 hours long. I find that the mechanics just become a little repetitive after a while and you also tend to get the same encounters coming up as well (even with the Dunwich Horror Expansion). It also doesn't really capture Lovecraft's horror; it is much more akin to an action horror movie since you spend a lot of your time killing hordes of monsters with a plethora of weapons. I've found Martin Wallace's A Study in Emerald to capture the feeling of Lovecraft's creations, of course Arkham Horror and ASiE are totally different games but if you're looking for a better fit for the Mythos theme I would look to ASiE.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The idea of Arkham Horror is initially very appealing.  Running around the streets battling monsters and traveling to other dimensions sealing portals.  Plenty of different characters to choose from, tons of spells and items, skills to learns, frequent encounters, and a boss at the end to boot.  Sounds great, right?  If only it didn't take as long to set up as it does to play and relied on something other than rolling dice for the main mechanics.  Fun for a while, but it gets old quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I see Arkham Horror as less of a board game, and more as an experience. My favorite experience with Arkham Horror was playing with Lovecraft fans for the first time in the middle of a powerful thunderstorm. The lights were flickering, the storm was approaching, and the Ancient One was stirring in his sleep. I've rated Arkham Horror a 6 because these experiences are few and far between - with the right group, I can see this game being incredibly enjoyable. It is less fun with unenthusiastic players or those who want to 'win' and turn to more experienced players for advice on every move. Having a number of plays under my belt and a very good win/loss ratio, I'm probably ready to tackle an expansion (which do appear to add a lot more of a challenge to the game). I'm just not sure when I'll get around to picking up an expansion for this heavily thematic game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
More an experience than a proper game. Fun with the right crowd at the right time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tutti contro uno, il Gioco. Un'ambientazione emozionante che ti fa giocare in apnea. Un sacco di gadget da usare, attivare, combinare, scambiare. Nessuno rema contro: si discute e ci si scervella per cercare di vincere insieme. Le strategie di attesa sono fallimentari, per cui vanno pungolati i giocatori più "cauti" in una corsa contro il tempo per evitare il confronto col mostro finale. Se si vuol vincere, oltre a un certo affiatamento e sincronizzazione nei movimenti, è necessaria una pianificazione comune della strategia, quest'ultima dipendente dalle caratteristiche dell'Antico. 
Un sistema di gioco diabolico: perdere da un giocatore è una cosa, perdere da un gioco inanimato è la cosa più frustrante che ci sia. 
Dopo anni di boardgame e qualche altra partita però emergono i difetti: la grandissima mole di regole e regolette, oltre a essere personalmente inaccettabile, rallenta il gioco in maniera eccessiva. Inoltre, il gioco risente del grande difetto di tutti i cooperativi: alla fine emerge un leader che dà ordini a tutti e trasforma la partita in un grande solitario. E poi, dopo diverse partite il gioco diventa più facile per i giocatori e necessita di espansioni che rendano più difficile il raggiungimento degli obiettivi. 
Infine, dopo aver provato altri giochi cooperativi, Arkham Horror passa da prima scelta a terza/quarta. 
Comunque sufficiente.

RATING: 8
Currently my favorite game. I just really enjoy everything about it. The theme, the complexity, the fiddliness. I love the setting, I love all of the investigator stories, I love the board and components. And I love the emotion that it has evoked in the groups I've played with. 

26/10/13 The more I play the more I see the problems with the game, namely that it is a problem you can solve. We rarely lose because the game is so manageable, but I'm reluctant to get more expansions that add more mechanics because the game is already borderline overwhelming for new people, which is the majority of who I get to play with. I still very much enjoy the theme and feel of the game and the story it tells, but most nights I'm finding I would rather play a game of Castles of Burgundy or Lords of Waterdeep with my wife than set this up and devote the time necessary to play it.

19/4/16 I really enjoy the experience and the story this game tells, but it has become a once or twice a year affair for me. I don't think I'll every get rid of it, but I don't want to play it any more often than that.
