=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[color=red]Soloable Game[/color]
Playtime: ~150 minutes. It varies so much that it can last 60 minutes to 210 minutes. Averages around 150 or so. 

Comment: Really digging this game more and more. It sat on my shelf for a few months before I could even figure out the rules. It's not hard once you've gotten it down, but man is there a ton of tiny rules to sift through. I've become known as the "Arkham Guy" since I've read the rulebook at least 5 times. Game is quite fiddly but it's great. Sit back and let the theme overtake you. Play it more for the experience than trying to win and you'll have a MUCH better time with the game. Roleplay your character a bit instead of playing optimally.

I do wish that they created a "2nd edition" of this game to clean up the Mythos cards, add some flavor text instead of "A monster appears!" and smoothed out how the expansions integrated. Eldritch is NOT the 2nd edition nor is it anywhere near as good.

Optimal Player Count: 4 > 5 > 3 > 2 > 6 > 1 > 7 > 8
Plays well with everyone as long as each person is paying attention and trying to get into it. More than 5 starts to drag if people aren't paying attention. Less than 4 starts to get really tough though.

Extras: FFG American Standard Sleeves on Location Cards. Have all but like 3 or 4 of the minis. I need to go through them soon and figure out the ones I'm missing. I'd love to finish off the remaining few. I also have Blessed/Cursed dice, regular arkham dice and a handful more extra dice to keep around the table. 

Note: This game is only a 10 with some of the expansions mixed in. The game by itself is more of an 8. Have all the expansions mixed in and depending on which I feel like, we can either remove or force events to happen via King in Yellow style. There is so much content with all the expansions it's hard to figure out where to even begin. I seriously doubt I will ever tire of this game. I just need to slowly craft the perfect game with the variants/rules/modules. So far my favorite is 1 large board and 1 small expansion. I really need to go through all the extras that the expansions brought to see what I like and what I don't.

Note 2: Have all the locations and Gate cards in a white card box. I use the app to not only reduce down the boxes that it's now contained in (2) but I use it to save table space and time. I might unsleeve the cards depending on how I feel and either sleeve the mythos deck or use those sleeves for another game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Weight: 3.54 / 5

RATING: 8
Love this game but I don't think I could ever play with full expansions. Have just about managed to 'heath robinson' the boxes so the game can be played out of them to save space, as long as one or two players are willing to be readers (makes the game a little more dramatic). I keep mythos cards separate since not all expansions are played at once, in mythos phase the mythos player chooses  two numbers on a D6, if rolled then a mythos card for expansion board is pulled instead of a standard board one

RATING: 10

RATING: 9
It was said in some review that:"You don't play this game, the game play you". There is a point in that statement, but it is not the whole truth. There are still choices to be made and a high random factor in a game like this is not necessarily that bad thing after all. The theme of the game is nice...although to emphasize it, cards should be read aloud which may make the play time much longer (we usually just say what the effects of the card are).

After a few more games I decided to raise the rating from 7 to 8. Just because I don't have to take this game too seriously. Things just happens. So what. I try to stay sane and in good health. Please please please...give me one more success...5...too bad I'm cursed.

March 2010: I decided to raise my rating to 9. It's mainly because I'm beginning to remember all the rules, so that I can concentrate on the theme.

RATING: 6
Bardzo ładna gra, która mocno trzyma poziom prozy, na bazie której powstała. Fajny jest aspekty współpracy między graczami przeciwko grze, która mimo wszelkich starań potrafi dokopać.
Za głównych zalet gry nalezy wymienić oprawę graficzną, klimat i niepowtarzalność rozgrywki, każdorazowo dobór postaci wymaga innego podejścia do próby pokonania przedwiecznego.
Minusów natomiast jest nieco więcej, czas przygotowania gry jest wyraźnie długi (multum kart, żetonów, rozkładania). Instrukcja jest mało przejrzysta. Przy jednej z dóch gier udało nam się dojść do momentu kiedy ani przedwieczny nei zbliżał się do przybycia ani baacze jakoś nie byli w stanie oddalić bardziej znacząco zagrożenia, to spory minus, przy tej okazji zabrakło mechanizmu, który zmusi graczy do sprężania się i wprowadzi element zagrożenia.

RATING: 7.5
I've had this a week and a half.  Two 2P games and five solo games so far...  When I'm not playing it I often think of playing it.  It doesn't hurt that it inspired me to read (and re-read) some Lovecraft stories.  The theme makes this game awesome, and the game makes the theme shine. Current rating 8.5

Up to 9.5, I have so much fun playing this game!  21 games in just under two months, about half of them solo. Definitely the highest number of plays in that amount of time for any game I've owned.  All the more impressive because of the time commitment.

Back to a 8.5, been a while since I've been in the mood to break this one out... more likely haven't had the social opportunity.

RATING: 10
I've never seen a board game/RPG hybrid this well done! This game succeeds quite well in capturing the look and feel of HP Lovecraft's stories. It also has an engaging combat/skill check system (dice pools! Love 'em!). The rules ARE long, and a bit disorganized, but if you put in the time and effort to learn this one, you'll be in for an epic adventure!

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
Besitzer: Peter
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Huge, fiddely, and awesome. Not to mention great bang for your buck. A great heavy thematic adventure co-op game that will get many, many plays. As excellent a solo game as it is with a group. Best with the expansions so save up your money. Download the excellent rules summary from headless hollow.

Not as random as people try to make it out to be as there are ways to mitigate luck in the game. Good team work so far has won us many a game, but sometimes things just don't work out. The game is definitely stacked against the players. Like Battlestar Galactica the game can fall flat sometimes depending on conditions and other times be an amazing experience. This can be remedied somewhat by playing select expansions and building your card decks.

also for this game and it's expansions a plano storage system will be your best friend.

edit: Well I've played this more than my count shows. I still think this is a great game, but it's large and takes forever to setup and breakdown. because of this I tend to play solo on vassal more these days. My wife prefers Eldritch horror over this game so I think Eldritch horror fired this one for us. 

I still like this one a lot so will continue to play with friends who have it or play on the computer, but I've now sold it off to people who will get it to the table more often.

RATING: 9
Once onwned and sold it since it did not get played.
One more game that takes too long to get any playing time.
But it was fun both times I played it solo with 3 investigators.
And now with all the expansions I am tempted to buy it again...

I just read some suggestions for how to play solo with only 2 investigators. Sounds interesting. There was a lot of stuff to keep track of when playing with 3 characters and all their equipment.

Half a solo game with 2 investigators and then a full game. Only rule modification was to only draw a Mythos card if 1d6 showed 1-4. If 5-6 then then the Mythos phase was skipped. Nice learning game. Playing time 2,5h. A litle bit too easy still. Or the dice had a good night...

1st solo game with big expansion, Dunwich, and 3 investigators. Slow in the start but the flowchart is great for learning. In the end I did not need it. Very good story building game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fun Factor: 10 (Lets face it, this game is towers upon towers of fun.  My nine year old boy loves adventure, asks for this game frequently, and this game is really the end-all of the adventure game genre in my opinion.)
Components: 9
Theme: 10 (Lovecraft! Come on!)
Mechanics: 8 (Fiddly and dice heavy.)
Theme + Mechanics: 9
Replay Value: 10 (Different game every time, no doubt.)
Scaling/Players: 7 (Bogs down quite a bit with huge numbers of players)

The sheer length of the game is the only real detracting factor.  For this, the game has to receive a -0.5 on the curve :(  However, I really feel that this is the only game of the adventure genre that needs to be owned, it's just that good.  Therefore, no curve need be applied.

Edit: Adj 8.75 > 8.5 on 8/1/2011

RATING: 10
I like the theme, I have read the books, I'm into RPGs, including CoC and I have a 7' dining table on which games can be left as long as needed so I have no problem with this as a solo experience, which it why I have bought it and all the supplements.
I also think it works well two player.
When there are more than two players, I am not so sure: there seems too much down time, Mansions of Madness works better with 3-6 players and bringing it to the table on a Friday night club session because it plays with 7 or 8 is far too optimistic because we usually only have about three hours for the main game. On the other hand I wouldn't say "no" (I am rating the game a 10!) and the guy suggesting AH doesn't have all the expansions so we can play just the core game without any effort.
I have bought the AH iPad app, so in theory it is easy to play with just the expansions that I want but I like holding real cards and rolling real dice - using the app feels like I am only pretending to play a game.

RATING: 9
I'm not really one for 2-4 hour dice fests, but this one really tickles the thematic itch for me.  I like the way skill checks work, the randomness of things, and the way strategies change based on the ancient one, the # of players, and the mythos card draws.  Some initial rules exceptions will come up on the first few plays, but with the flow charts printed out (kudos to that guy) the game runs really smoothly even for new folks.  Also kind of cool in that you can start playing without explaining more than a few rules and as explanations are needed you can resolve them.

It's still early, but I've drunk the AH kool-aid, and have given it a 9.

RATING: 7
Arkham Horror can be hit or miss.  I've had games where it was immensely fun and we did alright or won, which, win-or-lose, is great.  I've also had games where everything went wrong and we had a shitty time, but that's how the game goes!  This game is more restricted thematic than, say, LoW or Last Night on Earth, where it really isn't as much "fun" for anybody not into the theme/Mythos.  The ups are worth it, despite the downs, and the social aspect of it all is fun.

RATING: 9
The irony of why I give Arkham such a high rating while Android gets such a low one comes down to theme.  I can accept all the chaotic, maddening, unrelenting events occurring in Arkham Horror because as a player representing mere mortals, the idea of succeeding could only possibly happen by dumb luck where in all reality you would instantly be gobbled up... Game over. The ridiculous rules and chaotic events fit the theme perfectly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I will be the first to admit that my first impression of this game was not a good one.  The game took far longer than it should have, and the rules were murky at best.  Worse yet, after hours of play, we lost every game miserably.

I picked it up at a "going out of business" sale at my LGS, mostly because I am a big Lovecraft fan, and this would be the cheapest price I could hope to pay for this game. 

This time, I knew what to expect, and I was determined to get the rules down pat.  Focusing solely on playing the game right, we found ourselves memorizing more and more with each game.  Now, we have almost no need for the rulebook, and we can complete a game in 2 hours or less.  There is a steep curve here, but if you can climb that mountain, you will find a great treasure there.

RATING: 8
The true test that separates a "gamer" from a "non-gamer". Lots of rules and lots of exceptions. Dense, deep and thematically rich. The rule book needs a complete re-write - too many questions can only be answered in forums (ex: What is the difference between location, neighborhood and area? Answer: an area is any location including Other world spaces). Be sure to download the updated official PDF rules. Best to be seen as a gaming experience than a simple board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
We really like the feel of this game. The idea that we are running out of time, and monsters roam around keeps us very interested in the game. It is uncommon for a game to keep you interested in other people turns, but in this one is like watching a Lovecraft movie unfold, and that is pretty satisfying. We still need to play more and figure out some of the options of the game. We have yet to get a bank loan or get in the secret society. Lastly, despite how hard the game is, and the likelihood of us losing, that seems to be the core of cooperative games. Losing needs to be a constant reality for the game challenge to provide fun. Definitely a must buy for a full cooperative setting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do worry that it will get old after a number of replays, but maybe not.

RATING: 7
I've not invested in the expansions 'cos it's been some time since I played it last, but for one summer in particular this was my favourite board game and rated it as such. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After 5  plays now, and after teaching loads of new people on how to play and playing games with a varying number of players, I can honestly say that I enjoy this game.  The natural progression of 'easy to impossible' that this game provides is truly exciting.  Multiple plays will highlight a need for an occasional house rule to smooth out rough edges, and time required to complete a game is reduced through practise and/or 'quicker' endgame monsters.  The art is magnificent, the writing throughout each cards are fantastic, and there is an overall feeling of quality across every part of this game.  Another fantastic title from FFG.

Update:  I'm going to increase the rating on this one.. It's definately around that '8' level, as it's one of those games that I would just love to play but the circumstances have to be right.. namely, you ought to play with enough people who are generally interested in the theme, as well as being prepared for a very long game (3 hours at least), as well as being prepared for a lot of chits and fiddlyness (to a certain degree).

On the plus side, it's a good game for some solitaire if you want to give it a go.  I tried it once and it went very fast, destroying the old one and winning the game.  It was close, though.  In the solitaire aspect, it works and feels like reading a short story in a novel, only .. without the 'book' part.

As I play more, I become more and more interested, but must remain diligent on the fact that it's rare that I can get a good group of interested players together to play it.
---

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
It was my first game after I got into board gaming. I tried to love, but it didn't love me back, although I gave it multiple chances, even after I got rid of it. I like Lovecraft Mythos, but I couldn't get into the theme enough during play, and without the theme this game is too long, too random, too boring, and (have I already mentioned it?) too long. It's, like, several minutes until it's your turn again and then nothing exciting happens.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a lengthier and weightier game so I have a hard time getting people to play it, so thus far I've only managed to play solo. Loved it, though with just one investigator it's extremely difficult, if not near impossible, to win. The story and theme are really strong and it almost feels like if you fill in the gaps with some imagination, a play is akin to reading a Lovecraft novel. The mechanics and rules are a bit on the tedious side, but once you get them down they flow pretty smoothly.
As I understand it, the difficulty doesn't scale very well with different numbers of players. One or two players will find the game near impossible while five players and above might find it too easy. There are plenty of variations listed online though which help to adjust the difficulty though so this isn't so much of a problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pros: Thematics and quality of game components are great and it does a good job of conveying the hopeless "You are about to be eaten and/or driven insane" atmosphere of the Cthulhu mythos. Cooperative game too if that's your speed.

Cons: Very long and if you have a lot of players it has a lot of downtime while you wait for others to complete their turns. As a result it can be a long slog.  

Overall: Ok game but definitely not for everyone. I'd play it if my regular group wanted to, but I wouldn't buy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I enjoy playing this game.  The cooperation element is quite splendid, and without working together the investigators will be mauled.  Some games just seem to be easier than expected, while others are a bear just to survive and close one gate, but each time is different, something hard to ensure in a game where you are all playing against the game.  It is a bit longish and fiddly, really something I've almost come to expect from any Fantasy Flight game of this size.  It takes a few games to get comfortable with the amount of stuff that's going on at one time, and even more games to make sure you have all the rules right.  Of it's genre (co-operation games), I think it's right up there with Lord of the Rings as one of the best.  There's more theme here than in Lord of the Rings, but you definitely pay for it with added complexity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fun co-op game that doesn't require a GM or someone to take on the "evil" side. Great theme integration. Has a crazy amount of cards, but that helps increase the replayability as you're never quite sure what is coming next.

WARNING: This can be a very long game, although it usually remains fun for most of the duration.

WARNING: Rules are lengthier than needed, and poorly organised. There are some excellent play aids on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games.  The components are excellent, great theme and artwork, and the co-op experience is always a treat.  The base game is lacking in encounter cards, which is made up for in the numerous expansions.  On its own though, the game would get repetative after a few sessions.  Fairly easy to beat as well, but the difficulty increases dramatically in the expansions to a 50/50 at least.

RATING: 8
Ignore the horror stories of how long this game is. Sure, it can be long, but the pace of the game is really up to the spirit of the players. This game allows for lots of storytelling and role play opportunities, or you can throw it down and shoot for a high score. 
It has high replay value and excellent thematic elements. 
Turn on some relevant horror music in the background and enjoy the intensity the game can bring.

RATING: 8.35

Particularly love the descriptions in the otherworld encounters. My main gripes with this game are that some actions on the board feel as though it is never justified to spend the time doing them instead of other actions (e.g. buying items at the shop, or spending more than one turn healing sanity/stamina) and that I wish the original had come with a greater number of encounter cards for variety.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Recreates the feeling of hack and slash table top RPGing.  Unfortunatly, once you "get it," the game becomes a bit too easy.  Each expansion does ramp up the difficulty a bit, so this does help.  Also, the rules are convoluted and don't quite cover all situations.  For instance, there's a card you draw every turn and resolve in this order: bottom left, bottom of the central text after the bold heading, bottom right, top of the central text (not kidding).  The second printing of the game solved many of these issues.  Despite the game's drawbacks, this is one I've played several times and enjoyed.

RATING: 9
I've been a fan of H.P. Lovecraft for a long time. When my friend introduced me to this game, I was stunned. Fight the elder gods, collect stuff, and see your characters story to resolve through cards and actions. I was sold completely after one game. It was so good actually, that we stayed up all night and played another game, after watching the movie Dagon. Call it a Cthulhu night if you wish.
I give it 9. It is simply awesome. I would give it a 10, but it still has it's bad moments. It takes long to set up, and it has some flaws in mechanics.
Still, it's the best board game I have played.

RATING: 6
An incoherent jumble of elements from the Cthulu mythos that at least manages to capture the right feel.  Ostensibly a cooperative game, but players don't work together so much as simply win or lose collectively.  One of Fantasy Flight Games' finer works nonetheless.  A missed opportunity.  If you own a copy anyway, try the "Arkham Investigations" variant for a choose-your-own-adventure game with an underlying (coherent!) plot.

RATING: 5
Played twice now and definitely looking forward to playing again. Love the dice rolling and role-playing. Have no problem with it being to easy. Especially because I like to play it with just my wife. And it isn't to easy with just us!

Edit: Dropping the rating quite a bit. It is a great concept. But there is a critical problem with it. Any game that gets interupted for approximately half its playtime looking up the rules is a BIG GIANT BUZZKILLER. If your game is dripping with theme and all about the experience, but your flow of gameplay is so broken up that you don't actually experience it, then your game kind of sucks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
To play Arkham Horror is always a big event full of fun. Usually we gather in the evening around dinner time and continue playing until the small hours of the night or later. I love it that everything is so random, yet strategy matters so much. Passing or failing a skill check can make drastic changes to the course of the game and you'll have to be aware of the times where you can't have the game to change in the other direction. Yes, this is shitty abstract nonsense. But you know what I mean when the difference is to be devoured or have that terrifying monster off the board!

The base game offers already a lot of versatility, but this is greatly increased to huge amounts by the big box expansions, while the small ones offer some nice change of flavor. I prefer the game with one big box and a small expansion in play, but that causes the necessity to separate the cards after each session. Anyway, it's more than great!

RATING: 8

The theme is really inspiring, but in my opinion it is far from the Lovecraft universe. I mean, the background is ok, but 'heroes' in Lovecraft's novels are desperate people who dies-as-flies or fall into madness without recover, while in this game they are ultra-powered-up machines which handle Ancient Monsters loaded with spells and guns...!

After some time and reflection, I've dumped this game. After a few plays, it became the same every time. They threw all of Lovecraft's works into a blender and made rules for it. A game this the,attic should have way more story to it.

RATING: 6
A game that you either love or hate. I love it.
It's just fun. Each time it's an adventure, an experience, and players need to be in the mood to get immersed into it.
Because it's fiddly and requires players to act as a team.
Long ? Yes, but once players are used to it, it's not that long. We are usually 3 or 4 players, the first games took around 4 hours each, but now we tend to end up in about 2 and a half hours without hurrying at all, which is okay for us.
We don't play it that often anymore but we keep enjoying it.
My main complaint is that it gets too easy to beat once you have fully understood it. We lose the first 4 games, but from then on, we win almost every time, so we had to introduce some house rules to make it more challenging. I think it just lacks of a simple system for adjusting the difficulty level (like Pandemic for instance).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My favourite Boardgame. I have been playing it solitaire mostly and with others a few times. The theme is amazing (Lovecraft Ho!) and the game mechanics too. There is a lot of random stuff going on, which ties in nicely with the chaotic theme of the Cthulhu mythos, although I know a lot of Eurogamers who would not enjoy this. The expansion packs turn this into a huge game and it can easily compete with Descent in terms of scope. Only drawback, if you play with more than four players it gets a bit too long and confusing. Also, if you are not in the right mood, play with the wrong people or in the wrong place, all the "flavour" of the game might not come through. 

EDIT: I have played this twice with groups who did not enjoy it or found the experience boring, and it dragged my experience and joy down with it and I have to say, this game is a definite 10 for me IN THEORY. When played with the wrong group, this can be one of the worst games ever.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Arkham Horror is one of the best adventure games out there.  It's also one of the best cooperative games.  I'm not a huge cooperative game fan, but this game is so baroque in it's design it's easy to get lost in.  That's a good thing.

During the game, players wander around the town of Arkham trying to keep some big bad monster from materializing.  They do this by fending off monsters, collecting useful items and traveling through dimensional portals to seal off otherworldly gates.  If the big bad guy does materialize the players will have to fight it.  There are plenty of references to a wide variety of H. P. Lovecraft's creations.

Does it feel very H. P. Lovecraft-y?  I'm going to have to answer, no.  Sure it's got Cthulhu, et al.  But  Lovecraft's stories follow a pretty rigid formula.  They typically involve some nebbish intellectual getting far too interested in some mysterious occurrence.  He'll typcially uncover some horror man was not meant to know.  If he survives, his sanity suffers.

In Arkham Horror, the characters vary wildly from mobsters to sales-men.  More focus is placed on adventuring rather than trying to comprehend the incomprehensible.  This makes it feel more like "The Dream Quest of Unknown Kadath", a Dreamlands story, than one of Lovecraft's better know works.  This, in turn, is somewhat ironic considering the Dreamlands get such short shrift in Akham Horror and it's expansions.  Though perhaps that will change in the future.

And for those that complain about fending of Cthulhu with a shot gun, have you ever read "Call of Cthulhu"?
[o]In which, a character "kills" Cthulhu and sinks his whole island, R'lyeh, merely by ramming the big dude with a boat."[/o]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
LOTS to this game (more tokens and mini cards then you would believe).  Soo many expansions too.  Every game is different.

RATING: 10

RATING: 6.5
I really do enjoy this game, but it can be SUCH a slog to play or to even get through for that matter.  Everyone has to be in the mood, plus everyone needs to be willing to dedicate a huge chunk of time to play it.  Usually those stars do not come into alignment, and the game is overlooked.

Also its "winability" comes into play a lot as well.  The likelihood of you actually winning a game of Arkham Horror is generally slim, though not impossible, and no one wants to play a co-op game where failure is almost certain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I appreciate a game with a good theme, and this game oozes theme.  The lovecraftian theme is extremely well developed and is appealing to a wider base of gamer.  This is not your generic fantasy rpg boardgame, it is filled with characters players can relate too and monsters that capture the imagination.  That being said, it's a pretty detailed game, and you'll pay for that detail with increased length of gameplay and complexity of rules.  This means your casual gamer friends will potentially be turned off, and it will potentially lead to unfinished games. I suggest luring them into the game with the theme first, saving details for later. The cooperative nature of the game is a key selling point as well, as it makes learning-while-you-play a viable option. Update: Unfinished games DO happen!  But I have never been disappointed!  Also, changed to a 9...it's just really a fun game once you get the hang of it! Update: Changed rating to a 10.  I never get tired of this game...I only wish I had the new reprinted board!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's all about the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Arkham Horror reminds me of a game I adored in my childhood: Talisman, in that the basic principle is to fight monsters and find equipment and items to power up your character enough to face the final challenge.  It differs in that this is a cooperative game, and it is far more complex.  The complexity does not lie in difficulty so much as the incredible number of things to remember.  This game is also quite lengthy, which is fine for some groups, but mine prefers games that can be played in an hour or so.  We like to play multiple games in an evening, and Arkham Horror likes most of an evening to itself.  Unfortunately, the ending isn't much of a payoff either.  In Puerto Rico or Agricola, one builds an entire colony or farm throughout the game, and at the end, you can look it over and feel a sense of accomplishment.  You can see all the pieces of your 'machine' and get a feel for what worked and what didn't.  That sort of visceral satisfaction simply doesn't occur at the end of Arkham Horror, at least not for us.  I've heard a number of great things about this game, but I guess it's just not my cup of tea.

RATING: 6.5
This is a tough game to rate. On the one hand, the components are excellent, the theme is great, the mechanics good, but it's the LENGTH!!! Good god, the length is simply too long for what gameplay there is. If your plans were that important/strategic, that would be one thing - but the overwhelming luck kinda makes the long gametime play hollower than the fun it provides. While I can live with the dicerolls overwhelming the tactics, I think it's the lack of balance in the equipment cards that is the game's Achille's Heel. You could do the exact same sequence of character actions in 2 different games, and the results for one would be a very capable character, but the other (with bad equipment draws) would be useless.

RATING: 7.5
Having only played a couple of times, I may have ranked this higher than I should have. I had a great time playing it each time and loved the "we're getting a butts handed to us" rollercoasting with the "oh my god that was close" feeling.

 I want to get this, but one group I play with has it, and I don't think the other group would like it enough.

* * * UPDATE * * *

Still have only played twice, but have been reading a lot of the threads here about it. I can see how people are saying that the gameplay can almost be pre-dictated for you, but I still need a few more games now that I have these thoughts. 

* * * UPDATE #2 * * *

OK, I played this a third time with 6 people and the Dark Pharoh expansion mixed in. The cards were eally with us, as almost everyone had 1 or 2 weapons, and there were 2 Elder Signs to start off. I think it was Yig we were facing. Anyways, gates were opened and easily closed (by others). I had the Shotgun and a  5 magic weapon, but no clues, so I was basically the street cleaner. We soon had 4 gates closed and every gate afterwards that would have opened was prevented. We called it a game. The cards were both with us to win, but against us to make it interesting.

To sum up, I have lowered my ratings by 1. I will still play the game, and hope to with Dunwich, but I now see the flaws in the game.

RATING: 8
fun game. don't play with too many players. i know the box suggests that up to 8 players can play, but the resulting game would be too long and monotonous. as with a lot of games, 4 seems to be a pretty good number. more later.  

my one biggest complaint about the game is that somehow the rulebook becomes more horribly organized the more familiar you are with the rules. i might sit down one day and re-write them from beginning to end in order to minimize all the page turning and digging around for rules. 

o.k. so it's been a while and i've gotten a few plays of this under my belt. i still dig this game. whenever i get in the mood to draw some cards and roll some dice for a few hours, i'm reaching for this game. (i can just hear some of you gasping.) anyway, i don't understand the complaints about this coming down to a dice fest during the endgame. um, what? what do you want to do instead? would you rather collect sets of cards until the monsters die of boredom?  would you rather consult a crt? the combat system through out the game is clever and original. players have to spend the game preparing themselves for the end fight, while trying to prevent the ancient one from appearing at all. all in all i think  this facet of the game keeps game-play tense and interesting. i just don't think there is any other mechanic that could be substituted for die rolling that could generate the same amount of uncertainty needed to keep the game tense. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]RO[/b]: [i]01/24/2016[/i]

Look at my number of plays. Now look at when I added this to my collection (around when I rated it), now back to my number of plays. That isn't a mistake, I don't always faithfully record my plays but Arkham Horror has hit the table in my old apartment once, and in my now house once. Two times. In five years.

For me, Arkham Horror is a cautionary tale: I should not purchase extremely heavy, lengthy games, that swim or drown based on their theme. Now, if this is you, future David, reading over your collection comments repeat after me: YOU ARE THE ONLY PERSON YOU KNOW THAT LIKES THIS SORT OF GAME. DO. NOT. BUY. THEM.

If you aren't future David and Arkham Horror intrigues you, I would advise you to consider carefully. Arkham Horror is really cool, it combines the Cthulhu mythos of H.P. Lovecraft with a fantasy adventure game. However, it is extremely complex, takes forever to play (especially, I understand if you have expansions), and is a bitch to run if you aren't intimately familiar with the minutia of the rules, not to mention pretty damn difficult. But it's fun. Our first game (50% of my entire experience with it) involved us sorta dressing up like people from the 20's, speakin' in tarible' accents, dah'lin, and sipping apple juice like it was scotch (I was poor at the time and not all of us could drink, also we're total dorks). This immersion made it way more fun than it actually was (though it was pretty fun). So... read over the rules... carefully, peruse some images and check out some video reviews before you decide to tackle this monstrosity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
New in Shrink

RATING: 8

Eldritch Horror superseeded AH for me. But once in 2 years or so I like to return to AH for nostalgia reasons. 
*Falko Mexikos collection

RATING: 8
Excellent cooperative card-driven board game set in HP Lovecraft's Cthulu universe. The players must work together to stop the town of Arkham from being overrun by otherworldly demons before a randomly selected Old One awakes and destroys it. Lots of fun to play even if you are not familiar with the setting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I've grown to like this game with the right crowd. Of course, it takes a fairly long session to play and is not really about winning, but seeing what happens. The multiple expansions can be used on and off, mixed together etc. so you can really theme the game in a number of ways. The biggest gripe for me is the long setup time, but even that can be lessened by organizing the bits and pieces in a better way.

The game oozes replayability in a nice scale. The different Great Old Ones and Investigators always change the game a bit. Add in expansions, mix a few together etc. and the game varies greatly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
If you are looking to play this game like you would play chess, stay far away. This is a hot mess of rules, die rolls, skill checks and modifiers. There is a huge amount of things to keep track of. You have your boss counter, monster limit, gate limit, outskirts limit, rumors, curses, blessings, retainers and terror levels to keep in mind as you play. The sheer amount of content in this game is staggering. You have 16 highly detailed characters with their own stats in the 6 areas: speed, sneak, will, fight, lore and luck. You have unique starting items, heart/brain numbers and of course powers. Each character also has a cool backstory on the back of the sheet. There are tons and tons of cards. There are spells, common items, unique items, allies and memberships. And there are quite a number of encounters you get when you draw one for your turn to ensure replay value. This game is a total beast. Why do I like it? Well I for one appreciate the massive amount of things to go through. I like playing a new character and feeling how differently it goes. Or trying a new boss to take on. Maybe this game, the game will be easy and the town will be saved. Maybe next game will have us on our knees with the baddies never letting up. You have to appreciate randomness to play. This is a true American style game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you love Lovecraft, this is a must.

RATING: 6
This game would be more enjoyable if it were shorter.  Even so, it's a pretty good game.  I love the choose your own adventure style of the gameplay, and I love the large number of character choices and bad guy choice because they make Arkham Horror into a game with a lot of replayability.

But I don't like the tedious gameplay.  I feel like I'm moving bits around just to around bits.  Read the cards in this order and follow a prescribed routine doesn't appeal to me.  Plus, the story aspect should be the most important part of Arkham Horror and I have a hard time getting into the story.

RATING: 5.25

RATING: 7
*Recently upgraded after playing with Dunwich Horro Expansion!*

Damn you, Arkham, I want to like you more.  D&D without the imaginary landscape and uber-nerdiness, but it's just so fiddly.  This is guaranteed: if you have a new player in the game or the 'game master' hasn't played in a while, expect to spend 50% of time trying to find the special conditions and obscurities in the rules in just about every phase of a round.  

In addition, the base game is broken.  When you start to progress in sealing gates, the difficulty REDUCES as you get closer to the end.  You can be left with 1-2 hours of chore-like clean-up when victory is guaranteed.  House rules for getting more monsters on the board are needed or potentially the Dunwich expansion helps solve the issue by allowing sealed gates to burst open.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 8
A very challenging game dripping with theme.The production values here are through the roof, with beautiful boards and cards throughout. 

Setup time is pretty steep since the expansions introduce a lot of customization to the game. Actual playing time ranges from moderate to extremely lengthy depending on if players read aloud all the story/flavor text.

As with any dice game, there is a high luck factor. This works well with the Cthulhu theme though, as players find themselves getting cursed and pummeled into insanity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love games that tell a story, especially ones that inspire me to tell stories after the event. This one always seems to do so.

There is a popular saying around this game that "the game knows." Just when you think you've got the winning move, the game hits you with your worst nightmare, throwing you into the oblivion.

Sometimes (rarely) just when you think you're on the cusp of losing, along comes something that swings the game back in your favour.

Mechanically there are flaws and it takes an age to setup, play and pack away again, but when you get those moments where everything flows together to create a cinematic event that you remember for a lifetime, there's little that can match it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

Too much time spent looking up rules and their weird and subtle interactions, which ruins the mood. I think this is not a game for casual play: you have to play it often enough to become very familiar with it. I like it, but not that much. (Also, although this is my favorite cooperative game, I'm just not a big fan of cooperative games.)

RATING: 6
Enjoyable at first, though it has become a bit overblown.

I initially bought the game because I love the Lovecraft Mythos, and it was fun to explore through the medium of board games.  However, the randomness of the game leads to nonsensical story lines as often as it leads to interesting ones.  This is something that has been addressed in Eldritch Horror by using specific themed decks.

Setup time has always been too long, and the addition of expansions just make it worse.

I would recommend trying the campaign rules that can be found online if you have the time.  It will take you through the majority of the content and is quite enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow Arkham Horror! This was the first board game I played as an adult and the one that got me hooked. After this I bought every expansion as they came out and I think I would have rated it a 10 back then! It certainly got me into board games and for that alone it will always be well thought of.

The theme is brilliant and the mechanics in the base game - sound enough. It really is one of the most epic games available I think.

But even in its most basic form it is epic - there's a lot of rules and things that need to be done. It can take hours and sometimes you doom yourself in the first thirty minutes but it takes another hour before you lose. As an epic sweeping tale it is great but its not very practical and as I result I almost never play it now. Each expansion adds even more rules and things to do and even the base game takes up a huge space - with the expansions lets just say I hope your partner doesn't mind you taking a lot of space up!

If you have the time and desire it is unsurpassed as an epic thematic experience but games have evolved over the years and Arkham Horror I think is a crucial part of board game history that has since been surpassed by those who learned from it including its own successor of sorts - Eldritch Horror.

If you get trapped on an island though take this and all the expansions!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

If I wanted this level of die rolling, bookkeeping, and fiddling around with a million cards and bits I would play an RPG or some old-school 1970's wargame.  I would absolutely love to like this game.  Really I would.  But it's basically like playing Runebound in Hell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best H.P.Lovecraft-inspired game around!  All players must work together to stop an ancient evil from awakening.  Extremely challenging, even against the "easier" ancient ones.  The learning curve is steep, but game play picks up after a few attempts.

RATING: 8.5
Awesome game. Love the artwork, quality of the pieces and huge variety of monsters and investigators that comes with the basic game. The loads of pieces and card that comes with this game give the impression that it already has some expansions, but it is just simply very complete.  

The thing i did not like is the not so very clear rulebook. It's covered mostly everything, but some rules or situations is just frakkin hard to find. Especially the first game is gameboard horror. 

+ This game is great when you like playing together against the board and developing a nice storyline. 

- The game is not so great when you are into tactics and hours of scanning the board for the best possible move.

RATING: 7.61
My friends and I are casual board gamers, and so this took a few games to get the game mechanics right and 
remember all the different rules.  Which at first turned me off the game due to its complexity and led to some random game play to start with.
It's this very complexity that has increased the game longevity and made it one of our favourites as no 2 games are the same.
Great fun & well worth it, would highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a compelling cooperative game with a couple of hours spare.

You need to be able to invest the time in playing this game.

I like the game but i get the same fun from Eldritch Horror which for me has replaced this game.

RATING: 6
A good game, but it has its downsides. First, I don't really feel in control of what happens in the game. I admit that fits the theme, but I'd rather a game help me create a story rather than force one on me. Secondly, this game is LONG! I've had games last over four hours. On the positive side, though, this game really excels at creating that creepy, distinctly Lovecraftian atmosphere. It really does feel like your characters are all that stands between humanity and unfathomable madness from beyond the gulfs of time and space!

RATING: 7.5
Tulli
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Oh, Arkham Horror. I give it a 9, well, because its too good.  :P

1) Arkham is co-op, but don' let this fool you. It is one of the best board games ever made.

2) Not for casual gamers. Huge investment of time both learning the game and each time you play it.

3) Errata almost mandatory. Look it up after your first or second game. 

4) The BEST physical construction of any game ever. The board, cards, chits and pieces are IMMACULATE. The Monster tiles are out of this world good. 

5) It took us 3 days to learn the rules. The whole weekend, I am not kidding. Better to play with ppl who already know how to play :) Or watch online tutorials first.

6) You will need to take notes, and organize them, to play the first few times. Keep them for reference. Maybe soon I will make cheat sheets for you :P

7) I have never regretted buying Arkham Horror, even though it was over 50 bucks, even though almost no one ever wants to play it twice, even though we have only played it 4 times and even though we have only finished a game once...

8) I have never regretted it. The physical quality alone is worth owning it. I open the box and SHOW it off to more people than ever end up actually playing it. And they always go wide-eyed and "Woooowwwww..."

9) A nice copy of Arkham is required for any serious board game collection or anyone serious about co-op board games, period.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

Excellent, RPG as a boardgame. 

Probably too much chrome for gamers who like elegance and too much randomness for those who like strategy. 

However if you want a deep, thematic solo game that allows you numerous interesting choices every turn this is for you.

Minus 1 for too much maintenance dice rolling, Minus 1 for not enough Arhkam encounter cards (however the Mythos and exploration cards are wonderfully deep). Pluses on everything else. An extra .5 for being a solo enabled game put out by a big publisher and for being a good meaty old school game in an age of lighter designs.

Highly reccomended for solo gamers who are also Cthulhu RPG fans, hey thats me :)

Bring on the expansion packs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My experience:

4 games played - 2 players, each player controlling 2 investigators.

I think this game is fantastic.

I like: 
- The game produces a story. The encounters are very RPG-like. Skill checks, combat, choices, objects, magic items, spells, it is all there. 

- The rules are complex but less complex than almost any traditional RPG. The complexity pays off because it gives you many options each turn.

- 3 different ways to victory, a variety of characters and of GOO's add to replayability.

I don't like:
- The new player has to invest a fair amount of time to understand and start playing the game unless there is somebody else to teach the it.

No other complaints.

RATING: 9
I really like this game. I have played multiple times each solo and two players, but each was a blast. The theme is great for me as I am not a huge fan of the genre. 
Tense and fun, some call this a dice fest, but I disagree. Plenty of options each turn keep this fun. I have recently updated my score to 9 after two solo games and multi-player games. Any game that works well as a solo game and can be played with other players is a big plus for me. 
The only downside is the playing time which can run 4 hours, but if you can leave it out and come back to it there is no problem. 
It now has many expansion to enjoy your fun even more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I played the original edition back in the 90s.  Then 2008-01-05 I played a 5-player game of this new edition, with some expansions, and it took us almost 6 hours of collecting spell/weapon/skill cards and having wildly random encounters and cooperating to kill monsters and close enough gates.

The long play time was partly caused by 2 players selling their gate trophies instead of keeping them, but still, the game went way too long, and it got repetitive and frustrating.

The old me would have enjoyed that long slog more than the new me.  It's a good game if you're into this sort of boardgame roleplaying adventure.  It has some neat mechanics, and it's fun seeing the large amount of special cards.  But I don't seem to be into this kind of game very much any more.  My time is too short.

The components are quite well-done with some beautiful art, and some of the flavor text is nice.  (Some of it is silly, e.g. the "Twin Peaks" cherry pie reference in a diner encounter.)

Beware it is VERY text-dependent, if you play with non-native-English speakers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game with great atmosphere.

RATING: 7
Arkham reminds me very much of the eighties: very enjoyable when experienced in its proper context. It's flawed and random, but it's a very fun coop vehicle for light storytelling within a good group. I have no problem with the tons of setup concept when it leads to a good experience. And if you're lucky enough to have a great game runner, as we do, it's a blast.

RATING: 8.1
Not sure what to make of this game. The game simply beats you up for as long as you are willing to play it. Enjoyable in a weird sort of way, like a horror-themed dominatrix. In my experience, the game play has been long (usually four to six hours) and there are a lot of rules to follow. However, the components and theme are top notch and extremely well done. The quality of the game is what keeps me coming back for more. 

You need to be familiar with at least a few of H.P. Lovecraft's short stories before you play or the theme will be lost on you.

As far as expansions go, they say not to include more than one at a time or else they will dilute each other and you won't get a taste of their true flavor. Looking forward to trying them all but this will take some time to accomplish.

RATING: 7.1
It's a special occasion when we have a chance to enjoy AH because it does require a time commitment. We've tried Eldritch Horror but prefer AH. There's something about the intimate atmosphere of the Arkham streets, and mounting tension of desperately attempting to close the gates while alien creatures try to block you every step of the way that Eldritch Horror lacks. We also like the fiddly rules in AH, which aren't really difficult at all after a few turns. Just download and follow one of the excellent flowcharts on the BBG site, and after a few turns everything falls into place.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I think this one of those boardgames where you can just teach everyone the rules and plan.  You need a GM who is expert on the rules and can really sell the theme, like one would in a RPG, to the players progressing through the game. Without that, the game just really flopped for us. More streamlined co-ops like Pandemic are just a lot more fun to play. The constant skill checks just get so boring and tedious, and the game can easily stagnate where you're not making any significant negative or positive progress for a long, long time.  I really felt I was lost in time and space metaphorically during the 2 games I played. I'm willing to try it again if I'm in the mood and have an expert that can basically GM it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I feel like I can't play enough of this game. I'll punish myself and stay up way too late just to get in a game of AH. There's something rewarding and satisfying about getting your butt handed to you by this game. I love having terribly unsuccessful rolls all game long almost as much as I love those times when we put the game to bed. Nothing beats tommygunnin' hordes of monsters and racking up the trophies. This is a real epic game, and I love the details, the fiddliness, the theme, and the execution. I'm excited to acquire and play the expansions.

Update: I've had an abrupt change of opinion. Maybe I've played the base game to much, but the game feels too predictable. Recently, it feels like either I know I'm going to win after a long, slow process, or I know I'm going to lose roughly "X" number of turns from now and there's nothing I can do to stop it. I get really frustrated with poor die rolls, especially in the beginning when it feels like I'm getting a handicapped start. These are new feelings for me regarding this game. I feel very bummed, since I've had so much fun with this. The epic narrative that has me caring for my investigators has given way to frustration with fiddliness and bad luck.

Update: Dunwich Horror has rejuvenated my interest in this game. See below.

RATING: 4
Tried to play once solo to get a feel for it. Definitely not my type of game in that it is incredibly random and clunky.

Still, I could be convinced to play again. I would never play it solo again, but with a group of the right people, this could be an enjoyable experience. This could fuel a fun evening. It is random, but the way it is used means that every game will be different and could create some tense or even even hilarious moments that the creators of the game probably never even foresaw specifically.

The clunkiness of the rules would probably lessen after playing enough times to be familiar with them. 

In short, would try again in a group if asked, but not a game I would seek out.

RATING: 10
What can I say about this game? Epic battles between a few heroic citizens and the vast host of evil gathering as the Ancient Ones attempt to re-enter the world makes for one heck of a fun time. 

Rules can cause an astonishing amount of debate, which is probably the only negative I have about the game as a whole. Everyone I know enjoys playing it, everyone I know enjoy the stories that are made up on the spot to account for the strange happenings befalling everyone.

The length can be off-putting to some; but it's a hot property in my gaming group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A novel-based Role-playing game, a very good introduction to the Cthulhu mytho system. AH is never strategic: once you know the event cards, with a little bit of luck, you can waltz over the Other World and screw Cthulhu single handedly... So, really, this game is about experiencing other than managing. You play your role, you read the card text, and you pretend you were there, in that horrible town. Don't think of anything like 'I should definitely go to the newspaper as I have a 4/7 change to get a retainer'. It spoils the story.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Darn good Ameritrash. The mechanics are a bear to learn, but, once you have them down, adding the expansions becomes quite easy. Furthermore, if you have an experienced player, the rules can be introduced piecemeal, making the game easy to introduce. The base game with four or more players is easy, but if you remove some of the Elder Signs from the Unique Items deck, it should become more difficult. Or purchase the Dunwich Horror expansion set -- it adds thematic Insanity and Injury cards, and has an additional board to make 4+ play much more challenging.

****

The base game is 85% of the difficulty in the entire game series. At least play with the Injury and Madness cards. If you have 5+ players, play with the Dunwich board, though not necessarily with the Dunwich small cards.

The hardest part of the game will be the monsters. I *highly* suggest setting up the game ahead of time and playing a few turns yourself, and get the BGG player aid files with the flowcharts. When you play by yourself, fight monsters to learn the mechanics.

****

To save space on the board: 
* All the Encounter decks can be put into one deck. Just fan out the cards and pick one from your neighborhood.
* Put the smaller decks near locations that often use them. eg. Unique Items on the Curiousitte Shoppe location.
* Separate some space between an expansion board and the main board to put stuff in.
* Use "caches". When a player loses Stamina, Sanity, Money, etc. place the tokens on the board at the Hospital, Asylum, and Bank, rather than returning them to the storage bag.
* The AO sheet is the "cache" for Doom Tokens, Clues, and anything returned to the box.
* Use a small dice tray. A 100 card count plastic box works fine.

Other setup:

* Have the n00bs do as much setup as they can. Usually, this means anything with the tokens. Anyone who comes late plays a random character, setup before they arrive. While playing, I use the Bank, Asylum, and Hospital as caches to hold tokens. The BGG files also has a character sheet that avoids tokens, but it's too big for tables I play on. I also don't use dice because they roll.

* The Ancient One sheet is a cache for the Clue tokens and "return to the box" cards.

* Only play with one expansion set at a time, subject to Miskatonic. 

* Shuffle expansion and base decks separately, and place them next to each other on the board. Players draw the first card from the expansion set deck. Alternate drawing from the base and expansion Mythos decks, and don't even use the base Mythos deck with a small expansion (unless it's KiY). Use the expansion Encounter or Gate decks, instead of the base set.

***

I usually play with a single expansion, so don't mind keeping components in separate boxes -- just grab the base set and another box, and I'm good to go!

AH base game:
* All AOs which have no special components
* All Investigators with no cards from expansions
* All monsters except aquatic
* Injury and Madness cards (Dunwich)
* Final Battle cards (Kingsport)
* Personal Stories (Innsmouth)

Dunwich
* Investigators who start with cards from Dunwich set
* AOs with special components
* Curse of Dark Pharoah expansion set

Kingsport
* Investigators who start with cards from Kingsport set
* King in Yellow expansion set

Innsmouth
* Aquatic monsters
* Goat in the Woods expansion set

...if I get more frickin' monsters, I'm going to separate the hexagonal ones to the Goat in the Woods set for the Herald's cup!

***

Dunwich: Adds the much-lauded Injury and Madness cards. Also extends the playing area with a smaller board, pretty much necessary when you have more than four players.

Kingsport: Adds the Ancient One cards. Makes the Final Battle more unpredictable. The rest of the expansion is kinda less "exciting" (ie. deadly) since the additional board are stable locations. PM me if you want some custom heralds which add unstable locations to Kingsport.

Innsmouth: No "vital" cards, but makes the game much more dangerous. The Personal Stories add depth to the characters. I *think* Innsmouth has enough Innsmouth-related monsters for you to have a separate monster cup just of Innmouth monsters!

****

For your first game:

* Play a few turns solo. 
* Get the FAQ and reference sheets.
* Ancient One: Azathoth.
* Select investigators without a "3" stat. 
* Monsters appear on the board but don't do anything on the first turn. 

***

Feel free to use the DH board. With 4+ players, adding more real estate makes the game more of a challenge, and you will be there to "moderate" the game, anyway.

My house rule I use for n00bs is that they may place the slider anytime during the turn. Since they're new to the game, they'll have no idea where to put the slider during the first upkeep.

Also, explain how combat works only when the players have grasped the non-monster rules. Remember that the number of dice you will need *at least* is "3x the monster toughness plus the combat modifier". Investigators should have at least $2 cash on them for the Asylum and Hospital! 

*****

In the base box, I added stuff from some of the other expansions:
* Dunwich Horror: Injury and Madness cards
* Kingsport Horror: Ancient One Final Battle cards
* Innsmouth Look: Personal Stories
* Call of Cthlulhu LCG "Bag-o-Cthulhu" large and small tokens for the First Player and Terror Track tokens.
...plus various investigators, Ancient Ones, and monsters.

I threw out the insert and the box uses:
* Four 100-count Ultrapro deck boxes. They also fit the small cards.
* One large drawstring bag for the monsters
* One large ziploc bag for the investigators
* Several snack-sized ziploc bags for the other tokens.

Each big box expansion has enough space to put a small box expansion inside the well of the insert.

*****

Just some house rules I like to use... :goo:

1. For theme, separate out the aquatic monsters and put them in an Innsmouth cup. Since they're orange-bordered, they're easy to sort out. If any get in the monster cup, no big deal. I've also sorted out the Shub Niggurath monsters as the Black Goat hex cup. The Mask monsters are put into a deck. The first monster on the board is a Mask monster. The first monster in a gate surge is a Mask monster. For Dunwich, the first monster on the Whately gates (left side of board) is Old Man Whately, and the first monster at the Gardner's farm is a Colour Out of Space.

2. To reduce setup and teardown, draw regular-sized cards from the expansion cards first, and place the small cards from the expansion set next to the base game cards. This usually makes the game harder. For smaller cards, experienced players draw their first and third card from the expansion set cards first. Encounter cards are discarded, not reshuffled. When I run out of Encounter cards, I replace them all with those of the base set.

3. With all the Gate cards, you can make a separate deck for each Other World. In practice, for an Other World encounter, I draw a Gate Card, and, if it doesn't match the Other World, place it face down on one of the Other Worlds listed on the card, preferably the one with the fewest face-down Gate cards.

*****

Rather than shuffling the decks (and sorting them out after play)

* Small Decks: Put the base game and expansion small decks side-by-side on the game board. First card drawn is from the expansion deck. Newbies draw from the base game deck.

* Mythos Deck: Put the base game and expansion Mythos decks side-by-side off the game board. Alternate drawing from these decks.

* Encounter and Gate Deck: Draw from the expansion set deck first and discard (even for Encounters). When the deck or an Encounter location is exhausted, replace the deck with the base game deck.

Play the Injury and Madness cards (as well as Innsmouth's Personal Stories) with *every* game. Same with the monsters, Investigators and Ancient Ones. But, otherwise, there's no need to play the expansions together unless you have Miskatonic. No, don't sort out the monsters from the cup.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I feel like this game rides on the theme. I love the Mythos as much as anyone (Ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn, and all that), but Arkham Horror's mechanics are so fiddly and mathematical (and I don't usually mind fiddly and mathematical) that I lose the mood, as it were. It's super long, and every time I play it, it feels like all my running around is ultimately redundant. We usually end up prematurely waking up Ye Old Grand Un, and cheating until it's dead. Then we all cheer. I can appreciate why people love this game (and I don't have any of the expansions), but the giant Lovecraftian conglomeration of systems and theme just doesn't come together for me. Playing it feels like work, more often then not. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I was only very vaguely familiar with the setting--everyone knows about Cthulu, right?

The game (vs. Yig) also took 5.5 hours!  My brain was completely fried.

There's so much going on (Yellow paths, black paths, moves like: "Monsters with triangles, slashes, and stars, or moons move," that one wonders why exactly there need to be quite so many combinations of possible moves.  I guess it is a game balancing thing but it was just annoying to have to check every monster for what symbol, every single turn.  There were a lot of things that just slowed rounds down incredibly.

I do appreciate that this game is co-op, and enjoyed that element.  For that reason I'd play it again with the caveat that it needed to be a monster who could be defeated relatively quickly, or at least quicker than *that* game.

RATING: 6.5
I just haven't had a good game of this yet, where all the players were satisfied. It seems to play too long and the rules are too muddled with far too many exceptions. I heard [thing=146021]Eldritch Horror[/thing] does a lot to fix this game's issues.

[b]Expansions Owned:[/b]

RATING: 7
Quite a game.  Great looking board, lots of cards and tokens and overall a really good production (minis for the characters might have been nice...similar to those for Betrayal at House on the Hill.)  I have always liked Lovecraft's work and the Cthulu mythos and seeing a lot of that brought to life was really cool.  I particularly liked the allies, especially Pitmann.  That's an excellent story and I like how his effect is incorporated by negating physical immunity of monsters.

The game is long but I dind't find it to be overly long.  Its also a bit arbitrary.  One person runs into a monster, the next person finds a load of clue tokens.  But such is life in the world of Arkham.  This isn't a game I would play all the time but a couple of times a year, sure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There are a lot of things to like about Arkham Horror, like how it manages to create a fun pulpy paragraph game with lots of detail and thematic richness. The downside is that most of that richness must be avoided if the players want to have any chance at winning. The expansions only amplify the problem, filling it with little details that can never be explored if you want to have a shot at victory. It's also way more complex than it needs to be. Over twenty games and I still need to have a flow-chart in hand when I play. There's a lot to like, and it's such an important game from the last decade. Still, it's more of a museum piece for me now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Despite its reputation as a long and arduous heavy co-op game, this was one of my earlier board game purchases, and I have overall not been disappointed.  The myriad tiny cards and decent-quality tokens in this game come together to give you an experience that, despite that this game's production quality isn't on the level of a "premium edition" game, makes the game night feel like a special event.

This was also my first experience in the Lovecraftian theme in games, so there was some additional mystique there for me that I suppose would not exist for those already familiar (or bored) with it, but I think the game captures the feeling of cosmic dread quite well.  I have long sought a game which creates a compelling narrative that is different each time you play, and while I don't think this game completely achieves that - inevitably at some point you'll encounter events that seem incongruous with the overarching situation - I think it does so as well as any game I've played so far.

It's necessary to acknowledge that this game is carried largely by its theme and the way the mechanics embrace the idea of ever-present mortality, and the helplessness of mere humans.  You may find yourself against absurdly insurmountable odds at some times, and that is meant to be part of the fun.  If you don't tend to get engrossed in atmosphere and theme and/or don't accept that luck-based events with potentially dire consequences have a place in games, there is little reason for you to play this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
The disparate elements of Arkham Horror fail to come together in any fun or meaningful way. The goals, theme, and components all work to create a dark and interesting atmosphere that is easy to get invested in. This is undermined, however, by a complex mess of rules and text-based systems that slow the game down and are often overly-vague. What's more, there seems to be a number of items and sub-goals (I am thinking primarily of certain shops and encounters) that are totally irrelevant and unhelpful in the resolution of the game. Were these more than random items with modifiers and checks and perks that mean less and less the more you've collected, they might be fun to pursue. As it is, there just seems to be too little to do that is of any consequence and too much to keep track of. While the game has an end goal, your actions rarely seem to be driving toward it and instead feel like pointless tangents.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Note: I have not played any of the newer Lovecraft games Elder sign, Mansions of Madness, or Eldritch Horror. My opinion of AH is not influenced by them.]

Visual Appeal: (5)
I love Fantasy Flight game art. The board is super easy to read and isn't obscured by the art. Each monster, Great One and character has a lot of personality.

Components: (4)
Nice thick cardboard chips. Needs some organization system not included in the box. I use small bowls. I am not a fan of mini-cards, but I can appreciate the space saved by using them here. The only other thing I don't like are the sliders to mark player stats. On a busy table they inevitably get jostled. If the sliders were built into the card or on a dial I would prefer. The cards and chips are up to the FFG standard of high quality.

Theme: (5)
This is the kind of game where people start to get seriously stressed out if things aren't going well. If 2D printouts of monsters have that effect, then something is going well with the theme. Some monsters are so threatening that there's just no way to overcome them. And that's a good thing, because hiding is just as exciting! The characters aren't superheroes, and you become invested in their sanity.

Learning: (2)
It takes quite a while to teach this game and teaching plus a full play through is exhausting. The rule book is concise as it can be with good examples, so I would recommend some pre-reading if I have serious new players coming to a planned game. Returning to the rule book mid-game feels inevitable since I don't get it to the table often enough to remember everything.

Gameplay: (4)
This is a co-op game where all players are moving around in different locations. Like Pandemic, you could huddle together for safety, but you'll need to spread your assets uncomfortably thin to have a chance at victory. Unlike Pandemic, if you fail you could go insane or be torn limb from limb by extra-dimensional horrors. Whereas Pandemic has an overall sense of impending doom, Arkham Horror makes it much more personal through tense dice rolling encounters. 

Overall Fun: (4)
This game is great when we have the time to play it. I usually have 3 players and our running joke is to ask "who wants a quick game of Arkham?" Every time we've played has been an all night affair, but it always feels like time well spent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The complexity and how every game is different, makes it an outstanding game. I  love how your tactics and plan can be disrupted in just one or two turns. The unpredictability makes an agile mind bending game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a cooperative horror game set in the world of H.P. Lovecraft's mythos.  Players take on the role of investigators who must race to close and seal dimensional gates before a Great Old One rises and likely kills or renders insane the party, while also fending off "lesser" monsters who wander the streets of Arkham.  It can be played as a lite role playing game or as a strategy game with some role playing elements.

There is great tension as the players are usually outnumbered and rather doomed, which is fitting with the setting.  Each player's character is unique, and each round players may adjust their stats which allows for some wonderful tactical moments.

The game is long but worth the time, especially if you play up the role of your character, which will give rise to a good story.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yet to play. Want to like this, although I am dubious about 'flavour text' in games - if I want to enjoy bad writing I'll read Lovecraft, who does it best. 

After 1 play : Ok, the rule book deserves all the criticism, but this is no Magic Realm. Gameplay is reasonably smooth, and I have to say, so far, I am really liking it. Plus the wife actually enjoyed it a lot more than our previous co-op experience (Lord of the Rings and Pandemic), in spite of the fact that it took us nearly 4 hours to play.

Flavour text seems snappier than in Runebound, the theme is wonderfully worked. Shame about the Ghoul illustration (which is even accompanied by a description of the 'canine' features) - that ain't no Lovecraftian Ghoul, I must mewl.

Considerably exceeded expectations.

2015 edit:I eventually sold all my Arkham stuff - it never got played, and took up too much space. I bought Elder Signs as a replacement. Something about the comparative size and simplicity appealed to me. If space and money weren't an issue, though, Arkham might have stayed.

RATING: 8.5
Overly complex, with too many rules and a lot of unclear or ambiguous wording.  Takes too long.  Takes up too much room.  Requires expansions or house rules to fix the game once you understand the basic winning strategy.  And...

...I love this game despite all its apparent flaws!  Once I got into it I played virtually nothing else for several months, and bought most of the expansions within that time.

I highly recommend it for solo play as long as you have plenty of time and space available - or, like me, you have somewhere you can leave it set up somewhere safe from pets and small children!  While it's certainly rich with theme, you don't need to immerse yourself in the story, RPG-style, to enjoy it - there's plenty going on mechanics-wise if gameplay is your primary concern (as it is for me).

RATING: 3
Tedious. 

Encourages groups to set up 2-3 characters to run rampant across the board, killing monsters and doing whatever needs doing. If you are not one of those characters you will spend much of your time cowering in corners because it doesn't make sense to fight the monsters. I've never managed to accomplish anything significant in Arkham Horror, and I've never lost. 

Takes too long, is too random, and is disconnected from the theme. You have little control over the encounter you draw, and so you don't know what stats you will need. If you are loaded up with items and spells, then you should be fine. Otherwise you have too few meaningful choices about the game, and probably won't accomplish anything.

RATING: 9
There just isn't any substitute for Arkham. The game is highly thematic, varied, tense, immersive, and enjoyable. You can play it with a wide range of player numbers, but I think the most important thing for me is that you can play it alone. Arkham is a wonderful solitaire experience. It isn't the shortest game to play, nor is it the easiest to learn, but I think its worth both the time and energy to do so. I couldn't imagine not having it in my collection. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the more enjoyable cooperative games.  The theme and the game really work well together, and the additional expansions are also nice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have to give Arkham Horror props simply for being an incredible co-op experience. This is one of those rare games where everyone's working together towards a common cause, and it's an amazing accomplishment to actually WIN. 

My gripes about Arkham Horror would normally be pretty major (too many pieces, length of play, complex rules), but once the game gets going, it's so much FUN that it's really hard to dislike it.

I am less thrilled with the expansions, which are pretty much designed to make the game harder, more complicated and harder to set up. I'd rather just take the character cards out of the expansions and stick with the original game.
