=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There are a lot of positive things I will say about this game but as with some of my other reviews I will be addressing points made by people who hate the game and rated it poorly. Let's see here:

"Brain-Dead Turns" | "My Decisions do not matter" | "Game plays itself"|

This seems to be a general theme. I guess if you really feel that way you are absolutely playing the game wrong without a shadow of doubt in my mind. EVERY decision is meaningful, and if you don't do something right GAME OVER. Yeah, it's that brutal. This game is probably one of the hardest cooperative games that is WINNABLE I've ever played. But don't listen to those negative reviews, every choice matters. Between killing monsters so your outskirts don't get piled up, to beefing yourself up to be able to face encounters to get clues and/or seal gates, to cooperative with your teammates it's all very important. A turn wasted in this game could very well mean the difference between an advantage, and a disadvantage.

"Dice Luck." | "Game is completely random."

Uhm. Yeah. That's the point, random encounters, mythos, to make it  so when you face the same Ancient One you're not following the same storyline. Wouldn't that be boring? This is a narrative game you know. Complaints about dice luck make me laugh. Go play a card game then. Stay away from board games. It's so easy to mitigate bad dice luck.

"Poor game Mechanics" | "Game is Totally unbalanced, you can stay at certain locations and not lose." 

What? The mechanics in this game are pretty damn rich, well detailed, and the game is truly balanced. I've had hard games where I've lost by a long shot, games where I've barely lost, games where I've barely won, and games that I won by a fair margin. I don't see ANY balance issues here, or any locations that are overpowered/broken. You're most likely playing the game wrong, which seems to be a common trend with Arkham Horror players from my experience.

"x and x games are better for cooperative feeling."

To a point, this can be true. If you're simple-minded. I think the suggestion was play Pandemic instead, which from my experience is a neat game. But that's it, just neat. It get's pretty boring pretty fast. Core game versus core game, Arkham Horror overshadows most Cooperative games by a towering shadow, and I'm sorry Pandemic doesn't hold a candle to Arkham Horror in "Cooperative Depth." Don't get me wrong, Pandemic (core) certainly has VERY strong cooperative play, but Arkham has stronger. In Pandemic you're all running around doing the SAME thing, trying to remove cubs and maybe trade cards, bounce special abilities to get someone to remove more cubes, move further, etc. In Arkham you have that AND about 50+ more problems. A monster is going to attack someone? Can they handle that fight? I'll lower my sneak so it comes after me instead, clearing monsters so people can get to locations, ALL THE DAMN MYTHOS CARDS THAT REQUIRE TEAMWORK TO FINISH, I can bless my teammates!? Please.

"The downtime between turns is so long, there's so much board maintenance!"

Maybe if you're not fluent in english and it's your first time playing the game I'll agree. Resolving a Mythos Card, moving monsters, and placing a gate, counting monsters for terror, etc. This should take less than 3-5 minutes unless you're talking about the effects of a Mythos and what your next gameplan is. Players should be thinking about what they are going to do not just this turn, but the turn in advance as well. Turns take about 1-5 minutes depending on your encounter. The only problem comes in when you have AP, or analysis paralysis.

-

Well there are a lot of negative reviews so I won't go through all of them. Point is this game is amazing, if you want something fresh and new in a cooperative feeling and you're not afraid of complexity I would definitely recommend this game.

I will agree this game can be long, and usually you have to explain a lot, but I've never had any problems and my games usually take 3-6 hours depending on how long my friends take to think of their turn. Which to a lot seems like a long time but it's worth it because you REALLY do feel like you just saved the world.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
It could be because I learned this game and played only once on a heavily modded copy + 3 expansions. Or maybe it hasn't aged well, especially next to Corey Koniezcka's recent efforts. Whatever it is, this was an outright disappointment. Basically a huge sense of "do random things and have random things happen to you" without a way to tie everything together, making it more a stitched-together mash-up of choose-your-adventure (like Tales of Arabian Nights) instead of true board game. Shit happens to you, you roll a die, and look up the result. Rinse and repeat.

Mansions of Madness has the same setting, and feels like a board game with meaningful choices. And Gears of War scratches the Ameritrash cooperative itch with interesting missions and tense action (heck, you can even seal "portals" -- emergence holes -- in that).

The only thing I like here is the Focus, to change your risk exposure to different situations. In fact, most proponents of AH argue that it is a game of risk-taking, but still, I fail to see how a cooperative game with perfect information can transcend little more than an overly long, shared RPG narrative experience and become a board game, let alone a good one.

RATING: 7
Oh the pain.  The sweet, brutal, torturous pain.  Long set-up, 3 hours minimum to play, long breakdown to put away.  So WHY do I rate it a 9?  I love the theme.  Simple as that.  One of the few co-op games that I will suggest to play as it has a group element for overall planning, but you still get your OWN turn.  Cool items to pick up, monsters to fight, journeys to the "other" side, a potential fight against a Great Old One, and inevitably, defeat.  A fun, exciting, excellent ride into oblivion!

After playing Eldritch Horror, AH takes a serious step back.  I think that AH got way too big for itself and it collapsed under its own weight.  This went from a classic game that I would have held onto forever to something that I wouldn't mind seeing go.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Prior to 2011, I only played AH solitaire.  

This game can be crazy fun.  The theme is blended in perfectly, and the tension is pretty constant for the entire game.  Many have criticized the pace (less difficult as you seal more gates) but the you can either add an expansion or use a couple house-rules to fix whatever you think needs fixing.  This game is easily modifiable, especially with the excellent Strange Aeons program. Rolling a 5 or 6 has never been so satisfying.

There are negatives, of course, and the fiddly-ness (both in terms of components and rules) has to be at the top of the list.  Nowadays, I don't bring this out very often because if I have an hour or two to play something, I don't want to spend most of that time setting something up.   Best played in the middle of summer, during vacation, over the course of 2 days.

Update (Feb, 2011):  finally played this 2-player and it was great fun.  

Update (2014):  I'm down-grading this to a 6 now that I own Eldritch Horror.  I'll probably keep AH in my collection, but it doesn't have the same draw anymore.  When would I pull out AH over EH?  Not sure, not sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Yay. A board game for RPGamers.  Or what to do if you haven't time to DM and go into character building (yay for interesting pre-set characters with backstories). I really like the system (RPG wise). And this is what it is: a great RPG substitute with great atmosphere - if players immerse themselves in it. If that's not what you're after, don't even bother with this game. Furthermore each game can have a different atmosphere - one is romantic gothic disaster, the other noir detective film, and so forth. 

Prerequisite for playing the game is that somebody knows rules by heart (check player aids) - then people can immerse in the characters and the game also becomes newbie friendly (weight bellow 2.5 for them). Obligatory loud reading of encounters.

RATING: 5
There is a bit too much downtime in this game for me. While very thematic and pretty well done mechanics wise, the game is long... but too long. I don't mind a longer game, but this one drags on due to the player rolls and turns and everything associated with that. 

Gameplay slows to a crawl later on and you find yourself thinking that people should speed it up a little. I hate feeling that way about my fellow gamers, so to me this game definitely did not live up to the hype that I've read about it.

The game is best with 4 players. If you go for a large group (6 or 7) then you will find yourself dozing off inbetween turns.

Update: I've played this with 2 players recently and it flowed a lot better. The game still does not live up to the hype in my opinion, but it's much more fun with fewer people. The turns go quick, you get to plan your moves easier, and it flows nicer.

Great art and characters, and an almost-RPG feel make this for an excellent group experience, so long as everyone is open to falling on their faces a few times. I also had a blast playing solo on my first go. I already can't wait to get it back on the table, even after playing twice within a week.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The whole shebang works as a system but doesn't provide much exceitement or tension. Players basically assume a character in the town of Arkham and attempt to close gates that are opening across town.

Along they way, they can upgrade their skills/equipment (in true FFG fashion) and battle/evade baddies.

It's overly long for the experience and ultimately it feels a little solitaire-ish race against the clock, albeit lacking in tension or hard decisions.

In any case, the board looks dull and unattractive and confusing compared to the 1st edition. The other bits are well constructed and although the art is recycled from the Cthululu CCG, it's excellent nonethless.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
English language version. Sleeved.
Good game. Rulebook is not very well-organized. Takes quite long, but that is probably the point. Good fun, but does not capture Lovecraftian horror too well, or so I believe (to much shooting, not enough of the more subtle horrors.)
It is excellent as a solo adventure game (usually playing2 investigators), if one plays it as an adventure game and not as a find-the-way-to-the-optimal-win game. With more players I find it too slow, unless everyone is very concentrated, knows the rules and does not snack nor chat. Very unlikely.

RATING: 8
After first incomplete game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great game! Very involved and should draw in any Lovecraftian. In this game you and a group of friends must team up to stop an ancient elder god from coming into our world. You'll find clues, encounter monsters, find allies, and jump in and out of other worlds in order to close portals that have appeared in Arkham. 

The game is screaming with theme. Characters have great bits of backstory written up and almost every monster you encounter includes wonderful flavor text to describe their beastly form or terrify your mortal soul. The game can be punishing, which it should be considering you're trying to stop a god. This only makes victory taste all the more sweet when you manage to win. The rules are a bit heavy and can easily scare away newcomers to board games, so make sure you invite the right group of friends.

Arkham horror provides so much variation, you could play it for an eternity. You'll face different elder gods and encounters every play through making the game feel fresh every time.

The biggest blessing and curse to this game is the number of available expansions for it. Each expansion adds more encounters, items, spells, characters, gods, etc... And while these additions are wonderful, it can cause the game to feel bloated. AND if for some awful reason you decide to combine all of the expansions (like I did) you will find yourself tripping over all of the rules you must remember in order for the game to function properly. My greatest advice is to use one, maybe two, expansions at the same time, but no more.

There are some other rules in the game that can be improved upon with a few house rules. Many of these rules have already been improved upon by the game's newest incarnation, Eldritch Horror. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I want to like this more, based purely on loving the mythos. The truth is, AH just doesn't deliver a satisfying gaming experience. The inevitable result of the game usually becomes clear by about midway, where if you have not yet closed/sealed enough gates there is no way you are going to win aside from by an insanely lucky set of dice rolls at the end, fighting the Great Old One.

I'd rather spend the the two hours playing till that point playing something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Super happy fun in a box. Uh, and incomprehensible horror.

After playing solo, with two, and some larger multiplayer games, I think the sweet spot for Arkham Horror (for me) is two-three players. Even after a larger group knows the game well, finishing a game can take 4 hours. You can easily cut that in half for a two player game, and for two players each playing only a single investigator, there is superb tension.

Arkham Horror is, for my money, the best table-top adventure game around. It's definitely "pulp Cthulhu" what with blasting your shotgun at dread Cthulhu himself, but it makes for a fun game. It takes a few plays to figure out the rules. I'll just warn you ahead of time that the rule book isn't the best. You *will* run into situations that are not covered in the rules, often. This will force you to look up errata online, as well as develop some house rules of your own. In the end, the process is worthwhile however, as a fun game emerges. Production values are top notch - it's a gorgeous game.

The best thing about Arkham Horror, for me, is that it got me interested in the Call of Cthulhu role playing game, which I am now Cthrazy about! I never figured I'd come back to pnp rpgs after a 20 year absence, but life is full of surprises. Update: I'm less interested in CoC RPG than I was - I've found I like games with more character development. CoC is a neat game though, and features some of the best game writing I've ever seen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Of course, the game was just purchased and punched that day. As with my copy of Twilight Imperium, 3rd edition, the components are excellent, with all counters made of a heavy cardboard stock. Cards are solid, not flimsy. Very nice graphics. Overall I would give the components a 10. We played with seven players, all pretty much hardcore gamers. The owner of the game was the main rulesmaster. It seems he spent more time flipping pages than rolling dice. Hard to imagine in this game, eh? :) One other player was familiar with the original. The player to my left went first the entire game, which means I went last the entire game. We missed the rule about passing the "First Player" token to the left at the start of every turn until the last turn when I looked up the rule for myself. Yep, right there on page one. :) I commented at one point that we should all have a copy of the rules to save time in finding things. Most of the comments from the 2 rulesmaestros were about how bad the rules were written. After we got rolling, we seemed to beat the game pretty handily, whacking monsters and gates with ease. One player was down to 1 sanity. Doom track was at about 6. We never got the Terror track above 1. Of course, since I went last everyturn, everyone else beat me to all the monster/gate bashing b4 I could do anything. In that respect the game was boring. However, I never really felt any atmosphere to the game. Certainly, no "Horror". I mostly felt boredom and thought about how, after playing many games recently with other first time players, I will no longer be trusting that the rules are being interpreted properly. In my mind, there's nothing worse than playing a game, and then finding that you were playing it wrong. Waste of time. So, we all agreed to read the rules this week and play again next week. I guess I'm just not into the "horror" thing and definitely have never been into Lovecraft. But, as I stated, I didn't feel any atmosphere to the game, any excitement, any fear, nothing. I don't see how not moving last all game will change any of that, but I'm willing to give it another shot. If anything changes, I'll let you know.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

As a relative newcomer I have yet to delve into the expansions, but the prospect is certainly exciting (if a little daunting due to the time it takes to set-up and play just the standard edition).

Admittedly it *is* dice/luck heavy, which can put off more strategically-minded gamers, but if you are a fan of the Lovecraft Mythos then this is a game you should definitely give a try.

Edit: Slowly introducing the non-boardgamer friends to this one and so far it is going down a storm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Co-op games are hard to do. You need to make the game hard enough that it provides a challenge to the players, smart enough that every game doesn't feel the same and easy enough for the players to understand. Arkham Horror accells at these first two points but falls a little short at the third. The game is difficult, but not impossible, every monster, location and boss have a unique feel. But some of the game mechanics can be an absolute pain to explain to new players. No one mechanic is super complex, but it's a game with a lot of small medium complexity level parts and that can be a pain for new players. Once you get over this barrier though Arkham Horror is the most rewarding Co-Op board game I have played and the expansions will have you playing it forever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

Entertainment Value: 2 out of 4. Orginially when I bought it 4 out of 4. But as time went on I re-evaulated the "fun".  It gets boring.

The good: Componets are amazing.

The Bad: Although many boardgames are repetitive for some reason this one constantly reminds me how repetitive it is.

Bottom Line: If you like the mythos and HP lovecraft and you like complicated but interesting rules get it.

RATING: 8

RATING: N/A
I am trying so hard to like this game. 
Too hard.

UPDATE: Had another session with 3 players. I have now tried it out for 4 times and can't seem to be able to wrap my head around it. Main issues:
- Too fiddly. The exception of the exception of the rule written on page 28 without any logical reasoning sort of sucks the theme out. 
- Silly downtime, especially with annoying "delayed" moves or moving through the dimensions and only getting "nothing happens" cards
- Not too many cards on the locations (base game), too many of them with silly "nothing happens" or "lose 1 sanity, boo hoo" adventures. I understand that it's supposed to draw people towards expansions, but still annoying. 
- Half-themed. Do you really expect something to be dripping with theme when you publish it in Times New Roman? 
- Made too fiddly and difficult for a simple, almost blatantly naive game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I always run with these houses rules:
1> If you lose all health or sanity you can not drop half your stuff, you must take an injury or madness card.
2> Monster surges are always just one monster per gate (2 in larger player count games). This prevents game stopping from early monster surges.
3> Each player gets 3 random characters and chooses one of them to play. Only 1st time players get to pick from the entire cast!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

If you ever want to hear a collective groan go to any game store and mention you want to play it.  The collective groan will be massive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
French. Sleeved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yay!  It did not disappoint.  There is enough of the old game here that I was pleased that I don't have to go back and spend the bucks on it, but there is so much more in quality, quantity and elegance.  The only thing I liked a little better in the original game was that the monsters did more roaming, here they are a bit more static.  Still, I'm going to be playing this for years to come.  

Sure, it is a little heavy on dice and luck, but the level of fun is pretty friggin high.  Be prepared for a long game though, certainly by todays standards.  If you play this with 5 or less then the downtime should be significantly decreased.  I really wouldn't recommend playing it with more than 5.  

There is only one thing that I would change, when you get random cards to start with, you should be dealt one extra and discard one to tailor your character more toward your desires.  

When I am in the mood for a horror game, I think that for me this is the be all and end all (and I've played a number of them).  

UPDATE: I've gotten a number of games under my belt now and so far they have played out completely different every time.  I have found that this game plays best from 2-4, fine with 5, but don't bother with more, the downtime will hurt the experience.

RATING: 7

I recently played a game (nearly 5 hours) where my character didn't really do much due to bad die roles and when I looked at her right before the boss fight, she was only marginally improved over what she started with. 

I will enjoy this only when played seldom with the just right group. As for the card game, I love to play that weekly, or even a couple times a week if I get a chance!

RATING: 9
I was wary of this game once again because of the negative comments on here.  I'm beginning to think it just comes down to if you like American games or Euro games.

I played this two player, with my cousin, with the Dunwich expansion, and we had an absolute blast.  What can beat a crazyman soldier with a flamethrower and his female psychologist partner packing a tommygun?  The answer: nothing.  That's not true - Shudde M'ell can kill them, but you get my point.

This game is very, very rich in theme, amazingly so, and very fiddly to the point where it starts to approach War of the Ring.  I love the atmosphere of Arkham, and the story that the game tells can be engrossing in its thrills, suspense and hilarity.

Really, the game isn't that difficult, it's just that there is a lot to keep track of and there is so much going on. It's basically move, encounter, bad stuff happens. I now need someone who feels the same way about the game and can play in sessions.

RATING: 9
This game is the de facto storytelling game—it plays out like a novel. You don't come to Arkham to win or lose, you come here to find out what happens to you and all your friends as you move about town trying to solve the mystery of the GOOs, slay monsters, get cursed, join cults, search old run-down shops for elder signs, or whatever else the wretched hand of fate chooses to deal you. You practically need a football stadium to lay out this game with all of the expansions, but it is well worth the investment of time. Each game has been fun, exciting, and the stories this game tells have always been epic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really neat game, I had fun playing it but was a bit disappointed with the big game-end monster battle. I'm a huge fan of Lovecraft's work and really get into playing this game for the nicely executed theme and feel. Obviously, you win the game by closing and sealing the required number of gates, but if you allow the Old One to awake, you pretty much lose. This is true to the books, but that crazy dicefest of a battle leaves something to be desired game-wise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played 50+ times - always with the Dunwitch Horror expansion and mostly with many other expansions.

If you are interested in a highly immersive, thematic, cooperative board game that features a unique, unfolding story, this is it.

The game 'system' is so much more naturally integrated and evocative than those than in other cooperative games like Lord of the Rings and Shadows Over Camelot.

Hundreds of elements come into play and interact during a game. Each game plays out so differently that it's insane. One game, you may spend much of your time in the town shops, the next game they might as well not even exist. Crazy.

Our last game came down to one last roll to close the last gate before the ancient one awakened. 50-50 chance. We failed. Abhoth burst forth. In the final battle, Abhoth devoured three of us, leaving only the old soldier with one last attack with his flamethrower. He needed four successes on four die. Unbelievably, he got it. We cheered and cried and cheered some more. To me, moments like that are what gaming is all about.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A pretty nice game.

RATING: 9
This game is excellent. Light RPG elements mixed with Cthulhu Mythos makes for a fun (if not long) evening. I like how the game is stacked against the players... it really gives the proper feeling of dread that accompanies any Lovecraft story. It didn't bother us one bit that we got wiped out (oops... Terror Level got to 10), we all had great fun playing. Complaints? The board is flimsy and prone to warping easily. The rules contain a lot of picky details (we had to refer back to the rulebook a ton of times and make a few game rulings that didn't seem to be answered, but at least the manual was well designed). All-in-all a great time though!

RATING: 10
RPG-lite. Arkham Horror inspired me to devour a "best of" Lovecraft's literature, so it's neat to come back to the game knowing the story behind the characters and locations. I had rated this game a 10 the first time around; it [i]is[/i] as amazing as everybody says. However, as I'm wrapping my head around how to "beat" it, I find myself less and less inclined to pull it out with people who've played it before.

Update: This rockets right back up to 10 when we're using a bunch of Launius' personal house rules to toughen things up.

Double Update: Well, well. Two years after my first "real" boardgame purchase and I own every single expansion* - go figure, it's an amazing line - and oh my dear sweet sleeping scourge of sanity you don't even need house rules to make it impossible anymore.

*For the record, that's Dunwich Horror, Innsmouth Horror, Kingsport Horror, The King in Yellow, The Black Goat of the Woods, the Lurker at the Threshold, and the Curse of the Dark Pharaoh. I'm tired of having a separate entry for each one.

Very very fun.

RATING: 8
Very engaging cooperative system with rich atmospherics and genuinely creepy theme.  I would play this anytime, as random character selection and the varied global effects of the Deep One du jour are huge replay pluses.  Plays great from 1 to 4 players, but drags too much at 5 or more, unless you have a particularly fun and patient group.  

Warnings:
Occasionally, there is the sense that the game plays you, but it's a necessary evil in a pure co-op game.  Daunting set-up -- requires a pretty large space.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Effectively a Lovecraftian Mythos roleplaying game in a co-operative boardgame.  [And it's been around a lot longer than Pandemic etc ...].  Naturally the rules are quite detailed (as there is no Gamemaster), but the system of cards and counters with lots of info is ingenious.  When you get the hang of it (which is easier if you're a bit familiar with roleplaying concepts like skills, spells, lifepoints etc), the game's not really that complex at all.  It can be a longish game with many players, or when inexperienced.  It also plays with only 1 or 2 players, but then using  multiple investigators is recommended.  AH is not for everyone - so choose your invitees with a little care - but for the right people it's a blast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An enjoyable co-operative game that fans of Lovecraft will immediately take to. There are a lot of components and a lot of expansions. Requires a large table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I keep feeling as though this should be an awesome game. It requires a massive table, there are lots of cool places to go on the map and there are so many decks of cards with so many interesting things in them, however the whole game just seems to drag along endlessly. Players take turns moving about the map, visiting areas to gather items or kill monsters or any number of other things all in a co-operative race to seal the gates before the big greebly gets through and causes a showdown. I suppose in the 80s this would have been a superb game but in this day in age, there are much more interactive, immersive games available.

RATING: 9.5
I love Lovecrafts's Cthulhu mythos and I also love classic RPGs. This game is combination of both. It's engaging, strategic, with a bit of luck involved. Sometimes can be very mean, but since it's a co-op, this fact is mitigated by affecting the whole group. What I really hate about this game is the devour feature. Player elimination (even though you can make a different character... which takes you only like 10 minutes... or more...) in such a long game just gets on my nerves. This is the longest game I really enjoy all the time still, just wished the players were hindered not eliminated, but that wouldn't be thematic I guess. Anyway, great game, after many years of playing haven't got tired of it. Still a long game, needs to be planned ahead, usually we play 2-3 games one day during weekend once in a while. Like it very much.

RATING: 7.5
Revised: 11/14/2016:  Well, after a year or so and a dozen games, give or take, I'm upping it back up... to a 7.5.  It's just fun, as long as I somewhat check my brain at the door, and it's just so darn thematic.  The huge problem is that the rulebook is AWFUL. Revised: 11/10/2015:  Acquired in trade with Wrath of Ashardalon, for Evolution and Merchants & Marauders.

Looking forward to hopefully getting this to the table with one or two other interested players and seeing how it goes over!

With the right crowd, I'm game, but I do prefer actual RPGs to this style of co-op.  Having said that, Arkham is very cool, tightly designed, richly themed.  All in all, thumbs up!

Revised (06/15/09) Down to a 6.5 from a 7... it's fun, but I wonder at the lack of interesting decisions oftentimes.  It does seem like the game comes down to the draw of a card or the roll of a die more often than a tough decision, and that makes it less interesting to me.  Maybe if there were more cards that made you try and pick the lesser of two (or three or more!) evils...

RATING: 5
JH
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the Agricola of cooperative games for me.  I love variety and variability in a game and in that respect, this game is after my heart and has claimed it.

First of all, this game is deceptively less complicated than the rulebook and number of components would have you think.  Also, as a cooperative game you simply need one player who knows the rules well enough to "run the game" so the other players can learn by doing.

The amount of variety and variability in just the base game are staggeringly awesome.  There are 16 different characters for players to choose, 8 different Ancient Ones for the players to fight, huge decks of cards for every situation, many locations with special abilities on them.  The rules system, while like I said not that complicated, is also deep and incredibly thematic.  I would expect nothing less from the King of "Ameritrash".

I will say that you probably need more than 2 players to really have a good chance of tackling this game.  While a lot of things in this game scale with the number of players making it seem balanced across all player numbers (for example the number of successes needed to remove a doom token from the Ancient One and monster limits), one thing that you always get with more players is more opportunity to do stuff,  which means closing more gates, killing more monsters, and more time for players to go shopping.  With just two players you fall behind in both closing gates and killing monsters and are too busy mitigating both of these to really collect stuff for the inevitable fight with the Ancient One (you would have to be really talented/lucky to end a 2-player game without fighting the Ancient One).

I think the magic number of players is 4 as going to 5 puts two monsters in play each turn and to that end if you play with two I would play with each player playing two investigators.  5-8 still wouldn't be too bad since each player still gets to take a turn compared to one gate opening every turn (even with two monsters) and has me wonder why you score more for more players.  I personally think greater player numbers and actions each turn outweighs the monster limit/Ancient One combat number especially since these just seem to attempt to balance as the number of players increase.  3 might also be okay, though challenging but I haven't played with this number yet.

Also, the fight with Yig (suggested for a shorter game) feels just a little too truncated to really experience the game.  I would suggest not playing against this Ancient One if you do have the time for a standard length game (2.5-3 hours) as it might end before you really get to take it all in.  And there's a lot of good stuff to take in here.

RATING: 7
This is sometimes a little bit light-hearted in the theme area--I like my Lovecraft relentlessly dark and bleak, with no machine guns or private eyes. Too much fiddlyness too (having to move those monsters all the time is a special pain), and the rules are just too much, with a ton of stuff to get straight and remember every turn---get ready for a constant parade of clunky modifiers and exceptions, some of which you'll simply forget to apply. While it may feel like work to a casual gamer, it could certainly be fun for a well-seasoned one, with lots of variety, especially with the expansions (watch out, though--they only add to the complexity). Basically a must-try for Mythos freaks...IF they know what they're getting into.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.1
[i]Gameplay depth[/i] [b]4[/b]
[i]Immersiveness[/i] [b]10[/b]
[i]Elegance[/i] [b]3[/b]
[i]Aesthetics[/i] [b]9[/b]

At first an excellent thematic experience that really draws you in, further aided by the stunning visuals. However, after this initial hype wears off, the actual gameplay starts to show its many flaws. In theory I don't mind the lengthy playtime; I even love it providing the game stays interesting throughout. But Arkham Horror doesn't at all. Already after a few turns the game becomes tedious and repetitive, and there the fiddliness of it all really starts to annoy. Even though it is definitely hard to beat the Ancient One, it is not particularly [i]challenging[/i]. Luck triumphs over strategy at almost every point in the game through overly present dice rolling and drawing of random cards, which makes me feel powerless and indifferent about the final result. Overall, this game is very disappointing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So far, I've only played it solo, but as a one player board game its surprisingly engaging. Very well themed and there are a ton of little nuances that link back to it's source material. One such example: the creature Hound of Tindalos can attack any investigator, regardless of distance, as long as they are in a location. This is because in the Mythos story where they appeared, they emerge from the angles of corners of rooms. Lots of cool stuff like this for people familiar with the Mythos tales.

update: Finally played several games with others and it still holds its appeal. Happy to play this solo or with friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
In his house at R'lyeh, dead Cthulhu waits drowning in 210 different types of card, 4000 tokens, and a partidge in a pear tree. (Look at the Arkham Horror component list -- it's all there.) It's a typical Fantasy Flight mess, with a bag full of tokens where a slider would do, hundreds of dice rolls, and a lot of unnecessary chrome. 

It's not what you would call a "strategy game": it's a "thematic game", or to use my preferred terminology, an "experience game". Players take the role of colourful Cthulhu Mythos characters, investigating mysterious occurrences in the fictional New England city of Arkham -- soon to be the site of a dimensional breakthrough by one of the great old ones, who will devour the world: Azathoth, the Daemon Sultan, the Blind Idiot God; Yog-Sothoth, the Lurker at the Threshold; Shub-Niggurath, The Black Goat of the Woods; Nyarlathotep, the Crawling Chaos.

Mechanically the game is not interesting; turns generally consist of going to locations and resolving random events. The enormous luck factor can occasionally result in a game that is either a cakewalk or an impossibility, but I assume anyone playing an experience game doesn't mind that sort of thing. The only actual problems are the lack of variety in location cards and that it doesn't always scale well between player counts -- some old ones are virtually impossible with fewer than four investigators and perhaps far too easy with eight. The variety issue is solved by the expansions.

Though the ludic part of the game consists largely in resolving random events, its charm is in the rich flavour of those events and the items and monsters encountered along the way. Let go and enjoy the ride and it's a lot of fun. In fact, the biggest criticism I have is that it provides too much faux-game chrome -- when it works, it works because it's telling a story. As such, most players really would be better served playing a Lovecraftian RPG like Call of Cthulhu. Roleplaying demands a good group with a good GM, but can provide immeasurably richer and more satisfying narrative experience.

It's not unenjoyable, though, and I might still have decided to keep it if it didn't take four hours and up. That's just too long to spend for an experience as shallow as this one. Better to read a good book for the story and play a real game for the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 6
The strength of Arkham Horror lies mainly in the theme. There is a strong atmospheric element and a hint of role-playing that makes the game special.

I wouldn't turn down a game of AH, but for me it is not special and I would rather play something else if I had the chance. The role-playing element is not something I look for in board games, having been a D&D player myself. The mental challenge is limited and there is a lot of dice rolling. Although the co-op nature of the game is appealing, there is no remedy for the alpha male effect (someone who knows the game better determining all players' moves). The amount of components and cards creates an illusion of replayability, but we ended up winning in the same manner every time.

It's not all that bad - it's still fun to set up your character, find and buy equipment and slaughter monsters. Just not my favourite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
100% cooperative, RPG-like boardgame in the Lovecraftian (and firends) world. Featuring a great diversity of characters, gadgets and monsters, this sometimes leads to fiddly play (especially with new players). But once you are in it's a great team game.
Unlike many such games, the characters start fully developed and equiped, gathering some additional things (positive and negative) over the game instead of starting as an untrained child and ending as Conan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Game steeped in theme and fun.  Co-op game with excellent amount of player interaction.  The combat system is simple and elegant.  minimal downtime.  Game replay value is high.  The rules are well written with examples but could be better organized.  Components are excellent - mounted board, thick chits, card stock player mats, and somewhat durable cards.  Artwork is very good.  Game length is about 2.5 hours which feels right.

[1 play] Initial reaction rating.  I played in an eight player game.  A couple of the players were very experienced and knew the rules well, most of us it was the first time playing. Eventually we gave up, because we were getting terrible luck the monster was going to come through and over half of the people were recovering in the hospital, with very few good items.  I would say the main complaints were that it was confusing to always know what was going on, and mostly people were just bored with how long it was taking.  I would like to try it again with like 3 or 4 players and see if it would play faster and be more fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Oh Arkham, I will never stop singing your praises.

So, in the interest of full disclosure: I love co-op games.  If you do not like co-op games, please remove yourself from the vicinity of Arkham Horror.  

Okay, now, let's get this out of the way.  There are flaws in Arkham Horror.  Even one who loves it as much as I has to admit this.  The rules are numerous and have strange facets and interactions that could fill a novel with errata and FAQs.  There are seventeen gazillion little fiddly bits, so you will need lots of plastic bags and/or pill cases and/or fishing tackle boxes.  FFG churns out expansions for this at a steady pace, meaning that if you're a completionist or an expansion addict (Hi, that's me), you will be broke and have a closet taken up by this game alone.  Finally, it's lengthy; it often takes 3-4 hours, and can easily exceed that when you're playing with near the maximum number of players.

Now, on to the good stuff.  This game drips with theme and tension.  It can be brutal when you're unlucky, and brutal even when you're lucky (though sometimes, mysteriously, goddesses and gods will smile on you and you will have a smooth game).  There are tons of decisions to be made, and it's often never clear which is the right choice.  This makes it, I think, more enjoyable for newbies than some other co-ops, because there's a lot less of the "Loudest and most analytical person running everyone else's turn" problem.  It's hard to say "You should go here and do this" when, really, anywhere you go could either kill you or give you a great item depending on whether the game hates you or not (Hint: it hates you).  You have to approach it as a fun experience and be ready to lose.  Like a good role-playing game, you leave with lots of funny and exciting memories that you can be discussing for weeks to come (like the time your investigator nearly threw themselves into a well to their death on their FIRST ENCOUNTER, or the time your investigator got beaten up by a monster and woke up in the hospital with.. Tuberculosis?!?).

I love this game so much. :3

COLORBLINDNESS NOTE:  There is some necessary color-distinguishing going on here, but it's a co-op, which makes asking someone or putting someone else in charge of the color-dependent parts fairly easy.  In particular, Arkham location encounter and Other World gate cards are color-coded.  The former I've managed to adapt to by getting good at matching the pictures of the locations on the backs of cards rather than colors--this is a fairly necessary move since the colors are often very similar shades of blue-purple versus straight purple or yellow-green versus sickly yellow.   The Other World cards come in four colors--red, green, blue, and yellow--with no other pictures for distinguishing.  Luckily, I find that they're pretty bright shades that I can tell apart, but people with more advanced red-green colorblindness may have trouble.

UPDATE 3/3/09:  Okay, I finally admitted it.  I downgraded AH from a 10 to a 9.  I have to admit that there are a few problems with the game that are really starting to impede my enjoyment.
1) The difficulty is incredibly inconsistent.  We win some games without breaking a sweat.  Others are long, tense, wonderfully drawn-out battles.  Others are forgone conclusions that manage to still stretch over hours.  It's hard to convince myself to spend the large amount of time to teach, setup, and play the game when I'm not even sure if it will be hard enough to feel climactic and enjoyable.

2.) Fiddliness.  This is FFG at the height of their bizarre obsession with overproduction.  Setup and tear-down take FOREVER.  Digging through billions of chits--and, yes, I'm well-organized, it's not like I have them all in a giant heap--gets annoying.  It's not a game-breaking problem but it's frustrating.  If I had a devoted cat-free room where I could leave the game set up I wouldn't be so bothered, but, y'know.  Not that rich. Yet.

3.) Occasionally stagnant.  This goes with the inconsistent difficulty thing.  There will be times where the game just.. sits.  You're at more or less an impasse--no one has any good options, they're trapped behind monsters and constantly being sent to the hospital or something, and yet the game isn't advancing, no new gates opening.  Maybe it's clear that you're going to lose or win, but it could take another hour to get there, even if only the most wild act of [deity] could change that.  It occasionally goes on far too long in this way. 

I still love the game.  It's still a great -experience-, but as a game it has some serious downsides, and some more recent co-ops (particularly Ghost Stories) have hurt my desire to play Arkham as much.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
La città di Arkham, nel Massachusetts, è nel panico! Eventi orribili e bizzarri hanno iniziato ad accadere con sempre maggior frequenza - tutto sembra indicare il sopraggiungere di qualche evento cataclismico che può segnare la fine del mondo. Solo una piccola banda d’investigatori può salvare Arkham dai Grandi Antichi e dalla distruzione!

Arkham Horror era stato originariamente pubblicato dalla Chaosium, Inc. nel 1987. Questa nuova edizione, completamente rivista, presenta un nuovo artwork e un nuovo design grafico (che comprende un nuovo piano di gioco, segnalini, carte e pezzi di gioco), oltre a regole riviste ed espanse, disegnate dallo stesso creatore del gioco, Richard Launius. I giocatori possono scegliere tra 16 differenti personaggi investigatori, ciascuno con abilità uniche, ed affrontare cultisti e gli spaventosi Antichi, tra i quali ricordiamo Ithaqua, Hastur e il terribile Cthulhu! Nessun fan dei Miti di Cthulhu può perdere quest’occasione per acquistare questo classico gioco da tavolo ispirato ai lavori di H.P. Lovecraft!

Contiene:

1 Tabellone
16 Schede Investigatore + 16 Segnalini Investigatore + 16 Basette in Plastica per gli Investigatori
189 Carte Investigatore
5 Dadi
196 Segnalini di Stato degli Investigatori
8 Schede Grande Antico
180 Carte Grande Antico
20 Segnalini Fato
60 Segnalini Mostro
16 Segnalini Portale
14 Segnalini Vari
il Regolamento

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Having played 4 games at this point, I see what the problem is with length in a 5+ player game.  With 4, there is no issue, especially once the rules are understood by all.  There is essentially no downtime, which is another complaint I just don't understand.  If anything, players are going to be uncertain when their movement phase comes around where precisely they should go because they haven't analyzed all their options yet.  I feel that the endgame battle adds significantly to the experience, rather than being a huge dicefest letdown - the players must plan extensively for the fight, and they're either going to live or die depending on whether or not they had a chance to get the right things before the old one shows up.  For Yig, for example, everyone needs to be blessed before the fight.  All in all, it's better than Lord of the Rings, which makes it the best cooperative game on the market in my book.  Is it too easy?  Not sure yet - the game gets easier the more players are added, that's for sure.

RATING: 4
There's a lot I enjoy here; I love the pseudo-RPG nature and the enormous variety in the game.  But the set up time and clutter factor are huge.  Its so much work for so little return.  I keep wondering things like:
* Why is so much of the board useless space?
* Why do we need two dozen bland encounter decks that all amount to the same thing?  
* Why do I draw a card, which tells me to go draw a different card, which you can only get via the first card?  Why not just print the damn rules on the first card and keep it!
* Why didn't they stop to think that telling you to go locate a specific card out of a 200 card deck that's a pain to shuffle might be a bad idea?

Back when there were few co-ops, I loved to play this.  As more and more good co-ops come out, my interest has been steadily dropping.  If there was a way of de-cluttering it and tightening up the challenge level, my rating would go up a lot.
My review: https://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/146419/item/2728584#item2728584
+co-op+

House rules:
----------
* A new gate gives a monster but no doom token.
* A duplicate gate gives a doom token and monster.
* A sealed gate gives a monster surge.
----------
* Don't reduce ally pile.  Instead, when you recruit from Ma's draw 10-terror allies to pick from.
----------
In a final battle, the GOO has +7 doom tokens, -2 per sealed gate.  So, with 3 sealed gates the GOO has +1 token; with 5 sealed it has -3.

RATING: 6.5
I finally got to play one of the all-time Ameritrash classics.  It's so full of atmosphere which creates a great level of immersion.  There's a nice story laid out every time you play it which gives you something to remember long after your session.

This game has a LOT of rules.  It's long, and it's quite fiddly.  If you can get past that it's fun.  For me it's a bit of a turn off.  That said I'd play this anytime with the right group of friends.

Acquired in a Math Trade 03/2011.

Traded on 8/09/11 for Call of Cthulhu LCG starter set which I think will see a lot more play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cooperative adventure game set in the world of H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu mythos. The game revolves around a group of investigators attempting to prevent one of the 'ancient ones' from entering the town of Arkham. In order to do this they need to defeat a number of monsters and close gates to the 'other worlds'. All skill checks in the game are straightforward where you have to roll a five or a six on a variable number of d6 depending on modifiers and this determines the outcomes of combat, luck, will etc. The game can be a frustrating experience for some players who invariably have to spend the majority of the game acquiring objects just to pass them on to the their team-mates who then use them to do the fun stuff with them i.e. battle and explore the other worlds and close the gates. I love the 1920s setting and as always Fantasy Flight has done a great job with the artwork and presentation. This isn't a game for everyone due to the theme and there can be a lot of downtime with a higher number of players (there can be a maximum of eight), but Arkham Horror is one of the best cooperative games out there as well as being one of the best games with a horror theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
For a game that has some much packed into the box you'd expect to have tons of decisions to make and things to do but no. No. Sure you have to make choices often enough but each 'decision' is such a microcosm of insignificant obviousness that it doesn't really matter. 




waiting..... 





By far the most important game mechanism is the group optimization puzzle that is where each player plans to move. Usually the solution is straightforward but even if there are two worthy options it doesn't really matter which you choose as how the dice fall is vastly more important to your success or failure.




waiting.....





The poor fool running the game has 4 hours of tedious bookkeeping to keep him entertained. Imagine the fun of tracking monster counts, special monster types, bad guy abilities, rumour cards and various player abilities all whilst everyone else yawns and waiting for you to hurry it all up.  (First few games problem I'll admit) 





waiting.....




Still it's better than being a player where each turn is a matter of drawing and reading a card, rolling some dice or just 'experiencing the story'. But the events in game and the cards never really come together to create something memorable other than by sheer chance so the little value is quickly crushed by the constant




waiting..... 




As a story/social experience there is some value to be had but as a game it's just not good. Let me be clear. It's not any worse than other co-op games in this style (Pandemic, Shadows over Camelot, LotR) but their brevity reduces their offence whilst this revels in it. So if you think those are great then this is too.




-
A jumble of in-cohesive, poorly written, overly long, (possibly) random thoughts that completely miss the point of the work. My reviews? Arkham Horror?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Co-op game where all players try to prevent an other worldly creature from coming to our world and devouring everyone and everything.  Plays 1-8 players.  Very thematic.  

An other worldly creature is opening portals to try to come into our world.  Monsters pour out of these portals.  If enough portals open, the creature will enter our world and can destroy everyone.

Players are investigators who need to find enough clues and items to close enough of these portals to prevent the creature from coming to our world.  They must navigate the town of Arkham and avoid or fight off these creatures.  Different areas will give different items and resources to help in closing these portals and fight off these monsters.

This is a pretty old game.  I gave it a lower rating because there are some newer games that have a similar theme that has improved mechanics.  Still this is a sentimental classic for me.  I still get a sense of horror when playing this game.  The game can drag out a bit towards the end, but it is still fun bashing monsters while you finish closing off the last of the portals you need to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
- Excellent solo play, expands from one player to six player with ease in my experience. The game itself supports up to eight players but I have yet to try this.
- Co-op game, take on the role beating the game a as team of investigators, closing all or sealing six other world dimension portals or failing that meet the the Great Old One in a final battle of victory or defeat (see get devoured).
- Lots and lots of theme, in the world of Lovecraft.
- Every play is a new experience, with different investigators, Great Old Ones, items, spells, and of course horrible monster encounters and great encounters with new allies to help you in your quest of saving Arkham and ultimately the world.
- Variety in play with a cost, this game comes with several expansions (see money drainer) that are great and make for a different experience as they can be both integrated into the base game and play a supporting role. And of course they can be combined as well to some extent (see dilution).
- Difficult at times, but losing makes winning next time all the more sweeter.

RATING: 8.5
I really wish I had more opportunity to play this game. I admit, it is a little convoluted, but having someone to more-or-less GM the thing makes things a little smoother--things stay on track, the GM takes care of the monsters and players can help keep things moving along. I love just how fantastically one can fail at this; it's really hard to win, but it definitely has been a lot of fun for me. One caveat to those looking to pick it up: Play with the right people. I would not recommend it for the casual boardgamer. Best played with people who love boardgames and are not afraid of a little management.

RATING: 6
I like cooperative games, and the theme is well done.  The components are beautiful, but the gameplay isn't cohesive.  The extensive number of characters, enemies, & events seems like it would keeps the replay value respectible. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Let me just say this, I dislike long games.  I've wanted to play this since it came out but I could never justify pulling it out due to that time factor.  I'm a Lovecraft fan so that put an extra urge to give it a try.  Finally a few months back I picked it up, It sat on the shelf and gathered dust. Last night the stars were right, the old ones stirred.  Taking the role of Bob the Traveling salesman our quest began.

DEAR SWEET ELDERGOD, how did all that time fly by.  I've played hour long euro games that held my attention far less than this eldritch monstrosity!  We had 4 players, 2 who had played the classic and 2 new to the whole thing (I was one of the later).  I realized through Arkham Horror that I REALLY needed to get some adventure game into my system, this one was the yellow king of that genre.  While these games always put an unforetold pressure on space and time, taking up lots of room and lasting very long.  For the game itself, I found the length and pacing may be slow.  However despite it's length, you never really notice the time fly. I would have figured the play time would have ruined my sanity... turns out I was wrong.  Bob's sanity on the otherhand was something else entirely.

The rules are extremely fiddly on the grand scale with many questionable mechanics, this is not something I would feel comfortable playing with non gamers by any stretch of the imagination.  On an individual note the mechanics are quite simple, its the over all game itself that gets boggy.  Which in upon itself made it feel like it SHOULD have lasted longer.  Highly random, wildly stacked against the players and full of absolute chaos sums up the mechanics.  Monster Surges happened to us constantly, we had a board full of hellish nightmare spawn and the pressure was constantly on.  Portals proved very difficult to close and the university experiment forced some heavy combat to take place.  This is a brilliant cooperative game with many unique twists.  I really like the skill slider mechanic and the characters individual uniqueness.  The combat is pretty dice heavy (especially with items) which I'm not all that keen on, but it works.  It strikes me that with more than 4 players the game would be easier but have FAR more downtime.  All and all Arkham Horror is definitely getting more play and I am eager to add in the Dunwich Horror expansion.  Spending hours losing sanity has never been so fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The apex of the Ameri-game.  Only game I know of where it is often a more satisfying experience to lose than to win.

RATING: 8
For me simply the best game of 2005!
I haven´t played a single game that often in the last three years and everyone I introduced it to loved it. You really don´t have to be a H.P. Lovecraft-fan to enjoy this game. Actually, most people in my group don´t know Lovecraft at all.
The theme is great and it´s just plain fun exploring the town of Arkham. There are some very nice and novel game mechanics (the sliders for character attributes for example) and once you get the hang of it, the game moves very smoothly.
The main problem of the game is the rulebook. The rules, which are not that simple to begin with, are presented in a very confusing way and you will find yourself browsing forwards and backwards in the hope of finding the rule you are looking for.
Update May 2007: Ok, I finally did it - I gave my first 10-rating. I guess after over 60 plays in about 20 months this is due. 
Update November 2010: Have played it only a few times this last year - so I should lower rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If you're looking for a cooperative, challenging, thematic game set in the world of HP Lovecraft that you can play sporadically with friends on occasions such as Halloween or when you're in a spooky cabin in rural New England, this is probably the game for you. It just does what it says on the box, it's Lovecraft: the Board Game.

That said, however, if you're looking for a fun gaming experience that you'll want to play over and over, I would advise you to steer clear from this game. The basic game play philosophy that was adopted for making this game is that "whatever players choose to do, there will be one of two possible outcomes: either penalties will be incurred or nothing will happen. Whatever the player chooses will have very little influence on this." That is my biggest beef with this game; it conditions you to not want to play it, because everything is done through random negative reinforcement.

Want to fight that monster? First, you'll have to roll for your Sanity, which means you'll either lose Sanity or nothing will happen. Secondly, you'll have to try and fight it, which means you'll either lose Health or nothing will happen, because you rarely get anything from successfully vanquishing monsters.

Want to try and have an encounter in a cool place like the train tracks or the library? Brace yourself for either losing some of your resources or successfully managing to accomplish nothing. Your reward is not getting the penalty. Congratulations.

Essentially, what I'm trying to say is that the game play just tries to convince you that what you're doing is completely futile - which is GREAT as an adaptation of Lovecraft. However, the game succeeds a little too well, and within a few playthroughs, whether you win or lose, I think you'll be thoroughly convinced that your experience was futile.

Unlike a Lovecraft character, though, at least you can stay sane by letting the game accumulate dust.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not necessarily the "one" that got me into the board game hobby, but it definitely was one of those games that cemented my love of this hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game looks nice (and it's Cthulhu).  It took me a few readings to get the rules in my head well enough to try, but it is a BLAST solo (it can actually be creepy, I'm about to play it again with a thunderstorm outside, maybe get my wife to light some candles). It can be even better multi-player, but there is some significant down time with the full compliment of eight players.  Nice, though, that everyone does every phase at that phase, rather than player one does all the phases, then 2 does all the phases, etc.   That would make it drag. Instead, everyone does phase one, starting with player one, then repeat with phase two, etc. Pass the first player marker and repeat.  This way everyone is involved somewhat more frequently (but still, with eight players, there is a wait).  As much as I like thr base game by itself, I think the expansions are handled in this series just beautifully.  If I didn't like this game, I would have a hard time not buying the expansions anyway.  I'm not a collector, but this game certainly makes me think like one, if only for this series.

I enjoy losing no game nearly so much :)

RATING: 10
Brilliant co op game.  Fantastic components (all expansions), engaging gameplay.  Rules will take a good few plays to get down, but its worth it.  It becomes intuitive after a few games.

With all expansions, its a serious amount of stuff!!!.. you will need a large table.. Ive pimped it out with the monster miniatures (not all of them yet) and the bag of cthulhu which i use for the first player marker, doom track and terror track tokens, Gate stands, Blessed and cursed dice. Raptor Card Holders.  Ive spent more money on this game than anything else i own.  Would love the investigator minis.
I think this is truly a unique game. My favorite solo game. In my opinion it is the best adventure game ever published (I have no desire to play Eldritch). Indeed maybe my favorite game of all time. Cannot recommend it enough, but it is not for everyone.

I have all expansions mixed in, normally use Dunwich and Kingsport extra boards, Innsmouth only if i want hard mode!., i dont use the Heralds, its hard enough!.  Have the whole game stored in a old wine box.  With this much stuff yoo need a storage/play solution.

Have played: Solo,2,3,4

Playtime from 2-4 players ranges from 3-5 hours.

RATING: 9
Rating stands for all the best expansions parts added, since you may take out some parts of an expansion (e. g. Investigators [character], Skills, etc.) and added to the mix.

For the base game, a solid 7. The 3 points deducted are:
1. The game is too long, too repetitive, and/or too much dice rolling for some people.
2. The game may become anti-climatic when near the game end that either wait for the final battle for too many gates opened; or wait for the final gate be closed. Both of which may take a few turns.
3. The game relys on text on cards for interaction, the combination of card texts and rules may contains plenty of uncertainties. That results in extensive FAQs and specific offical rulings for some conflicts, and FAQs are needed to be checked every gaming sessions to resolve all these problems arised.

Point 1 & 2 can be addressed by various expansion sets. Therefore the current 9 rating.

Point 3 is the major problem of this kind of game system, especially with so many expansions existed. Without some devotions to the game, causal players may be turned off by this jumble of FAQs.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of the main reasons I got back into gaming.  While I find the game to be frustrating at times, it absolutely oozes theme.  I have been a fan of Lovecraft and the Cthulhu mythos for 20+ years, so this game really sits well with me.  

That said, it is definitely not for everyone.  It can be tedious to set up and it has lots and lots of rules to remember.  It also is known for difficulty and for long game times. I've had games in excess of 5 hours. I've also won games in under 90 minutes, it really depends on the crowd and their knowledge of the game.  I can also definitely see those who are not interested in the theme not enjoying the game anywhere near as much as I do.

However, I feel that if you have any interest in the Cthulhu mythos at all, you owe it to yourself to at least try the game.  If you like the idea of a small band of investigators facing down a horrible ancient slimy tentacled evil, then this is your game.  If you like theme and lots of fiddly bits, then this is your game.  And if you like that the next card you flip could spell doom for not only your team, but for the world, then this is your game!

I often say Arkham is my favorite game, but it is a game that requires me to set aside a large chunk of time to dedicate to it.  As such, it is not rated as a 10.  It requires time and effort to get a group to play, so I don't want to play it as often as other games.

RATING: 6
If you have one good role player in the group, you will have fun when he describes how Sister Mary rushes on the street, emptying her Tommy Gun into the lurking creature out there and preparing herself to jump into the gate to some other world. The game is luck based, especially some event cards can have a huge influence on the outcome. Rules are a mess when you play for the first time, but it is actually not difficult to play.

Reduced rating from 8 to 6 after the last game night. We had some new players and all were too impatient to accept rules lookup during each turn. And with the mess of rules it was of course necessary and took a lot of time o look up information. The last play was some time back, so we had too look up monster movement, monster abilities, gate limits, monster limits - a lot of stuff. The game was horrible, and ended rather suddenly when we realized that we overlooked the gate limit... 

(The German rules may be worse than the English rules: They made some obvious mistakes like on the GOO-card of Hastur which says you need clues to close gates [wrong info] and that he makes you roll on luck to defend [but the rules use him as example and say it is will]).

RATING: 6
Wow.  After initial play, this game won't see much playing time.  However, AH is one fantastic game.  Theme is a little on the weird side, but I knew that going in.  I wanted to play it as an activity, not a theme.  And man does it deliver in spades.  The first game I have ever played where the dice are thrown time and time again, and it did not bother me.  A very long and involved game that makes you feel as if you earned every bit of your quest.  Great, myriad bits, wonderful interaction, and replayability all over the place.  Can't wait to play again, whenever that will be.

UPDATE: 1/30/08--Two recent plays have only solidified my initial thoughts on the game.  At the end of a game, two thoughts emerge:

1.  I really worked to win this game.  I earned it.
2.  I know I messed up something along the way.

Very good game nonetheless.

RATING: 6

RATING: 6.5
Initial impression: I can see in AH the roots of Android, a game I absolutely adore.  What I can't see is why AH is the more popular and widely-acclaimed game.  The mechanics neither promote the theme nor promote compelling or narrative gameplay.  I think both Android and Elder Sign are worthier successors to AH's throne.  But I'm also eager to try a few more games and see how my mind changes....

Later impression: I've come to enjoy this as a solo title, with three or four investigators.  While it doesn't tell very Lovecraftian stories, and doesn't have a ton of interesting decisions, it's entertaining.  With other players the downtime doesn't seem like it would be worth it.

RATING: 9
I really, really like this game, but it is soooooo frustrating! Really difficult to win and there is never enough time to do everything you want before the big guy wakes up. 

As an old fan of HP Lovecraft's literature and the genre, I love the atmosphere that the game creates. It really builds the horror well and some of those monsters are best given a wide steer until you can send 'em back where they belong with the judicious closing of a gate.

Depending on the Old One that you get, it seems that it may sometimes be better simply concentrating on gathering whatever is going to help defeat him.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hands down one of the best board games around.

I've always been a big Cthulhu Mythos fan - reading H.P. Lovecraft, Robert E. Howard and others (not to mention playing and running the Call of Cthulhu role-playing game off and on for over two decades) – so of course I love the theme.

But the game play and production values are just outstanding.  I really like the cooperative element (it’s the players vs. the game – not each other).  Also, the game pieces and cards are sturdy and covered with great, evocative artwork.

I currently own all of the expansions.  They all maintain the same high production values that Fantasy Flight Games has become known for (though I personally find that Kingsport Horror is probably the weakest when it comes to game play and concept).

Oh yeah, and don’t forget Strange Eons - an application which you can download for free - which allows you to make your OWN investigators for use with the game.  I personally use Lobster Johnson: The Crimefighter to battle the Ancient Ones and their minions (yes, I’m also a Hellboy/B.P.R.D. fan).

So, if you’re a fan of the Cthulhu Mythos (or just horror fiction in general) and what to play a fun, cooperative game with your friends, then I’d say that Arkham Horror would probably be a must buy.

RATING: 7
Only played one learning game plus another game where I felt more confident with the rules. The game is less complex than it appears once you get the basic sequence down. Seems a bit repetitive, which is a worry after only a couple of plays. I'm interested to see how the rating goes after a few more plays.

After half a dozen games I don't feel the game is as repetitive as first thought and once the rules are mastered you can concentrate on the adventure element which is definitely fun. Have also started winning against the Mythos on a regular basis. Rating increased from 6 to 7. Plan is now to play through each of the Great Old Ones in the basic game in order of toughness (Yig to Azathoth) for the next eight games. When they are under my belt it will be time for an expansion to freshen things up.

10 plays: Have now played 10 games and, after losing the first 3, have won the last 7 against the Mythos. Definitely time for an expansion to spice things up. Rating remains a solid 7.
20 plays: Investigators 16; Mythos 4. The game length and set up and tear down times keep it from being an 8. Stays at 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Does a truly awesome job doing the massive Cthulhu mythos to life. The text on the cards properly convey the horrifying, unnerving nature of the events being described. And the game is appropriately challenging - it has never felt easy, and has often felt brutally, cruelly difficult.

It's not without its flaws, though. For one, it makes little sense that all of these horrifying things (which become even more numerous with expansions) take place in one small backwater town. For another, though each event on its own is very thematic, there is no overarching story I could find in it. And the story doesn't much depend on which particular Ancient One the players are fighting - sure, there is the mechanical impact, but the story remains the same for all of them.
Gameplay-wise, the game sometimes feels too random and too fiddly and clunky (the skill sliders and number of hands used by each item being good examples of that).

Because of the flaws (more because of the story flaws than the gameplay flaws), I find this game is completely superseded by Eldritch Horror. Arkham is awesome by itself, but since buying Eldritch I never opened the Arkham box except to sort out the expansion components when I sold it.

15 of the logged plays have used my copy of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.75
This game has a fun theme, and great bits, but it's all in service to a standard dungeon-crawler with more rules than any game needs.  It doesn't feel at all Lovecraftian.  It doesn't help that this is the easiest cooperative game I know of -- though it feels like you're in trouble the first couple times you play, I've never actually lost it.  (My friends tell me that it's gotten harder since they bought the expansions, but I still won the two games I've played since then.) It's not worth it, especially since the game takes about 3 hours (and only the boss battle in the last 10 minutes matters).

Admittedly, it's very difficult to give a board game a Lovecraftian feel.  Maybe the designers should have started from Shadows Over Camelot, the only game I know of that gives the players a sense of dread.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Letter Grade: B-.  Very big, very brawny.  Clunky, hard to teach, hard to navigate the rulebook, long. [05-08-09]

Great solo play that would work as well with more players.  The atmosphere and difficulty give the game a mounting sense of tension as the game progresses.  A deeply-themed adventure for those who can stomach the length and the involved rules.

9/11/07: Needs a few things for it to work, like time, patience with learning rules, the right crowd, and a proper balance (2-4 characters).  The number of variables in the game means you can almost tune the experience to the sort of session you'd like to have--a strength in an adventure game of this sort. 
 
[05-08-09]: Old rating: 8.5.  New rating: 7.5

RATING: 9.3

RATING: 6

It's a weird game to play. Good and bad and random all rolled into one. 

I'd play it again, especially with people who know the game, but I likely wouldn't suggest it.

RATING: 6

Its cooperative which is unique to my game shelf.  But those rules... oh good God... could you be more ambiquious?  

Example:

Go through the portal to the nether realms (see diagram c on page 15), to close the portal (see portal closing on page 3).  Then do a sanity check (see sanity checks on page 18).  If you fail you loose sanity (see going insane on page 6).  

WHHHHHYYY!?

RATING: 7
Pretty neat game, I had fun playing it but was a bit disappointed with the big game end monster battle. I'm a huge fan of Lovecraft's work and really get into playing this game for very well done theme and feel.  Obviously the way to win the game is to close and seal the required number of gates.  If you allow the Cthulhu beast out…you pretty much lose, which is accurate from the books, but that crazy dice fest of a battle leaves something to be desired game-wise.  I'm thinking if each monster had an attack, a multiple attack, a special attack, a bind attack that held players, etc...see different types of attach, then a random way of determining what attack it used, and what not, it'd be a little bit of spice for the game.

UPDATE: I got to play the original 80's version of the game and Looooovvvveeeedddd it so much. Loads and loads of fun. If I could rate them individually I would give the original a 9 probably.

RATING: 5
Fantasy Flight games seem to divide themselves over the years very distinctly into those that I really like and those that I really don't like; unfortunately Arkham Horror fell into the latter category after my first play, but I'm still willing to give it another shot to confirm, just as I gave Twilight Imperium two tries before deciding that it really wasn't for me. It's interesting because I really enjoy Descent: Journeys in the Dark, War of the Ring, Battlestar Galactica, and A Game of Thrones, but really can't stand TI3, Cosmic Encounter, and now Arkham Horror. I suppose this means I really need to try some of their other games that I'm skeptical about, but which could I suppose end up being favorites, such as StarCraft. I think the biggest hurdle to Arkham Horror for me is that I know absolutely nothing about the underlying subject matter and have absolutely no interest in that subject matter. Theme is not usually a major consideration for me, but when it comes to these sorts of epic games, I guess it's a different story, which explains why I like Battlestar Galactica, and Dune and War of the Ring for that matter. This is really cemented by my explanation here of my initial dislike of BSG before watching the television show, which seems to be a common experience. I think when it comes down to it, I'm happy to disregard the theme of a one hour game, but less inclined to do so for a three or four hour game. This seems like a good theory until you try to explain my love of Die Macher, which is simply inexplicable, but so very fantastic; who knew German elections could be so much fun.
