RATING: 7
I'm a sucker for flavor and this one had lots of it.  Plus, like a good video game, it's fun to build up your character with lots of cool items.  Long and fiddly but I still ended up playing five times in one weekend and couldn't wait to play again. Consequently I impulse bought it with both expansions.  The perfect game to play in between all those dry euros ;)

As long as one person really knows the rules well, the fiddly parts of the game aren't so bad for the rest of the players.  Also, make sure the players know they are in for a long game and tell them you will take care of all the hard parts.  Provided they like the theme and would enjoy wandering around reading cool encounters for four hours, they should have a blast.

Despite some issues, I don't remember the last time I had this much fun playing a game.

RATING: 9
Awsome game but not for everyone, some consider this a very complex game with poorly written rules, I however have had really no issues with the rules.  

I will addmit that there is alot going on in this game and alot to keep track of but with reading the rules quite a few times and after 4-5 games under your belt this should move smoothly, be prepared to invest about 2-4 hours of your time in a game of AH (at least for the first few times you play) 

The sweet spot for this game is 4-5 players ,with a few different ways to win this game after 5 or so games you will realize how to win this game more than not... then it will be time to look into getting a few expansions and learning some more rules.

Don't give up on this game so quickly, it is drenched in theme and a wonderful way to spend a few hours of your time.

A word of warning... if you end up enjoying the base game you will most likley want to aquire the expansions, with the expansions this game is a table hog, be prepared to play on the floor or buy a huge surface to play on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably one of my most played 'big box' games of all times. I first played this game in 2006 when the DM of our Call of Cthulhu games recommended we play this when one of our players was sick. I was immediately hooked on the game and bought it the day after. Sure, the game has its flaws but I don't care. It perfectly encapsulates the Lovecraftian horror feel. 

Lots of people have jumped ship to Eldritch Horror, which I don't enjoy as much. Eldritch is a fun game but feels TOO slick and almost feels like a step down from Arkham, especially in difficulty. Sure, it fixes some things and streamlines the game but I think the clunkiness of Arkham HELPS the game's horror feel. 

I own all the expansions and we frequently play this game with a mix of expansion content thrown in. With well over 100 games played (probably a LOT more) I'm still enjoying Arkham just as much, if not more, as when I first played it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A flavorful and tense co-op game that sets players against a massive invasion of an ancient evil.  Very bits-intensive, but it is worth it for the overall experience.  It is also a bit long...

A lot of people have said that the rules have a lot of little "gotchas", but I've found it to be pretty intuitive.  The manual could use a little work, but overall I think it does a good job of explaining the core concepts and giving examples of gameplay.

As of now, my favorite co-op title.

**EDIT 8/19/2010 - Bumping my rating up to a 9 after a great solo session.  This game has crazy amounts of narrative, challenge, and variety.  I haven't even branched out from the base game, and I feel like I'm scratching the surface.

**EDIT 6/12/2011 - Bumping up to a 10.  Was there ever any doubt?  Sure, the length is enormous, but if you're going to play a game for that long, this is it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The [b]best totally cooperative board game ever made[/b] (that I know of, and have played). Full of theme, tension and decisions, and not the decision making is not really pre-set, as in boards like Pandemic, where if you are de Medic, you MUST do this and do basically ONLY this for all the game.

In [b]Arkham Horror[/b] the player normally have several options all with their own merits. Really no two plays of AH are alike (I played over 100 times, and none were the same). It works even better if the players know the works of Lovecraft? Yes, it does, but it is not necessary or required. All you need is to want to work together (or solo) to experience a great game.

A warning tough: avoid at all costs to play this game with 6 or more people. If they are all crazy fans of the game (that say things like: "the best cooperativa game ever"), then you may consider. But, in 95% of the situations, it will translate into a poor (if not awful and/or hateful) experience: the downtime is huge and the game can easly surpass the 3 hours of game. And if one investigator gets lost in time and space? Go take a nap and be back in 30 minutes.

I like AH more than any other game, and I still say that the biggest mistake made is say that this game is for 1 to 8 players (consider 1 to 5 and be happy!).

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/686940/review-arkham-horror-em-portugues-in-portuguese]here[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Rules: Unacceptable mess of inconsistency. Needs approximately 3 times the rulebook page count of errata and clarifications.

Game Length: eons of broken repetition.

Gameplay: Seriously flawed/broken (co-operative game with not a slightest hint for need of co-operation). Very, very, very repetitive.

Components: Average, most components non-purposeful. Way, way too much repetitive clutter.

Overall impression: Very limited re-playability, once to learn the system, second time to realize that there is nothing in it.

Any player having tendency to think will stall the game for hours to come. In this case, it is strongly recommended to have secondary game around to kill the downtime, something like ASL will do perfectly.

RATING: 6

They just get boring if I'm honest... I like to think about my strategies when I play a game, unfortunately Arkham doesn't scratch this itch. However it does manage to tell a story and I love using my imagination and seeing an almost "movie-like" story getting woven infront of me. Beautiful.

Dunwich Horror
Innsmouth Horror
Kingsport Horror
Miskatonic Horror
Black Goat of the Wooods

King in Yellow
Lurker at the Threshold

RATING: 8
This game is very good.  The theme is amazing as you really feel like your in the game and monsters are appearing from portals.  Very cool mechanics and dice rolling to either fight, evade, or close gates.  A rather difficult game, especially with only playing one player.  I have found that to even the solo play a little bit, is to use two player rules except you get two actions for every mythos card.  It works for an easier time to beat the game a few more times.  Using items, and spells and abilities is a must.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Arkham Horror is a cooperative adventure game themed around H.P Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos. Players choose from 16 Investigators and take to the streets of Arkham. Before the game, one of the eight Ancient Ones is chosen and it's up to the Investigators to prevent it from breaking into our world. During the course of the game, players will upgrade their characters by acquiring skills, allies, items, weapons, and spells. It's up to the players to clean out the streets of Arkham by fighting many different types of monsters, but their main goal is to close portals to other dimensions that are opening up around town. With too many portals open the Ancient One awakens and the players only have one last chance to save the world. Defeat the Ancient One in combat!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Arkham Horror is a cooperative adventure game themed around H.P Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos. Players choose from 16 Investigators and take to the streets of Arkham. Before the game, one of the eight Ancient Ones is chosen and it's up to the Investigators to prevent it from breaking into our world. During the course of the game, players will upgrade their characters by acquiring skills, allies, items, weapons, and spells. It's up to the players to clean out the streets of Arkham by fighting many different types of monsters, but their main goal is to close portals to other dimensions that are opening up around town. With too many portals open the Ancient One awakens and the players only have one last chance to save the world. Defeat the Ancient One in combat!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Just go's to long.  Love HP Lovecraft.  Tries to capture the feel of the RPG.  Didn't really do it for me

Fazit:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ugh, Arkham.  One of my first introductions to playing 'against the game'.  For helping popularize that concept, Arkham deserves a good score.  The game itself, though, is as shaky as someone who's just seen Shub-Niggurath.

This monster (the moster-sized game, not the Old Ones.. :P) will eat your entire table for five hours as you stumble around, wandering into gates because you have to, and hoping not to get too badly altered by the events that transpire while you're in otherworldly places.

There are RPG elements, with Lore and Luck as interesting slider attributes, along with the entire slider mechanic.  Different characters have different abilities and are more suited to one thing or another.  Places on the map have flavors in the cards they can produce...

Except.. none of it really matters.  Whether you get tossed on your ear or discover some shattering insight at the Miskatonic University comes down to what card was on top.  Whether you get lost in time and space or have a day as uneventful as a trip to the mall when you go literally out-of-this world is .. dependent on which card was on top.  Your character's special ability is basically irrelevant.  Your success or failure is not something you can see the grand strategy of.  

Yes, vaguely you can see that killing this or that monster keeps them from overflowing, or perhaps they're just in the way.  Or maybe you think you'll trade their heads for some useful gear before a shop closes.  Ultimately, though, there isn't a feeling of progression the way there in in, say, Pandemic, nor a feeling of tension, despite the fact that you're more likely to lose Arkham than many other coop games and that that will represent a much larger chunk of time invested.

Ultimately, this creaks and groans its way through hours of play, turns seeming interminable when it's not your turn (unless you devolve to Play-by-Committee) at which point your participation might be made moot anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Iconic game that has too many moving parts and takes too long to play.  Is there an app for that?

RATING: 8
I love this world so much.  This game is just wonderful, though a bit clunky.  I love the board and the characters and the locations and the monsters.  I get this nostalgic feeling every time I play it.  It takes a really long time to play but I feel it's worth it.  People say Eldritch Horror has replaced it.  I haven't played that yet but after watching a couple of playthroughs I don't think it would for me.  I would miss the city too much.  For me the game is far more about the story of Arkham itself than the game play so the whole globe-trotting thing doesn't appeal to me as much.  That being said I would probably like Eldritch, I just don't think it would replace Arkham for me.

It's a brilliant game, love it.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Things I liked about this game: Excellent components. Truely a visual stunner. The background story and theme of the game are captured in every piece of the game. The monster movement system is excellent and really captures a the feel of monsters roaming the streets unpredictably (which was a concern when I heard about how the game works). There are loads of encounters and for the most part they really pull you deeper into the game and keep your interest through out. I found that with every card came greater anticipation of what was lurking in the next turn. I also thought the characters were well put together and thier backgrounds were represented well in thier effects on the game. I will say that some are far better than others in the overall outcome of the game. That can be percieved as an added challenge to game play, or an easy elimination for character choices. I also really liked the towns "Terror Tracker" and the adverse effects on the game if monsters are not dealt with. 

What I didn't like: The game may take longer than the average gamer can commit to often. I am not sure I can spend 5 hours playing a game all that much. It was fun, but it really takes a long time to finish a game. I also felt (and this is pretty petty) that you should have gotten more dice than just 5, as many rolls used 7-10 dice. I also would recommend that anyone who is learning this game with out another person who has played a few games read through the rule book more than once and have everything layed out, as the rule book can be a little difficult to refer back to for specific Q&A. 

With that in mind, I really feel that if this game could be finished on average within 2 hours that I would have rated it 9. And for those of you who are married and want to game with your wife, my advice would be to read through the rules a couple times first (as this will keep the game moving and not burn time referencing in the rule book). My wife is not a gamer, but I took a friends advice and did just that, and 5 1/2 hours later she wants to play again. I feel that is the strongest aspect of this game, is it's ability to entertain a broad audience. It is involved, yes. But with a good understanding of the rules you can introduce casual gamers to a fun, interactive game that will have everyone laughing and working together to close just one more gate...........Buy it! It is worth the investment. 

Thanks to everyone who posted feedback. I bought this game due to your posts!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very nice cooperative game. 7 becouse it's not my type of game/story.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
later Elder Sign and Eldritch Horror
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Well-designed for what it is, but what it is isn't necessarily what I usually want from a game.  If I spend several turns acquiring the necessary clue tokens, and then move to a gate, and then spend two turns in that other world, I want that gate to close when I come out of it.  I don't want to fail the roll and have to go back into the other world for two more turns and try again.

It's the kind of randomness I don't usually like.  There are ways to mitigate it, but not to the degree I personally prefer. (Cf., for example, Blood Bowl, which has a high degree of randomness but is, to a degree, about using good strategy to mitigate that randomness and bend it to your will.)

But that's me, and YMMV.  Certainly it's fun with the right crowd.

RATING: 9
and all its expansions up to Miscatonic University
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
My wife and I got this game from Barnes and Noble.  I spent the first day just trying to learn the rules on my own (I'm the more experienced gamer).  To start, the rulebook was over 20 pages and did not lend itself to quick or easy set-up and play.  By the time I had the game set-up, my wife said she was bored and didn't want to play.

I continued to setup the game, determined to play on my own.  After about a dozen rounds, I agreed with my wife and put the game away.  The biggest issue with the game are the amount of rules, many of them only trigger in certain circumstances.  For example, each turn, all monsters with a symbol that matches a drawn card move or attack.  Sounds easy right?  Unless the border of the monster's token is red, in which case it moves twice, or yellow in which case it doesn't move, or blue in which case it moves to the closest outdoor player (or a holding area called the sky if no players are outdoors), or green in which the movement follows rules unique to the monster, or purple which case the monster can jump to an investigator under certain conditions or orange which can jump between aquatic locations if it is in an aquatic location and a player is in a different aquatic location.

Those are the rules that need to be remembered for one quarter of one phase.  Most of the rest of the game is handled the same way.  You spend more time looking up what a purple border meant then actually forming strategies and actively playing the game.   Its just not fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
One of the better co-op games I played. Tons of options each round, great atmosphere and brilliant components. My first play took 6.5 hours with four players, but the game was never boring. The only thing I am concerned about is its replayability. The available expansions (which I will rate separately), however, should fix this. The expansions should also fix the fact that the game is a little too easy for four players. Finally, I have to admit that it took quite some effort for experienced gamers to get all the rules straight. Be prepared to read some extensive FAQs and posts during your first play in order to resolve specific situations.

RATING: N/A


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the first game I bought, when my new found love for board games began... This is one of our (wife & my) favorite games.  We have played it several times and enjoy the massive amounts of options in gameplay, in terms of characters, ancient ones, and locales to visit/explore as the adventure unfolds.  I also like the fact that losing happens just as often as winning.  Leaves us wanting to go back in and kick the Ancient One back into the dark aeons from which it came.  This game is slanted to reflect the desperate environment of H.P. Lovecraft's world.  As one of my gamer friends put it, the game can often feel like "upper cut, nut punch, upper cut..." as the cards unfold and enemies populate the board.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A couple of years ago I would have given Arkham Horror a 10. Every game tells a fantastic story and, if you play with a bunch of hardened Call of Cthulhu role players like I do, the experience is exceptional. Unfortunately my patience for mammoth game sessions has waned over the years - set up time alone (if you're adding some expansion material) takes longer than many good games. Added to that is the real possibility of the game ending in failure and, unless you're careful, of an alpha player taking over the entire play. 
Yup, AH with it's hundreds of tiny cards and counters littering the gaming table like an explosion in a confetti factory is starting to show its age - an age where the BGG landscape shook to the tread of the coffinboxes.
I still have a soft spot for the old tyrannosaurus though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
We always try with one character each for two players, in any game. This one seems clear you need four investigators minimum. While more players does increase spawn, it gives you more investigators-worth of movement and battle action before the Arkham/Other World phase encounters (which may, themselves, spawn more monsters) and the Mythos phase (which ain't nevah good). 

We quit after 8 hours, eight closed gates, three sealed, and still four open gates (at the time) away from any sort of victory. I was getting grumpy and bored, and we already dedicated an extra day of Shametember to it and couldn't spare another anyway. We don't have a game table vault to put it away, so it sits in the middle of our living room taking up our only gaming space so long as it is set up. To make room for other games, it had to go.

In related news, I referenced multiple forum discussions on commonly misunderstood/missed rules, and the only one-and-a-half we were getting wrong were ones that would have helped us rather than made the game harder, so the fact that with two investigators we lasted that long (and maybe even could have won? We were only 5/10 on the Doom track when we quit)...I think we did pretty good. Verdict: Chris liked it and wants to play again soon. I felt it had some needlessly fiddly bits (in the battles particularly) and needlessly hard bits, some of which the creator of the game even wrote a PDF of house rules he uses/recommends now even addresses. Overall I enjoyed many elements of it; and the turn order/flow, once we grokked it, is pretty good for a game of this scale.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

The theme elements and rules bloat do provide a sense of discovery during the first couple of playthroughs that is quite satisfying. But once these are understood there is no game left.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Very fun co-op game. 

Update: I started out really liking this game but have found it's faults. Something needs to be done about making it a little easier to win by sealing/closing gates and make battling the ancient one harder. While this was somewhat fixed with the Dunwich expansion, it also broke some other things. The spells also make me groan, spells just aren't worth using except for the ones that don't cost any sanity. Still fun but down from an 8 to a 7.

Update #2: This game is back up to an 8. I've started playing it again without the Dunwich expansion and it is a MUCH better game without that expansion. The DH expansion just adds a bunch of junk that makes the game harder and more tedious. More detail in the DH entry.

Update #3: It's been 2 years since I've played this. I'm now scaling it back from an 8 to a 5. This game is so frustrating, it seems like you're always getting punished. Sometimes when you succeed you still get punished. It's like you have an alcoholic father who beats your ass when you manage to only score 3 touchdowns in a state playoff game. You really feel helpless and it seems like there's not a lot of planning you can do. 
     
It's also not a lot of fun to watch your character get weaker and weaker as the game goes on. I suppose this is supposed to make it feel like you're playing out one of Lovecraft's stories, struggling to keep your sanity as you strive to stave off the ancient one, but this argument is moot when the easiest way to victory is to just duke it out with the ancient one.
    
My last complaint is the spells. Ugh, wtf? Sanity is used in a lot of the tests during the game, but then if you want to use spells you have to spend more of that precision resource. Even then it's not guaranteed you're going to get the benefits of the spell. I mean really, how much sense does this make? The melee attacks don't use health so why do the spells use sanity? 
   
The best bet is to just lay low, collect the easy stuff if you can, and then wait for the ancient one to come calling. I guess that's how you're supposed to play it, but does that really sound appealing? Not to me. Overall, I think the developers struggled with trying to balance the game and tie it into the mythos. Unfortunately, they failed. I'm giving it a 4 and I feel I'm being generous giving it that high of a rating.

Update #4: After looking over how I've rated some other games I'm dropping it to a 3. Strange, I just cracked a malicious grin...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A tough, cooperative survival game set in Lovecraft's Arkham city. Rules for combat and movement are a little clunky, but the sense of victory from successfully completing a game is tough to beat. Player death is a real possibility, and is a bit of a bummer if you get knocked out of the game while other players are still in. Gorgeous art and the theme can't be beat. Improved upon in many ways by Eldritch Horror.

RATING: 8
Haven't logged all of my plays for most of my games, but this is the most under-logged; probably missing hundreds of plays.  As you might be able to tell, this game never gets tired for me.  With all of the expansions, the game is so different from play to play, and the different investigators change the experience so much, that it's tough to see how this game could ever get boring or repetitive. 

Having played enough, the game is currently at an average play time of ~2.5 hours for our usual game group, including set up time.

RATING: 4
I love the world of Lovecraft, but I generally dislike playing 2 hours into a foregone conclusion. 

Even though Arkham Horror is a co-op game, and the players won both times I've played, the victory seemed unimpressive, because very few players were actually able to contribute to the war effort.

I find it a little odd that physically strong characters are allowed to close gates, because this renders most of the intellectuals redundant. Slap a gun on the detective, and watch him handle pretty much everything, while the other players grab the odd elder sign every few turns or so.

This seems to be a recurring theme in the Fantasy Flight games.

RATING: N/A
:star::star::star::nostar:

For me, [thing=146021]Arkham Horror v3[/thing] is a strict upgrade over [thing=15987]Arkham Horror v2[/thing]. I can certainly see the appeal of v2, especially for those with a lot of experience and/or cash invested. But with a couple plays of v2 and a couple plays of v3, I'm all in on Eldritch Horror.

First, it allows me to play solo with fewer characters. If I wanted to fiddle with that many characters at once, I'd be playing [thing=91872][/thing] or [thing=92190][/thing]. 

Second, I love the streamlining of EH. If I wanted to deal with that much overhead, I'd be playing [thing=96848][/thing] [-]or [thing=121921][/thing][/-]. 

Third, it gives a stronger set of goals that feels like a better alignment between "what I should be doing" and "what I feel like I should be doing." If I wanted to do that much shopping, I'd be playing [thing=35002][/thing].

RATING: 5
The problem with this game for me is that it is nominally a cooperative game, but it feels much more like everyone is working on their own solo project. For an exciting cooperative game, I find Shadows, Fury of Dracula, Lord of the Rings, or especially Battlestar Galactica to fit the bill much better. There also seems to be needless complexity with all the pieces, decks of cards, etc. Revised edition.

I gave this another try at Origins 2014 and it was as disappointing (and BORING!) as ever. I don't understand how a horror game can be this tedious.

RATING: 9
We enjoy this.  Seems like role playing in a board game, which is no surprise given its lineage.  We haven't done much role playing lately.

We'll probably get at least one expansion.  Not for everyone, not much strategy.  I don't mean that it a bad way, but the game plays you rather than the other way around.  Plans might not last long.  Good atmosphere.

There currently seems to be a "not quite as fun" hump in the middle of the game.  Here's to hoping that goes away with more plays.

Ok, the rating has gone up to an 8 from 7.  While we'd rather play with 4 real players, the 2+2 is quite enjoyable.  The game is still a serious time commitment but we usually plan on a food break sometime in the middle which really helps.

We're still not completely on top of all the rules.  We know them but still look up quite a bit just to make sure.

Now the rating has risen to 9.  I think when we chose Arkham Horror over weeding the garden (needed to be done)....   I guess we just like getting beat up for hours.  "The Camellot 'terror level' was at 9 so the garden was closed."  That's our story and we're stickin' to it.

We haven't played this in a while, mainly because of the time commitment.  There's been a marked move towards euros lately.

RATING: 5
The game that gets worse the more you play it!

The good: Thematic lovecraft fun. The art is great. Tons of components. RPG experience without a DM. Combat works out pretty well.

The bad: Essentially broken. Sneak is completely useless since it can only be used while moving, and in order to use it effectively you have to stop moving. Encounters are random and there is no meaningful way to prepare for them. Impossible with 2 people, Incredibly easy with 4-6. 2 hours longer then it should be. Spells don't offer any unique or powerful benefits yet punish you severely for using (or trying to use) them.

I play this with a friend who is REALLY enthusiastic about it. Unfortunately having it brought to the table so much has killed it for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I know there are a lot of people out there who absolutely love this game.  Good for them, I am glad they found something they enjoy.  In fact, I think this is probably the best co-op game out there.  I think the mechanics and theme are very well constructed so that you feel like you are one of a team of investigators trying to stop a horrible outcome.. to a point.  Maybe its not the theme and mechanics I have a problem with.  Maybe its just the whole Lovecraftian vibe that I just can't get into.  I mean, I respect it as much as any other made up lore for its complexity and detail, but its just not my cup of tea.  Plus, the game seems overly complicated.  I agree with those who say that its complexity helps to draw you into the theme.  I also agree with those who say that the game is enjoyed more when you do understand the mechanics.  I am simply saying that the game is very complicated, especially if you did not have someone around who has played the game before.  If the downloaded flowcharts for the game are 6 pages long, then the game is too complicated. I have learned alone and taught many games, but this one was a chore.   Perhaps there will come a day when I will request Arkham Horror be pulled off the shelf, but today is not that day.

Tedious Setup and tear down and probably plays longer than it should.

However - what it does well, it does damn well - and that is tell a story.  My kids love playing. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Luca Iennaco say:

Sort of multiplayer gamebook (or simple RPG with an automated Master).
Theme is nicely implemented. Some efforts to "roleplay" (when possible) improve the experience.
A bit of strategy and tactic is possible, but luck has a decisive role (cards and dice rolls).
Cards and characters aren't too well balanced.
Rules have some ambiguities and missing points; you'll have to fill the gaps and add some house rules to make the game playable (download the latest FAQs as well, since they're finally available).
It doesn't scale very well: too easy with more than 4 characters (and a lot of downtime) and too difficult with only one or two (we suggest: when playing solo, use 3 or 4 characters; with two players, use 2 characters each). I won't play it again with more than 4 players.
Game lenght was significant, but is reduced to about 2 hours (with up to 4 players) after some games. 
It becomes repetitive (similar gameplay and too few cards). Expansions alleviate this problem.
Fine components.

Overall, it is an EXPERIENCE the first time(s) and you MUST modify it to make it a decent GAME (my rating regards the game after you find a suitable set of global rules; it'd get only a "4" considering the game "as it is out of the box"). 

2006-11-20
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another fun game even solo. Many different characters to play, each with unique strengths and weaknesses. Took me several plays to get the hang of, but now I enjoy it a lot. Setup takes awhile, but not as bad as Mage Knight. Games can take a really long time to finish.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game drags on and one must really get to know the cards. My son really likes it though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rated after 17 confirmed games with different groups. The game itself is good (at least thematically) and it is nice to play. The rule book on the other hand is poor, and it's quite difficult really understand the rules or check some details. Despite the theme, the rule book is the most terrifying thing in this game. Checking the rules (when playing every now and then) is very painful.

I have not played much co-op games, but they are nicely different than regular games, not competing against others but against the board.

There are lots of little chits and cards and other stuff. They look good, but there are millions of rules to remember - and did I already said, that the rule book is not good? The problem grows with expansions, which add new cards, new decks and new rules. Still, with a proper group and rules in your head, the game is good.

Update after 14th play: The amount of decks and cards is not the biggest problem, there are just so many tracks to update and things to remember, special abilities of monsters, old ones, investigators etc, that you either need to be very careful or have a good player aid, if you want to have a smooth game.

The 15th game was a solo game with two investigators, I just wanted to play the game and be able to check all the rules and twists without hurry.

One play with just the base game (basically) and although it was over a year since the last play, it went quite well. There are not that many things to worry about in the base game, but of course there are so many small rules and modifiers, that it is hard to remember them all. Fortunately, that is not always necessary, it all rounds up in the end anyway. :)

The latest game was with expansion, but not with the Dunwich board, which seems to be quite boring - at least with 4 or less players.

UPDATE: Fired by Mage Knight as our epic wandering around a board game.

Fun with two players if you play two or three investigators each.

RATING: 8
An excellent game. The downside is that it has SO MUCH material and details that is very difficult to put everything together and play correctly. If you have a group that can dedicate hours to it, then grab a copy!

EDIT: After some time without this game, and after playing other games, I can realise that this game is a double-edged sword.

In one side, it is imense! Seriously, it has tons of material in the main box alone. If you add the expansions, you'll be probably swimming in chits and pieces.

The downside is that this game NEEDS commitment. When playing this, you must act like you were going for a RPG session, where you'll spende some hours to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Neat ideas, interesting mechanics, and a great theme.  The game takes about 2 hours too long for what I get out of it, and the mid-game seems to get terribly drawn out as people wander around, waiting for something interesting to do, but dammit, it's a whole heck of a lot of fun.  I like the way that the game handles die rolls (instead of modifying the die result with different bonuses, you modify the NUMBER of dice you roll, with the winning results never changing), but it means that there's still no guarantee that you're going to get what you need at the right time.  Still, a game with a Cthulhu theme should contain no minimum of chaos, so it works.  If I could play it within about 2 hours, I'd probably like it even more.

1 play: 4 players
2 plays: 6 players

RATING: N/A
The year is 1926, and it is the height of the Roaring Twenties. Flappers dance till dawn in smoke-filled speakeasies drinking alcohol supplied by rum runners and the mob. It's a celebration to end all celebrations in the aftermath of the war to end all wars.
\13\ \13\
Yet a dark shadow grows in the city of Arkham. Alien entities known as Ancient Ones lurk in the emptiness beyond space and time, writhing at the gates between worlds. These gates have begun to open and must be closed before the Ancient Ones make our world their ruined domination.
\13\ \13\ 
Only a handful of investigators stand against the Arkham Horror. Will they Prevail? 
\13\ \13\ 
Arkham Horror is a cooperative adventure game themed around H.P Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos. Players choose from 16 Investigators and take to the streets of Arkham. Before the game, one of the eight Ancient Ones is chosen and it's up to the Investigators to prevent it from breaking into our world. During the course of the game, players will upgrade their characters by acquiring skills, allies, items, weapons, and spells. It's up to the players to clean out the streets of Arkham by fighting many different types of monsters, but their main goal is to close portals to other dimensions that are opening up around town. With too many portals open the Ancient One awakens and the players only have one last chance to save the world. Defeat the Ancient One in combat!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played once or twice (from brand new).  Game has sat on the shelf for years, so may have some shelf wear, but I've kept it because it was one of the first games (in modern board gaming) I bought.  Components will look great.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my first exposure to the Cthulu mythos, and it turned out to be a highly interactive game.  People seemed interested in everything happening in the game.  The rules are a bit dense, but the manual could be laid out a little better.  No ambiguities!  I strongly recommend that you use a player aid to reduce the amount of rules page flipping. The game took about five hours to play the first time, with about an hour to go over rules and set it up.  The tension was high starting out, but seemed to go smoothly once we got into it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
its a very nice adventure game, very atmospheric, after my first few games of this I wasnt sure what to think of it but I'm definitely starting to warm to it. I think that when you play this game you have to try and roleplay a little bit and try and get into the spirit of things, and just enjoy it, win or lose.
I feel that people should tweak the rules from game to game and try different things out, i've yet to lose to this game except in solitare though, despite 4x2 player games, although 2 of them have been very close affairs. All in all a game that has risen in my estimation but probably not one for the harcore abstract strategy gamer.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Have you ever played this game with 5 or 6 players? It's hell on Earth, and one of the worst possible games I can think of for that player size. 

The game also got old fast for me, even with more manageable player numbers. It is just too easy, and once you understand the rules it becomes bleedingly obvious that you should just never ever close a portal, and to have at least one guy just camp forever at the newspaper. The result is pretty monotonous.

But man, is this game fun and scary before the novelty wears off. I also love the idea of playing against the board rather than against each other - it lets me play competitively without having to worry about stepping on anyone's toes.

Anyway, I'm told the expansions add a lot to the game, which is why the rating is still pretty high, despite the fact that I would never touch the base game again if I had my way. My hopes are that when I get around to getting an expansion, the game will be revived for me. 

EDIT: The expansions helped, but caused game length to balloon to ridiculous amounts. I've moved on and regret all of the purchases I did for this, trying to get it to a playable state.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The first coop. experience in my life. 'Nuff said.

RATING: N/A
Also have a full set (48?) of the painted miniatures for the characters. Also have Blessed Dice, Cursed Dice and regular Dice Set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game nails its theme like no other. The monsters hunt you, the events constantly thwart your best laid plans, and sometimes just for fun, an Elder God devours you.

Awesome.

As for how it plays, it requires quite a bit of maintenance on the part of the players. There are a million things going on every Mythos phase (which happens every turn) and it can be a challenge to keep track of it all. That being said, all the upkeep results in a fantastic adventure for the players. The game challenges and fights them every step of the way, delivering a very fulfilling experience. The A.I. of the game is really just a large deck of cards that spits out random effects, but it is eerily effective in making the players feel hunted, adding tension and drama to every flip of the Mythos deck.

Make no mistake, Arkham Horror is a light RPG for those of us who don't role play and the group it is played with certainly makes or breaks the game. If everyone at the table gets into their characters, drops funny dialogue and expounds upon the text delivered in the encounter decks, then the fun level goes through the roof. Without this, it is a dull game of random token shuffling. Fortunately for me, my group really enjoys getting into the story and we often joke about the various ways our characters have been devoured or lost in time and space...often for weeks afterwards. Maybe it's even less of a game and more of an experience, but either way, it's a good one!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Exciting, shouty game for when we have too many people or just don't want to to grind each other's faces into the ground.

But when I do get a group fired up to play, it is still loads of fun when you get into the right mindset. It's pretty telling that even all these years later I still go back and play every now and then.

RATING: 8
We have the base game and all the expansions. This is a great game for 3 or more players. Set up takes a while and there are many small pieces, but once the game gets going, it really draws the players into the world of Lovecraft's mythos and the 2-fisted 20's.The horror is often "humor" ... especially with some of the random encounters. Only a couple drawbacks are evident: the cash and allies are rare to come by. The nature of the game and the mechanics makes earning money and buying stuff a luxury. The cardboard figures... plastic miniatures would have been nice, considering that everything else is made of paper.

Your not forced to play with all the expansions but using a little bit of everything makes the game different each time.

One of my top favorite games to play in solo

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There are problems: too long (but not that bad with < 4), wildly varying balance from game to game, obvious cruft from development (monster limits, outskirts, and terror leap out), really poor scaling. But most annoying is the weird front-loaded arc where you're under massive siege at first and then you coast toward the end; this is a fundamental failure of the designers to understand how gates and doom really interact. All this, along with focus sliders and monsters, seems cool at first, but breaks down under scrutiny.

Expansion integration is questionable at best. Seems clearly designed to play with one big + one small, no more. Beyond that it gets fragmented, both in terms of too much ground to cover/too few actions, and that of game effects that become too diluted to produce enough tension. Again, the fundamental failure is the gate/doom interaction, and their patches (spread out the board and/or undo gate seals) are both wrong-headed.

In the end, this has to be approached as a fun adventure game, and it does manage to create a convincing atmosphere, while still offering some crunchy bits in terms of decisions. But it's one of those paradoxical games, where if you play to win, it's either trivially solvable or it loses all thematic coherence (gear up and take down the big bad; about as anti-HPL as you can get). So you have to truly "play" to enjoy it, and I've done that many enjoyable times with my daughters, and I'll never sell it due to the warm nostalgia.

But it's fading, and Eldritch renders it more and more obsolete, as EH is just a flat out better game design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love this game.  The theme is amazing.  The coop aspect is fun.  IMHO this is the perfect RPG lite game.  The more you put into it, the more you get out of it.  I will own all of the expansions to this

RATING: 5
Maybe I'm being a bit too harsh on ol' Arkham Horror, but I've just been completely underwhelmed all three times I've played it.  There's just soooo much compounded randomness that, for the time investment, it ends up feeling kind of pointless.  Maybe if I was more invested in the theme or more familiar with the (many, many, many) decks of cards, it would click a bit better.

There are several individual mechanics that I do really like, however.  One is the system for monster movement.  It's very simple and introduces uncertainty in a very controlled and manageable way.  The sanity/stamina slider is also a very elegant but significant bit of player customization.

--

Heh.  I've been hacked by a rabid Arkham fan who changed my 5 to a 10 and wrote the below comment.  That'll teach me to leave myself logged in all over the place.  I've revised my rating upward slightly since.

An Arkham Horror SuperFan writes:

[i]Don't know what I was thinking with that "5". This is possibly the best game I've ever played. Every game is different, the challenge level is perfect (and can be adjusted with ease if needed). There is a ton of decision making (do we go for a seal victory or prepare to fight the ancient one? Should I go after monsters or spend my time shopping?) and resource management (gate trophies/ monster trophies/ money). The random elements keep the game fresh without ruining the strategic element. Character/resource management and team strategy is always more important than luck. I'm sure glad I realized the error of my ways and changed the score to what this masterpiece truly deserves. Thank you Heidi and Jason for enriching my life by exposing me to this work of art.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Approx 3-4 hours long.   Complicated rules for a boardgame - lots of dice.  Learning Curve:  1 game to get the rules straight.  Played another game after a while - didn't take long to get back in the groove.

Very nice bits (thick linen cardboard).  Nice pictures for items,  events cards are mostly text,  but can change gameplay a lot.  Wish there were more pictures,  à la Shadows over Camelot.  And the "read the Mythos cards bottom-up"  is pretty annoying.

Plays like an RPG-lite.  I found it very atmospheric,  had a blast.  Kind of like a very fancy Fighting Fantasy novel.  High customisation potential (new characters, Ancient Ones).

All the bits are nice,  but makes for a pretty fiddly game.  I imagine a 3rd edition redesign could make this the be-all end-all game.  For now,  it's still based pretty heavily on random "skill-tests".  The skill test mechanic is usually pretty good,  although extreme results are possible (it's possible to just keep on rolling failure after failure).  Doesn't seem to be much of a way to predict what skill to optimise for - events are pretty random.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I very much enjoy the variety of this game.  I like that you can play 1 or more characters, that you can play with 1 or 2 or many players, that there are several characters with different characteristics, that the mix of characters is random (which will suggest different playing styles depending on which mix you get), that the Ancient One you fight in the end is random and has various attributes which again suggest different tactics.

All of this adds greatly to its replay value.  

And I love all the bits.  The artwork is nice and moody, but not gory.  On top of all that it's fun, and I'm already wondering if I've rated this too low.

Edit:  I've had to bump this from an 8 to a 10.  This is my game group's favorite game, with and without the expansions.  The replay is high; we really enjoy the variety of things that can happen, which makes us opt for a different strategy each game.

RATING: 6
The more we play the game the more we realize the mood has faded long time ago. The main problem is that all the encounters are too dry. Lovecraft was known for his rich descriptions of the environment and the characters yet here the descriptions look more like an excuse to make the system checks. That plus the terrible feeling of being drag into a mechanic that goes nowhere has make me drop my rating to 5 and everytime we play it it will probably go down if we do not use house rules.

 [b]Base game fix: [/b]
http://boardgamegeek.com/article/3205289#3205289

Here are my modifications:
  [b]SPEED UP GAME RULES [/b](http://boardgamegeek.com/article/1588905#1588905)
  [b]HERALDS - THE WHITE NAPHALOT[/b]
(http://boardgamegeek.com/article/1586719#1586719)
  [b]HERALDS - NYARLATHOTEPH[/b]
(http://boardgamegeek.com/article/1588043#1588043)

[b]GAME SESSIONS:[/b]
  Fighting Ithaqua solo with the White Naphalot Heralding (http://boardgamegeek.com/article/1588692#1588692)

[b]OTHER RULES:[/b]
- Themed Monsters (http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/320538)
- Designer's House Rules (http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Arkham_Horror/House%20Rules%20RL.pdf)

[b]COOL LINKS[/b]
- Strange Eons (http://www.sfu.ca/~cjenning/eons/index.html)

RATING: 2
Pick up clue tokens, kill monsters, seal gates.  When not doing that, have largely unpredictable random encounters.  The game seems to be trying to be an RPG, but it isn't.  It's trying to be atmospheric, but it's not.  The artwork and bits are nice; the game is repetitive and not fun.  As a cooperative game, Arkham Horror also fails.  Where Shadows Over Camelot (which I rate a 6, ok game) has a steadily building tension and allows players to address worsening hotspots, Arkham Horror just seems like an unruly, random mess.  I hope never to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I really really love Lovecraft's works and I wanted this game for a long time. Once I get it I was very disappointed:
If you have a small house, which is my case, this game is almost unusable, its board is so huge that you don't have any place to put it. 
The setup takes so many time that when you are finished with it you are tired and bored and you don't want to play.
Finally I find it too repetitive (monster > go to that place > fight > monster > go to that place > fight > over and over). I really love the investigation part of a RPG, not the fighting part, so this game based almost only in the fighting part doesn't meet my expectations.

RATING: 8
I'm going to go with an 8 on this one because I enjoyed playing this a lot.  As a character I didn't feel completely overwhelmed.  I mean, we were always getting screwed but it wasn't like [GameID=29368] where there was no chance of hope.  There were glints of light that we capitalized on.

My character had [i]Claustrophobia[/i] most of the game and was only driven insane a few time.

Fiddly is an understatement when it comes to this game but luckily we had some AH experts on hand to run the game.  It wasn't so bad for the newbs.  I can't imagine tackling this game without any idea of the rules.

Another reason this game isn't high for me is the down time.  We started with 3 and we eventually amassed 6 or 7.  I didn't find there to be much player interaction other than telling a person what to do or being told what to do which usually happens in co-op games.

Overall though very good experience.  Even when I rolled those low numbers I cheered because thematically it works.

The theme is very solidly implemented (mmmm grammar).

RATING: N/A
I am not assigning a rating to this game until I've played a proper game with people who know what they're doing. There are so many rules in AH that it's nearly impossible to trudge through the entire game for the first time without stopping midway and pulling out one's hair. I love the game mechanics- the ones I understand, anyways. And I love the theme of the game, being a big Lovecraft fan and a horror fan. But, damn...the page-after-page rulebook and the tiny, tiny things that make a huge difference to the game's outcome just make me want to scream.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Long, complex and fiddly games are not usually my first choice. This game is all of those things, but also one of my favourites. The cooperative nature of the game makes it much easier to bear the length (I care what happens on everyone's turn.) Only one or two players need to be well-versed in the complexity, since you can cover the basics then just go over other stuff as it comes up. The fiddliness is what gives each game its unique story and character. I do recommend getting one or two of the expansions if only to have more variety in the location decks, though the expansions offer much more than that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The "in medias res" strategy of the storytelling in this game doesn't get enough credit.  People complain that the events seem too random and come out of nowhere.  But the vignettes on the cards are skillfully designed to be fragments that can create the illusion of a larger story and world -- and I think it does that better than most other games, which often just end up with a pile of discrete stories.

And despite another common complaint, the game actually does reward tactics and strategies.  Yes, you will often get blown off course -- but you can't win if you don't have plans and follow through on most of them. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Torturously long. One of the big reasons I have avoided cooperative games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.68
This is a great game, and the best proof of that pudding is my girlfriend making the first move to play it with me instead of me promising the moon and other chores...
The game is very challenging because it makes every investigator an easy target and one should be ready to take on some flak. The player may take time to gather material or allies, but then monsters pile up and there are portals everywhere. So far it looks like fighting the Old One is mission: impossible with a lesser number of investigators, so I think that games with 1 or 2 player should be played with several investigators per player. A game takes a few hours to complete when rules are assimilated and it takes only a thorough game to be sufficiently familiar with them.
Replayability is high due to the number of different investigators to choose from at the beginning, and the rest is up to luck and some tactics about how to use spells, clues, and chosing the right target at the right time.
The game material is great, standard with current Fantasy Flight products, and is a pleasure to play with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
The only game i like solo!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
As you'll no doubt have realised from the many positive reviews, this is a great game.  Firstly, for the money you pay you get a ton of stuff. Not necessarily the biggest plus point, but then again I've paid twice as much for some games to get a few minis and not much else.  Secondly, it's brimming with theme and got my son well and truly hooked (which is a good thing ... stops him sitting texting for hours on end).  The only downside is your evening disappears in a flash.  Takes hours to play, but it really doesn't seem like it.

UPDATE  - One  month in and I love this game; jjust can't get enough. It's now a 10.

RATING: 7.7
Great components and theme.  Hate the fiddly nature of the game, the "subject to every gentle breeze" -style rules wherein even the designer of the game says he plays with multiple PAGES of house rules.  Hate billions of dollars in expansions.  Hate shuffling 100 decks of cards just in the base game.  Not much of a story, despite what many say.  HOWEVER, the setting, the moody theme created by flavor text and components is pretty sweet.  Minus the flowchart-style effects rules, that alone would have made it a keeper.  Still willing to play as long as someone else is in charge of all the bullshit.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite Co-op games, which I love for it's theme and that it allows for a bit of roleplaying at the table. The game does take quite some time with 4+ players, which causes this game to hit the table less frequently as I often have to plan playing the game.

Nevertheless, I love how you can customize your character based on the situation, improving your sneaking to stay hidden for a monster while waiting for the cavalry to arrive and them change it back to full speed to get quickly where you need to go.

I'll always play with random character selection and random selection of greater evil.

RATING: 4

I'd like to see a boiled down version that is 90 minutes long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
{ P - 1 2 [3] [4] [5] 6 7 8 }

Still the best in co-operative gaming. Lovecraftian theme isn't just pasted on - it meshes seamlessly with the game's robust mechanics, including controlling the number of gates in Arkham, doom tokens, monster limit + outskirts + terror level, varying types of items, sanity/stamina gauges, and stat bars with tradeoffs. There are plenty of things to do in Arkham - gather clues, make and spend money, fight monsters, seal gates, complete tasks, courier items, mitigate rumors - while the item decks and mythos deck ensure that a repeat of a game with all the same characters, guardian/herald, and GOO will be materially different.

I have played with all of the expansions through Lurker at the Threshold and don't recommend mixing them randomly because additional expansions dilutes the effect of each. For example, including both board expansions, Dunwich and Innsmouth, reduces the likelihood that you draw gates from either.

Curse of the Dark Pharaoh
This is a very minor card-only expansion. The main points of interest are the new allies and the spells Astral Travel, Feeding the Mind, and Revelation of Script. Exhibit items are difficult to come by and their effects are hit-or-miss.

Dunwich Horror
This is a board expansion and absolutely crucial. Without Dunwich, the number of unstable locations is too few so there's no real threat of losing to doom tokens. If you can seal three of the four majors (Woods, Witch House, Unvisited, Independence) you basically win. Injury and Madness cards are perfect design; I can't imagine playing without them. Gate Bursts add urgency; investigators can't be certain every elder sign seal will stick. It is necessary for investigators to visit Dunwich to kill monsters and seal gates, though admittedly the stable locations are useless. The new spells, excluding Call Friend and Wrack, are excellent. The majority of the new common and unique items are also very well-designed, with the exception of the missions, which are largely impractical to accomplish.

Dunwich is the only expansion you need for a challenging game. With four players, I highly recommend the designer's suggestion of having two monsters on every gate, as is normal in 5-8 player games. At this point you have two main problems. First, the terror level isn't relevant. It can increase and increase but it doesn't really mean anything until it hits 10. This is where the King in Yellow herald enters the picture; he basically sets the standard that every good herald should either increase the terror level faster or penalize you when the terror level increases. Secondly, the game is very slanted towards unique items. Every item deck has its fair share of mediocre junk but the unique item deck has power cards like Elder Signs, King in Yellows, True Magick, Mi-Go Brain Case, and many others. The only comparable cards in the common item deck are Old Journal, Press Pass, Sledgehammer, maybe one or two more. The spell deck has nothing at that level; it is bogged down with too many weapon spells (unique weapons are almost always better) and only-situationally-useful cards like Flesh Ward and Voice of Ra. The top tier of spells includes Find Gate, Mists of Releh, Vision Quest, and Alchemical Process ... 12 out of 61 spells. Uniques by comparison offer a better top tier at 7 out of 64 uniques, a better second tier (Mi-Go Brain Case, Healing Stone, Pallid Mask, Silver Key, etc.), and you shop three at a time versus two at Ye Olde Magick Shoppe. Basically once you have enough games under your belt you are going to find yourself going for retainers, buying uniques at the Curiositie Shoppe, sealing gates and turning in the trophies at the Science Building, while ignoring common items and spells and other trophy spots. There's no precedent, but if you prefer a bit of balance consider tweaking the common item and spell decks to make them better, and making the unique item deck a little worse.

King in Yellow
Half of a great herald! The three act part is dumb and very literal, codifying the bad Mythos = unwinnable game effect. Blighted allies however are genius; the terror level needs to hurt like this every increment. Many of the unique items are spectacularly bad.

Kingsport Horror
Workable, but design-wise this is a major step back. Adding unstable locations would make too many areas for gates to appear, but instead of reassigning the unstables or finding someway to compensate, the board is all stable. So nobody goes to Kingsport because they don't need to and it isn't useful, which means the expansion uses rifts as a punitive measure for not visiting Kingsport. Most of the new characters are also riddled with problems - really over-the-top powerful designs like guaranteed starting Elder Sign and auto-Evade, or Press Pass as an ability for every clue. Daisy Walker is broken any number of ways and Lily Chen is pretty close. Also what is with mythos cards like "move the first investigator to the SHH" with no skill check involved? On a positive note the GOO's other than Eihort were quite good.

Innsmouth
Design seems to have fallen off a cliff. The GOO's are worthless. Randomly devouring people (Qauchil Uttaus, Ghatanothoa) doesn't matter and you can prepare by giving away items. Zhar and Rhan Tegoth could be easy or hard; how much grief they give you is chance-dependent. Nyogtha and the Jungle Fever guy don't do anything, Cthuga's fine, and Bokrug is playable at least. The new investigators take broken to a whole new level. People that start with things like Find Gate and King in Yellow, or multitudes of clue tokens (lol gravedigger). Someone with 5 fight and can avoid horror checks. Roland Banks is mathematically imbalanced. He has an extra focus and will out of nowhere; after his skill and ally he's basically good at everything. (Looking at the construction, apparently his useful ability is valued at $0.) The violinist - who was smoking what. Innsmouth track is another big fail. If gates don't open in Innsmouth early, the track does nothing. Unlike Dunwich's elegant vortex placement, monsters in Innsmouth either move straight into vortices or take forever as they shuffle about the trianglular streets.

Lurker at the Threshold
Is this a guardian or a herald? Pretty helpful for a herald!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
excellent entry in the coop game genre -- much better if you enjoy the theme.  we found it to be rather easy with five folks pitted against the poor major deity. There's so much variability, what with the different characters and elder gods, that i end up enjoying it more almost everytime i play.  with the Dunwich Horror expansion coming out, i can see playing this a bunch more times, and liking it better each time.  so, this is a great game.

RATING: 8
Wow, that's a lot of cards. Once you are done sorting and shuffling though, setup really isn't that bad. Sort of a paradox really, there's so much to be explored in this game (shops, locations, strange items) in a relativly short time, yet the manner in which the game is won or lost (closing gates or beating the final bad guy) is such a simple concept. Very high replay value, and the rules aren't really that bad (remembering some of the more arbitrary values is kind of rough). Still, the size of this one may put off some, and I've noticed that the dice seem to come up sixes an awful lot, but maybe I'm just really lucky. God, that witch lady is hot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[b]THIS GAME MADE ME FAIL MY SANITY ROLL.[/b]

There are more bells and whistles in the box to this game than I've seen in many other bigger, better games. That being said, the artwork is top-notch, and the theme is as glorious as Shud M'El rising from the deep, mewling for manflesh. The downside is that the game is as longwinded as one of said monster's tentacles.

I wanted to love this game. Really I did. When I finally bedded her she was all looks, no talent.

[b]THE STARS ARE RIGHT:[/b]

1. Beautiful artwork. On everything.
2. Amazing theme.
3. Depth.
4. Semi-RPG riff going on.
5. Great cards for literally every bloody thing.
6. Oodles of equipment and magic thingamabobs.
7. Can be expanded to your heart's desire.

[b]THE BLACK GULF OF N'KAI:[/b]

1. Rubbish board.
2. Overcomplicated.
3. Too much game maintenance.
4. Too big a boardgame for "normal" dining rooms. You need a 6' by 4' table, for pity's sake!
5. Too loooooooooooooong!
6. Bad rulebook.
7. Shocking, impenetrable flowchart style play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I found this game to be far too easy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
This game is a lot of fun to play. It works well if you have people who don't like conflict as you are working as a team in this game. It can be a little of the easy side as I have yet to lose a game but there is no point in the game that I feel like we are doing really well. If you feel like the game is to easy what I tried was every time you lose all of your sanity or stamina you have to draw a new investigator, lose all your items and skills and your old one is replaced with a monster (fitting your death or insanity) if you were knock out in Arkham. This made the game much more intense in my opinion. It made us play more cautiously so that we didn't loose all our stuff.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Was really excited to try this out for the first time, always wanted to participate in a co-op board game.  However, having to muddle through the setup and rules, trying to understand how everything works while explaining it to others, needing to pay attention to every single detail as the first player.  The whole session felt more like work than play.  I imagine I would've had a better time with it had I been taught by a more experienced person.  I wasn't turned off by it, but I was glad when it was finally over, victory didn't taste as sweet as I had hoped it would be.  Well, I'm looking forward to trying it again in the near future, and maybe this time it would go a lot smoother and faster, I would like to improve "leading" the game before introducing Arkham Horror to the rest of my family, so their first time with it will be better than mine.

After 2 sessions now I bumped the rating up to 8 because the game does become a lot more enjoyable the more you are used to the flow.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
As we heard that setting up this game would take about one hour minimum, and that playing would also take a couple of hours, we had to wait until time was on our side, to play this one. Once in a blue moon, we have time to screw around. Woke up this morning and told M. that we had no time to lose. Started to set up the game. And everybody is right about this one. It took us something over an hour to set it up. And we have to say, that we bagged and labeled everything, which means that we almost have no work with sorting components. As we already watched a video review of this game, and we’ve played Elder Sign before, the reading of the rules was pretty quick done (something about 1 hour). Then it was time to play. When you’re having fun, time flies, and before we knew, we were defeated by the Ancient One. We looked at the clock, and it showed us, that 4 hours passed since we started the game. And we weren’t bored a single minute. In basic this game isn’t too difficult. Just 5 steps, that are pretty easy to remember.

    Update your investigator cards and skills.
    Move
    Encouter in Arkham
    Encouter in the Other World
    Play a Mythos card

The first two steps shouldn’t be a problem at all. The encounters makes it a bit more complex (especially, as all the text on the cards is in English, and English isn’t our mother language) (but, this is a cooperative game, and two know more then one, this it’s workable), just as playing the Mythos card will. But it all isn’t really hard. It’s just a lot of it. Also the checks that has to be played are pretty easy when you played a couple of them. It’s just a matter of adding and subtraction numbers and then roll the die. When you roll a 5 or 6 (or a 4 when you’re blessed), then you have a success. When you have enough successes, you full-fill the check that you’re doing. Basically that’s all there is. Of course, there are dozens of additional rules and exceptions, but if you remember these basic things (playing order, how to full-fill a check and the fact that’s cooperative), you can play this game. This is just a fantastic game. Minor thing is that you will need lots and lots of time to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not a bad game by any means, however in terms of sheer enjoyment I find it lesser then other co-ops, it feels that there is too much unnecessary complexity and frankly it takes far too long for what it actually gives back.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
First and foremost, This game has to be the most complex I have ever played, especially when multiple expansions are added to the base set!  

I think the artwork is stunning and the game components are very nicely done.  I think actual miniatures for the investigators would really take this to the top, but so much is packed into the box for the price as it is.  There are a TON of components inside!  

The game play can get very fiddly at times though and the difficulty level to win is relatively high, but not winning every game is what makes the game truly unique!  I expect to lose more often than not and that aspect may not appeal to everyone.

The game is dripping with the Cthulhu theme and has to be one of the best out there! It certainly is not for everyone.  Yet the atmosphere it helps to create will be unlike other games carrying this theme.

I look forward to playing more expansions in the future! :goo:

[UPDATE] 
It has been a few years since my initial remarks, and I can report that this game has fallen in both my ratings and my eagerness to play it.  

It all comes down to two reasons: it is extremely fiddly and with the addition of each expansion players decide to incorporate into the experience (with the exception of Dunwich Horror) that aspect gets utterly worse and worse!  Also, it takes FOREVER to play!  Now I like a good, long game, please take a look at my list and you will see that sitting down for an epic adventure is all fine by me, but this one can certainly lag on for no good reason.  In my opinion, a streamlined design, more actions available to players on their turns and better, more useful weapons could repair many player's complaints.

As it stands currently, this game does not see the table as much as it should.  Sad, but very true.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The amount of work, and good editing that went into this game is amazing.  Its fabric is densely woven with theme; however, for my tastes, there is way more mucking around with rules, phases, steps, cards, and tokens than there should be for the really small number of interesting decisions to make.  Like [thing=10547]Betrayal at House on the Hill[/thing], there's just too little interesting going on, and negligible strategy to be had.  Unlike [thing=10547]Betrayal at House on the Hill[/thing], Arkham Horror is specifically designed to last at least X long, where X is way, way too long for my tastes:  After four hours, I would prefer to be more than merely halfway toward just one of the victory conditions - in fact, I'd prefer to have played several exhilarating games laden with agonizing decisions!

However, as with all "experience" games, playing with the right people - especially if the time was pre-ordained for this game - can make for a fun time.

update: the pulp, B-move kind-of approach to mythos doesn't bother me anymore, but the way game plays feels a little bit fiddly and if you just approach this game mechanically instead of drenching yourself into the atmosphere, it kills this game, it's super dry and dull. But if you immerse youself into the story and character, this can be fun.

RATING: 6
Arkham Horror is a pretty good deep co-op game. I enjoy running around the city looking for clues and then jumping into gates to fight off the rise of the Old Ones. It suffers a bit from being niche locked into a 3 or 4 player game, from my experience. 2 player and 5 player games both feel overwhelming and don't really give you a chance to do anything useful before waking the Old One.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Knowing I'm a fan of h.p.lovecraft my fiendish friends used this game as an introduction to their gaming group. Up until that fateful night the most complex game I had played was solar quest (with lasers) about 20 years ago. Arkham Horror was an eye opener and an instant hit with me. I found the rules complex at first (to be honest I still have to check the rule book all the time), but my friends have played A.H. for years and were able to explain things quickly as the game progressed...to the inevitable madness and devouring of investigators that seems to be the most common way our adventures end.

I'd recommend that first-time players invite a veteran A.H. gamer to help explain the rules and turns,but don't let that put you off. This game has an immersive quality and builds a unique narrative each time you take on the Ancient Ones. We usually only have three players, but have found it's best if we each control two investigators with the first-player marker moving between them as if it was a six player game.

We also use the Innsmouth and Dunwich etc expansions and they  add even more depth to the game-play.

To sum up I am a biased fan of this excellent game. If you like lovecraft and have not played this game go and buy a copy now. If you don't know lovecraft, but like the idea of battling hordes of undead and extra-dimensional beings then this is the game for you, get a copy now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This thing had a few plays with various expansions and numbers of players. My rating reflects my thoughts on the game plus expansions as a whole, since it's impossible to separate them in my mind. Biggest con of this game: Too fiddly - too much setup, too many pieces. I never thought I'd say this... "too many pieces"... Game is confusing as hell, but also great thematic fun. If you don't mind putting an hour or two of work in to set it up (on a table twice as big as the universe), and if you then don't mind that you're sure to forget at least ten rules per play for the first ten plays. 

Oh, and putting the whole thing away again... I'd say that's another half hour to forty-five minutes.

Edit: Starting to think about downgrading this since there has never been that much incentive to take it out. It's always a "planned" occurrence, never a gut feeling of "just wanting to play"

Edit edit: I upgraded it instead.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love the Lovecraft theme. I like to roleplay my characters and thus I always have fun when I play the game. I don't think the rules are hard, it's the rulebook that not very structured. I believe it's more a repeated mantra here on bgg that this game is hard to learn/play, but in reality I never had a problem teaching the game to new people. It's not easy to win though there is a strategy that mostly works. There's great variety between each game.  

While Eldritch Horror is a more slick variant, I have a feeling that AH is more of an immersive horror roleplay thing than EH is. The latter feels a bit more randomly thrown together Indiana Jones with Cthulhu mish-mash. 

Negative points: 
A lot of luck is involved. The deck can leave the players with no chance to win. You need luck to draw good cards, mostly its something bad that happens to you. There is also a great amount of luck with the dice you roll for everything from fighting, sneaking, card texts, closing gates, casting spells etc. 

Fiddly setup with all the card decks, and one of the biggest boardgames to setup on a table. A nightmare to properly store back in the box. 

On playtime: the game can take a long time to play. I would not recommend it with a lot of players. Also it's a game that I like to play once each year, but not more than that. You also need the right kind of players for this more then in other games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good luck compiling all the rules for the game - the rulebook is one of the most notoriously lacking documents in the whole boardgaming industry. But they are out there, and when you find them, the result is one of the most engaging and mentally challenging co-operative games out there.

RATING: 9
The definitive board game, at least to this point in my gaming career. Perfect blend of theme, style and substance, and the randomness and variability only make the game that much more satisfying. This is a game of theme and doom first, and strategy second. If that is likely to upset you, this is definitely not your cup of tea. For me, though, it's as close to a RPG as a board game has ever come.

EDIT: 1/16/14
Finally played this with a group of core gamers. Went over amazingly well. Bumping the score a final time. Gonna' be a long time till something replaces this as my favorite game.

RATING: 5.5
Pretty complicated (20+ page rules book) but enjoyable, purely co-operative game - but way too long.  Stacks of atmosphere for the die hard Mythos fans *guilty hand raise* and a nice feeling of tension is built when the town is over run with monsters, the Old One is close to waking, but only one more gate needs closing....
However, this is a BIG, LONG game.  Expect 3 hours to come and go with ease, and don't plan to play this on a small coffee table.  The board alone is far bigger than most games out there today, and thats without factoring in the reems of cards (not to mention expansions).
